Souter held that the defendant should have been allowed to present testimony that the victim behaved in a sexually provocative manner toward several men in a tavern, the group said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Souter, Ponders for Two Hours, Then Makes His Choice
With PM-Souter Bjt
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter shook hands with President Bush on Monday afternoon for the first time, then sat down in the White House family quarters for a 45-minute chat. A few hours later, Bush was introducing Souter as his nominee to be the next U.S. Supreme Court justice _ less than 72 hours after William J. Brennan stepped down from the court. Although his nomination unfolded with surprising speed, administration officials said that they've had an eye on Souter for some time. Shortly after he took office, Bush asked the Justice Department and White House staff to put together a list of potential Supreme Court nominees. Souter's name was placed on that list early last year. He was bought to the attention of Justice Department judicial candidate screeners by White House chief of staff John Sununu, said a senior administration official. As governor of New Hampshire, Sununu had appointed Souter to that state's highest court. Souter's name came up again last fall when officials were searching for someone to fill a vacancy on the 1st Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston. He underwent a series of interviews last year and Bush nominated him to that court on Jan. 24. After the American Bar Association gave him its highest rating _ ``well qualified'' _ the Senate confirmed Souter on April 27. He joined the 1st Circuit only in May and hasn't had the opportunity to publish any rulings. Souter's name came up again Saturday morning when Bush, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Sununu and White House counsel Boyden Gray met to launch their weekend search for new justice, said another senior official. ``We know this man because we had this man through our judicial process last fall,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. At Saturday's meeting, Bush was given background materials on a dozen or so potential candidates to study over the weekend, officials said. The president added several names for consideration, which were given a ``cursory check'' by those assigned to review the candidates, the official said. White House and Justice Department officials met throughout the weekend. No ``short list'' was drawn up, but on Monday, Bush arranged to conduct two interviews, one with Souter and another with a candidate whom administration officials declined to identify. The president talked with Souter in the family quarters of the White House and later filled three legal-sized pages with ``his handwritten feelings or conclusions about the candidate,'' said spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. While Souter waited elsewhere in the White House, Bush weighed the ``strengths and weaknesses'' of Souter and two other candidates, then wrote out three more pages before making up his mind, Fitzwater said. After a two-hour wait, Souter was called to the Oval Office, where Bush offered him the nomination.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Souter, Bjt
A Quick Look At Bush's Choice for the U.S. Supreme Court
DOC.TEXT: Here is a snapshot of David H. Souter, President Bush's nominee to succeed Justice William J. Brennan on the U.S. Supreme Court.

NAME: David Hackett Souter. BORN: Sept. 17, 1939 in Melrose, Mass. EDUCATION: Graduated from Harvard University, 1961. Attended Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar from 1961 to 1963. Received law degree from Harvard in 1966. RELIGION: Episcopalian. POLITICS: Republican. PERSONAL: Never married. Lives alone on the family farm near Weare, N.H. PROFESSIONAL: Practiced law in Concord, N.H., from 1966 to 1968. Became an assistant attorney general in 1968, appointed deputy attorney general in 1971 and attorney general in 1976. Appointed a state Superior Court judge in 1978. In 1983, named by Gov. John Sununu, now White House chief of staff, to the New Hampshire Supreme Court. Appointed to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston on April 30 and began that job last month.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Under the U.S. system of separation of powers, it is the president's job to choose Supreme Court nominees and the Senate's role to confirm or reject them. Twenty-seven high court nominees in the nation's history have failed to win Senate confirmation, only seven in this century. Most recently, the Senate in 1987 blocked President Reagan's appointment of Robert Bork to fill a vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Lewis F. Powell. The Senate vote was 58-42, with six Republicans joining 52 Democrats in opposing Bork. Reagan's second choice, Douglas Ginsburg, withdrew after revealing he had smoked marijuana. The Senate then confirmed Reagan's third pick, Anthony M. Kennedy.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's announcement of his intention to nominate David H. Souter to the Supreme Court.

My oath to the Constitution charges me to faithfully execute the Office of President, and to the best of my ability preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. Few duties are more important in discharging that obligation than my responsibility under Article 2, Section 2 of our Constitution to select from among all possible choices one nominee to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court of the United States. The task of narrowing the selection to one highly qualified jurist committed to the rule of law and faithful to the Constitution could never be easy, but I have found it enormous _ enormously satisfying. My choice will serve the Court and the Constitution well. I am most pleased to announce that I will nominate as associate justice of the United States Supreme Court a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability, one whose scholarly commitment to the law and whose wealth of experience mark him of first rank _ Judge David Souter of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit. Judge Souter, I believe with all my heart, will prove a most worthy member of the court. His tenure as an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the state of New Hampshire, as attorney general of that state, and more recently as a federal appeals judge, unquestionably demonstrates his ability, his integrity, and his dedication to public service. And he has a keen appreciation of the proper judicial role rooted in fundamental belief and separation of powers and the democratic principles underlying our great system of government. Let me pay tribute, too, to the justice whose retirement from the court created the vacancy, Justice William Brennan. His powerful intellect, his winning personality, and importantly his commitment to civil discourse on emotional issues that at times tempt uncivil voices have made him one of the greatest figures of our age. No one can question his dedication to the nation and the energy that he has brought to his high office. His retirement is marked by the dignity and honor that characterized his 34 years of service on the bench. And I told him the other day when I talked to him of the respect that Mrs. Bush and I have for him for his wonderful service. In choosing to nominate Judge Souter, who like Justice Brennan is largely a product of the state court system, I have looked for the same dedication to public service and strength of intellect exemplified by Justice Brennan. My selection process was not geared simply to any legal issue. It is not appropriate in choosing a Supreme Court justice to use any litmus test. And I want a justice who will ably and fairly interpret the law across the range of issues the Court faces. Our country serves as a model for the world at a time of special significance, and I stressed within the White House to the attorney general that our process could not be dominated by politics or special interests. And I believe that we've set a good example of selecting a fair arbiter of the law. Judge Souter will bring to the Court a wealth of judicial experience on the Supreme Court of his state and, before that, as a state trial court judge. Prior to his appointment to the state bench, he was attorney general of the state of New Hampshire. Judge Souter is a graduate of the Harvard Law School, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Harvard College. He was also a Rhodes Scholar. My respect for his outstanding record led me earlier this year to nominate him to his present position on the court of appeals. The Senate unanimously confirmed him to that position because of his exceptional qualities and his experience. His opinions reflect a clean intellect _ keen intellect as well as wise balance between the theoretical and practical aspects of the law. Judge Souter committed to interpreting, not making the law. He recognizes the proper role of judges in upholding the democratic choices of the people through their elected representatives with constitutional constraints. Judge Brennan's retirement took effect last Friday. The Court is now reduced to eight members. It is important to restore the bench to full strength by the first Monday in October when the Court begins its 1990 term. I look forward to presenting Judge Souter's nomination to the Senate as quickly as possible, and I look forward as well to a fair and expeditious confirmation process.

DOC.TEXT: Q: Did you ask Judge Souter his views on abortion? Do you know what his views are? And affirmative action? All of these things that have become so controversial, the major issues of the day? Bush: No. And I had one meeting with Judge Souter. I was very impressed but, in my view, it would have been inappropriate to ask him his views on specific issues. This process has been going on, this selection process, not with any specific seat in mind, but just being prepared for a long, long time. Judge Souter was considered for the High Court back when Mr. Justice Kennedy was selected. And so there's a lot _ and then, of course, his name was very much in the forefront when he was nominated and subsequently confirmed for the Appeals Court. So I am familiar with him, with his, his general views, but I did not and would not, as I think I've said before when I talked about _ not just here, but other times _ the litmus test approach. I wouldn't go into that with him. Q: Does that mean you do not care what he thinks on the ... Bush: It means that I have selected a person who will interpret the Constitution and, in my view, not legislate from the federal bench. Q: Mr. President, barely three days have passed since you learned of Justice Brennan's resignation. Why did you move so quickly on this appointment? And you also called the leaders of Congress, and others, over the weekend for their advice. When did you come to the choice of Justice Souter? Bush: I came to the choice this afternoon and wanted to _ I think I told the leaders that I talked to over the weekend that I wanted to move very fast. As I said, this isn't precipitous in the sense that we just started looking for names last Saturday. I remember meeting with the Attorney General and Boyden Gray, perhaps within the first month I was President _ at least the first two months. And I've had a couple of meetings with them, and they've been in discussion with each other for a long time on this. And so just the prudence would dictate that one be prepared lest there be a vacancy. So we've been talking about who I might want to appoint for a long time. Q: Sir, if I could follow up, you're not certain in your own mind how Justice Souter will vote if Roe v. Wade comes before the Court next term? Bush: What I'm certain of is that he will interpret the Constitution and not legislate from the federal bench. Yes? Q: But, Mr. President, I believe Judge Souter is about 50 years old, and many of the candidates you considered were younger than the current justices. What kind of lasting legacy do you want to leave on the Supreme Court? Do you expect this to be a long-term shifting of the center of balance for the Court? Bush: I'm not looking _ he's in good health. I was looking over there to see how he's looking at 50 _ but he seems to be in very vigorous health, and I would expect he'd serve a long term on the bench. And I'm not viewing this as some personal ``Bush imprint'' on the Court. I have pledged to get, to seek out excellence, and I've pledged to look for somebody who would interpret the Constitution, and I'm satisfied I've found the very best in that regard. Q: Do you expect the Court would shift to the right philosophically? Bush: I haven't put it in terms of shifting left or right. I read a great deal of speculation about all that, but all I'm saying is that we've got a nominee here who is extraordinarily intelligent, has a record, has been confirmed by the Senate, and who has satisfied inquiry at the state and federal level as to his objectivity and as to his judicial philosophy. And I am satisfied as to all those counts. Q: Mr. President, as you know, the whole issue of abortion has _ over this choice is major ... Do you know if this judge has written on this issue? Has _ is he _ does he have a record on this issue that either side can point to to make it an even bigger issue? Or is he _ is it unknown and therefore more difficult to get at? Bush: In the first place, I think it would be inappropriate, although I'll let him make up his own mind for Justice Souter to make any comments on any specific issue. Out of the respect for the Senate, I would urge that he not do that. Any specific questions on specific issues should be addressed in an orderly confirmation process by the Senate. But, beyond that, Lesley, I _ you know, I think what I said earlier responds to your question. Q: No, I _ you said you hadn't asked him, but I wonder if he has a record, if ... Bush: Well, I don't know about that. I didn't consider that, as I thought I made clear. Yeah, Jerry? And then ... Q: Mr. President, since you concluded that it's inappropriate to ask about a specific case like Roe versus Wade, do you also therefore consider it to be inappropriate for the Senate committee that'll do the confirmation to ask about a specific case like that? Bush: I would let the Senate do whatever they want. They're a separate and independent body of the _ of our government, and there are certain precedents for how they approach these issues, but I'm _ listen, I've got enough problems down here without trying to tell the Senate how to conduct its confirmation hearing. I've been handed a protocol note. Marlin Fitzwater, who's not known for his protocol, but I _ he says it would be most appropriate to let Judge Souter respond at this juncture. So, with your permission, we'll proceed. Judge Souter: Thank you, Mr. President. I'm really not sure how to do that. If it were possible for me to express to you the realization that I have of the honor which the President has just done me, I would try and I would keep you here as long tonight as I had to do to get it out. But I could not express that realization and I'm not going to try to do the impossible. Beyond that, I hope you will understand that I think I must defer any further comments of mine until I am before the Senate in the confirmation process.

Q: Well, you may be called upon throughout your term to actually name one or two others. Do you have those in mind? And also, if _ Bush: Yes. Q: By having those names in mind of who you would appoint, are you doing the same thing like in foreign policy, saying that you want to choose a prudent man or that the imprint would be something peculiar to you, in other words a _ Bush: Look, I'll tell you how I look at this, not in terms of some specific imprint, but I want it said when I'm about _ let's see, 66 _ about 90, 24 years from now, that I made a superb choice, and I think it will be so writ. Q: Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about the phrase you're using on you're opposed to somebody who would legislate from the bench. You're on record as wanting Roe vs. Wade overturned. You're on record as favoring a flag-burning amendment to the Constitution. Aren't those sorts of issues tantamount to legislating from the bench as well? Bush: Well, what _ you'd have to tell me the case and advise me as to how _ I don't think so. I don't think, when called upon to answer a constitutional question, that that has to be legislating from the bench. Q: But you would not be upset if the Court overturned Roe vs. Wade? Bush: No. Q: Or if the Court upheld the flag-burning amendment? Bush: No, and a lot of other things, too. I believe in the separation of powers. I happen to think that there's been a _ many, many things have troubled me, encroachment of micro-management by the United States Congress on the presidency. But I haven't asked this able judge about those things. But I could cite _ you cite two. You cite one that's been on everybody's lips ever since I _ since Justice Brennan retired. Listen, I never heard such coverage on the television. You might just think the whole nomination had something to do with abortion. And it's far broader than that. I have too much respect for the Supreme Court than to look at one specific issue and one alone. I've got time for one _ yeah, Kathy? Q: Mr. President, there's been some speculation you might name an Hispanic this time and make history in doing so. You went a different route. What do you say to those who might be disappointed that didn't happen, and what is the likelihood you might name an Hispanic should another vacancy develop? Bush: First, I say to whoever it is that inquires, I've made the best choice I possibly could make in terms of qualifications, ability, background, and temperament to serve on this court. And then I say: Look, the great thing about this country is you can achieve anything. And there's a lot of time down the road in which I'm sure you'll see a different makeup on the Court. But I don't _ I'm not going to deal in any one specific group, vis-a-vis another one. And that's what I would say. But I just would ask the American people to understand I looked at a wide array of names prior to my getting into it in as much depth as I have very recently. The Attorney General, his staff, Boyden Gray and his staff, went through this process. It's a continuance _ it's a process that's been going on for some time. And this _ the excellence was just there at the top. And so, I would not cite this as something discouraging for anybody that aspires to the Supreme Court or any group that would aspire to have representation on the Supreme Court. Listen, I really do have to go _ Q: What did you ask him when you interviewed him? Q: Did you interview the other finalists, Mr. President? Did he win in the interview? Bush: He did very, very well. Q: Two or three _ Bush: Yeah, let me get one _ I've been _ I failed to _ Q: Two or three of the candidates that were mentioned were from your home state and there was talk that you perhaps would choose somebody from the South because you felt the South was in under-representation since Justice Powell resigned. Wasn't anybody qualified in the South or why did you _ Bush: No, there's plenty of people qualified and you raise a good point because there aren't _ there is nobody from the _ what I would call the Southeast conference South, but the South, excluding Texas, that _ that is on the bench now. And there's about a quarter of the people from there. So, this is a consideration and was a consideration; it was forcefully brought home to me by key members of Congress. And yet I determined that Judge Souter, given the qualifications I've tried to extoll here, the virtues, is the choice for the federal _ for the Supreme Court at this time. But no, these calls are not easy. And Kathy asked about different ethnic groups. You asked about regional distribution. And I think one considers all these _ all these criteria. I think it's fair to say that New England, which is not represented on the bench now that Justice Brennan is retired, might look at it, if I had gone with another nominee, as why were they excluded? So, I can understand regionalism. But, please believe me, as a proud Texan, I tried to look at it on a _ in a national sense. And I think I've come up with the best nominee. Jesse, I'm sorry to disappoint you _ Q: A very quick follow-up, if I could. Senator Simpson suggested that you follow the counsel of Mrs. Bush. Did you in any way on this particular issue? Bush: How did he know? He doesn't even know who I nominated. How could he have said that? Q: He said that he hoped that that would be what you would do. Bush: Oh, I see. Wonderful fellow, Al.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative Think Tank Pops Up in Land of Liberalism
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: Minnesota, which last voted for a Republican presidential candidate in 1972, has a new conservative think tank aimed at challenging liberals on their own turf. The Center of the American Experiment may seem out of place in the land of prairie liberalism. Its founder says that's the point. ``We are purposely going after the most difficult, the nastiest issues we face as a state and as a nation,'' said Mitchell Pearlstein, the center's founder and president. The center opened in March and held its first conference, on poverty, in April. A conference titled ``What Do We Do When School Reform Fails?'' is scheduled for Nov. 16. The center plans to publish papers, hold more forums and deliver recommendations on such issues as drugs, welfare and taxes. Minnesota is where Hubert H. Humphrey and his protege, Walter F. Mondale, got their start in politics. It is the only state to vote for Democratic candidates in all three presidential races in the 1980s. Richard Nixon was the last Republican to carry Minnesota, when he defeated George McGovern in 1972. ``Conservative ideas are not terribly well attended to in this state, in part because they're not terribly well articulated,'' Pearlstein said. ``You can say that the niche is that much larger.'' Pearlstein, 42, had another reason for establishing the center in Minnesota. He wanted to come home. A former speechwriter for Gov. Al Quie in 1981-82, then editorial page writer for what is now the Saint Paul Pioneer Press, he left for Washington in 1987 to work for the Education Department. But Pearlstein, who grew up in Far Rockaway, N.Y., and later moved to Binghamton, N.Y., longed for Minnesota. ``I tell people about 20 minutes after getting to Washington, I started to conspire to return home,'' he said. ``This is literally where I want to die.'' The center is nonpartisan, but most of its 12 directors and 16 advisers are Republicans. Two Democrats have joined the board of advisers, and more Democrats will be added, Pearlstein said. Republican Sens. Dave Durenberger and Rudy Boschwitz are on the board of advisers. Five members of the boards of directors and advisers are black or Hispanic, and five are women. ``We have very much an interest in changing the imagery of conservatives ... as a very white male idea,'' Pearlstein said. Rep. Vin Weber, a Republican on the board of advisers, believes the time is right for a conservative think tank in Minnesota. ``I think activist states will find their successes copied around the country,'' Weber said. ``So if the center is successful in formulating some new responses to old problems in Minnesota, they're in a significant moment in history to have a significant national impact.'' Former St. Paul Mayor George Latimer, a liberal, said he welcomes any fresh approach to social problems but was disappointed after the center's conference on poverty. ``I saw them trotting in a lot of people who have published their ideological tracts. They brought out their conservative Hispanic, their conservative black, their conservative intellectual,'' Latimer said. ``They were not listening; they were being ideologues.'' Pearlstein is the only full-time staff member at the center, which has a first-year budget of $250,000. Funding comes from individuals, corporations and foundations, he said, adding there are no plans to take government money.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Nominee a Tough Judge, Quiet Man
With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter is a quiet, hard-working judge who lives an ``almost monastic life'' but can skewer stuffed shirts with his sharp sense of humor, friends say. Friends, colleagues and lawyers who know Souter, 50, described him as an intellectual and a man with a deep respect for the Constitution. President Bush nominated him Monday to replace retired Justice William J. Brennan. ``I don't think the president could have nominated a person with better qualities, background, a keener intellect, than David Souter,'' Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., a close friend, said Monday. Souter moved to Weare, N.H., from the Boston suburb of Melrose at age 11. He has never married and still lives alone on the family farm where he grew up. ``He has a small circle of very good friends and lives an almost monastic life,'' said Rudman, who first recommended Souter for the high court when President Reagan was unable to get Robert Bork confirmed in 1987. ``If he has any fault, I believe it's that he's worked too hard all his life. But that's the way he is,'' Rudman said. Tom Rath, who replaced Souter as state attorney general and also is a close friend, said Souter enjoys hiking and reading. His voracious appetite for books shows in his farmhouse, which, he said once in an interview, ``looks as though someone is moving a bookstore and has stopped.'' Despite Souter's quiet, conservative appearance, he has ``a wicked sense of humor that can skewer the most stuffed shirt,'' Rath says. Souter has left rural Weare only to attend Harvard College and Oxford, where he was a Rhodes Scholar, and Harvard Law School, from which he was graduated in 1966. As a law student, Souter was a resident adviser in a freshman dorm at the college, where his charges included Chase G. Untermeyer, now White House personnel director. Souter could ``give the impression with the movement of an eye and the slightest inclination of his head that he was catching everything that goes on _ which is exactly the type of person you want watching over a freshman dorm,'' Untermeyer said Monday. After graduating from law school, Souter went into private practice for two years. Named an assistant state attorney general in 1968, he became deputy and then attorney general in 1976. Arch-conservative Gov. Meldrim Thomson made him a Superior Court judge in 1978, and then-Gov. John Sununu _ now White House chief of staff _ elevated him to the state Supreme Court in 1983. In April, Souter won confirmation to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston, where he began work in June. If confirmed, Souter would be the Supreme Court's 105th justice. He would be its sixth bachelor, the first New Englander since Felix Frankfurter retired in 1962, and the second Rhodes scholar, joining Justice Byron R. White. Though friends recall him driving rusting, aging cars, and living a less than extravagant lifestyle, Souter had a net worth of $621,000 at the end of 1989 _ including $191,000 in personal property, $190,000 in securities and $150,000 in real estate _ according to financial records released Monday. He listed no liabilities. Some immediately challenged the selection. Elliott Berry, a New Hampshire Legal Assistance lawyer, voiced reservations about how Souter would treat ``the disenfranchised.'' ``His overall philosophy tends to result in support for the status quo,'' Berry said. But he was praised by Ellen Musinsky, who teaches family law at Franklin Pierce Law Center in Concord and who appeared before Souter often when he was a trial judge. Though she frequently disagrees with Souter, she said she respects him. ``A lot of the male judges were not real pleasant to practice in front of, but he was great,'' she said. ``He was nice. He respected me. He made me feel like if I had done my work, which I did, I'd get a very fair shot. He was delightful.''

DOC.HEAD: Rotary Club Chapter Makes AIDS Documentary
With PM-Jennifer's AIDS, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Rotary Club chapter has made its own AIDS documentary for distribution to 24,000 chapters worldwide that chronicles the lives of three Rotarians affected by the deadly disease. ``Our idea is to change the attitude in Wichita, Kansas,'' said Dick Hasenpflug, chairman of the Rotary AIDS Project of the Los Altos Rotary Club. Dushan Angius challenged the Rotary Club to get involved in AIDS education last summer when he told the group his son, Steve, had AIDS. ``When a son tells you he has AIDS, all you hear is `Gee Dad, I'm going to die.' There's no way I could let it go that way,'' Angius said. The documentary, scheduled to be shown to the media today, eventually will be distributed to 24,000 Rotary Clubs worldwide, Hasenpflug said. ``Rotarians around the world tend to be leaders in their communities and we think the Rotarian network gives a unique opportunity to make an impact on community thinking,'' he said. The film initially was going to feature Steve Angius's story alone. But as word of the project spread, two Rotary Club members publicly acknowledged that they tested positive for the AIDS virus. Greg Betts, president of the Bayshore Rotary Club in neighboring Palo Alto, volunteered to appear in the film. Walter Singer, a 67-year-old retired businessman, went one step further. He allowed crews to film the meeting in December when he told the Los Altos Rotary Club how he contracted the AIDS virus in a blood transfusion during heart bypass surgery. ``It was an individual reaction, sort of a gasp,'' Hasenpflug said. ``It was dead silent, a lot of hugging and holding. All of these things you don't expect a lot of 60-year-old men to be doing.'' Singer said the courage of the Angius family and the public support they received persuaded him to go public. ``The Rotarians are not exempt, which they thought they were,'' Singer said. The local Rotary Club's involvement with AIDS is a departure for the conservative organization that usually avoids politically controversial subjects, Hasenpflug said. ``We believe strongly that the AIDS project transcends politics,'' Hasenpflug said. ``The political part of it is how people catch it, and in my opinion, how people catch it is irrelevant once they catch it. People need our support.'' Hasenpflug describes the film as ``a very powerful piece'' that avoids presenting facts about the disease and instead focuses on the impact AIDS has on individuals. On the first day of shooting, crews filmed Steve Angius asking his family to take him to the hospital. He died the next day, Nov. 25. ``Grown men cry when they watch this thing,'' Hasenpflug said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 31,702.46, down 192.33 points, or 0.60 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Americans On First MIA Mission To Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: U.S. military experts arrived in Cambodia today to examine what may be the remains of America's wartime missing, the first such mission since the 1975 Communist takeover. The six-man team, including two forensic scientists, flew from Bangkok, Thailand, in a U.S. Air Force C-141 jet transport. The U.S. delegation shook hands awkwardly with a group of mid-level Cambodian officials then drove into Phnom Penh, where they spent an hour touring the city before meetings with Cambodian officials. On Wednesday, they are to examine remains collected by the Cambodians. If it appears the remains may be those of American servicemen, they are to be removed to the United States for further examination and identification. The United States still does not recognize the Vietnamese-installed Phnom Penh government. On Wednesday, however, it announced it was withdrawing recognition of the guerrilla coalition battling the government in order to open talks with Vietnam on ending the country's civil war. U.S. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said on July 13 that today's mission would be strictly humanitarian and have no political intent. American officials have complained that the Cambodians postponed repatriation of remains in order to exact political concessions from the United States. The visiting team is from the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory, Hawaii-based agencies that try to account for U.S. military personnel listed as missing in action in the Indochina conflict. It is led by Lt. Col. Joe Harvey, head of the resolution center. Harvey said on arrival in Phnom Penh that he came only to view the remains and the issue of normalized relations between Cambodia and the United States ``definitely is not on the agenda.'' In Bangkok, team spokesman Lt. Col. Thomas Boyd said that if the remains are identified as those of Americans, a 17-member team will fly to Phnom Penh Thursday for a military honors ceremony. The remains would be flown to Hawaii. Boyd said he did not know how many sets of remains the team will examine. A total of 2,299 Americans are officially listed as missing in action in Indochina. Of those, 1,678 are missing in Vietnam, 533 in Laos and six in China's coastal waters. Of the 82 missing in Cambodia, most are airmen whose planes were downed during strikes on the Ho Chi Minh Trail in eastern areas that North Vietnam used to infiltrate men and supplies into South Vietnam. U.S. airplanes heavily bombed the country from 1969 until 1973. U.S. officials have said there also are at least eight civilians missing in Cambodia, including four journalists, two contractors, a merchant seaman and a missionary. The Khmer Rouge toppled the U.S.-backed Lon Nol government in April 1975, sending the American ambassador fleeing. Over the next four years, the Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodians as it tried to turn the country into an agrarian commune. The Vietnamese invasion of late 1978 ousted the Khmer Rouge and installed a new communist government in Phnom Penh. The Khmer Rouge then joined two non-communist groups in a guerrilla coalition backed by China and many other countries. Earlier this month, John Gunther Dean, the last U.S. Ambassador to Cambodia, made a six-day visit to Phnom Penh _ his first since carrying out the U.S. flag during the 1975 evacuation. Phnom Penh said in 1984 that it was willing to cooperate on the issue of missing Americans and declared in 1988 it was willing to hand over remains. But the repatriations had been delayed by the diplomatic stalemate. Prime Minister Hun Sen was quoted as saying in February 1989 that his government had eight sets of American remains and was searching for more. Last month, the Cambodian government said it had set up a five-man commission chaired by a deputy minister to help search for the remains of U.S. servicemen.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Charged in Panama Invasion Worried About Getting Fair Trial
DOC.TEXT: A soldier the Army charged with murder in the slaying of a man in civilian clothes during the U.S. invasion of Panama says he is worried that politics will prevent him from getting a fair trial. ``If I'm found innocent the Department of Army will look bad,'' said 1st Sgt. Roberto E. Bryan, an 82nd Airborne Division paratrooper and 19-year Army veteran. Bryan is charged with unpremeditated murder and faces a maximum life prison sentence if convicted. He says he was merely performing his duty in the heat of battle and that he has enough evidence to be acquitted. ``Where I'm concerned is the political issue. I have to keep my eyes open so they don't use command influence in the trial,'' he said. An Army spokeswoman said Bryan's fears were unfounded. ``As far as getting a fair trial, that's the purpose of a trial by court-martial,'' Staff Sgt. Cindy Darst, a spokeswoman for the 18th Airborne Corps, the umbrella command of the 82nd Airborne, said Monday. The Army alleges Bryan shot a Panamanian man without provocation on Dec. 23, 1989 _ three days after the United States began the invasion that toppled dictator Manuel Noriega from power. The shooting occurred during a barrage of gunfire that erupted when a Panamanian tossed a hand grenade that wounded 10 soldiers at a roadblock. Bryan's battalion and brigade commanders recommended dismissal of the murder charge. An officer who conducted an Article 32 investigation, similar those conducted by civilian grand juries, reduced the original premeditated murder charge to voluntary manslaughter. That charge was upgraded to unpremeditated murder _ the military equivalent of second-degree murder _ by Lt. Gen. Gary E. Luck, 18th Airborne commander. ``I was basically convicted before'' the Article 32 investigation, said Bryan, referring to a March report in the Army Times newspaper that quoted unnamed Army sources as saying Bryan killed a wounded Panamanian prisoner attempting to surrender. ``Publicity is the reason it has gone this far,'' said Mark L. Waple, Bryan's attorney. The Army does not want to face ``criticism from the media or Congress.'' Bryan and other soldiers at the roadblock said the wounded man did not attempt to surrender and prompted gunfire at him by moving suddenly, like he was reaching for a weapon. Bryan said the body was not searched and it is not known if the man was armed. No autopsy was performed, Army officials said. Five Panamanians, wearing civilian clothes, were ordered out of a vehicle so it could be searched. Members of Noriega's Panamanian Defense Force and his Dignity Battalions were known to wear civilian clothes. A search of the vehicle produced a tear gas grenade, a machete and an unfired rifle cartridge. The Panamanians were ordered to lie on the ground and soon afterward a hand grenade exploded. Witnesses said many soldiers fired at the Panamanians. Bryan said he was about 70 yards from the roadblock when he heard the grenade explode. He said he ran to the highway and told the men to cease firing. Four of the five Panamanians were killed, Bryan said. ``It was chaos,'' he said. ``I saw the man make an arm movement, like he was reaching for something. But how do they know the bullets I fired killed him? When I opened up everybody else opened fire in that direction again.'' At least three other U.S. soldiers have been prosecuted for their actions during the Panama invasion. One was convicted of unpremeditated murder and two others were found guilty of lesser charges after a firefight investigators said was staged to cover up a soldier's loss of his handgun at a bar.

DOC.HEAD: Fast-Food French Fry Lovers in for Healthy Oil Change
DOC.TEXT: After a little prodding from a well-heeled health crusader, the nation's top four hamburger chains agree: french fry lovers need an oil change. McDonald's Corp. and Wendy's International announced Monday they are switching to cholesterol-free, all-vegetable oil to cook their fries. Hardee's made the change two years ago and Burger King said last week it will no longer use beef tallow, the industry's previous standard oil for french fry vats. ``Everything that's deep fried is now done in 100 percent cholesterol-free oil,'' said McDonald's spokesman Chuck Rubner. The company started cooking its chicken items, pies and fish in vegetable oil four years ago, he said. McDonald's has been a target of newspaper and TV ads placed by anti-cholesterol crusader Phil Sokolof, who accused the world's largest restaurant chain of poisoning Americans with fatty foods. Sokolof said a recent Advertising Age-Gallup Organization poll indicated a significant number of people responded to his ads by shying away from fast-food outlets. ``Consumers have the power to move mountains, and that's what they did,'' he said in a telephone interview after the McDonald's announcement. ``We obviously speeded up the process.'' ``That's really ridiculous,'' countered McDonald's spokeswoman Terri Capatosto. ``We've been in the nutrition business a lot longer than Mr. Sokolof has been in the ad business.'' Rubner said McDonald's has been experimenting with using vegetable oil for eight years and that test marketing in 500 restaurants began in October. ``Clearly, the challenge that we were looking at was to maintain the same taste _ the worldwide favorite _ while at the same time improving the nutritional value,'' said Rubner. Sokolof, a 66-year-old millionaire from Omaha, Neb., blames a high-cholesterol diet for a near-fatal heart attack 22 years ago. In April, Sokolof placed ads headlined ``The Poisoning of America!'' in several major U.S. newspapers. The ads criticized McDonald's and other restaurants for cooking foods in beef tallow rather than using ``heart-healthy oils.'' McDonald's warned newspapers against printing Sokolof's ads, contending they were inaccurate. On July 3, Sokolof placed ads aimed specifically at McDonald's. McDonald's new french fry oil, expected to be in use nationwide by the end of the year, is a combination of corn and cottonseed oil. The company said the new cooking oil will be cholesterol-free and result in a 45 percent reduction in saturated fat content. For a regular-size order of fries, Rubner said, saturated fat will go from 5.05 grams to 2.7 grams. Wendy's vice president Charlie Rath said the company's change drops the cholesterol in a 3.2-ounce french fry serving from 15 milligrams to a trace and reduces saturated fat by 20 percent, from 15 grams to 12 grams. Vegetable oils don't contain cholesterol, but certain kinds of vegetable oils contain saturated fats, which the body converts to cholesterol. Thus, eating ``cholesterol-free'' food doesn't necessarily protect a person from cholesterol. Doctors advocate food cooked in polyunsaturated fat or monounsaturated fat, found in corn, sunflower and other oils. Vegetable oils to avoid are palm and coconut. Rubner said McDonald's has a market share that exceeds that of Hardee's, Burger King and Wendy's combined. Sales by McDonald's franchisees and company-owned stores totaled $4.6 billion for the second quarter of this year. Two other fast-food rivals, Arby's and Kentucky Fried Chicken, already fry their food in vegetable oils.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Skipper Faces Fight to Keep License
DOC.TEXT: Four months after his Alaska acquittal on most charges in the Exxon Valdez disaster, Joseph Hazelwood is fighting a new legal battle to save his seagoing career. A Coast Guard hearing on whether Hazelwood should keep his master's license is set to begin Wednesday. Administrative Judge Harry J. Gardner could choose to dismiss all charges against the skipper, revoke his license or place him on probation. Hazelwood and his lawyers will present evidence intended to show that he is innocent of negligence and misconduct in the nation's worst oil spill, his lawyers say. ``Capt. Hazelwood looks forward to putting on his case and being vindicated much as he has been in Alaska,'' said one of his lawyers, Michael Chalos. ``He's been spending most of his time helping us prepare for this hearing.'' Chalos and Thomas Russo, lawyers for Hazelwood in his Anchorage trial earlier this year, will call at least five expert witnesses who testified for him in that proceeding, including two fellow tanker captains. The hearing is scheduled for Long Beach because it is the headquarters for the 11th Coast Guard District, which includes Alaska. The 987-foot Valdez tanker struck a charted reef and spilled 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound. The spill killed fish, birds and wildlife and blackened the shore for hundreds of miles. The disaster became a rallying point for environmentalists and led to criminal charges against Hazelwood. After a two-month trial, Hazelwood was acquitted of being drunk and reckless and was convicted of one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. The conviction is under appeal, along with his sentence of $50,000 in restitution and 1,000 hours cleaning beaches at Prince William Sound.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Ratifies New US Bases Treaty
DOC.TEXT: By the narrowest of margins, Parliament today ratified a defense treaty with the United States that will allow two American bases to remain on Crete for at least eight more years. The treaty, which guarantees U.S. help if Greece is attacked, has been a divisive issue in Greek politics and hundreds of anti-base demonstrators clashed with police on Monday near the city of Khania on Crete. Three policemen were reported slightly injured after being shot by demonstrators. The parliamentary approval early today ended more than 18 months of uncertainty about the future of the bases. The previous defense treaty expired in December 1988 but was extended as negotiations continued through several changes of government in Greece. A simple majority of the 300-member Parliament was required for ratification, which came after three days of debate. Conservative politicians support a continued U.S. military presence, but leftists demand the removal of the bases. The pact takes effect in September and runs through 1998. A State Department official, requesting anonymity, said late Monday that the United States considers the pact an executive agreement, which would not require ratification by Congress. The treaty allows the United States to continue operating two major military bases on the island of Crete _ a naval support facility at Souda Bay and Iraklion Air Station near the village of Gournes. Two bases near Athens _ a Navy communications station at Nea Makri and the Hellenikon Air Base _ have been slated for closing by the Defense Department as a cost-cutting measure. Numerous relay stations throughout Greece also will close. The treaty continues a defense relationship between the NATO allies that began in 1953. The U.S. administration has also agreed to seek congressional approval for an aid package that would provide Greece with about $345 million in assistance to buy U.S. military equipment, supply surplus planes and destroyers worth about $1 billion, and write off about $50 million in past debts for military purchases. All 151 deputies from the governing conservative New Democratic Party voted in favor of the treaty. It was opposed by 144 Communist, Socialist and environmentalist deputies. Four deputies were absent and one abstained. Uunder the socialist government of Premier Andreas Papandreou, 17 rounds of talks on a new bases treaty proved fruitless. The talks were put on hold last year when coalition governments held power. On April 8, the conservative government was elected. The United States reached agreement in principle on May 30 after two rounds of talks. On Crete, a coalition of leftist groups opposed to the U.S. bases staged demonstrations in Khania on Monday night. As many as 2,500 people took part in the protests, according to witnesses and journalists. Police fired tear gas to prevent demonstrators from entering a municipal building to deliver a petition, the Public Order Ministry said. Clashes then broke out, and three police officers suffered gunshot wounds, the ministry said. Another five officers were injured by gasoline bombs and stones hurled by demonstrators, it said. A hospital source said 10 civilians were treated for respiratory problems caused by the tear bas, and another 40 people received treatment for minor injuries. A police official in Khania said eight people were arrested during the disturbances.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up In Tokyo, Stocks Slide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen in Tokyo Tuesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange shed moderately. The dollar stood at 148.70 yen, up 0.20 yen from Monday's close of 148.15 yen. After opening at 148.15 yen, the currency ranged between 148.05 yen and 148.75 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 192.33 points, or 0.60 percent, closing at 31,702.46. The index had lost 526.72 points on Monday. In bond dealings, the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 85.86 points as of 3 p.m., up from Monday's close of 85.77. The yield was 7.445 percent, down from 7.465 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar remained weak during morning trading, but the currency advanced in the afternoon session. Daiwa Securities trader Naoki Ohno said many of his counterparts had expected the market to fall lower after Monday's stock market decline in New York, but Tokyo remained calm. Ohno said that a slip in Tokyo bond prices combined with a report in the respected financial newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun that long term credit banks were planning to raise their prime rates served to calm Tokyo stock traders. ``The index began taking a recovery step toward the end of morning session,'' said a Nomura Securities dealer who spoke anonymously.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Knock Out Opposition Candidates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: It is common for Mongolians to only use one name. ^By KATHY WILHELM
DOC.TEXT: Communist Party candidates fighting to extend 70 years of rule defeated most of the opposition slate in the initial round of Mongolia's first multiparty elections, the government said today. Preliminary results from Sunday's primary indicated that just 96 of 300 candidates from the five opposition parties survived, Prime Minister Sharavyn Gunjaadorg said. The balloting was to reduce the field of 2,400 candidates to 860, two for each seat in the national legislature, or Great People's Hural. The final round of voting is Sunday. Gunjaadorg maintained that a Communist victory would not hinder Mongolia's dramatic transformation, which began in December, from an authoritarian, one-party state obedient to Moscow to a multiparty nation eager for Western contact and investment. He said the non-Communist parties would still have ``some possibility ... to get into power.'' The opposition's only hope for gaining a significant voice in government lies in the 53-seat Small Hural, which will handle legislation between annual sessions of the Great Hural. Its seats will be assigned to the various parties according to the percentage of the vote each receives. Even a Communist-controlled Great Hural would be very different from its predecessor, however, because most of the party's candidates this time are intellectuals and bureacrats, rather than herders and workers as in the past. The election process so far ``is a comparatively free and fair one,'' Gunjaadorg told a news conference. ``Of course since we are exercising this kind of election for the first time there are some shortcomings and some bumps,'' he said. Nineteen foreign observers are in town, from the Soviet Union, United States, Poland and Britain. A source in the capital, who spoke on condition of anonymity, visited 10 polling stations in the city and described the voting as ``very well organized.'' Mongolia is especially eager that the election be perceived as fair because Secretary of State James A. Baker III is scheduled to visit next week and discuss extending most-favored nation trade status to Mongolia. Mongolia's ambassador to the United States, Nyamdoo, said the State Department did not confirm Baker's trip until the opposition parties dropped a threat to boycott the election. Opposition nominees had been far outnumbered at the start, with the Communists fielding nearly 2,100 candidates. The opposition acknowledged early on that it had no hope of controlling the Great Hural. Formed only over the past few months, the five non-Communist parties claim a combined membership of about 12,000, to the ruling party's 98,000. They have only a fraction of its financial assets and no daily media outlet. Although they appear to have substantial support in cities, where half of Mongolia's 2 million people live, the oppositionists have had to scramble to spread word of their programs to the rural people. Many of those people are semi-nomadic herders only dimly aware of the large demonstrations in Ulan Bator that began in December and forced the Communists to agree to elections. They know even less of the anti-Communist revolutions in Eastern Europe that inspired Mongolia's opposition. In the Great Hural, one seat has been allocated for every 2,000 rural residents and every 10,000 urban residents, hurting the city-based opposition. In recent months, the Communists have embraced many of the goals of the opposition, including its demand for market-style economic reforms, decreased reliance on the Soviet Union and a revival of traditional culture. Gunjaadorg said the government is drafting legislation to define the role of private and cooperative ownership in the economy, in which now almost all enterprises are state-owned. However, he indicated private ownership would be restricted to agriculture, the service sector and small-scale industries. Other parties, including the National Progressive Party, have called for bolder privatization. The largest opposition party, the Mongolian Democratic Party, says the Communists are incapable of reform and seek only to stay in power. Mongolia has been ruled by the Communists since 1921, when a small band of revolutionaries aided by Soviet troops drove out the Chinese, who had controlled Mongolia since 1691. China retained southern Mongolia, called Inner Mongolia, where Mongolian tribal princes had formed alliances with the Chinese.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Says Test Shows Florida Chair in Working Order
LaserPhoto of July 23
DOC.TEXT: The condemned ``man'' had a metal strainer for a head, a vat of salty water for a body and piece of pipe for a leg. Engineers testing the state's electric chair said he died quickly. But attorneys trying to win reprieves for Florida death row inmates after flames jumped from electrodes strapped to a prisoner's head in a recent execution say they were unimpressed with the unusual test Monday. A series of tests were ordered by Gov. Bob Martinez after the botched May 4 electrocution of Jesse Tafero. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals has blocked several scheduled executions because of questions raised by defense attorneys about the effectiveness of the chair. The makeshift ``inmate'' was jolted with current during the 15-minute demonstration, which caused a noisy buzzing. The test showed the chair was putting out 2,000 volts and 10 to 11 amps. ``The electric chair works as it is supposed to,'' said Mike Morse, an associate professor of electrical engineering at Auburn University. ``We see no indication of smoke, arcing or burning.'' The test carried out in the death chamber at Florida State Prison was viewed by news reporters, state officials, representatives of the General Electric Co. and officials from Virginia and South Carolina. Martinez said he is ``satisfied that this objective test by independent experts conclusively shows what we have been saying all along _ that Florida's electric chair is in working order. The source of problems during this state's last execution was accurately identified and has been corrected. ``It is my sincere hope that defense attorneys will cease using this false argument as a basis for unsubstantiated appeals,'' Martinez said. But Jay Nickerson, with the Office of Capital Collateral Representative, a state-funded agency that represents poor death row inmates, was unimpressed by the test. ``It proves it works real good on a colander. It works real good when you take a sponge and put it in a toaster. But I certainly don't want it used on my client,'' he said, adding that his group was denied permission to bring in its own experts. Morse said almost 50 tests of the chair had been conducted over the weekend. He said he is convinced that it was a synthetic sponge that caused sparks and flames to shoot from Tafero's head. Tests using a synthetic sponge under the head electrode produced similiar results with flames and sparks spewing out. Corrections Secretary Richard Dugger immediately notified the governor's office of the test results, but said he didn't know when they would be forwarded to the appeals court. The execution of Anthony Bertolotti, which had been scheduled for 7 a.m. today, was stayed by the Florida Supreme Court until 7 a.m. Thursday. But attorneys have predicted that it is unlikely any executions will take place until the faulty-chair issue is settled in court.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Insurance Shortage Threatens Health System
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0465 to fix cycle designator
DOC.TEXT: National health insurance is needed to avert a financial collapse of the health-care system, say some physicians and hospital officials. The Bush administration is unconvinced. ``Abandonment of the uninsured is becoming a societal disgrace and a financial disaster for many hospitals,'' said Edward Thomas, president of Detroit Receiving Hospital and chairman of the Michigan Hospital Association. Michigan hospitals lost $350 million last year treating patients who could not, or would not, pay, Thomas told a Senate subcommittee monday. Nearly 25 percent of the people treated at his inner-city hospital are not covered by insurance, he said. ``There is mounting evidence that the system is on the verge of fiscal collapse,'' said Norton J. Greenberger, chairman of the Department of Medicine at the University of Kansas Medical Center. As many as 37 million Americans have no health insurance, Greenberger told the Senate Finance subcommittee on health for families and the uninsured. Nearly as many have inadequate or interrupted overage, he said. Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., the subcommittee chairman, said the situation ``underscores the need to develop a national strategy for providing health care for all Americans. It ought to be clear to us that the system is breaking down.'' However, Health and Human Services Secretary louis Sullivan told business leaders in Atlanta on Monday that the solution will be found in a free market where businesses are not burdened with requirements. ``Those who call for a radical revamping of our health-care system -- suggesting nationalized medicine -- are mistaken,'' Sullivan said in his prepared remarks, which were made available in Washington.
DOC.HEAD: Workers Cited Safety Problems To Relatives
DOC.TEXT: Two of the 17 workers killed by an explosion at a Texas chemical plant had told relatives they were worried about the plant's safety, according to family members. The workers also had worries about training at Atlantic Richfield Co.'s plant in Channelview, where vapors caught fire and exploded near an electric compressor July 5, witnesses told a House panel on Monday. ``Safety has to come before profit,'' said Sandy Davis, widow of Greg Davis, an electrician killed in the blast. Ms. Davis wept while testifying that her husband told her several times he was unsure of the skills of some of his fellow contractors. The chief of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Gerald Scannell, said the agency has proposed new safety rules for the chemical industry. But the rules aren't being put into place fast enough, said two Houston congressmen, Democrat Mike Andrews and Republican Jack Fields. ``There's not a chance in hell I'd work for a chemical plant unless I had a 1-year-old child and was out of work,'' aid Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., referring to Davis, whose widow said he took the Arco job in suburban Houston after being unemployed for six months and becoming a new father. But Fields cautioned, ``It is doubtful that the government, or any particular company, can ever completely guarantee that something isn't going to go wrong.'' The congressmen said they were frustrated that 40 workers had been killed at chemical companies in the nine months since the House employment and housing subcommittee examined the October explosion that killed 23 at a Phillips plastics plant in Pasadena, another Houston suburb.
DOC.HEAD: Some States Still Allow Public Schools To Teach About Religion
DOC.TEXT: Public schools in 13 states are permitted to teach about religion, and the Bible may be taught as literature in 10 states, a new survey finds. It also shows that 23 states allow excused absences for religious holidays and 22 mention observance of a moment of silence in their laws or regulations. The survey was conducted by the National Council on Religion and Public Education, which says its purpose is to provide a forum for issues involving religions and public education. The survey, which drew responses from all states except Hawaii, was to determine how many laws, regulations or guidelines were on the books of states in matters of religion or moral education. A law or regulation was counted whether it permitted or forbade a practice. Teaching about religion in public schools is different from teaching religion, said Charles C. Haynes of Americans United Research Foundation. ``We advocate public discussion about religion in public schools,'' he said Monday. The survey was by Charles R. Kniker, assistant dean of education at Iowa State University.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Combination of Factors can `Tip the Balance' to Suicide
DOC.TEXT: A psychiatrist testifying in behalf of the rock band Judas Priest said two men who allegedly shot themselves because of subliminal messages by the group had a number of risk factors that could lead to suicide. Donald Lunde, who teaches at Stanford University, testified Monday the two men exhibited personality disorders and suffered from drug and alcohol abuse, dysfunctional family lives and emotional problems. A combination of these factors can ``tip the balance'' toward suicide, Lunde said. ``Each of these young men were supportive of the notion of suicide,'' he said. ``The more of these things you have, the greater predisposition you have toward suicide.'' Lunde said his review of extensive medical histories and files on both fans of the heavy metal group convinced him the two exhibited a combination of risk factors that could potentially lead to suicide. The families of Raymond Belknap, 18, and James Vance, then 20, filed suit against the band and CBS Records, claiming subliminal messages on Judas Priest's 1978 ``Stained Class'' album drove the young men to a suicide pact. Belknap died from a single blast from a shotgun held to his chin on Dec. 23, 1985. Vance blew away the lower half of his face but survived the shooting. He lived three more years and fathered a child before dying of complications from his injuries and a reaction to medications. The defense denies subliminal messages exist on the album, and counters that the young men's troubled lives, including family violence, drug and alcohol abuse, poor academics and brushes with the law, determined their fates, not some subconscious command. Lunde, who has testified as an expert witness in such high-profile cases as the Jonestown Massacre, Hillside Strangler and Patty Hearst trials, said the brain cannot decipher messages recorded backward and cannot perceive words masked by music or other sound. ``You either hear it or you don't. We don't have more than one mind up there. It either hears it, it perceives it and it registers it or it doesn't,'' he said. ``Suicide is not a decision that can be made by the subconscious mind.'' Vivian Lynch, representing Vance's family, disparaged Lunde's testimony. ``I don't think it's relevant,'' she said. ``He's not knowledgeable in the field of subliminal messages.'' The plaintiffs have not finished presenting their case, but Lunde was allowed to testify for the defense Monday because it was uncertain he would be available when the band and CBS Records begin to present their cases.

DOC.HEAD: Castro's Island Feels Pinch As Soviet Energy Aid Slows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0430 to CORRECT category code. ^By GEORGE GEDDA
DOC.TEXT: In some areas of Cuba, oxen are replacing gas-guzzling tractors. In Havana, office workers are being asked now and then to do without air-conditioning. Fuel at most state enterprises has been cut back 10 percent. And this could be only the beginning. Cubans are bracing for tough times, the result in part of last year's democratic upheaval in Eastern Europe and the prospect that Cuba may no longer be able to count on Soviet generosity to buttress its economy. For years, Cuba has suffered from a U.S. trade and financial embargo. But now, all over the island, Cubans are being warned at town meetings that additional belt tightening may be around the corner if bargain-rate Soviet oil supplies, averaging about 90 million barrels annually, are cut off and there is no money to tap alternate sources. Soviet deliveries already have slowed, and President Fidel Castro alluded to the problem in a speech last month: ``Stubborn realities are there. We constantly have to think in terms of less and less fuel. We have to tell the truth.'' An added concern is that Soviet officials have spoken publicly about the possibility of a phased reduction of overall Soviet economic assistance to Cuba, a windfall estimated by some at $4 billion to $5 billion a year. U.S. sources have said there has been a marked decline in purchases of Cuban sugar by the Soviet Union at prices substantially higher than world market levels, a form of subsidy for the Cuban economy. President Bush has been appealing to the Soviets to cut Castro off. The United States has expressed reluctance to provide direct aid to the troubled Soviet economy as long as Moscow sends billions of rubles to Cuba. ``Special period in peacetime'' is the somewhat benign sounding name for the draconian measures Castro has in mind in the event Cuba has to go it alone. To show that he means business, dress rehearsals are being held around the island to give Cubans a taste of what may lie ahead. Oxen are being tried out on farms in western Cuba. Military recruits are being asked to extend their tours of duty by two months to help the armed services become self-sufficient in food. Under the most extreme austerity measures, thousands could be thrown out of work in Havana, partly because a suspension of most bus service would make it impossible for many to commute. Already, some offices are experimenting with allowing employees to try working at home to see whether their labors would still be useful. Under the worst case scenario, Castro has said that all housing construction would be halted immediately and the manufacture of adult clothing would be suspended. Not all enterprises would be affected. Cuba's ambitious tourism program, slated to bring an almost five-fold increase in the number of foreign visitors to 1.5 million by 1995, would be spared. Castro is discovering somewhat belatedly what his non-Communist predecessors here knew all along: As earners of foreign exchange, Cuba's biggest assets are its tropical climate and its miles of sandy beaches. Some Cuban officials believe that a shift in trading partners from the former socialist bloc to Western industrialized nations will brighten Cuba's economic prospects over the long run. Castro has complained bitterly about the low quality products sent by Eastern European countries to Cuba in exchange for prized Cuban exports such as sugar, citrus fruit and nickel. Cuba may now be able to use these exports to buy high quality goods from the capitalist West, the officials said. But reshaping foreign trade relationships takes time and for now, the future is extraordinarily bleak. Some Cubans have lost hope. More than two dozen presumed asylum seekers are holed up at three European embassies these days. They decided to abandon the revolution even though Castro has said none of them will be given permission to leave the country. According to the U.S. Coast Guard, the number of Cubans who fled to Florida during the first six months of this year totals 196, compared with 57 for the same period last year. But Castro seems determined to maintain his orthodox brand of Marxism even at the cost of the most far-reaching austerity measures. He has criticized Gorbachev's reforms and condemned the changes in Eastern Europe. ``If in five years we don't build housing, if that's the price for saving the revolution, then we will spend five years without building them,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: Biggest Daily Point Losses for Dow Industrials
With PM-Market Drop-Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 56.44 points on Monday, finishing a session in which it was down more than 100 points at one time. In terms of points lost, here are the 10 worst days for the average, including the percentage change in value: Oct. 19, 1987 _ 508.00 to 1,738.74, 22.6 percent. Oct. 13, 1989 _ 190.58 to 2,569.26, 6.91 percent. Oct. 26, 1987 _ 156.83 to 1,793.93, 8.4 percent. Jan. 8, 1988 _ 140.58 to 1,911.31, 6.9 percent. Oct. 16, 1987 _ 108.35 to 2,246.74, 4.6 percent. April 14, 1988 _ 101.46 to 2,005.64, 4.8 percent. Oct. 14, 1987 _ 95.46 to 2,412.70, 3.8 percent. Oct. 6, 1987 _ 91.55 to 2,548.63, 3.5 percent. Sept. 11, 1986 _ 86.61 to 1,792.89, 4.6 percent. Jan. 22, 1990 _ 77.45 points to 2,600.45, 2.9 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Ariane Set for Launch After Five-Month Suspension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS in lead that Ariane a European program, ADDS one graf of background on its makeup. ^By TERRIL JONES
DOC.TEXT: Five months after it was suspended because of an explosion, Europe's Ariane program is back in business with today's launch of a rocket carrying a double payload of French and German television satellites. The 37th Ariane rocket was to blast off tonight from the Ariane facility in French Guiana, South America with a 49-minute ``launch window'' beginning at 6:25 p.m. EST. It is the first attempt at an Ariane launch since a similar rocket carrying two Japanese communications satellites blew up less than two minutes after takeoff on Feb. 22. Both satellites were destroyed. Investigators said the explosion was caused by a tiny piece of cloth that clogged a line carrying water coolant to one of the engines. The respected French weekly L'Express reported in a cover story that the explosion, and at least two previous Ariane failures, may have been caused by sabotage. Officials of Arianespace, the commercial branch of the European Space Agency, have said there was no evidence to indicate sabotage but that technical and security checks would be intensified. The Ariane project has been dogged by embarrassing and costly setbacks, including rockets that have exploded or crashed, and expensive delays. But Ariane rockets dominate the private aerospace industry, carrying about half of the world's commercial payloads into space. Excluding today's flight, Arianespace has contracts worth $2.8 billion to launch 37 more satellites. Ariane rockets have sent into space 45 commercial satellites from Canada, France, West Germany, Great Britain, India, Italy, Spain and the United States, as well as international organizations such as Intelsat and Eutelsat. Ariane is facing increased competition, however, from American private-sector rockets including the Titan-4 made by Martin Marietta Corp., General Dynamics' Atlas-Centaur and the Delta built by McDonnell Douglas. Until now U.S. rockets have mainly launched military and scientific satellites under the supervision of the U.S. Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. China also is a contender in commercial launches with its Long March rocket, as well as the Soviet Union with its Proton and Japan with the H-2 rocket now under development. Flight 37 was to put two satellites into geostationary orbit _ TDF 2, a five-channel French television satellite, and the 11-channel DFS Kopernikus 2, for West Germany's Deutsche Bundespost Telekom. The French satellite weighs 4,621 pounds and will join a twin already in orbit to form a powerful relay system that can serve 400 million television viewers, according to Arianespace. The Kopernikus weighs 3,126 pounds. The two satellites are being lifted into space by an Ariane 4 rocket, the most recent version introduced in 1988, two years behind schedule. It features four strap-on boosters powered by liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen, and stands 190 feet high on the launch pad. Different configurations of the strap-on boosters, using liquid or solid fuel, can be used according to the needs of individual clients. A newer version of the rocket, the heavy-lift launcher Ariane 5, is being developed for planned introduction in 1995. Arianespace is a consortium made up of aerospace, electronics and banking companies from 11 western European countries _ Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland, Sweden and West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: 1990 World Horseshoe Tournament Gets Under Way
DOC.TEXT: He may not be the first president who hankers for a ringer, but organizers of the 1990 World Horseshoe Tournament credit George Bush with boosting the popularity of the ancient pastime. ``His playing has boosted us tremendously,'' said Bob Champion, a spokesman for the National Horseshoe Pitchers Association. ``It's similar to golf, when (Dwight) Eisenhower was into it. And John F. Kennedy? Wasn't he into football?'' Bush is a member of the 16,000-member pitchers group and is invited to all the tournaments, conventions and meetings, Champion said. ``But, as you know, he is busy,'' he said. ``One day, I think he'll surprise us out here and all hell will break loose.'' More than 1,000 horseshoe contestants are in this Atlanta suburb for the annual, two-week tournament, which opened Monday at Stone Mountain Park. They came from across the United States and Canada, from as far away as Australia, either for the sheer thrill of victory or for a piece of the $95,000 in prizes. ``Most people think that horseshoes is something that farmers do out behind the barn, or maybe in the backyard,'' competitor Noel Guy said. ``Very few people know how very well organized the sport is ... because we don't get much exposure,'' said Guy, a retired electronics technician from San Jose, Calif. ``We don't make it on TV like bowling or golf.'' Bush's attachment to the sport ``did a big shot in the arm'' for horseshoe pitching, but he's not the first man to practice the game at the White House, Guy said. ``Harry Truman pitched horseshoes,'' he said. ``I didn't know that either, until just about a year ago. Horseshoes was not that far developed at that time. Now, President Bush is getting all the attention.'' Horseshoe pitching originated with soldiers in ancient Greece who used discarded horseshoes for sport, imitating discus throwing at the Olympian Games. More than 30 million people now pitch horseshoes in tournaments or in city parks and backyards, the organization says. A ringer, when the points of a horseshoe encircle a steel stake in a clay or sand pit, counts as 3 points. One point is awarded when a horseshoe lands within 6 inches of the stake. Two people compete in a game by throwing two horseshoes to the opposite end of the court. They tally points before repeating throws to the opposite pit. The first to get 40 points is the winner.

DOC.HEAD: More Bodies Found, Death Toll Surpasses 1,600
DOC.TEXT: Earthquake search teams reported finding more bodies today in remote mountain communities devastated by last week's temblor, and the death toll surpassed 1,600. A quake measuring 6 on the Richter scale struck the central island of Negros early today but there were no reports of damage or casualties. On Luzon island, President Corazon Aquino inspected damage in her home province, Tarlac, where numerous churches, schools and highways were damaged by the July 16 quake, which measured 7.7. On Monday, she asked Congress to approve $500 million to rebuild damaged areas. Many congressmen also want to stop paying the $26 billion national debt to free funds for reconstruction. Figures from the Office of Civil Defense and the Red Cross showed at least 1,621 people were killed in the quake. More than 3,000 were seriously injured and about 1,000 were listed as missing. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos, chairman of the National Disaster Coordinating Council, said nearly 90,000 people had been left homeless. Rescuers continued digging through the rubble of buildings in the resort of Baguio, where more than 370 people died, and in remote areas of mountainous northern Luzon island. In Baguio, 130 miles north of Manila, three bodies were recovered from the wreckage of the Hyatt Hotel. The luxury hotel collapsed during the quake. Aftershocks continued in the quake-ravaged north. Seismologists said the tremor on Negros was actually an aftershock of a June 14 quake that killed seven people on the central island of Panay. The Philippines sits astride 10 major faults or tremor tracks and is among the most earthquake-prone countries on earth. Mrs. Aquino on Monday rejected proposals to divert foreign debt payments to finance recovery, but supporters said they would press ahead with their proposal. She also thanked foreign rescue and aid efforts. ``I should like to thank all of our friends throughout the world _ governments, institutions as well as individuals _ for the humanitarian assistance given to our people and the victims of the earthquake,'' Mrs. Aquino said. She did not mention an American serviceman, Marine Capt. Michael Shannon of Ashland, Ore., who was killed Friday when his plane crashed near Baguio on a rescue mission. Mrs. Aquino's spokesmen said the government was grateful for American aid but that Filipinos did most of the work. She also did not cite cadets of the Philippine Military Academy in Baguio, who were the first to launch rescue operations in the mountain resort following the quake. Graduates of the academy have been at the forefront of the six coup attempts against her government. Mrs. Aquino said she would ask the National Disaster Coordinating Council who to specifically thank later.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to RECAST lead and CORRECT Fillmore did not install first bathtub, ADDS details of Mencken hoax. Pick up 3rd graf, `This year ...
DOC.HEAD: Town Gears Up for Bathtub Contest
DOC.TEXT: Residents are gearing up for an annual bathtub contest held to honor one of America's least known presidents, along with an infamous hoax. Residents of this town 30 miles south of Syracuse hold Fillmore Days to honor Millard Fillmore, a Cayuga County native who journalist H.L. Mencken falsely reported in 1917 installed the first bathtub in the White House. Mencken, who said he wanted to show how gullible the public was, tried to retract his widely publicized column in 1926, but many people continued to believe the bathtub story. This year, a decorated bathtub contest will replace tub races in Moravia because of road construction downtown, said organizer Anne Townsend. The races began in 1972. A trophy of a bathtub will be awarded to the winner of Saturday's contest. About 2,000 spectators and at least 20 bathtubs are expected. Fillmore, the nation's 13th president from 1850 to 1853, was born Jan. 7, 1800, about five miles west of Moravia.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced to 80-Year Prison Term for Attacks on Elderly
DOC.TEXT: A self-proclaimed Satanist was sentenced to an 80-year prison term in a plea bargain over attacks on elderly women. Willie J. Hills, 28, flashed a victory sign Monday after he pleaded no contest to sexual battery with force, attempted felony murder, armed burglary and two counts of aggravated battery, amony other charges. Hills was accused of beating two women in their 80s until they were unconscious, raping and beating a third elderly woman and fondling and tying up another. The attacks occurred last August and September at trailer parks in Bradenton and Palmetto, less than a month after Hills was released from a 3{-year sentence. Hills told police and psychologists that he believes in Satan and that he committed the attacks ``to gain power.'' According to testimony, Hills suffers from possible brain damage and hallucinations.
