He has a history of violent crime and spent eight years in prison on convictions for aggravated battery, armed robbery, robbery and auto theft.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Slide
DOC.TEXT: The dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen today over news of increasing unrest in the Persian Gulf, prompting traders to buy the currency regarded as a safe haven. The dollar closed at 148.70 yen, up 0.20 yen from Monday's close of 148.15 yen. It opened at 148.15 yen, and ranged between 148.05 yen and 148.75 yen. Spot transactions totaled $8.833 billion, up from Monday's $8.021 billion. Masaya Ueno, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said trading picked up after a report in today's Washington Post that Iraq had moved 30,000 troops to its border with Kuwait and the United States ordered its warships in Persian Gulf on alert. ``With the coming of the news shortly after noontime, the dollar was bought as a safe haven in times of international tension,'' Ueno said. The Washington Post quoted unidentified western military attaches as saying they had seen 2,000 to 3,000 Iraqi Army vehicles moving south on a northbound trip they were allowed to take from Kuwait to Baghdad, capital of Iraq. Kuwait backed Iraq during its eight-year war with Iran, but Iraq is angry with Kuwait because, it claims, Kuwait's oil production beyond quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is depressing the price on world markets. On the stock market, Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 192.33 points, or 0.60 percent, closing at 31,702.46. The index had lost 526.72 points on Monday. Volume on the first section was estimated at 350 million shares, up from the previous day's 300 million shares. ``The index lost some 390 points at one point in the afternoon because of arbitrage selling, but made its recovery toward the closing on index-related buying,'' said Tetsuya Abe, an analyst with Nikko Securities. In arbitrage trading, investors seek to profit from the spread between the spot and futures markets. Abe said the stock market as a whole remained weak over uncertain prospects for interest rates in Japan. Japan's long-term credit banks are considering raising the nation's long-term prime rate by as much as 0.3 percent to 7.9 percent a year, said an official of the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan. An official decision was to be made later this week, the official said. The long-term rates, which lending institutions charge on loans for more than one year, will set the pace for long-term interest rates. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond stood at 85.84 points as of 5 p.m., up from Monday's close of 85.77. The yield slipped to 7.450 percent, down from 7.465 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Television's `China Beach' Shakes Things Up
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``China Beach'' will move not only to a new time next season. It will travel to new decades, its producer says. The Vietnam War series goes to Saturdays at 9 p.m. in the fall. In the season pilot, it jumps forward to 1985, executive producer John Sacret Young said Monday. The acclaimed drama that chronicles nurses and doctors attending to war has been set in the 1960s since its debut two years ago. In the fall, the series will follow the lives of main characters through the 1970s and 1980s, Young said. ``The characters are going to have a wild ride,'' he said. The show, despite laudatory reviews and an Emmy award last year for star Dana Delany, never was a ratings winner and faced an uncertain fate until ABC renewed it for fall at the last minute. Bob Iger, the network's entertainment president, said he hopes the show's new time slot, preceding ABC's cult hit ``Twin Peaks,'' helps to ensure its survival. Young and Delany, speaking to television critics Monday, said they were surprised their series has lasted this long. ``China Beach'' premiered as a spring replacement series in 1988. ``I didn't think the pilot would get picked up,'' Delany said. Next season, Delany's character, the hard-drinking, emotionally stifled nurse Colleen McMurphy, will be shown as an oft-married woman in flash-forward sequences, Young said. Another major character will lose a leg, he said.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Says Talks With ANC Will Go Ahead Despite Arrests
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk will continue talks with the African National Congress on ending white rule despite claims that black nationalists are preparing to seize power if negotiations fail. De Klerk says he will meet Aug. 6 with Nelson Mandela and other top ANC leaders to try and clear the way for negotiations on sharing political power with the black majority. But he has warned all political groups against trying to seize power. He said after a meeting with senior government officials late Monday that there was no room ``for any political organization to stockpile arms in order to force its will at the negotiation table or in any other way to prevent the political process taking its normal course.'' The ANC has confirmed that its guerrillas continue to infiltrate South Africa, but denies police and media reports of an ANC plot to seize power if political negotiations fail. Police have arrested dozens of ANC militants in connection with the reported plot. De Klerk said he viewed the arrests in ``an extremely serious light.'' He rejected calls from the pro-apartheid main opposition Conservative Party and other right-wing groups to call off talks with the ANC. But he said the government was determined to maintain law and order. ``It is imperative that good government be maintained at all times. Therefore disorder, anarchy and terrorism will not be tolerated,'' he said. The government and the ANC are trying to clear the way for constitutional negotiations on sharing power with the black majority. The ANC is demanding release of imprisoned militants and other preliminary conditions. In other developments, the independent South African Press Association said today that the death toll from black faction fighting Sunday in Sebokeng outside Johannesburg had risen to 24. The area was reported quiet today, with police patrols roaming the township to prevent further clashes between ANC militants and supporters of Inkatha, a conservative Zulu group. The dead in the Sebokeng clashes included a white police officer who was speared in the chest, officials said. Police said today that four blacks had been killed in violence Monday near Kimberley in the Orange Free State, including a youth who was shot when police opened fire after one of their vehicles was attacked. Police also said today the bullet-riddled body of a police officer was found overnight in the black homeland of Bophuthatswana. Brian Ngqulunga had testified before a government commission investigating charges that army and police agents killed anti-apartheid activists. Police said they were investigating the death, but gave no details. The United States Embassy in Pretoria announced today that an ANC militant who sought refuge in the Durban consulate on Monday had left of his own free will. Bhekumusa Jabulani Ximba went to the consulte and asked for political asylum, U.S. officials said. The embassy did not say why Ximba had left the consulate.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Jet's Cargo Door Includes High-Tech Probe
LaserPhoto NY7, HU1 of July 23
DOC.TEXT: An electronic grid laid down by a Navy tug will guide a high-tech probe in the Pacific Ocean search for a cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jetliner, killing nine people. The National Transportation Safety Board completed its investigation without the cargo door, but asked the Navy to find it because the door could provide evidence to help improve aircraft safety. The 226-foot tug Narragansett today was to lay down the last of eight transponders, which transmit electrical signals to chart movements of the video camera-equipped submersible, the centerpiece of the Navy's Orion search system. The transponders will hang about 150 feet above the ocean floor around the perimeter of the 24-square-mile search area some 100 miles southwest of Honolulu, said Lt. Cmdr. Bob Anderson, spokesman for the Pacific Fleet. The door is believed to be lying in about 15,000 feet of water. The submersible, called a ``towfish,'' is expected to be lowered into the ocean on Wednesday, Anderson said. If the door is spotted, another device will be used to recover it later. Once the tug reached the search area Monday ``they anticipated a day and one-half setting up and getting ready. We expect they'll be ready to put it in the water by Wednesday,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Sandy Stairs, another Pacific Fleet spokesman. Flight 811 carried 355 passengers when it left Honolulu International Airport for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989. Shortly after takeoff, a cargo door opened at 22,000 feet, tearing away a section of fuselage and causing the Boeing 747 to decompress. Nine people were swept to their deaths and five others were seriously injured. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. The safety board decided faulty design of the door's locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit panel light to falsely indicate the door was locked. The federal agency blamed United, the Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failure to correct problems with the locking mechanism.

DOC.HEAD: Common Interests, Children and Violence Linked to Increased Sex
DOC.TEXT: Couples who have violent relationships, common interests or several children tend to have sex more often than other couples, a sociologist says. Next to youth, shared interests were the greatest indicator of sexual frequency in a marriage, said the University of Florida researcher who based the study on a nationwide survey of 5,292 married couples. ``Whether it's something as simple as taking walks together or enjoying the same hobbies, sharing activities outside the bedroom is a big predictor of how often married couples have sex,'' sociologist Denise Donnelly said Monday. Ms. Donnelly said she found that partners in violent marriages had sexual relations more often than other couples. ``People in these marriages may have intercourse more because of a honeymoon period that follows each outbreak of violence,'' she said. ``These couples may not only fight with a passion, but make up with a passion as well.'' Another explanation might be that people who are physically expressive in showing their anger might be physically expressive in other areas of their lives, including their sexual relationships, she said. Ms. Donnelly also found that people who lived together before marriage had more active sex lives than couples who didn't. ``Since these people are more individualistic and less prone to follow society's expectations, they may also be less likely to have `normal' levels of coital frequency,'' she said. Income, education, race and place of residence had no bearing on how often a couple had sex, she said. But, contrary to other studies, she found that couples with more children led the most active love lives. ``Other researchers have thought that the more children present, the fewer the uninterrupted opportunities for intercourse,'' Ms. Donnelly said. ``In reality, the more one has intercourse, the greater the odds of conceiving a child, and the more children one ultimately has.'' Not surprisingly, she said, couples with school-aged children said they had sex more often than did those with younger children. ``That is because preschoolers need more care and tend to intrude more,'' she said. ``Your 13-year-old probably wouldn't pop his head in the bedroom door and say, `What are you guys doing?,' but your 5-year-old very well might.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Tapes of Talks With Brando's Son Can't Used in Court
LaserPhoto LA6 of July 23
DOC.TEXT: A police tape made after a fatal shooting at the mansion of actor Marlon Brandocannot be used in court against his son, Christian, who faces a murder charge in the death of his pregnant sister's lover. Municipal Court Judge Larry Fidler ruled Monday that detectives failed to properly advise the younger Brando of his rights following the May 16 shooting of Dag Drollet, 26. Prosecutors wanted to play a lengthy recording of Brando's statements to detectives, but his lawyers objected. Detective Steve Osti said he informed Brando of his right to remain silent, but neglected to say that if he could not afford a lawyer, one would be appointed. Fidler ruled the omission was serious enough to invalidate the tape as evidence. The dispute came at a pretrial hearing that will determine whether there is sufficient evidence for Brando to stand trial for murder and a weapons violation charge. The elder Brando, star of such films at ``On the Waterfront'' and the ``The Godfather'' sat solemnly in the courtroom's front row, occasionally taking notes. His 32-year-old son appeared nervous as he was led into the jammed courtroom. Outside, reporters, camera crews and movie fans crowded hallways. Officer Steve Cunningham, the first witness to testify, said Brando told him he killed the boyfriend of his pregnant sister, Cheyenne, during a scuffle. Brando said the fight broke out when ``the deceased went nuts,'' Cunningham testified. ``I didn't mean to shoot him,'' Christian Brando was quoted as telling Cunningham, the first police officer on the scene. Ms. Brando was then seven months pregnant with Drollet's child. She recently gave birth to a boy in Tahiti, where the Brandos maintain a home. She is said to be suffering from nervous exhaustion and a doctor told authorities she could not return to California to testify. The officer's testimony appeared to support the defense contention that the .45-caliber handgun went off accidentally during a scuffle between the 6-foot Brando and the 6-foot-3 Drollet. But prosecutors have said they found no evidence of a struggle and that Drollet was shot while sitting on a sofa, holding a cigarette lighter in one hand and a television remote control in the other.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Patriarch Blesses `Weeping' Virgin Mary Icon
DOC.TEXT: The spiritual leader of Eastern Orthodox Christians prayed, blessed and kissed a painting of the Virgin Mary known for tears that attract thousands of pilgrims each year. Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios I blessed the scarlet and gold painting Monday at St. Nicholas Albanian Orthodox Church, where moisture described as tears was first reported near the Madonna's eyes in 1986. He seemed emotionally drained as he turned away from the painting near the small church's altar in a 20-minute ceremony attended by about 400 people. A crowd estimated by police at 600 waved white flags with the church's red and gold emblem as the 75-year-old patriarch emerged from the church. ``He is offering prayers to the health of the sick and for eternal peace for those who have passed away,'' said the Rev. Alex Karloutsos of the archbishop's office in New York. ``He comes not only as the patriarch, but also as a pilgrim,'' Karloutsos said. ``He is here because the Virgin Mary began weeping and the Virgin plays an important role in our church.'' The patriarch has appeared tired during his three-day Chicago visit. Some events on his schedule here have been canceled, including a meeting with Greek-American and Jewish leaders. Dimitrios I, world leader of 180 million to 250 million Eastern Orthodox Christians, is on a 27-day tour of the United States. His visit concludes Sunday in Boston, the first visit to North America by anyone in his office. The archbishop has visited Washington, New York, Allentown and Johnstown, Pa., and San Francisco. He leaves Chicago on Wednesday for Buffalo, N.Y. Christian Orthodoxy is largely divided along national lines, including Greeks, Russians, Albanians, Serbians, Ukrainians and others. Six million followers of Eastern Orthodoxy live in the United States, including about 250,000 in Chicago and its suburbs.

DOC.HEAD: Donor Drive Fails to Turn Up Match for Young Leukemia Victim
DOC.TEXT: A leukemia victim's search for a perfect bone marrow donor helped triple the number of potential donors in a national registry, but none of the 50,000 people who volunteered for blood tests were compatible. Instead, 20-year-old Allison Atlas will get an imperfectly matched transplant from her mother _ before time runs out. Thanks to the Atlas family's search, 10 other patients have found compatible donors since November, said Simon Atlas, a cousin of Allison's father. He said Monday that Miss Atlas, from Bethesda, Md., will be admitted to the Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, probably at the end of this week, to begin week-long preparations for the transplant. Her mother, Arline, ``has been a fallback all along. She's not a perfect match, obviously, or we would have used her'' at the outset, Simon Atlas said. Miss Atlas is one of about 10,000 Americans a year who search for a potentially life-saving marrow match from an unrelated donor. Largely because of patients like Miss Atlas, public awareness about transplants has grown over the past eight months. Dozens of grassroots groups around the nation have emulated the campaign of her supporters, Friends of Allison. They implore neighbors, co-workers, schoolmates and worshipers to take blood tests and give money. If the particular patient doesn't find a match, they reason, maybe someone else will. Friends of Allison has given blood tests to 49,400 volunteers in the United States and 600 in Israel since November. The group has also taken in $3 million in donations to pay for laboratory work. The test results were listed with the National Marrow Donor Program, and a related international registry. When the Atlases began their search, the national registry had gathered 57,000 donors in three years. Now, because of the Atlases and other families' efforts, it has more than 150,000 names. The odds for finding a marrow match are at least 20,000-to-1.

A burglar washed a stack of dirty dishes and grabbed a shower before cleaning out the apartment of Stephanie Pitts. Ms. Pitts said her stereo equipment and a long list of other things were stolen, but the apartment was left spotless. The burglar washed the dirty dishes, mopped the kitchen floor and scrubbed the bathroom tub, Ms. Pitts said. He even re-arranged her furniture. The break-in was discovered over the weekend when her boyfriend stopped by her apartment to pick up a dress for Ms. Pitts. ``When he got there someone was upstairs taking a shower, but he just figured one of my sisters had stopped by,'' she said. Ms. Pitts said reported the break-in to police. ``I was kind of glad the house was cleaned up, but where's my stuff?'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: City Health Commissioner Shakes Up Department Over Pap Smear Scandal
DOC.TEXT: City officials who allowed about 3,000 Pap tests to languish for a year betrayed the public trust, Health Commissioner Woodrow Myers said before firing a top aide in the scandal. After the delay, 11 tests revealed cancerous cells, 93 showed pre-cancer conditions and 600 contained other abnormalities. No women have died as a result of the mishandling, but some could be at risk, Myers said. Mismanagement and poor supervision caused ``critical delays,'' Myers told reporters Monday. The scandal involved Pap tests administered to about 3,000 women at city-run clinics. The tests were allowed to accumulate for a year without laboratory analysis. Pap smears test women for cervical and uterine cancer. Myers announced a departmental shakeup that included the firing of Dr. Kenneth Dressler, former assistant commissioner in the department's bureau of laboratories. The health commissioner also announced Norman Scherzer, former assistant commissioner for epidemiology and prevention services, and John Miles, former director of the Sexually Transmitted Disease Department, were being reassigned within the department. Dr. Stephen Schultz, former deputy commissioner for epidemiology and prevention services, already has been reassigned from administrative to clinical duties. Myers said investigators found that department policies since 1988 ``have resulted in an outrageous insensitivity to women who rely on this department.'' He said all but two of 104 women whose test results were most ominous have been located. Myers conceded there was a ``very low'' prospect for finding the other two, one of whom he said had used a false name. The other was wanted by the FBI, Myers said. He said all of the tests that went unread have since been analyzed and department laboratories will return results within a week.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Generally Lower; Gold Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major currencies in early trading in Europe today, following sharp declines overnight in New York. Gold prices were mixed. Dealers said the market was likely to wait for the resumption of trading on the New York Stock Exchange to see whether Monday's decline continued. ``We want to see if the Dow Jones (stock index) recovers or remains under pressure,'' said a dealer at a large Frankfurt bank. ``That will be the big indicator for the dollar today.'' However, in Tokyo, where trading ends before it begins in Europe, the dollar rose to close at 148.70 yen, up 0.20 yen from Monday's close of 148.15. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 148.45. Tokyo dealers said the currency was strengthened over news of increasing unrest in the Persian Gulf, prompting purchases of dollars, regarded as a safe haven. They said trading picked up after a Washington Post report today that Iraq had moved 30,000 troops to its border with Kuwait and the United States had ordered its warships in the Gulf on alert. In London, the pound also strengthened against the dollar. A pound cost $1.8225, more expensive than $1.8215 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday: _ 1.6226 West German marks, down from 1.6278 _ 1.3805 Swiss francs, down from 1.3880 _ 5.4435 French francs, down from 5.4598 _ 1.1833 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8430 _ 1,188.00 Italian lire, down from 1,192.00 _ 1.1558 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1568 Gold was quoted at $368.25 an ounce at the morning fixing in London, compared with $368.15 bid late Monday. In Zurich, gold was quoted at a bid price of $368.00, up from $367.75 bid late Monday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $6.97 to close at a bid $369.25. Silver bullion traded in London at a bid price of $4.90 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Skies Dry After a Night of Rain
DOC.TEXT: There was rain in Maine early today, but skies were dry elsewhere after a night of showers throughout the United States. Showers and thunderstorms Monday produced high winds that knocked down trees in southern Mississippi and produced a tornado in southern Florida near Okeechobee. Rain extended from eastern Virginia to New England on Monday and fell in parts of Michigan, Nebraska, Minnesota, Colorado, Wyoming and New Mexico. Showers and thunderstorms also extended from the southern half of Texas to Florida and Georgia. Rain fell early today in Portland, Maine. It was a tie for the nation's high temperature Monday; Borrego Springs, Calif., and Lake Havasu City, Ariz., each peaked at 111 degrees. DOC.HEAD: Officials: W. Germany To Begin Shipping Out Chemical Arms
DOC.TEXT: The United States will begin removing its chemical weapons from West Germany this week and will ship them a U.S. atoll in the Pacific, where they will be destroyed in an incinerator, officials said. The West German Defense Ministry said Monday in a statement that the operation to remove the 100,000 artillery rounds will begin Thursday. A U.S. army spokesman in West Germany said he was awaiting confirmation from Washington and could not confirm that date. Chancellor Helmut Kohl and former President Reagan agreed in 1986 to remove the weapons by 1992. President Bush advanced the timetable to 1990, said James Boyle, a spokesman for Headquarters U.S. Army, Europe. Boyle said the artillery shells _ in 6-inch-diameter and 8-inch sizes _ are loaded with liquid nerve agents. He said they have been stored since 1968 at a U.S. military site in Clausen, a small town near the U.S. military complex at Kaiserslautern in southwestern West Germany. ``This is the most well-planned operation we've had here as far as the transport of munitions. There is safety measure upon safety measure redundant throughout the operation,'' Boyle said. Each convoy will include 20 flatbed trucks loaded with the chemical weapons stored in two air-tight steel containers and 60 other escort trucks, including German and U.S. security forces, emergency crews and decontamination teams, he said. Boyle said there would be about 30 convoys, running one a day. The trucks will travel a variety of routes, for safety and security reasons, from Clausen to a U.S. depot at Miesau about 30 miles away, he said. The containers will be loaded onto special trains at Miesau for the trip north to Nordenham, on the North Sea, where they will be reloaded onto U.S. Navy ships for transport to Johnston Atoll in the Pacific. Boyle said the chemical weapons will be destroyed later in a specially built incinerator on the U.S. atoll, about 800 miles southwest of Hawaii. Joe Badilla, an Army spokesman in Washington, said the administration first had to certify to Congress, on Tuesday at the latest, that the incinerator was working. Once that was done, shipment from West Germany could begin, he said. Officials said the removal operation was expected to be completed before October.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Highlights Fears of Anti-Semitism in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: A Moscow man went on trial today in a packed and raucous courtroom on charges of inciting intolerance of Jews in a case that highlights fears of growing anti-Semitism among Russians. But Judge A.I. Muratov postponed the trial of Konstantin Smirnov-Ostashvili after only a few minutes of procedural work and two breaks because of the crush of reporters hemming the docket and noisy viewers who shouted ``Shame!'' at him. Smirnov-Ostashvili, 64, was arrested for allegedly organizing protesters who broke up a meeting Jan. 18 at the Central House of Literature in Moscow and insulted Jewish writers. If convicted, he could be sentenced to up to five years in prison. The case has received wide publicity in the Soviet press at a time when Soviet Jews are emigrating by the thousands, many because they fear a wave of anti-Semitic attacks by extreme Russian nationalists groups like Pamyat. Speaking to reporters from the docket during a break in the case, Smirnov-Ostashvili denied being anti-Semitic but charged that the Soviet Union's 1.4 milion Jews hold a disproportionate number of high places in government and society. ``A Russian person is brought to trial in the center of Russia ... for insulting, injuring the dignity, and for instigating intolerance against those who enjoy massive privileges, and who hold the leading posts in our society,'' he said. ``Even if I am accused and punished, in no instance will I agree with the punishment because no one can show me that I somehow, somewhere, broke the law,'' said the defendant, a short, emphatic man with a fringe of gray hair around his bald head. Smirnov-Ostashvili said his was the first such case brought to trial under a law passed as the Soviet Union grapples with widespread ethnic unrest. He said he was not certain whether the judge and two civilian assistants would consider the case as a purely legal matter, or consider its political implications. Convicting him would further polarize Soviet society, he said. A 36-year-old Jewish psychiatrist in the crowd who identified himself only as Eduard said the case would test whether Soviet courts, traditionally considered arms of the ruling Communists, had become fairer. Among those in the front row of the crowd were two well-known progressives, writer Ales Adamovich, and historian Yuri Afanasiev. More than 71,000 Jews emigrated from the Soviet Union after travel laws were eased last year, and thousands more have left so far this year. Jewish leaders have cited ``an unprecedented panic among the Jewish population.'' Judge Muratov adjourned the case for a day after rejecting Smirnov-Ostashvili's bid to dismiss his court-appointed attorney, and before the defendant could enter a plea. Members of the crowd, packed into wooden benches in the stuffy courtroom of the Moscow City Court building, shouted ``Shame!'' at the judge when he denied Smirnov-Ostashvili's bid. Smirnov-Ostashvili had told the court he wanted to dismiss defense lawyer Svetlana Birulina because he did not trust the Moscow lawyers association to which she belongs. He also told the court that the majority of Soviet lawyers are Jewish. In a report on the January confrontation at the Central House of Literature, the popular weekly Ogonyok quoted one of the protesters as saying through a megaphone: ``Your time is over. Neither the police, nor the KGB, nor the party will help you. Now we will be the masters of the country, and you, newcomers, clear out and go to Israel. How long can we tolerate your Russophobia?'' In an editorial on Sunday, the Communist Party daily Pravda called for the country to recognize that anti-Semitism exists, and to find a solution.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Cautious as Bush Names `Blank Slate' to High Court
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 7th graf pvs to UPDATE with Specter, Leahy comments today on abortion. Picks up 8th graf pvs, ``Meanwhile, conservative ...
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Souter Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= WASHINGTON (AP) _ Senators are reacting cautiously to David H. Souter's nomination to the Supreme Court, most conceding they know little about him even though they confirmed him as a federal appeals judge three months ago. ``I want to get to know him, get to know his record so I can make a considered decision, and I'm sure he'll be fine,'' Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said Monday after President Bush chose Souter to succeed retired Justice William Brennan. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said senators must ``determine whether he possesses a strong commitment to the fundamental values of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights'' while Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said he wanted to know more about Souter's record as New Hampshire attorney general. Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, called Souter ``pretty much of a blank slate.'' All four are members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which will hold confirmation hearings on Souter. There, questions are bound to be raised about his views on abortion and other matters. Most senators said, however, they would not break tradition and ask Souter point-blank how he would decide the abortion issue if confirmed. But they said the topic was guaranteed to come up. ``People are very much focused on the abortion issue and, frankly, I think that's a mistake,'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., said today on the ``CBS This Morning'' television show. ``I do not think there ought to be a single litmus test for a nominee for the Supreme Court. That judgment was seconded by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., who said on CBS: ``The president avoided making this a litmus test candidate. I would hope the Senate would avoid making it a litmus test candidate.'' However, Leahy acknowledged earlier that ``it would be naive to think that Roe vs. Wade in one form or another is not going to be part of a lot of the questions.'' He was referring to the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion. Meanwhile, conservative groups reacted favorably to Souter's appointment while pro-choice and civil rights organizations urged caution. Souter aroused no controversy when the Senate approved him as a judge of the 1st U.S. Court of Appeals in April. As a result, his confirmation proceedings apparently blurred into those of numerous other judicial candidates, at least for some senators. Judicial candidates are screened by the FBI, the American Bar Association, the Judiciary Committee staff and various court watchdog groups. But their hearings are often love fests with a friendly senator presiding, and confirmation frequently comes without a formal vote with only a skeleton crew of senators on the floor. One lawmaker who has known Souter for years, Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., described him as ``the classic conservative intellectual'' but added that the nominee ``cannot be described as an ideologue in any way, shape or form.'' Sen. Slade Gorton, R-Wash., said he had known Souter since they both were attorneys general of their states. ``He was an excellent attorney general, so my initial reaction is positive,'' Gorton said. The top Republican on the Judiciary Committee, Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, said Souter's brief time on the federal bench and lack of a controversial record should keep him safe from initial opposition. Simon said the same but added that he was concerned about a pair of cases handled by Souter when he was New Hampshire attorney general. One involved the issue of separation of church and state while the other concerned voting rights, Simon said. ``It would be a terrible injustice to confirm a nominee without knowing that he is committed to protecting Americans' fundamental constitutional rights, including privacy and the right to choose,'' said Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``We are pleased that President Bush says he is nominating a justice who will interpret the Constitution according to its text and who will not legislate from the bench,'' said a statement from the National Right to Life Committee. But Eleanor Smeal, president of the Feminist Majority, said: ``The Senate Judiciary Committee members must demand to know his position on abortion rights. Our lives are on the line and for once in political decision-making women's lives must come first.'' Republican National Committee spokesman Charlie Black called Souter ``an excellent choice.'' ``Judge Souter is an intelligent person who will be a fair arbiter of the law,'' Black said. ``He's a pig in a poke, a Sununu special,'' said Harvard law Professor Alan Dershowitz. ``How can we be expected to confirm a nominee that no one knows anything about?'' White House chief of staff John Sununu, as governor of New Hampshire, appointed Souter to that state's Supreme Court. Richard A. Viguerie, chairman of the United Conservatives of America, said in a statement that the Souter nomination represented a ``first step'' for Bush ``in repairing the split between himself and the conservatives, his most important constituency.''

DOC.HEAD: Detective: Tricked Teen to Get Him to Talk About Jogger Attack
DOC.TEXT: A detective testified that he lied about non-existent fingerprints to get a teen-ager to confess to taking part in the Central Park jogger attack. Defendant Yusef Salaam, 16, repeatedly told Detective Thomas McKenna he was not in the park the night of the attack, the law officer said on the witness stand Monday. Convinced the boy had been there during the so-called ``wilding'' attack, McKenna said: ``We have fingerprints from the jogger's pants. They're satin and very smooth. We'll compare those prints with yours, and if they match you don't have to say anything. You're going for rape.'' McKenna said Salaam then told him: ``I was there but I didn't rape her.'' The detective admitted under cross-examination that he knew of no such fingerprints and that his reference to them was a lie. Police found no fingerprints at the crime scene where the investment banker was beaten unconscious, gang-raped and left for dead. Courts have upheld the use of deceit by police to extract confessions as long as the accused were not threatened, coerced or improperly advised of their rights. After Salaam's alleged confession, McKenna said he then asked: ``How could you possibly do something like this?'' ``It was just something to do; it was fun,'' McKenna quoted Salaam as saying, referring to handwritten notes. The April 19, 1989, attack was allegedly carried out by a gang of youths roving the park looking for random victims _ a practice known by the slang term ``wilding.'' Salaam admitted hitting the woman with a pipe and fondling her, and gave the names of other youths who allegedly assaulted her, McKenna testified. Unlike other defendants, Salaam gave police no videotaped or signed written statement. Salaam's lawyer, Robert Burns, denied his client made the statements that McKenna recounted. He tried unsuccessfully to get the testimony barred from the trial. Salaam, Antron McCray, and Raymond Santana, all 16, are being tried on charges of rape, attempted murder, sexual abuse, assault, robbery and riot in connection with the attack on the woman and less serious attacks on two male joggers. The woman, now 30, is back at work at Salomon Brothers Inc. investment banking firm, but suffers from impaired vision and balance and has lost her sense of smell as a result of the assault. Three other youths charged in the attack are to stand trial later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Homeless in Lake Baikal Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Severe flooding caused by heavy rainfall in the Lake Baikal region of Siberia has killed a number of people and left thousands homeless, the newspaper Sovietskaya Rossia said today. More than 400 bridges were swept away as rivers flowing into Lake Baikal overflowed their banks during the rainfall in early July, the newspaper said. Power and water supplies in the region have been disrupted. The newspaper said a number of people died in the flooding, but did not give a death toll. In the city of Chita, 2,500 miles east of Moscow, residents ignored warnings by officials to take precautions against the predicted rainstorms. ``Several days before the flood, we had arranged for a special car with a loudspeaker to mve along the streets of the city warning people about the danger,'' said Chita Mayor Yuri Timofeev. ``But, people only laughed at us.'' According to Sovietskaya Rossia, the flooding caused $635 million in damages, including $270 million in farm damage. More than 600 cattle and 10,000 sheep drowned in the flooding, the report said. The newspaper said a regional task force has been set up to deal with the emergency. Sovietskaya Rossia said meteorologists were predicting more rain in August. The newspaper blamed much of the damage on the intentional destruction of forests in the region. ``The situation is aggravated by the fact that thoughtless, large-scale, wood-felling renders the region particularly vulnerable to any summer rains,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Capture Key Rebel Village
DOC.TEXT: Government troops have captured a key northern village in fierce fighting that left 30 Tamil rebels dead, military officials said today. The village controls access to the Jaffna peninsula, where the rebels are based. Four soldiers were killed in the Monday attack, in which helicopters dropped troops and commandos behind rebel defenses to take the village of Paranthan, officials said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. Paranthan is seven miles south of Elephant Pass, a causeway that links the Jaffna peninsula with the mainland. The capture of Paranthan could provide a launching pad for attacks on Jaffna, which the Tamil Tiger rebels have held since they repudiated a cease-fire with government forces on June 11. The rebels control all of Jaffna, except for four government bases that have been under siege for more than a month. Almost one million civilians, mostly ethnic Tamils, live on the peninsula. Tamil militants took up arms in 1983, claiming their community was being discriminated against in jobs, education and language by the Sinhalese majority. Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhists, comprise 75 percent of the population and control the army and the government. At least 13,800 people have died in the Tamil insurrection. Last week, the rebels blew up the Elephant Pass causeway, the only viable route for a large-scale crossing into the peninsula. Military officials said the causeway has since been repaired. At least 2,890 combatants have been killed in fighting since the rebels violated the June cease-fire. The latest casualties included eight soldiers killed Monday near the east coast port of Trincomalee in a rebel ambush, military officials said. Another soldier was killed near Batticaloa, south of Trincomalee, they said. When the fighting began last month, the rebels held the Tamil-dominated areas on the north and east of the island. The army has dislodged the rebels from most towns in the east, and the guerrillas have retreated into the jungles to fight what could be a protracted war. In the north, the army has been unable to make significant headway because of the difficult access to Jaffna.

DOC.HEAD: Maples Speaks Out On Trump Divorce Battle
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples, the woman who has been romantically linked to millionaire developer Donald Trump, says his estranged wife, Ivana, is a cold woman who is neglecting her children. Ivana is ``out every night in London and New York, going on dates to her society parties, while Donald is home raising the children,'' Maples said in an interview published today in the Daily News. Mrs. Trump disputed the charges. ``I see my children every single day,'' she said through spokeswoman Lisa Calandra. ``Donald sees them once a week at most _ and has gone weeks on end without seeing them at all.'' Maples also insisted that Ivana ``had to know'' that she and Donald were an item. After all, she would have. ``There is no way (Ivana) could not have known. When I'm seeing someone, I know every little thing,'' Maples said. ``I'm psychic. And a woman better keep her eyes open.'' Maples also claims she's not responsible for the Trumps' separation: ``I had nothing to do with Donald's marriage. I'm not a homewrecker.'' When asked if she would marry Trump, Maples said, ``Of course I would think about it, of course. This could be a story with a very beautiful ending.'' But would she sign a prenuptial agreement? Never, she said. ``That makes the relationship too shallow. You fall in love with love, not money.'' Maples and her publicist, Chuck Jones, have been subpoenaed and are expected to give depositions at an Aug. 20 hearing on the validity of the agreement Mrs. Trump signed in December 1987. Mrs. Trump, who is seeking half her husband's assets, said in court papers that had she been aware of her husband's ``adultery and philandering,'' she would not have entered into a contract limiting her to $25 million and a $7 million mansion in the event of a split. Besides battling his estranged wife, Trump has been battling financial problems. He recently agreed to a $65 million bailout plan, under which a group of banks put the Trumps on a monthly allowance of $450,000.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Reject New Talks, Vow More Road Blockades
DOC.TEXT: The Quebec government has offered to resume talks with Mohawks over a land dispute, but Indian representatives rejected the offer and some said they would close more roads across Canada today in protest. The Canadian province's native affairs minister, John Ciaccia, said Monday the government was ready to resume the talks and would agree to have human rights representatives as observers. But he said the talks should be held away from the barricades where the Mohawks and police have faced each other for nearly two weeks in an armed standoff involving the land claim dispute. Last week, the Mohawks asked observers from the United Nations or Amnesty International to monitor the talks. The Red Cross, one of the few groups that has been allowed beyond the barricades by Quebec provincial police, would be permitted to continue providing food and supplies, Ciaccia said, meeting another Mohawk demand for free movement of food and medicine. But Ellen Gabriel, speaking for the Mohawks at a news conference Monday night, rejected the main condition that the negotiations take place outside the Oka barricades and exclude representatives from the Akwesasne reserve, which straddles the Ontario, Quebec and New York state borders. She said the Mohawks fear the provincial police. ``How can we feel safe outside these barricades when they won't even let food and water through?'' she said. The conflict began July 11 when Quebec provincial police stormed a 4-month-old roadblock set up by Kanesatake Mohawks to stop the expansion of an Oka golf course on land they claim. An officer was killed in a gunbattle, but it was unclear whether it was from Mohawk or police fire. Ciaccia, who had held negotiations near the barricades until talks broke down about a week ago, did not say where he'd like new talks to be held. In an interview, Ciaccia said the proposal to have talks outside the barricades is ``not for security reasons but to create an atmosphere of calm.'' While the barricades remain at Oka, 30 miles west of Montreal, a blockade by the Kahnawake Mohawks of the Mercier Bridge continues, forcing thousands of people to find other ways to get into the city from the south shore of Montreal island. A new commuter train service went into effect Monday, but only 550 people took advantage of the service. Indians in British Columbia and Saskatchewan vowed to close more roads today in support of Quebec's Mohawks. ``Chiefs definitely are prepared to shut the country down,'' said Lawrence Courtoreille, Alberta spokesman for the Assembly of First Nations. ``Natives have been talking about that possibility for years,'' he said, noting that major highways, main railway lines and hydro lines run through reserves, making them vulnerable to attack. There were 12 road blockades in place in British Columbia, and Saul Terry, president of the Union of British Columbia Indian Chiefs, said more could go up. Peaceful protests in support of the Mohawks continued across the country Monday in Calgary, Saskatoon, Fredericton and Perth-Andover.

DOC.HEAD: 3-Year-Old Girl Undergoes Rare Liver, Small Intestine Transplants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with surgery over. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Small intestine...'.
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old girl received a transplanted liver and small intestine today in a rare operation that lasted nearly 14 hours. Tracey Kay Gonzales of Corpus Christi, Texas, was in critical condition and breathing with the help of a respirator in the intensive care unit at Children's Hospital following the surgery said hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo. The operation began at 5:25 p.m. Monday and ended about 7:10 a.m. today. ``Everybody seems to feel it went fairly well,'' Ms. Cardillo said. ``It will be at least a week before doctors are able to form any type of prognosis, if then.'' Ms. Cardillo said the next three days will be especially critical, and doctors will watch closely to see if the organs are functioning properly and free of infection. Tracey needed the double transplant because of a condition called short gut syndrome, Ms. Cardillo said. Her liver was damaged by a high-protein liquid she was fed intravenously since birth. ``A child with short gut syndrome has no way to absorb nutrition,'' Ms. Cardillo said. ``There isn't enough intestine there to do any good. Her skin is very yellow from the liver damage.'' Small intestine transplants have a poor success rate. Since 1983, three adults and three children have died within a year of their surgeries at Pittsburgh hospitals. Tracey has been a patient at Children's Hospital since April 22, Ms. Cardillo said. The donor of her new organs was not identified. The girl's large intestine, or colon, functions normally. An estimated 2,000 children are born with short gut syndrome in the United States every year. Dr. John Fung announced earlier this year what he called the world's first successful small intestine transplant on a man who was shot in the abdomen. The man, who was not identified, was able to eat after the April operation but still was recovering, Fung told the University of Pittsburgh's board of trustees. Three-year-old Tabatha Foster of Madisonville, Ky., died 192 days after a 1987 transplant of parts of her stomach and colon and her pancreas, liver and small intestine. Rolandrea ``Rolly'' Dodge, another 3-year-old girl from Fruitland, N.M., died three months after her November 1988 transplant of part of her colon and her stomach, pancreas, liver and small intestine. An unidentified 6-year-old girl died hours after a transplanted small intestine replaced an organ damaged in a 1983 swimming-pool accident.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Dies From Wounds, First Army Shooting Death in a Month
DOC.TEXT: An 18-year-old Palestinian died today of wounds suffered in an earlier clash with soldiers, Arab reports said. It was the first death from army gunfire in a month. The victim, Mahmud Helal Salame, was shot in the neck July 14 in a clash between soldiers and stone-throwing youths in the West Bank village of Beit Lid, Arab reports said. They said he died in Tel Hashomer Hospital near Tel Aviv. An army spokesman confirmed a Palestinian was shot by troops in Beit Lid, near Tulkarem, during the mid-July confrontation. He said the army was checking the reported death. The last death in a clash with troops was June 25 when a 25-year-old woman was shot to death in Tulkarem. In June, 10 Palestinians were killed in uprising clashes. In the past month, the army has adopted a new policy of avoiding confrontations with stone throwers in small villages and crowded refugee camps where many of the uprising deaths have occurred. The policy follows the appointment of Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who took office after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing coalition government was formed June 11. Arens has said his policy is to deploy more soldiers along roadways to protect Jewish settlers as they travel to and from their homes in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Tuesday's death brought to 724 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians during the 31-month-old revolt against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. During the uprising, 242 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Forty-five Israelis also have died in the violence. Also Tuesday, Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza staged a general strike ordered by the Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas, or ``zeal.'' The strike was called to mourn the destruction of Baghdad, the capital of the Abbasid Islamic empire, by Mongol warriors in 1258. Hamas has, in the past, scheduled general strikes to mark historic dates in Islamic history.

DOC.HEAD: British Official Visits China, First Since Protests Crushed
DOC.TEXT: The first senior British official to visit China since Beijing crushed its pro-democracy movement arrived today, extending a pattern by other Western nations of gradually restoring political ties. Francis Maude, the foreign office minister responsible for Hong Kong, is the highest-ranking European official to visit China since the European Community banned high-level government exchanges to protest Beijing's June 1989 crackdown on the student protests. ``As permanent members of the (U.N.) Security Council, we have many shared interests and common responsibilities in the world. It's essential that we work together on these,'' Maude told reporters at the airport. His visit coincided with that of former Australian Prime Minister Gough Whitlam, who met Monday with Chinese Premier Li Peng. The official Xinhua News Agency said Li told Whitlam, ``The clouds of attempting to isolate China are dispersing as more and more countries are responding to China's sincere desire for friendly co-existence with other countries.'' Most Western nations banned high-level governmental exchanges after the military crushed the pro-democracy movement, leaving hundreds dead. But the European Community granted exceptions to Britain because of its links with Hong Kong and to Portugal, because of Macao. The British colony of Hong Kong reverts to Chinese rule in 1997 and the Portuguese colony of Macao is to be returned two years later. Observers said Maude's three-day visit could pave the way for other Western countries to resume diplomatic contacts. In recent weeks, high-level officials from Japan and Canada have also visited China. Maude's main mission is to advance discussions on Hong Kong that stalled after the Chinese crackdown. ``The Chinese and British governments have a common responsibility for promoting stability and prosperity of Hong Kong,'' Maude said. ``During my visit here, I shall be emphasizing to my hosts the British government's wish to work constructively and positively with the Chinese to ensure the future of Hong Kong based on the Joint Declaration and the Basic Law,'' he said. Maude was referring to the 1984 Chinese-British agreement to return Hong Kong to Chinese rule in 1997, and to the mini-constitution that will govern the island after the turnover.

DOC.HEAD: Union Truck Drivers Agree to Support Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to add location of counties named, all in and around Portland.
DOC.TEXT: Union truck drivers have agreed to support a strike by workers at 116 supermarkets, and the action could affect store inventories. Rick Sawyer, a spokesman for Local 555 of the United Food and Commercial Workers, said Monday stores were already running out of some products. ``The meatcutters are out, and meat has a shelf life of a couple days,'' he said. ``Produce items are the same way. I was in a store last night, and they were completely out of lettuce.'' The Teamsters Joint Council voted Monday afternoon to honor the supermarket workers. The strike began Saturday. Council president John Trout said food products from independent distribution centers may not be delivered. Deliveries from dairies, breweries, soft drink bottlers, bakeries and laundries also could be affected. But for the time being, the sanctions would not affect operations at retail chain distribution centers, he said. Health care has been the major issue during contract talks, with the union pressing for employers to continue paying the full cost of benefits. The employers have been trying to get employees to assume part of the rising costs. The workers, who have not had a pay increase since 1986, also are seeking wage increases greater than the 2{ percent yearly boost management has offered as part of a proposed four-year agreement, Sawyer said. Journeymen clerks now make $11.05 an hour. The union represents employees at stores in Multnomah, Washington, Clackamas, Yamhill and Columbia counties, all in and around Portland.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS LYNDHURST, N.J.-dated 11th items in Deaths package to add that film, television appearances confined to `extra' parts. SUBS ST. PAUL-dated 12th item to restore dropped state name in dateline, delete reference to man having been `wheelchair-bound.
DOC.HEAD: Patrick Joyce
DOC.TEXT: Actor Patrick Joyce, a bit player who nonetheless became well known in the entertainment industry, died Saturday at age 82. Although Joyce's movie and television credits included only stints as an extra, he was well known to producers and appeared as a guest on ``Late Night with David Letterman'' and ``The Joe Franklin Show.'' He was a retired clerk for U.S. Rubber Co. in New York City. The cause of death was not disclosed. Joyce's movie appearances included ``The Pope of Greenwich Village,'' ``Fame,'' and Woody Allen's ``Stardust Memories.'' His television appearances included the soap opera ``Guiding Light,'' ``The Gentleman Bandit'' and ``Born Beautiful.''

Robert J. Moreland, a paraplegic who invented a hydraulic table for people in wheelchairs, died Saturday of heart failure at age 76. Moreland began using a wheelchair after an operation for cancer in 1968, which prompted him to invent the Moreland Hydraulic Table. The device allows people in wheelchairs to get up on their own or with assistance from another person.

DOC.HEAD: Souter's Mother Says He Couldn't Be a Better Son
DOC.TEXT: While senators who will vote on David Souter's confirmation are being cautious about the new nominee for the Supreme Court, his mother says flat out that he ``couldn't be better'' as a son. And a woman who resides at the same retirement home as Helen Souter says he's ``a darling.'' ``I think a tear drop fell'' when Souter phoned her with the news that President Bush was nominating him to the high court, Mrs. Souter said from the retirement home where her only child visits her weekly. ``He's a darling,'' said Mickie Carson, a close friend of the nominee's mother and a fellow resident of Heritage Heights. ``Everyone knows David is very special.'' Souter, 50, has never married. He still lives at the Weare farm where his family settled in when he was 11. He left there only for college, law school and to be a Rhodes Scholar in England. Mrs. Souter said her son was very close to his father, Joseph, who died in 1982. Carson added that although Mrs. Souter is proud of her son, she was already thinking Monday that his confirmation would mean he'd move to Washington and might not be able to continue his weekly visits. Mrs. Souter said any move by the man who ``couldn't be better'' as a son would be painful because she would miss him being nearby.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Agreements Average 3.8 Percent So Far This Year
DOC.TEXT: Contracts settled so far this year through collective bargaining gave workers average annual wage increases of 3.8 percent over the life of the pacts, the government said today. The last time parties covered by those settlements negotiated, usually in 1987 or 1988, average wage gains averaged 2.5 percent over the contract term, the Labor Department said. Part of the gains reflected wage increases that were larger than those in previous contracts, such as those for workers in transportation equipment manufacturing, petroleum refining, food stores and health services. In addition, there were wage increases for some workers, such as those in the steel industry, where there previously had been wage cuts or freezes, the Labor Department said. For the 12-month period ending in June, settlements that were reached provided wage adjustments averaging 3.6 percent a year over the contract life, compared with 2.4 percent when the same parties bargained previously. The average annual wage gain over the contract life has been increasing since the low of 1.7 percent for a 12-month period, which occurred for the year ending in September 1986. The collective bargaining report, like the Labor Department's broader Employment Cost Index also released today, showed workers in the fast-growing service sector winning larger wage gains than manufacturing workers. Service workers received an average annual gain of 3.8 percent over the contract life while manufacturing workers received an average boost of 3.3 percent. The average construction worker received gains of 4.2 percent a year over the life of the contract, the report said. The Labor Department said the 216 collective bargaining agreements it analyzed in the first six months of 1990 covered about 810,000 workers. The government tracks agreements covering bargaining units with at least 1,000 workers. The government said 88 such agreements covering about 983,000 workers are scheduled to expire or reopen for wage negotiations during the July-September period, with many of those jobs in the automobile, parcel delivery and construction industries. In addition, there are about 726,000 workers under 130 contracts that had expired or been reopened, but not negotiated or ratified, prior to the end of June. Nearly half those workers are railroad employees, the government said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of England Searches for Ukrainian Barrel of Gold
DOC.TEXT: Two Bank of England researchers today searched dust-covered, leather-bound account books for records of a barrel of gold Ukrainian officials said was stored there 270 years ago, a spokesman said. The archive search was prompted by British newspaper reports that the Soviet republic of Ukraine was claiming compensation for a barrel of gold left with the bank by the 18th century Ukrainian military leader, Col. Pavel Polubotok. Ukrainian officials reportedly have said the gold plus accrued interest would be worth $29 trillion. That figure is roughly five times the U.S. gross national product. A spokesman for the Bank of England said a check of the bank's live accounts and safety deposit accounts made Monday did not turn up a record of the barrel of gold. He added that gold deposits do not accrue interest. Polubotok was reportedly put in jail by Czar Peter the Great, where he died in 1723. Two researchers are now looking back through 300 years of defunct accounts preserved on microfilm and in leather-bound ledgers for a record of any account with Polubotok, the spokesman said. ``If there were a barrel in the vaults we'd know about it,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We have quite a lot of gold as well as valuables and documents in the vaults which extend over three underground floors,'' he said. The Bank of England was a private bank until 1946, when it was acquired by the government. It is now the government's central bank, but it continues to provide services for foreign governments and some private customers.

DOC.HEAD: Souter at White House Preparing for Senate Confirmation Hearings
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, David H. Souter, returned to the White House today for briefings on the confirmation process in the Senate, where he is certain to be grilled about his views on abortion and other divisive social issues. White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that the president would formally submit Souter's nomination on Wednesday, and that the nominee would then begin making the rounds of members of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Souter was meeting today with Frederick D. McClure, Bush's congressional liaison, to help prepare him with the meetings with senators. ``It is just the normal practice associated with new nominees,'' McClure said in an interview. ``We're going to have a chit chat about what lies ahead over the next few weeks.'' McClure said Souter will meet first with members of the Senate leadership, then with committee members, and with any other senators who want to meet him. ``He's a well-qualified guy. We hope the Senate will agree,'' McClure said. Souter spent Monday night at the home of Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., who actively promoted the 50-year-old federal appeals court judge from his home state. Calling Souter ``a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability,'' Bush said Monday that he and his advisers had deemed it ``inappropriate'' to ask Souter his views on specific issues. That will be the task of the Senate Judiciary Committee, expected to hold hearings in September. One liberal committee member, Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., pledged, ``There will be a lot more known about him, I guarantee you that.'' ``I don't think it'll be a hard sell at all, when you look at the man's record, experience and integrity and ability to deal with tough questions of law,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' Souter, 50, spent a dozen years as a state judge before joining the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on April 30. If confirmed, he would become the court's 105th justice _ its sixth bachelor. Never married, he lives alone on the family farm near Weare, N.H., where he moved from the Boston suburb of Melrose, Mass., when he was 11. Souter has a reputation back home for brilliance and diligence. Outside New Hampshire, he's barely known. The president moved quickly in announcing his intention to nominate Souter to replace Justice William J. Brennan, 84, who retired Friday because of ill health. Bush on Monday praised Brennan, the court's longtime leading liberal, as ``one of the greatest figures of our age.'' Brennan's departure gave Bush his first chance to name someone to the nation's highest court. If he is confirmed, Souter's vote may prove decisive for the future of legalized abortion, as four of the remaining eight justices appear ready to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that made abortion a constitutional right. Souter has not yet had to rule directly on abortion. Abortion rights groups already have demanded that the Senate hearings focus on Souter's abortion views. The increasingly conservative court also has been closely split on such issues as civil rights and criminal justice. The reaction from key senators was restrained. Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., a Judiciary Committee member and early opponent of President Reagan's failed nomination of Robert Bork to the court, said he would wait to hear from Souter before making up his mind. Kennedy said the Senate must determine ``whether he possesses a strong commitment to the fundamental values of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights that are obviously at stake in this important nomination ....'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Souter's experience as a judge and as New Hampshire's attorney general are pluses, but did not commit himself. Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, the Judiciary Committee's ranking Republican, said he expected few if any fireworks, noting that Souter was confirmed unanimously for his 1st Circuit Court job. But another committee member, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, said, ``There is a difference between being confirmed for the appeals court and for the Supreme Court.'' As a member of the New Hampshire Supreme Court for seven years, Souter established himself as a close-to-the-vest judicial conservative. In one of the rare civil rights cases in which he participated, Souter joined the state court's ruling in 1987 that said homosexuals may be barred from becoming adoptive or foster parents. But the state court ruling also said that homosexuals may not be barred from running day care centers. In a 1986 case, Souter joined the majority in ruling that doctors have a responsibility to test for birth defects and inform pregnant women of the option of abortion. In a concurring opinion, Souter questioned the impact the decision would have on doctors who oppose abortion on moral grounds. He said such physicians should not have to choose ``between rendering services that they morally condemn and leaving their profession in order to escape malpractice exposures.'' Souter was the lone dissenter in a 1985 state Supreme Court decision that struck down the use of police sobriety checkpoints. The nation's highest court upheld such police tactics earlier this year. Alan Dershowitz, a liberal attorney and professor at Harvard Law School, called the nomination ``a Sununu special.'' John Sununu, Bush's conservative White House chief of staff, was the New Hampshire governor who promoted Souter to the state Supreme Court. But Sen. Warren Rudman, a moderate New Hampshire Republican, also has been a political patron.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Addressed Abortion in At least One State Case
With PM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Supreme Court nominee David Souter issued a ruling on the New Hampshire Supreme Court that could be seen as arguing that doctors should be free to decide whether to counsel women about abortions. Souter agreed with, and issued a concurring opinion in, a 1986 case in which the court said it would not recognize a right not to be born. The ruling dealt with a woman's lawsuit against her doctor, charging that he did not advise her of the possibility that the German measles she contracted during pregnancy would result in birth defects. Her daughter was born with multiple birth defects, and she argued that she should have known of the possibility and been counseled about the possibility of abortion. In a unanimous decision, the court ruled that it had no business deciding whether such a child would be better off having been aborted. But it did rule that the parents of children with birth defects have a right to sue. It also held that doctors have a responsibility to test for birth defects and inform pregnant women of the possibility of defects to give them the option of abortion. ``We recognize that the termination of pregnancy involves controversial and divisive social issues,'' said the opinion with which Souter agreed. ``Nonetheless, the Supreme Court of the United States has held that a woman has a constitutionally secured right to terminate a pregnancy.'' The mother, Linda Smith, also made her daughter, Heather, a plaintiff. But the court rejected the child's suit, saying the ``right to life, and the principle that all are equal under the law are basic to our constitutional order. To presume to decide that Heather's life is not worth living would be to forsake these ideals.'' Souter agreed with the ruling, and raised an additional question in a concurring opinion. He wondered what impact the ruling might have on doctors who don't support abortion, but who were bound to advise patients of it as an alternative. The court did not address the question. ``The court does not hold that some or all physicians must make a choice between rendering services that they morally condemn and leaving their profession in order to escape malpractice exposures,'' he wrote. He suggested that such doctors might tell patients of their religious or moral scruples and refer them to other doctors in time for such testing.

DOC.HEAD: Cloud of Cleaning Solvent Blamed in BASF Blast
DOC.TEXT: Vapors of a cleaning solvent leaking from equipment used to mix chemicals led to the deadly explosions and fire that rocked a chemical plant last week, a fire investigator said. Capt. Jim Mara said Monday that a reactor in the resin building of the BASF Corp. plant was being cleaned with a chemical solvent known as PX when a valve apparently ruptured and released the vapor cloud into the building. Investigators still do not know what then ignited the vapor and triggered the explosion, Mara said. ``But we know the reactor, or kettle as it's known, was over-pressurized, either through mechanical error or human error,'' he said. A series of blasts at the plant Thursday killed one worker and injured at least 68 others, many of them residents of the surrounding neighborhood who were cut by flying glass. Three people remained in critical condition today. A maintenance foreman at the plant who set off a fire alarm seconds before the first blast said he was alerted by a cloud of vapor escaping from the building, where the company handled resins used in paints and coatings for aluminum food cans. ``We know it was the reactor in the resin building, and we know there was a vapor cloud,'' Mara said. ``The ignition source could be a hard call, because there are several possibilities.'' He refused to speculate on the cause. Assistant Fire Chief James Ross said damage from the fire has been set at $50 million. Mara said the fact that the first blast struck at about 2:15 p.m. was in part responsible for the low death toll. ``Most of the people who work in that area went on break at 2 p.m.,'' he said. ``The call came in at 2:19 p.m. There could have been at least nine people, maybe more, in the immediate area if they hadn't been on break.'' Occupational Safety and Health Administration officials have begun interviewing survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gets Eight Years for Killing, Dismembering Husband
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `Juanita Stinson...', to UPDATE with woman surrendering. Changes second reference to Ms. Stinson sted Juanita Stinson throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A judge who sentenced a battered wife to eight years in prison for killing and dismembering her former husband lamented her suffering but said the man didn't deserve to die. Juanita Irene Stinson pleaded guilty in April to murdering Charles Stinson in 1987. He was shot three times and his body was cut into six pieces with an ax and buried in a shallow grave. Testimony during the trial revealed the woman was the victim of 35 years of physical and mental abuse. ``It's a tragedy, the abuse that your husband heaped on you over the years,'' Judge Frederick C. Wright III said Monday after hearing testimony from experts who said she suffered from battered-woman syndrome and post-traumatic stress disorder. ``I've heard a lot about him _ that he was not a good person, but people who are not good people deserve to live,'' Wright said. ``Taking an individual's life is never going to be approved by this court.'' Ms. Stinson, 57, of Mountain Lake Park lied about Stinson's whereabouts for two years, saying he was away on business, a pla The Times' story on questions surrounding the bailout appeared July 8, the day before Metzenbaum held a hearing on the subject. Howell Raines, the Times' Washington bureau chief, said, ``As a matter of policy we don't discuss sources or the editorial process.'' He said the story was ``meticulously researched from a number of sources'' and ``was industriously and honorably reported.'' Nancy Coffey, a spokeswoman for Metzenbaum, said the senator considered Brand's complaint too ridiculous to comment on. ``Since when is it against the law for a senator to talk to one reporter?'' she asked, adding that ``no prearrangements'' were attached to Metzenbaum's comments. Meanwhile, the Times reported in today's editions that Thompson invested $100,000 with a federal regulator, Paul G. Heafy, who also was involved in Thompson's negotiations to buy an insolvent bank in Oklahoma. The newspaper reported that the investment, which was to buy distressed loans from federal regulators, did not violate conflict of interest laws, but Senate investigators wanted to look into the financing of the deal. Heafy is chief liquidator for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in Oklahoma City. The Times said he and Thompson refused the Times' requests for interviews.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Seeks Expanded Probe of Pierce
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A congressional panel asked a special prosecutor today to broaden his probe of former Housing Secretary Samuel Pierce, saying it has evidence Pierce steered money to clients of his former law firm and may have committed perjury. In urging independent counsel Arlin Adams to expand his investigation, the House Government Operations housing subcommittee said its 14-month-long probe uncovered ``widespread abuses, influence peddling, blatant favoritism, monumental waste and gross mismanagement'' at HUD. The subcommittee specifically asked Adams to widen his investigation into three areas of possible wrongdoing: _Whether Pierce committed perjury during the only appearance before the subcommittee, on May 25, 1989, in which the former Cabinet officer gave detailed testimony. The congressional panel said many of Pierce's statements were contradicted by subsequent testimony. Pierce essentially maintained that he did not play a direct role in the awarding of housing projects. _Whether Pierce conspired with others to steer HUD business to clients of Battle, Fowler, Jaffin and Kheel, the Wall Street law firm where Pierce formerly had been a partner. It also questions whether Pierce conspired with his former top aide, Lance Wilson, in connection with contract awards. _Whether Pierce and other HUD officials ``conspired to defraud'' the government in the handling of the Department of Housing and Urban Development's coinsurance program, which provided backing for housing development projects during the Reagan administration from 1981-89. The letter came as the eight-member panel neared an end to its investigation of the HUD scandal. A subcommittee source, discussing the panel's role on grounds of anonymity, said no more hearings are scheduled. The aide said the subcommittee hopes to complete a final report, with recommendations for reforms at HUD, sometime in late August. The letter said documents found in HUD files show that Pierce's former law firm frequently sought Pierce's assistance in HUD-related matters. It said they included having Pierce meet with a client to discuss a development grant application and helping securing lucrative housing subsidies. It cited a letter from a partner in the firm to Pierce's assistant, Deborah Gore Dean, in 1985 seeking her help in obtaining a subsidy for an Amherst, N.Y., project, and recounting past assistance in another project there, Allenhurst Apartments. ``In light of Secretary Pierce's long and close relationship with his former law firm, Battle, Fowler, it defies logic and reason that Ms. Dean would have assisted Battle, Fowler in obtaining these scarce and much-in-demand (subsidy) units for the Allenhurst project on her own without the direct and intimate involvement of Secretary Pierce,'' the letter said. Pierce was expected to return to the firm, but has instead spent much of the past year working with a team of lawyers defending himself against allegations of favoritism raised by the subcommittee and now Adams. Thousands of pages of HUD documents released through the Freedom of Information Act last year included dozens of letters from Battle, Fowler lawyers to top Pierce aides. But the law firm and Pierce, through his attorneys, have denied any favoritism. Several members of the subcommittee, including Chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., have repeatedly said Pierce may have committed perjury during a May 1989 appearance before the panel. At that appearance, the former secretary portrayed himself as a hands-off manager and said he took no direct role in funding decisions. Subsequent witnesses and documents released after Pierce testified indicated that Pierce had indeed played major roles in numerous funding decisions, including several for projects involving associates or prominent Republicans. Pierce's lawyers have said their review of the testimony and documents indicated no wrongdoing by Pierce. Pierce again appeared before the subcommittee and vehemently denied any wrongdoing while accusing the panel of targeting him for criticism and investigation. But Pierce refused to answer questions, invoking his Fifth Amendment protection against possible self-incrimination. The silence of Pierce and several former top aides who also refused to testify has left many questions unanswered 15 months after HUD's inspector general set of a firestorm by releasing a report that concluded the department's costly Moderate Rehabilitation Program was riddled with mismanagement and political favoritism. Acting on a request from Congress, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh in March sought and won the court appointment of Adams. At that time Adams, a former federal judge, was charged with investigating the role of Pierce and top aides in the Moderate Rehabilitation Program. Since then, Adams' jurisdiction has been broadened to include Pierce's administration of Urban Development Action Grants and the secretary's discretionary fund for technical assistance and other special projects.

DOC.HEAD: Kenjiro Takayanagi, Japan Television Pioneer, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Kenjiro Takayanagi, known as the father of Japanese television, has died of pneumonia, company officials said today. He was 91. Takayanagi died Monday night in a hospital in Yokosuka, near Tokyo, the officials said. An electrical engineer, Takayanagi achieved the first television transmission in Japan in 1926 and developed the main component of a television camera in 1933 only months after it was invented by Vladimir K. Zworykin in the United States. After teaching at a Japanese college, he worked for the Japan Broadcasting Co. (NHK) and then at the Victor Co. of Japan, where he later became vice president.
