Masaru Ibuka, honorary chairman of competitor Sony Corp., told Kyodo News Service that ``(Takayanagi) was a true technician who developed the television, which people had only dreamed about, from nothing.'' Takayanagi was awarded by the Japanese government with the Order of Culture in 1981, the Grand Cordon of the Order of the Sacred Treasure in 1989 and various other prizes for his work in advancing television technology. Takayanagi was born in Hamamatsu in central Japan in 1899. Funeral arrangements were pending, and there was no immediate word of survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins In Ohio Cult Slayings Of Five
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began this morning under heavy security in the trial of Alice Lundgren, accused of helping her cult-leader husband and 11 others kill a family of five. Lake County Common Pleas Judge Paul H. Mitrovich convened the proceedings with 40 prospective jurors in the the first trial stemming from the 1989 killings. Mrs. Lundgren, 39, and 12 others, including husband Jeffrey and their 19-year-old son, Damon, were arrested earlier this year in the deaths of Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl, and their three young daughters. Lundgren is a defrocked minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints. The Averys were among Lundgren's followers. Mrs. Lundgren has pleaded innocent in Lake County Common Pleas Court to five counts each of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder, complicity to commit aggravated murder, and kidnapping. If convicted, she faces a possible life sentence. As jury selection got under way, at least three sheriff's deputies stood guard outside the courtroom near a metal detector. Police have said that the Avery family was killed April 17, 1989, at a farm in nearby Kirtland, where Jeffrey Lundgren directed the cult. The corpses, buried under a barn on the farm, were not found until early this year. Authorities have speculated the deaths may have been a religious sacrifice. Mrs. Lundgren is the first of the cult members to stand trial in the case. Four cult members pleaded guilty to reduced charges and agreed to testify for the prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Record Store Owner Pleads Innocent To `2 Live Crew' Obscenity Charge
DOC.TEXT: A record store owner who refused to stop selling a controversial 2 Live Crew album pleaded innocent today to a charge of promoting obscene material. David Risher, owner of Hog Wild Records and Tapes, was released on a personal recognizance bond after a hearing before County Court-At-Law Judge Tony Jimenez III. ``Your tax money at work,'' Risher said as he was ushered off to be fingerprinted and booked. Risher's attorney said he intends to show in a jury trial that the album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' is not obscene. ``After listening to the album, most of the four-letter words are standard locker room talk,'' defense attorney Bob Switzer said. Risher was charged with the Class A misdemeanor last month after a citizen complaint was filed against him for selling the album. The complaint followed a crackdown by the San Antonio police vice squad. Officers went to record stores around the city and told store operators the album had been declared obscene by a Florida judge. The officers also showed the store operators copies of the album's lyrics. Many record stores pulled the albums from their shelves. But Risher refused. If convicted, he could face up to one year in jail, a $1,000 fine or both.

DOC.HEAD: Daily Discloses Official Death Toll Of Invasion
DOC.TEXT: At least 82 people were shot to death by soldiers during the first four weeks of the 1968 Soviet-led military invasion, according to a declassified government report published today. The first six victims were shot at 3:30 a.m. on Aug. 21, 1968 _ the day Warsaw Pact troops and tanks rolled in _ according to the Interior Ministry report. The declassified report was carried in the Obcansky Denik daily, which said only five top Communist Party officials had been privy to it immediately after the invasion. The invasion crushed attempts at democratic reforms in Czechoslovakia. The first shootings occurred near the city of Liberec, about 65 miles north of Prague, the paper reported. ``During the occupation of Czechoslovakia by the armies of the five states of the Warsaw Treaty ... its members used various weapons against Czechoslovak citizens like machine guns, submachine guns and artillery ... killing 82 people, seriously wounding 302 and causing light wounds to more than 500,'' the daily said. Romania was the only Warsaw Pact country that refused to take part in the invasion. ``The killing and injuries occurred both in direct shooting against groups of people and individuals, as well as in shooting against buildings and in the air, when people were shot in their apartments, on balconies...and in some cases even by deflected bullets,'' the daily said. The report was the first in a series published in advance of the 22nd anniversary of the invasion. The invasion restored hard-line Communism in Czechoslovakia, and Communist rule was sustained for another 21 years. Democratic changes swept Communists from power in Czechoslovakia last year and brought dissident playwright Vaclav Havel to the office of president. On Nov. 28, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze condemned the 1968 invasion. Hungary's Parliament on Monday demanded a similar reassessment of the Soviets' 1956 intervention in Hungary to crush an anti-Stalinist uprising. Today in Prague, Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said the 1956 invasion of Hungary was ``inadmissable.'' ``I do not know of this (the Hungarian) request, but we are in the process of reassessing our history right now,'' Gerasimov told reporters. According to Western estimates up to 32,000 people were killed in the Hungarian invasion. There have never been any estimates given of the death toll in the Czechoslovak invasion, but most of the shooting occurred in the first few days.

DOC.HEAD: Worries Over Profits, Credit Batter Wall Street
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Although worrisome...', with 2 grafs to UPDATE with early trading today. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Companies as...'. Version moved on financial wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street may have mended many of its ways since the excessive 1980s, but it still hasn't found an antidote for the ``Blue Monday'' syndrome. The tendency for volatile selloffs to occur right after weekends repeated itself Monday when the Dow Jones industrial average, fresh from a series of runs at record highs above 3,000 points, took its worst plunge in six months. The average, an index of stocks in 30 of the country's best-known industrial corporations, dropped more than 100 points in the first 90 minutes of trading, then fluctuated through much of the day in heavy trading. At the close, it was down 56.44 points, or 1.9 percent, at 2,904.70. The selloff wiped out a big chunk of the early-summer gains posted by some of the nation's most prominent blue-chip stocks, and analysts placed much of the blame on a rash of disappointing corporate earnings. Other catalysts for the fall, they said, ranged from revived fears of higher interest rates to continued anxiety over the federal deficit. This morning, the Dow industrial average traded within a narrow range. It was up 0.50 at 2,905.20 at 11 a.m. on Wall Street. An hour earlier, the average sported a gain of 5.70 points. Although worrisome, analysts said Monday's drop did not seem to presage a crisis on the magnitude of the crash of October 1987 or mini-crash of October 1989. Companies as diverse as American Telephone & Telegraph, Dow Chemical and U.S. Shoe posted earnings below expectations for the quarter ended June 30. Late last week, Texas Instruments and a slew of computer and technology companies also announced disappointing profits. Investors initially treated the profit reports as individual cases, dumping shares of the companies involved while leaving other stocks unscathed. The Dow kept making new highs, benefiting from enthusiasm for a few of its component issues. But on Monday morning, investors' urge to sell broadened, causing what analyst Michael Metz at Oppenheimer & Co. called ``a mini-panic.'' Newton Zinder at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said ``people who concentrated on the Dow Jones industrial average at 3,000 got a misleading picture. There had been an underlying erosion over the last few weeks, with a lot of stocks falling into black holes after their earnings were released.'' In mid-July, the Federal Reserve took a step toward easier credit when Chairman Alan Greenspan declared his intention to keep the financial system supplied with ample money while the banking industry retrenched and regrouped. But after an initial burst of enthusiasm over that news, both the bond and stock markets turned wary. On Monday, many observers saw evidence of continued worries over what jolts the economy still might suffer in the unwinding of the debt boom of the '80s. ``A rising tide of debt, even if unsound, immoral or fattening, is bullish,'' observes James Grant in the current issue of his newsletter Grant's Interest Rate Observer. ``Having borrowed money, people spend it.'' Now, he argues, ``a shrinkage of debt is bearish. Denied new credit, people don't buy things.''

DOC.HEAD: Indian Guards Kill 20 Moslem Militants in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Indian frontier guards shot and killed 20 Moslem militants and arrested nine others after they sneaked into India-held Kashmir from Pakistan, a senior official said today. The militants were killed late Monday at Kupwara, 56 miles north of Srinagar during gunbattle with Indian guards, said the Kashmir official, who cannot be identified under standing briefing regulations. India, alarmed by a spurt in Moslem separatist activities in Kashmir, has stepped up border patrol to stop alleged infiltration of separatists from Pakistan. A total of 80 Moslem militants have died in frontier incidents in the past week. Indian officials maintain that Kashmiri militants regularly cross over to Pakistan through the porous border and return by the same route after reciving arms training in Pakistan. Pakistan denies it is training or helping the militants, but says it supports the separatism, terming it a fight for self determination. The Kashmir official said the fighting erupted when the militants fired at Indian border guards after crossing over from Pakistan. Indian guards seized 22 AK-47 rifles, three machine guns and 1,425 rounds of ammunitions. Kashmiri separatists are fighting for independence of the Moslem dominated Jammu-Kashmir from the predominantly Hindu India. At least five more Moslem separatists were killed in three separate incidents across Kashmir today. The deaths brought the total number of people killed to at least 863 since Jan. 20, when the government launched a crackdown on the separatists. About 65 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslems, making it India's only Moslem majority state. Nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million people. Hindus make up 82 percent of the population. Kashmiri separatists earlier demanded union with Pakistan, an Islamic country, but have recently been fighting for total independence and the status of a neutral country.

DOC.HEAD: Government Troops Kill 70 Rebels, Capture 110
DOC.TEXT: Government troops killed at least 70 rebels and captured 110 in fighting in eastern Uganda, a newspaper reported Tuesday. The Munno newspaper said troops mounted a counterattack Friday and Saturday after insurgents from the Uganda People's Army killed three soldiers and later attacked army barracks, burning several buildings. The newspaper said the fighting was in the countryside around Kumi, a trading town 300 miles from Uganda's capital, Kampala. A military official, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the clashes, but said he was unaware of any government casualties. The Uganda People's Army is led by Peter Otai, a former Cabinet minister. It took up arms against the government of President Yoweri Museveni soon after Museveni seized power in February 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Warm Weather Hits Sydney in Mid-Winter
DOC.TEXT: It's mid-winter here, but many Sydney-area residents headed to the beaches Tuesday as record-setting warm weather created near-summer conditions. Downtown workers ate lunch in parks and other people sunbathed as temperatures rose to 79, the highest July reading since the Bureau of Meterology began keeping records in 1859. Bureau of Meteorology spokesman Steve Symonds said temperatures were expected to fall over the next 24 hours as the warm weather front passed through the country's midsection.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Offers Guidelines to Tell Workaholics How to Relax
DOC.TEXT: The government, concerned that the one skill the industrious Japanese have yet to master is how to relax, is offering advice on how hard workers can become happy campers. The Health and Welfare Ministry this week released a 38-page report titled: ``A Study on How to Take Proper Rest and Recuperation.'' It suggests Japanese forget about their jobve the office and take leisurely and lengthy vacations, concepts well-rooted in the West but yet to take hold here. To help the nation relax, the government report offers a wide range os when they leaf general guidelines. For example, it argues that constant overtime work cuts down on sleep, adversely affects the quality of work and results in ``chronic fatigue physically and mentally, eventually leading to bad health and illness.'' The report advises workers to ``go to bed early and get up early, take breakfast without fail, forget about the job after hours (and) eat dinner with their families....'' White-collar Japanese workers often eat and drink with colleagues after leaving the office and do not get home until late at night. According to government statistics, Japanese workers are on the job an average of 2,150 hours a year compared with 1,924 hours in the United States and 1,655 hours in Wuter train route from Montreal's southern suburbs. On Saturday night, two men carried the same sign that led Friday's procession, showing Indians on horseback chasing a train. The men toted the sign away from the barricade, hoping to whip up another mass march. Only a dozen people follow this time, and the feeble procession trailed off into a gas station parking lot. Two other men carried a cloth banner showing a Mohawk in feathers with a slash through his face. One man in a tweed jacket and maroon tie stood out in the crowd of people in shorts and T-shirts. He marched through the mob, carrying a sign in French that reads, ``Give them what they want: the war.'' The Indians steal the show Saturday night. They set fire to a pile of tires, creating a wall of flame in front of their barricade that spits a monstrous black cloud over the town, a smoke signal to let police and townsfolk know they're still there. The crowd in Chateauguay responds with an Indian war cry. Occasionally, they can see the silhouette of a Mohawk dancing behind the flames. The mob surges forward, and the line of police in riot gear stiffens, bracing for another rush on the barricade. But a few sprinkles of rain begin falling, and the crowd begins scurrying for their cars. By 1 a.m., just a handful of people are left. They will return again Sunday night for more junk food and another march that winds up back where it began.

DOC.HEAD: Chauffeur Testifies He Did Not Drive Barry to Alleged Drug Pickup
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Top 8 grafs new with morning testimony, edits to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's chauffeur testified today that he drove Barry straight from a ribbon-cutting ceremony to a city meeting without stopping at a building where prosecutors say he picked up drugs. Walter Bracey, who has served as the mayor's driver for 12 years, testified in Barry's drug and perjury trial that he transported the mayor directly from the opening of a grocery store to a meeting with fire officials on the morning of Sept. 7, 1988. Prosecution witness Lydia Reid Pearson, an acknowledged drug dealer, has testified she handed Barry crack cocaine and a city job application at a city municipal building shortly after 10 a.m. that day. But Bracey testified that Barry arrived at the ribbon-cutting ceremony at about 9:40 a.m., spent about 45 minutes there, and then was driven straight to the fire department meeting. ``Were there any stops made at any other location?'' Barry attorney R. Kenneth Mundy asked. ``No,'' Bracey replied. Earlier, a grocery store employee and a member of a community group who attended the grand opening testified that Barry spent about 45 minutes there before leaving. Bracey's testimony came on the second day of an assault by Mundy on Pearson's credibility. Pearson originally testified that she has not used cocaine since June 8, but with the jury out of the courtroom Monday, Mundy called her back to the stand and asked whether she had visited an apartment building ``known as a crack house'' on July 7. Pearson acknowledged that the building is recognized as a place where drugs are sold, but she denied visiting there. Minutes earlier, with the jury also out of the courtroom, a city police officer, Otha Batts, testified that he had seen Pearson visit the building. Pearson testified earlier in Barry's drug and perjury trial that she went to city offices on Sept. 7, 1988, where she met the mayor and ``handed him ... crack cocaine. ... He gave me the money for it'' and ``I gave him'' a job application. Mundy said he intended to repeat his questions to both the police officer and Pearson before the jury, but U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he will not allow the defense to pursue that course unless he is first shown a legal precedent for such a move. Mundy promised to research the matter and present an answer. The questioning of Pearson followed testimony by a city employee, Clifton Roberson, that he _ and not Barry _ accepted a job application from the woman on Sept. 7, 1988. Roberson said he saw no evidence of drugs when Pearson visited his office. He also said he recalled that Pearson was upset because she was forced to wait for almost 20 minutes before being informed that neither Barry nor mayoral aide Anita Bonds was present. Roberson said Pearson gave him the job application and then left. Pearson's testimony for Sept. 7, 1988, forms the basis for one of 10 cocaine possession charges with which Barry is charged. He also is accused of one misdemeanor conspiracy count and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Group Says Higher Wine Tax Could Hurt State Incomes
DOC.TEXT: Doubling the tax on wine as a deficit-reduction measure would cost state and local governments 32 cents for every $1 collected by the federal government, an industry group said Tuesday. ``Lower business profits and lost wages would reduce tax collections of state and local governments by an estimated $81 million,'' the Wine Coalition said. Doubling taxes on wine and beer is said to be under consideration by congressional leaders and the Bush administration as part of a long-range plan to reduce the budget deficit. A study commissioned by the industry group concluded that the higher tax would reduce U.S. wine consumption by about 4 percent to 500 million gallons a year, reduce business activity by $1.1 billion and cost workers in wine and related industries $293 million a year in lost wages. Wines are subject to federal taxes ranging from 17 cents a gallon for table wine to $3.40 a gallon for naturally sparkling. The levy brought in $270 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominating New Envoy to Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: President Bush plans to nominate Ryan Clark Crocker, a diplomat with broad experience in the Middle East, as ambassador to Lebanon, the White House announced Tuesday. Crocker would succeed Thomas McCarthy. Crocker, 41, has been political counsel at the American Embassy in Cairo since 1987. Previously he had held diplomatic posts in Lebanon, Iran, Qatar, Tunis and Iraq. From 1985 to 1987, he was chief of the Office of Israeli and Arab-Israeli Affairs of the State Department. The announcement was made while the president was in Philadelphia for speaking engagements.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Gets `Money From Heaven' Selling Meteorite
DOC.TEXT: You've heard of pennies from heaven. Would you believe enough to buy a new car? That's roughly how much money Robert and Mildred Eichstadt got recently for selling a 160-pound meteorite found on their land nine years ago. The couple won't say exactly how much they were paid by Marlin Cilz, a collector from Malta, Mont. But Mrs. Eichstadt says it was ``a large amount'' and agrees that comparing it to the price of a new small car is fair. ``It's probably the best crop we ever took off of our farm,'' she said. The meteorite, about the size of two basketballs, was found on their farm in eastern South Dakota, near Huron, by their oldest son, Bruce, when the disc harrow he was using to prepare a field caught the object and rolled it over. ``Bruce knew right away what it was,'' said Mrs. Eichstadt. ``He said it was a meteorite, that it couldn't be a rock. It's so hard, it just made a shiny spot on it where the disc hit it.'' The Eichstadts had no idea it had any value, so they let it sit in their yard. But they began looking to sell it a few months ago after they saw information about Cilz in a farm publication. When Cilz made the Eichstadts an offer, their reaction was, ``This can't be happening to us,'' said Mrs. Eichstadt. ``As soon as we found out it had some value, we didn't have it setting out (in the yard) any longer.'' Cilz estimated that the meteorite fell on the land that is now the Eichstadts' farm about 2,200 years ago. Mrs. Eichstadt says Cilz indicated the meteorite likely will be cut into pieces to be sold to collectors.

DOC.HEAD: Mansion Valued at $16 Million for Taxes
DOC.TEXT: The Vanderbilt family's 250-room Biltmore House has some plumbing and electrical problems that could drive down its value, but the county tax assessor says it's still worth at least $16 million. If the assessment stands, the tax bill will be $109,903. And by the way, the assessment doesn't include the antiques, art works, and 8,000 acres of land. Biltmore House, opened in 1895, was built by George W. Vanderbilt, of the railroad and steamship Vanderbilts. It's a National Historic Landmark and open to the public, but it's still owned by the family and may be the nation's largest preservation project that still pays taxes, says William Cecil, a grandson of George W. Vanderbilt. Buncombe County tax assessor Charles Clark spent a month going over the house. Tourists, he said, don't see ``a circuit board that was designed in 1900, a heating system that won't keep the water in the third and fourth floors from freezing, and copper flashing that needs replacing.''

DOC.HEAD: Interior Alaska Blanketed By Smoke From Wildfires
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with lightning fires creating new problems. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Motorists on...'. SUBS last graf to delete now-redundant reference to lightning.
DOC.TEXT: As many as 300 lightning strikes were recorded in Alaska's Interior since midnight, complicating efforts to battle wildfires that have charred 1.25 million acres of timber and tundra so far this month. ``The Weather Service says the thunderstorms won't bring much rain,'' Trish Hogervorst-Rukke of the Fire Information Center in Fairbanks, said today. Nearly all of the 129 fires raging in Alaska on Monday were caused by lightning. The same conditions that create thunderstorms bring erratic winds that cause problems to firefighting crews, Hogervorst-Rukke said. ``It can send the fires back toward them,'' she said. The cost of fighting fires this season in Alaska has topped $21.5 million, said R.J. Hayes, a spokesman for the Alaska Interagency Fire Information Center in Fairbanks. That's up from about $15 million two weeks ago and dwarfs the state's initial firefighting budget of about $3 million for the season. And not all the fires are being fought. Dense smoke has hampered fire crews and cut visibility to less than a mile, interrupting air and ground travel in parts of Alaska's Interior. ``I haven't turned a prop yet today,'' said Walt Walton, owner of an air-taxi service in the Kuskokwim River community of McGrath, 225 miles northwest of Anchorage. Visibility there Monday was one-half mile, he said. Motorists on the Taylor Highway near the Alaska-Canada border encountered periodic delays because of poor visibility. State highway officials advised motorists not to drive the two-lane Dalton Highway north of Fairbanks. The 24,000-acre Hess Creek fire was burning within two miles of the road that parallels the trans-Alaska pipeline between Prudhoe Bay and the town of Livengood. Officials said the pipeline, buried in the vicinity of the fire, wasn't threatened. Health centers in some Interior communities reported treating more people with scratchy throats and watery eyes caused by the smoke. However, ``concentrations do not exceed ambient air quality standards and probably won't,'' said Jack Coutts of the state Department of Environmental Conservation in Fairbanks. The interruption of light-aircraft flights had repercussions in some communities not served by roads. Mail delivery was interrupted out of McGrath, and Walton was two days overdue picking up clients he had flown to a remote hunting camp in the Alaska Range. No one has been injured in the fires and few dwellings have been lost, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Near Armagh; Three Police, Nun Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with deaths confirmed, nun among the victims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A huge bomb exploded today on the outskirts of the border city of Armagh, killing a Roman Catholic nun and three policeman, police said. The murder of the nun was thought to be the first time a nun has been killed in 21 years of sectarian violence in British-run Northern Ireland. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but suspicion immediately fell on the Irish Republican Army. The killing of a nun would be seen widely as a grave embarrassment to the mainly Catholic IRA. The bomb blew apart an unmarked police car, instantly killing the three officers traveling in it, police sources said. The nun, who died later in hospital from severe injuries, was traveling with a woman social worker in a separate car caught in the blast, Jim Cantwell of the Catholic Press and Information Office said. He said he could not identify the nun until her family had been notified. Police and troops rushed reinforcements to the area near the border with the Republic of Ireland. The area is considered prime territory for operations by the outlawed IRA. The blast was the deadliest terrorist attack in the province since an IRA bomb April 9 killed four soldiers of the locally recruited Ulster Defense Regiment. Paul Corr, who owns a gas station near the Killylea Road where the bomb exploded, said, ``the ground shook beneath us and it was accompanied by a very large explosion.'' ``We were first on the scene and saw a white Mini Metro with two young lassies in their 20s in the car unconscious,'' Corr told reporters. ``The ambulance then arrived and they managed to get them out. It wasn't until then that we saw the police car on the opposite side of the hedge buried in there.'' The bomb, which blasted a crater in the two-lane road, was apparently detonated by a timer device or by guerrillas lying in wait, police sources said. Politicians and church leaders expressed outrage. ``This is one more example that when terrorists want to do something they do it in an indiscriminate manner and it doesn't matter what happens to others,'' said the Most Rev. Robin Eames, the Anglican primate of Ireland. The blast occurred two miles outside Armagh, the ancient religious capital of Ireland and seats of the heads of the Catholic and Anglican churches throughout Ireland, north and south. Seamus Mallon, deputy leader of Northern Ireland's main Catholic political party, the Social Democratic and Labor Party, described the attack as ``wanton and brutal savagery.'' ``That is four more murders to add to the spiral of murders we have had over this past 20 years,'' said Mallon. ``But it is not just that. It is four more families bereaved, four more families having this type of suffering heaped upon them.'' Nearly 3,000 people have been killed since Protestant-Catholic violence erupted in Northern Ireland in 1969 and the British government sent in troops. The IRA is fighting a guerrilla campaign to end British rule and unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the Republic of Ireland under a leftist administration.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysia to Track Turtles with U.S. Satellites
DOC.TEXT: Ten leatherback turtles will be fitted with transmitters and tracked in international waters with the help of NASA satellites, an official said. Fisheries Department Director General Shahrom Abdul Majid said Monday the project would provide accurate information on the movements of the giant leatherback turtles between their annual nestings in Malaysia. Scientists say the species, which has been around for an estimated 150 million years, is facing extinction due to pollution and pilfering of their eggs, which are a delicacy in Malaysia. The turtles measure up to 5 feet in diameter, can weigh 900 lbs and live for about 100 years. Majid said Malaysia will be the third country after French Guiana and the United States to use this system, the national news agency Bernama reported. He was speaking after launching the project at Rantau Abang, the site of the turtles' annual nesting migration. The program involves using NASA satellites to relay signals emitted by a platform transmitter terminal on the back of each turtle to ground stations. The project cost $27,000. The turtles roam the seas around Japan, the Philippines and Australia, but return annually to Rantau Abang, 180 miles northeast of the capital of Kuala Lumpur, between June to August to lay their eggs. In the 1950s between 1,700 and 2,000 of the turtles came ashore annually, but their numbers dwindled to about 500 per year during the past few years and to only about 60 last year, government officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Accuses Kuwait Of Plot With US, American Forces on Exercise
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Pentagon announcement U.S. Navy ships on ``short-notice exercise'' in region. Pickup 12th pvs, `The United...' ^By SALAH NASRAWI
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi government accused Kuwait today of conspiring against it with the United States. Diplomats said the neighbors' tense confrontation has been aggravated by Iraq's massing of troops on Kuwait's border. The border buildup began last week and coincided with a verbal assault on Kuwait by Iraq's president, and threats of military action. The Pentagon today announced that U.S. Navy ships are holding a ``short-notice exercise'' with forces of the United Arab Emirates in the Persian Gulf area. Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, told reporters in Washington said he could provide no details on the exercise beyond saying that it began Monday and that two Navy vessels left early from their port at Bahrain in order to participate. Williams declined to comment on the purpose of the maneuvers or say whether they were scheduled before Iraqi President Saddam Hussein accused Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from wells Iraqi territory and of trying to wreck the Iraqi economy by conspiring by push down world oil prices. The oil in question comes from the Rumaila field, on land near an unmarked part of the border that is claimed by both Kuwait and Iraq. Diplomatic sources in Bahrain said the U.S. Navy was on alert. They also said a Washington Post report of 30,000 Iraqi troops massed at its southern border with Kuwait appeared to be correct. Williams would not comment on the Washington Post report, which said the U.S. Navy had canceled shore leaves for its forces in the Persian Gulf. The report quoted Western military attaches. White House spokesman Mrlin Fitzwater said of the situation today, ``We're concerned about the troop buildup by Iraq and we ask that all parties strive to avoid violence.'' Diplomats in Iraq and Persian Gulf states said that soon after Iraq-Kuwait dispute erupted, travelers saw battlefield missiles, armored personel carriers and tanks prominently displayed along the road from Iraq to Kuwait. Kuwait put its forces on alert for several days, but the diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the alert was canceled to defuse tension. Kuwait's entire armed forces has just 20,300 men. The United States has at least seven warships in the Persian Gulf at any given moment. The State Department announced at the beginning of the crisis that it backs Kuwait's territorial integrity. During the Iran-Iraq war, some Kuwaiti tankers flew the American flag as protection from attacks in the gulf. Baghdad kept up the verbal assaults on Kuwait today. The government newspaper Al-Joumhouriya accused Kuwait of coordinating its moves with the United States in order to ``clear the way for foreign powers to intervene in the area.'' It also accused Kuwait of ignoring Arab solidarity by demanding repayment of loans made to support Iraq during the Iran-Iraq war. ``The Kuwaiti government should have written off all the debts at the moment Iraq asked it to do so,'' the paper said. Kuwait lent Iraq an estimated $15 billion during the war out of a total $70 billion Iraq is believed to have borrowed. The attempts to repay the debt and rebuild the economy are putting massive financial pressure on Iraq, which is trying to rebuild following its 1980-88 war with Iran. Diplomats called the Iraqi moves brinksmanship, and did not expect Iraq to invade Kuwait. But the reports sent jitters through world financial markets. In Tokyo, the dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen today over news of the increasing unrest, prompting traders to buy the currency regarded as a safe haven. The dispute will overshadow a strategy meeting of ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which begins Wednesday in Geneva. The Iraqi president last week threatened to use force if necessary against countries pumping more oil than they OPEC quotas. Although Saddam did not mention names, he clearly was angry at Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. The two nations have persistently ignored their OPEC prooduction limits, sending a flood of crude onto the market and lowering oil prices. Saddam claimed Iraq had lost $14 billion in revenues in the past year because of falling crude prices due to the oil glut.

DOC.HEAD: Here's a Vegetable That's Full of Minerals
DOC.TEXT: George Gross got more than a few vegetables when he went gardening this week. He pulled up a one-carrot diamond ring. The retired high school biology teacher was pulling carrots on Monday when he found the ring, which he'd lost about a year ago. It was buried in the ground with a carrot growing through it. Gross said the ring, a cluster of small diamonds, was a Christmas gift from a friend, Ruby Ledford. Since losing it, he had looked everywhere, not only hunting through his house but using a metal detector to search his yard and garden. He said he found plenty of nuts, bolts and nails, but no ring. Ms. Ledford presented him with another ring, but Gross said he missed the original gift ``because it was so special to me.'' After finding the old ring, Gross said he asked Ms. Ledford if he had to give one ring back. ``She couldn't believe that I found it,'' he said. ``She said I could keep both rings.''

DOC.HEAD: Pacific Leaders Don't Want Chemical Weapons in Pacific
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `An Army ...' to UPDATE with Pentagon announcing transfer dates
DOC.TEXT: Pacific island leaders and environmental groups are raising concerns about the Army's plan to store and destroy chemical weapons at Johnston Atoll, 800 miles southwest of here. ``I think it's a very bad decision based on undue haste,'' Skip Spaulding, an attorney for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund in Hawaii, said Monday. ``The Army seems more concerned with carrying out its mission for its commander in chief than thoroughly assessing the consequences.'' ``The Pacific must not become the dumping ground for the world's chemical agents and munitions,'' Hawaii Gov. John Waihee said last week. The U.S. weapons from West Germany would add 100,000 rounds to the 300,000 rounds of nerve and mustard gas stored at the remote island since 1971. The transport of the munitions from West Germany will begin Thursday and would continue through September, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Tuesday. Containers holding the weapons will be loaded onto Navy ships for transport to the Pacific. The containers will be put in storage on Johnston Atoll until the Army finishes testing an incinerator for the munitions. The tests are to be completed late next year, and full-scale destruction is not expected to begin until 1992. The Army said moving the weapons and destroying them at Johnston Atoll would have minimal public health, safety and environmental effects. ``Safety of people and nations and protection of the environment is foremost in our minds,'' said John Fairbank, a spokesman for the Army Western Command in Honolulu. ``The good part is we are in fact destroying a very unpopular weapon,'' Fairbank said. ``The end result when we get through is all of the weapons will be destroyed. We think the environmentalists should cheer that goal.'' There's been little cheering. ``Transporting the European stockpile halfway around the world inescapably increases the risks,'' said a statement issued by the Federated States of Micronesia, a former U.S. territory. Leaders of the Marshall Islands, Cook Islands, New Zealand and the U.S. territory of American Samoa also have expressed reservations about the plan. While most of the leaders have said they support destruction of the weapons, they said they worry about the environmental dangers of transporting the weapons across the Pacific and destroying them at Johnston Atoll. The Pacific Council of Churches, representing 26 Protestant and Roman Catholic churches in the South Pacific, asked the Army to cancel the move. The Hawaii Legislature and Honolulu City Council also have objected. Spaulding said the Sierra Club Legal Defense Club was planning legal action to halt the shipment of the weapons until officials have fully assessed the dangers. ``The problem with Johnston Atoll is this is an unproven technology,'' Spaulding said. ``It hasn't been tested enough to prove it's safe.'' Fairbanks responded that the Army has tested the incineration technology. ``This isn't something that we're just jumping off and doing all of a sudden,'' he said. He agreed that the safest way to get rid of the weapons is to destroy them in place. However, he said, ``We could not do that in Germany because they are our munitions on foreign soil and we've agreed to remove them.'' Fairbank emphasized that the weapons at Johnston Atoll combined with the weapons from West Germany represent about 6 percent of the United States' chemical weapons. He said the Army has no plans to use Johnston Atoll to destroy munitions from mainland storage sites. The $240 million disposal system was built to meet a 1985 congressional requirement to destroy all U.S. chemical weapons by 1997. The Army began testing the incinerator on June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Supreme Court Nominee Has `Great Legal Mind'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today ``the Supreme Court must be guided by independent minds'' and there there should be no ``litmus test'' in the Senate confirmation of nominee David H. Souter. Bush, addressing a Pennsylvania state Republican fund-raising luncheon, said, ``my sole priority was to appoint a justice true to the life and the spirit of the Constitution, a priority that I'm confident will also guide the Congress in the confirmation process.'' Without mentioning abortion or other divisive matters, Bush said, ``there was no single issue, no litmus test on standards dominating my decision to nominate. ``I would add, there should be no litmus test in the process of confirmation,'' Bush said. The speech was Bush's first since his surprisingly quick decision Monday to tap the little known federal appeals judge from New Hampshire for the vacancy left by the retirement of 84-year-old Justice William J. Brennan. Bush was also journeying to New York later for another GOP rally. ``The Supreme Court must be guided by independent minds and its members are appointed for life largely to keep them above the flames of political passion,'' Bush told 400 people at the GOP luncheon. He called Souter ``a great man of enormous intelligence, strength; a tough trial court judge with a great legal mind and an impartial quality that will serve the court well.'' Before leaving Washington, Bush huddled with the five top Republican and Democratic leaders of Congress on the budget summit. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said they agreed to cool partisan rhetoric in an effort to forge an agreement to hold down next year's estimated $169 billion deficit. But Bush still took a few swipes at what he called the Democrats high-spending ways. ``All of us, Republicans and Democrats, deserve and should demand real budget reform ... some discipline on the process,'' Bush said. ``The budget charade, these fiscal follies, must end,'' Bush said. En route to Philadelphia, Fitzwater said Bush would be ``very gentle'' toward Democrats in his campaign speeches. ``They're working in a spirit of harmony and compromise. In fact, they agreed this morning at the meeting that they would try to keep the rhetoric under control and really try to make this a productive week of work,'' Fitzwater said. Bush planned to meet with the congressional leaders every morning this week while a larger, 21-member group of administration and congressional officials grapples with the details each afternoon. ``The president feels they made progress. It was a good meeting,'' Fitzwater said. ``The large group is doing the heavy lifting in terms of going through specific proposals and reaching conclusions about various options,'' the spokesman said. ``Then the leadership group basically reviews the work done by the large group and gives them any instructions they might have for the next day's work,'' he said. Bush was campaigning in Philadelphia for Barbara Hafer, a pro-choice Republican trying to oust Democratic Gov. Robert Casey, who is anti-abortion. After a stop at an anti-drug rally in a west Philadelphia community center, Bush was bound for Manhattan to raise funds for Pierre Renfret, an economist and political novice seeking to defeat Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. After attending an anti-drug rally in a West Philadelphia community center, Bush was bound for Manhattan and a GOP dinner to help the New York gubernatorial campaign of Pierre Renfret, an economist and political novice trying to oust Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. Fitzwater said the president would devote the speech at the Philadelphia fund-raiser to ``the differences between the two parties and the need for fiscal discipline.'' Bush sounded the same themes in a Western swing last week in which he blamed Democrats for the spiraling deficit and ``government by gridlock.''

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Answer U.S. Move With Appeal for World Support
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Khmer Rouge guerrillas, stung by a U.S. move to isolate the group, on Tuesday appealed for world support to help end Cambodia's civil war. Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan, in a statement over Khmer Rouge army radio, said the guerrillas must have a role in any peace settlement. It was the group's first reaction to the U.S. decision to withdraw its recognition of the U.N. seat held by the guerrilla coalition. The United States, citing its opposition to the Khmer Rouge, said last Wednesday it will instead open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian war. Vietnam ousted the Communist Khmer Rouge from power in late 1978. The Khmer Rouge is now joined in a resistance coalition with the non-Communist forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and with Son Sann's Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Together they are fighting the government installed by Vietnam. The U.S. move was prompted by reports of strong military gains by the Khmer Rouge, who killed hundreds of thousands of people during their 1975-78 rule of Cambodia. Khieu Samphan noted the support given to the resistance by other countries, including the six-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations. ``The Cambodian people also ask them to continue providing steadfast assistance and support until the Vietnamese war of aggression against Cambodia is comprehensively settled in conformity with the spirit and principle of the U.N. charter,'' he said. ASEAN comprises Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines and Brunei. ASEAN foreign ministers, in Indonesia for an annual consultations, said Monday that attempts to change Cambodia's U.N. seat at this time ``would set back the search for a comprehensive political solution.'' China, the main arms supplier for the resistance and particularly the Khmer Rouge, has said it will continue its backing despite the U.S. policy shift. But China agrees with other members of the U.N. Security Council that there should be a U.N.-monitored halt to all outside arms supplies once a political solution is reached, the U.S. assistant secretary of state for Asian affairs, Richard Solomon, said in Washington late Monday. In the radio broadcast, Khieu Samphan said that ``only with the participation of all four parties can there be genuine national reconciliation and can we correctly implement international law and the U.N. charter, which says that the people of each country have the right to decide their own destiny.'' He noted the vast majority of the U.N. members supported the guerrilla coalition's seat. ``The position is to ensure that the U.N. charter and international law prevail over the law of the jungle and the use of force,'' he said. Vietnam said it withdrew the last of its soldiers from Cambodia in late September. Before elections for a new government are held, the Khmer Rouge wants an interim coalition representing each of the warring parties installed. The Cambodian government wants the interim power and says any settlement must include measures to prevent a Khmer Rouge return to power. Many Cambodians hate and fear the Khmer Rouge. But many citizens give the guerrillas food and other aid during operations deep in the country. Khieu Samphan said the guerrillas' battlefield victories have ``proved (they) ... have been supported by the people.''

DOC.HEAD: Test-Tube Twin Dies at Age 7
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Michael Duda, one of the nation's first test-tube twins, has died at age 7 of complications from a congenital heart defect. Christopher died Sunday at Children's Memorial Hospital. The boy's father, Robert Duda, 40, of Chicago, said he was grateful for the time Christopher spent with him, his 37-year-old wife, Patricia, and the boy's twin sister, Danielle. ``I don't know what his mission in life was other than to make me happy,'' said Duda, who manages a car dealership. Christopher had entered the hospital a month ago for surgery to correct the defect that was resulting in low levels of oxygen in his blood. He had undergone a series of related operations since shortly after his birth. Christopher and Danielle were born May 14, 1983, at Evanston Hospital and were believed to be the nation's second set of test-tube twins. Doctors have said the birth defect was not related to the method of conception. Services are scheduled for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Loses Voting Rights Case on Appeal
DOC.TEXT: A ruling that a county's voting districts should be redrawn to increase black voting strength was overturned by a federal appeals court panel Tuesday because the lawsuit was filed too late. The ruling was a setback for the American Civil Liberties Union, which has sought redistricting to increase black voter strength in about 18 Virginia localities. The plaintiffs, black voters in Brunswick County in southern Virginia, probably will appeal, their lawyer said. ``We're incredibly disappointed and we think the decision was very inappropriate,'' said the attorney, Gerald T. Zerkin. The ruling by a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned an order by U.S. District Judge James R. Spencer that the county's voting districts be redrawn. The plaintiffs' delay in challenging a 1971 redistricting ``was inexcusable and unreasonable,'' said the opinion by Judge Robert F. Chapman. The appellate panel also said it would make no sense to change the county's voting districts just before 1990 census figures become available. ``A court-ordered reapportionment at this date would be completely gratuitous, because there are no elections scheduled before November 1991 and the 1990 census figures may require reapportionment,'' Chapman said in the ruling joined by Judges James M. Sprouse and William W. Wilkins Jr. If the plaintiffs believe the 1991 redistricting violates the U.S. Voting Rights Act, they can file another lawsuit, the judges said. Until Tuesday's ruling, the ACLU has won out-of-court settlements or court rulings that were not appealed in nearly all the redistricting cases it pursued in Virginia, said Kent Willis, director of the state ACLU chapter. A case against Henrico County is pending before the 4th Circuit. Brunswick County, which is 57 percent black, has a five-member board of supervisors elected from single-member districts. Four of the districts have populations that are more than half black, but only two have elected black supervisors. The board created the districts after the 1970 census and left them intact after the 1980 census. ``The plaintiffs voiced no objection either to the 1971 redistricting or to the 1981 decision not to redistrict and waited until September 1988 to file this action,'' the appeals panel said. The judges rejected the plaintiffs' contention that the delay gave them information from several elections on which to base their claim that blacks are discriminated against in the county. ``The plaintiffs, in the exercise of reasonable diligence, could have discovered at a much earlier time the facts upon which they now base their claim,'' the opinion said. Zerkin protested: ``We relied on the analysis of voting records that included elections in 1987. If we had brought it earlier the first thing they would have said is, `You have insufficent data.' '' Zerkin also said the rural county has gained so few people that the 1990 redistricting is unlikely to produce major changes. ``The net effect of this decision is that we have to start all over again,'' he said. Raymond S. Daniel, vice chairman of the Brunswick County Board of Supervisors, said he was ``pleased the ruling was in favor of Brunswick County.'' Daniel said he had not seen the ruling and did not want to comment further.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Win Court Order; 17 Arrested in Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists won a court order temporarily barring Louisiana-Pacific Corp. from logging an old-growth forest that has been a target of ``Redwood Summer'' protesters. Seventeen other protesters were arrested Tuesday in protests further north, near Eureka. The order, issued Monday by Mendocino County Superior Court Judge James Luther, appeared to be the first under new state emegency regulations that bar logging that threatens the northern spotted owl. ``There's obviously going to be some precedent set here,'' said Louisiana-Pacific spokesman Shep Tucker. As part of the Redwood Summer campaign, environmentalists have targeted the 110-acre Louisiana-Pacific logging operation in the Navarro Ridge area, 10 miles south of the coastal village of Mendocino. Nearly 40 people were arrested there last week on trespassing charges. Further north in Humboldt County, protesters with the environmental group Earth First! chained themselves to gates at two Pacific Lumber Co. sites, one 10 miles south of Eureka and one 30 miles southeast of the city, sheriff's Sgt. Forrest Schafer said Tuesday. The 17 were arrested for investigation of trespassing. One person had to be cut from the gates, Schafer said. Three of those who chained themselves were juveniles, Schafer said. The protesters, who assembled before dawn in hopes of blocking logging traffic, are trying to save the Salmon Creek headwaters area on Pacific Lumber Co. land, which they say is the largest intact old-growth redwood watershed left.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Jobs Held Key to Cutting Illegal U.S. Immigration
DOC.TEXT: Creating jobs in Mexico and other countries is the only long-term way to cut illegal immigration into the United States, a special commission told Congress on Tuesday. Diego C. Asencio, a former U.S. assistant secretary of State, headed the 12-member Commission for the Study of International Migration and Cooperative Economic Development, established by Congress in 1986. Asencio told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that, initially, economic development encourages people to leave a country. But he added: ``Promoting economic development is the proper way to proceed if we are serious about stemming unauthorized migration in this hemisphere over the long term, and I must emphasize that we are talking about a process that will probably take decades.'' The commission recommended creating an Agency for Migration Affairs to take charge of refugees and immigrants. ``As a young vice-consul, I could never understand why one agency should allow immigrants to come in and another decide if that was all right,'' Asencio said. Consuls, who work for the State Department, issue visas in other countries for entry into the United States. The Immigration and Naturalization Service of the Justice Department has authority over immigrants after they arrive, including the authority to issue green cards, which give the immigrants the right to work. Asencio said the first reaction he had from the State Department was unfavorable to his proposed new agency. ``Some people would lose their jobs and they don't like that,'' he explained. The commission said any major decision on aid and trade for other countries should have with it an ``impact statement'' to show the effect of the decision on immigration. The commission also recommended: _Speeding creation of a free trade area with Mexico and bringing it into the free trade area with Canada. _Supporting freer trade with other Western Hemisphere countries but leaving the initiative to them. _Gradually letting Mexico and Caribbean countries make and ship here the cloth, clothes and steel now coming from Asia. _Increasing sugar imports from the Caribbean. _Linking trade benefits to rights of workers in the exporting country, particularly rights in the ``maquiladora'' plants along Mexico's border that process goods for this country. _Working with Mexico to improve the quality of life in border areas.

DOC.HEAD: Gingrich Will Seek Censure of Barney Frank
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich said today he supports the censure of Rep. Barney Frank, rather than the less severe reprimand recommended by the ethics committtee to punish the Massachusetts Democrat for using his office to help a male prostitute. Gingrich made clear he was not speaking for the House GOP leadership. But his position as the second-ranking House Republican could influence lawmakers wavering between a censure and the ethics committee's recommendation of a lesser punishment _ a reprimand. The Georgia Republican said one consequence of a censure would be Frank's automatic loss of his chairmanship of the House Judiciary subcommittee on administrative law and governmental relations. Gingrich told a news conference his support for a censure had nothing to do with Frank's admittedly gay lifestyle. Rather, he said, censure is appropriate because Frank wrote a misleading letter to a probation officer that was favorable to the prostitute _ who was convicted on drug and sex charges. ``Censure is the minimum appropriate action,'' he said, because lying to or misleading a court official ``is clearly a standard Congress cannot accept.'' Gingrich said, however, he would not back a move to expel Frank. The case is to reach the House floor Thursday. On the other hand, Rep. John T. Myers of Indiana, ranking Republican on the ethics panel, said he will urge House members to uphold the committee position for reprimanding Frank, an acknowledged homosexual. The Republican leadership planned to discuss the party's strategy at its regular meeting this afternoon. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said the Frank case would be considered on the floor Thursday. Republicans could only hope to override the committee decision with the support of conservative Democrats, who will be urged by their own leadership to back the 12-0 recommendation last Thursday by the ethics committee. A key to the seriousness of the conservative GOP effort will be House Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who is the leader of the right wing ranks. He has yet to announce his position. A reprimand would involve the House voting to approve the report of the ethics panel. A censure would involve a similar vote, along with the requirement that the member face his colleagues while the action is approved. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif. already has announced he would introduce a resolution to expel Frank. The expulsion resolution must pass by a two-thirds majority and even conservative Republicans gave Dannemeyer no chance of success. Myers would not predict whether a censure resolution would pass, but said, ``It sure would get more voters than expulsion.'' He said the reprimand proposal ``wasn't an easy decision to come to. This is the compromise we worked out.'' Frank, a liberal serving his fifth term, is expected to be on the floor regardless of the punishment, because he has promised to apologize to the House. ``I believe the committee position will be sustained on the floor,'' Foley told reporters Monday. Majority Whip William H. Gray III, D-Pa., concurred, saying, ``Attempts at censure or expulsion will fail.'' The ethics committee concluded in a report released Friday that Frank brought discredit upon the ouse in two areas of his conduct with male prostitute Stephen L. Gobie. The panel found he used his congressional status for dismissal of 33 parking tickets incurred by Gobie while not on official business. Frank said he had employed Gobie as a personal aide from 1985-87 and paid him with personal funds. The panel recommended that Frank make restitution of an unspecified amount to the District of Columbia for the tickets. The committee also said Frank also wrote a memo that wound up in the files of a Virginia prosecutor, which made misleading statements favorable to Gobie during his probation. Gobie had been convicted on drug and sex charges. Rep. Robert S. Walker, R-Pa., said he's aware that some GOP members are considering a censure of Frank and added he would vote for such a proposal. Walker said a key factor for those favoring censure would be Frank's initial failure to pay Social Security taxes on Gobie's salary. He called the issue ``a serious question that merits a penalty greater than the ethics committee's recommendation.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Propose $7 Billion Defense Conversion Bill
DOC.TEXT: Laid off defense workers would be guaranteed health benefits and part of their income for a year under a $7 billion bill proposed Tuesday by Connecticut's two senators. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., called his proposal the most comprehensive of several measures already under consideration in Congress this year. The legislation, cosponsored by Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn., would guarantee laid off workers a basic level of income, help companies shift to non-military production, and provide aid to affected communities. ``The changing nature of foreign threats will dictate some reduction in defense spending,'' Lieberman said during a news conference. ``But we must not embark on wholesale cuts in defense programs that destroy important parts of our economy and jeopardize our national security.'' He said defense workers are ``veterans of the Cold War'' whose efforts helped lead to peace between the superpowers. The lawmakers said the bill could affect millions nationwide who hold defense industry jobs. ``This thing reaches from the Bath Iron Works in Maine to San Diego and very few places in between are left untouched,'' Dodd said. The proposal would use up to 10 percent of the so-called peace dividend _ money saved through defense spending reductions _ in each of the next seven years met with widespread publicity, seemingly out of proportion to their impact on the traveling public, and American spokesman Tim Smith said, ``I think because of that coverage, the impact on competition of these surcharges would have gone beyond the dollar amount of these costs.'' American had estimated the higher fees at the airports would add $4 million a year to expenses. Although the carrier earned $730 million last year, Smith said, ``$4 million is still a lot of money when you feel that it is unfair.'' ``The bottom line was not an impact on this,'' he said. ``It was an attempt to take action against something that was unfair in our mind.'' However, no other carrier had moved to match the surcharges, and Smith said, ``We cannot ignore competition. You can't sacrifice competitive advantage for an idea that's not working or might not work.'' The reversal was the second time this year American has failed in an attempt to influence fares. In March, American announced plans to implement a mileage-based fare system, but ditched the plans after no other carriers followed suit.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Reduction In Military Aid To Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Intelligence Committee has voted to slash aid for the Afghan rebels, reflecting growing congressional disenchantment with proxy wars around the world, officials said Tuesday. Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, a member of the panel, said the main rationale for the move was that the United States had achieved its purpose in Afghanistan when Soviet troops withdrew in February 1989. Some senators also were concerned about reports that the rebels _ known as the Mujahedeen _ were overlooking narcotics trafficking in the region, Murkowski said. Several conservatives, along with a State Department official, said they hoped money would be restored to higher levels before work is finished on the bill that includes 1991 money for covert actions around the world. ``The level of appropriation is not yet decided,'' said Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., a staunch supporter of the rebels. ``There are many steps in the process and those that are concerned have high hopes'' for full funding, he said. Murkowski said he wasn't present at the Intelligence Committee meeting when members voted to cut secret aid for the Afghan rebels in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. But he said the vote on the Democrat-controlled panel was not close. Murkowski _ along with several other senators _ refused to discuss dollar amounts. But a congressional source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he understood the panel reduced funding for the rebels by about $100 million. Last fall, Congress reportedly appropriated roughly $300 million for the rebels for fiscal 1990. Despite the withdrawal of Soviet troops, fighting has continued between the Moscow-backed government of Afghan President Najibullah and the U.S.-backed rebels for control of the mountainous country. U.S.-Soviet negotiations are underway in an effort to set up internationally supervised elections. Meantime, a State Department official said Moscow spends roughly $300 million a month to maintain the Najibullah government, sending in food, fuel and advanced weapons such as Scud missiles. ``What Congress appropriates has been less than 10 percent as to what the Soviets do,'' one official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Senate panel's action comes at a time many members of Congress are questioning continued funding for U.S.-financed guerrilla wars in Afghanistan, Cambodia and Angola. Those questions have been prompted by the easing of East-West tensions as well as a shrinking defense budget. The Senate intelligence panel also voted on June 28 to eliminate a $13 million covert military aid program for the rebels opposing the Soviet-backed government of Cambodia. Some lawmakers also have criticized aid to guerrilla fighters in Angola, where efforts are under way to reach a peace between the Marxist-backed government and rebels headed by Jonas Savimbi. Meanwhile, Rep. Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., chairman of the House intelligence committee, said the panel has postponed consideration of the 1991 covert action budget until after Congress' August recess. The panel was under no time pressure to finish the budget, he said, adding that in the next six or seven weeks ``maybe negotiations will work'' in hot spots around the world. Beilenson said there was some sentiment on the panel to close down U.S.-financed wars in some cases. On a more general note, Beilenson said he generally favors more open discussion of U.S. military aid programs.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Arthur Forms East of Trinidad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with storm status
DOC.TEXT: The season's first named storm, Tropical Storm Arthur, swirled to life Tuesday in the Caribbean, east of Trinidad. The government of the nation of Trinidad and Tobago issued storm warnings for Trinidad, Tobago, Grenada and Grenada dependencies. The islands separate the southeastern Caribbean Sea from the Atlantic. At 2:30 p.m. EDT, Arthur's top sustained winds of 40 mph _ just 1 mph above the speed required for named-storm status _ were centered near latitude 10.7 north and longitude 58.5 west, or about 160 miles east of Trinidad. It was moving west at about 20 mph and was expected to continue that motion through the day, said Hal Gerrish of the National Hurricane Center. Some additional strengthening was likely by mid-afternoon Wednesday, Gerrish said. Three to 5 inches or rain and local flash-flooding were expected to accompany the storm across the islands. Tropical storms become hurricanes is their sustained winds top 74 mph. Arthur grew from a depression, the second of the 1990 season, that formed Sunday in the open Atlantic. The Atlantic season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Servers Paying Taxes on Just One-Third of Tip Income, IRS Says
DOC.TEXT: The average U.S. restaurant tip is just under 12 percent and food-servers are dodging taxes on as much as two-thirds of it, the Internal Revenue Service said Tuesday. Employees of restaurants with 10 or fewer workers are reporting only $1 of every $3 received in tips, Marshall Washburn, deputy assistant IRS commissioner, told the House Ways and Means Social Security subcommittee. Waiters in larger restaurants are reporting half their tips, he said. Those figures are up significantly from 1982, when the disclosure that only 16 percent of tips were reported to tax collectors prompted Congress to toughen the law on tips. Under the new law, Washburn said, voluntarily reported tips rose by $1.6 billion in 1984 alone. Federal tax collections on tip income rose by more than $1 billion in the three years ending in 1986. The 1982 law requires tipped employees of larger restaurants to prove it if they claim to have received tips averaging less than 8 percent. Employees are also required to report tip income to their employers, and the employers to pass that information on to the IRS. The subject of Tuesday's hearing was an effort by the restaurant industry to repeal a newer law, which requires employers to pay Social Security taxes on all an employee's tips, up to $51,300 a year. The employee pays a matching amount. Before the law was changed in 1987, the employer paid Social Security taxes only on an amount equal to the minimum wage, which today would be $7,904. Rob Haimson, a Greeley, Colo., restaurateur speaking for the National Restaurant Association, said the 1987 law should be changed because it penalizes businesses as well as employees, is difficult to enforce and is not needed by the Social Security system. ``The Social Security tax is a payroll tax which is intended to be based upon wages paid by an employer,'' said Roger Branigan, who operates a restaurant in Indianapolis. ``Tips are not wages.'' Changing the 1987 law would require that either workers or the Social Security system pay most of an employer's share of Social Security tax. Those options were opposed, respectively, by the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union and by the American Association of Retired Persons.

DOC.HEAD: Loyalists Repel Rebel Attack; Insurgents Fire at Doe Mansion
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is based in part on a pool dispatch filed by journalists in Monrovia, including AP correspondent Michael Goldsmith.

Soldiers loyal to the president fought off rebels and appeared in control of the city Tuesday after an ambush on the capital. Insurgents launched another attack from the sea. A spokesman for President Samuel Doe said the seaborne attack appeared to have been launched by a U.S. submarine. The State Department denied the allegation. A presidential spokesman, Selly Thompson, also told the British Broadcasting Corp. in London that government troops were advancing against rebels in Monrovia. Followers of rebel leader Prince Johnson penetrated the city center Monday after wading through swampland and evading troops guarding bridges into town. Followers of Charles Taylor, a rival rebel commander, were blocked by government troops in the city's eastern suburbs. Taylor said he had infiltrated some men into the capital, but only in small numbers. Taylor and Johnson split sometime in the past three months, and some foreign diplomats have said Johnson's group is now stronger than Taylor's. Witnesses said an unidentified vessel approached the coastline in the darkness and fired at least six rounds at Doe's mansion. Doe was believed to be inside the compound. Troops inside returned fire, and the booming of cannon shots echoed through the city. After the boat sped away, one shot from the mansion was seen to fall harmlessly into the sea, a few hundred yards offshore. The damage to the heavily fortified mansion could not be immediately determined. Reporters who tried to go there or to the nearby ministry of information were turned back by soldiers. Later, Thompson read a statement to the BBC saying ``the mansion had been the target of a missile attack from the sea by what seemed to be a United States submarine.'' The African nation, founded by freed American slaves 150 years ago, has traditionally had close ties with Washington. But Washington has refused to send in a peacekeeping force, and on Saturday Doe ordered the American military attache expelled, accusing him of helping the rebels. The United States denied the accusations. It has offered to provide safe conduct out of the country for Doe. In Washington, the State Department flatly denied it had fired on Doe's compound. It was not known how many soldiers were still fighting on the government side, other than the 500 members of Doe's presidential guard. Some government forces remained in pockets outside the capital but were unable to offer much help against the rebels, who have advanced steadily since launching their siege in December. Government forces between Taylor's men and the capital included the 72nd Infantry Battalion and units based at Schiefflin Army Base. The infantry battalion was said to be putting up stiff resistance. Units at the army base had ventured out on several occasions to retake ground held by rebels, according to reports from the rebel side. Troops loyal to Doe patrolled Monrovia's streets. Shops were closed. Civilians, searching in vain for food, were harassed by soldiers nervous after the surprise attack Monday by followers of Prince Johnson. Little is known about Johnson. He apparently served in the Liberian armed forces and was a supporter of Brig. Gen Thomas Quiwonkpa, who launched a 1985 coup attempt against Doe. Johnson joined up with Taylor last year and was a lieutenant in the rebel National Patriotic Liberation Front. ``He's posing a much more formidable challenge than we thought,'' one U.S. official said of Johnson. There have been conflicting reports on whether Johnson and Taylor have reconciled. The rebels have accused Doe, who took power of the nation of 2.4 million people in a 1980 coup, of corruption, mismanagement and human rights abuses. At least nine male bodies, most of them stripped, were found on a beach not far from the city's embassy district Tuesday. Other bodies were scattered nearby. Witnesses told a photographer that soldiers had brought the people there during the night and summarily executed them. Doe's troops, fearful the rebels will kill former soldiers if they take the capital, have frequently been seen shooting civilians. The civilians usually belong to the Gio or Mano tribes, which provide the main support for Taylor. Taylor's soldiers have similarly executed troops belonging to Doe's Krahn tribe. Doe has been deserted by nearly all senior members of his government but had not asked the United States for help, a U.S. official in Washington said Monday. Doe has said he will not leave the besieged capital until the civil war has been decided. Sources said his presidential guard would not let him leave unless they were provided safe passage to their home territory in Grand Gedeh County.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Blames US Radio Stations for Embassy Incidents
DOC.TEXT: A senior Cuban official on Tuesday blamed exile radio stations in Miami for stirring up the Cubans who have sought asylum in foreign embassies over the past two weeks. The vice foreign minister, Jose R. Viera, demanded the ``unconditional and voluntary'' departure of the 25 Cubans now being sheltered at three European embassies. On Sunday, three Cubans entered the Swiss Embassy. Earlier, 18 had sought refuge at the Spanish Embassy and four at the Italian Embassy. Viera said it is ``not admissible'' for a Cuban desiring to emigrate to circumvent normal procedures by forcing his way into a foreign embassy. If Cuba acquiesced in this practice, ``the embassies in Cuba would not be able to function'' and embassies throughout the Third World might be overrun by people wishing to emigrate, Viera said. At several points during his hourlong talk, Viera blamed exile radio stations in Miami for inciting the incidents at the embassies. The first incident occurred at the Czechoslovak Embassy on July 9. Cuban reports said at least three of the exile radio stations can often be heard clearly in Havana but the Cuban reports were unable to substantiate Viera's claims that they have been been encouraging Cubans to seek refuge. The reporters said one of the stations is operated by the Cuban-American National Foundation. Another is run by a group called Cuba Independent and Democratic, they said. Viera sought to portray the incidents at the embassies as unrepresentative of the overall situation here. He said the annual carnival celebration this week has been proceeding normally. The events at the embassies have led to a substantial increase in security around many diplomatic missions of NATO countries. The highlight of the carnival celebration is a speech Thursday by President Fidel Castro commemorating the 37th anniversary of his debut as a rebel fighter. Castro took power in Cuba in 1959. The incident at the Spanish Embassy has led to a deterioration in Cuba's relations with Madrid. While Cuba has called the asylum-seekers ``scum'' and habitual vagrants and said it will never allow them to leave the island, Spain has said it will not expel the Cubans and will try instead to negotiate their departure. Last week, reflecting escalating tensions between the two countries, Spain suspended a $2.5 million aid program to Cuba, recalled its ambassador and sent four guards to bolster security at its embassy in Havana. Spain's foreign minister, Francisco Fernandez Ordonez, had said Castro is afraid his hard-line Communist government will fall like those in Eastern Europe if he allows Cubans to leave. Fernandez Ordonez also urged a transition to democracy in Cuba. The wave of embassy break-ins began two weeks ago, not long after similar incidents were occurring at foreign embassies in Albania. Albania, like Cuba, is a hard-line Communist state.

DOC.HEAD: Jurist's Record Offers Little Insight on Vexing Social Issues
With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The extensive paper trail of David H. Souter's New Hampshire Supreme Court tenure shows he is a clear, dispassionate writer of legal opinions. But it offers scant insight into his views on the vexing social issues he'd face as a member of the nation's highest court. President Bush's choice for the Supreme Court spent seven years as a member of the New Hampshire high court _ a period in which he wrote nearly 200 opinions and cast votes in hundreds of other cases. But his views on such issues as abortion, civil rights and church-state relations are largely or completely unknown. A review of many of his decisions reveals Souter is most assuredly a judicial conservative _ a judge who believes in sticking to the case at hand and shies away from making sweeping statements about the law. He often sides with positions advanced by state government officials, especially in criminal cases. But there have been notable exceptions. In a 1988 decision, Souter led the state court in declaring unconstitutional a state law that barred a non-profit group from providing legal services to some disabled people. The New Hampshire Disabilities Rights Center (DRC), authorized by state law to provide such services to the poor, sought permission to represent some disabled clients who were not poor. ``The DRC's request runs counter to the applicable state statutes,'' Souter said. ``Despite this conflict, we hold that enforcement of state law to prohibit the DRC, as a non-profit corporation, from representing non-indigent clients in its advocacy in behalf of disabled people would violate the First and 14th Amendments of the National Constitution.'' He added, ``Organizations, their members and their staff lawyers may assert a protected First Amendment right of association for non-commercial purposes to advocate the enforcement of legal and constitutional rights of those members, or of others within a definite class whom the organization exists to serve.'' In upholding the dismissal of a Somersworth, N.H., police chief, Souter said in a 1989 decision, ``The trial court really had little choice but to find that the (chief's) infidelity in finance and ineptitude in administration had rendered him incapable of holding a position demanding honor and integrity of its incumbent.''
