In a ruling earlier that year, Souter said a bank could not be held contractually liable for failing to discover poor workmanship on a construction project for which it had tendered loans to Ross and Virginia Seymour. ``The Seymours' responsibility for workmanship could not escape any reasonable reader of these documents,'' he said. ``The Seymours make a further try at salvaging the contract claim by ... pointing to a loan officer's alleged remark that the bank's inspections would be a `safeguard and well worth it.' They conveniently forget, however, that they never asked the trial court for a specific finding that the remark was made.'' In a 1988 decision criticized by women's rights groups, Souter ordered a new trial for a man who had been convicted of sexual assault because his lawyers had been prevented from offering evidence of the complaining woman's public behavior with other men. Souter said such evidence was essential to the man's defense that the woman had consented to having sex with him. In a 1987 sexual assault case, Souter upheld a prosecutor's closing argument comment that the defendant's lawyer had failed to prove the victim was ``promiscuous.'' ``The comment can reasonably be interpreted as nothing more than a response to defense counsel's attempts, in cross-examination and closing argument, to present the victim as a woman of small virtue seeking a stranger for sexual amusement,'' Souter wrote. In one of the rare civil rights cases in which he participated, Souter joined the state court's ruling in 1987 that said homosexuals may be barred from becoming adoptive or foster parents. But the state court ruling also said that homosexuals may not be barred from running day care centers. In a 1986 case, Souter joined the majority in ruling that doctors have a responsibility to test for birth defects and inform pregnant women of the option of abortion. In a concurring opinion, Souter questioned the impact the decision would have on doctors who oppose abortion on moral grounds. He said such physicians should not have to choose ``between rendering services that they morally condemn and leaving their profession in order to escape malpractice exposures.'' Souter was the lone dissenter in a 1985 state Supreme Court decision that struck down the use of police sobriety checkpoints. The nation's highest court upheld such police tactics earlier this year. As New Hampshire's attorney general in 1978, Souter defended Gov. Meldrim Thomson's plan to fly flags at half-staff from all public buildings on Good Friday to commemorate the death of Jesus Christ. Souter said the governor's proclamation sought to recognize Jesus as a historical figure without endorsing Christianity. But as the state's chief lawyer, Souter was obligated to represent the governor in court, and he never was confronted with a similar church-state issue while on the bench.

DOC.HEAD: Government Acts to End Annual Row Over Royal Finances
DOC.TEXT: In an attempt to end yearly budget-time rows over the royal allowance, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Tuesday the royal family will receive a fixed annual increase for the next decade. Such an arrangement was used for about 200 years before 1975. Then, the government began granting the royal allotment on an annual basis as part of the national budget. The Civil List, as the payment is known, will rise at about 7.5 percent per year for the next decade, Mrs. Thatcher said. She said the royal family is ``a focus of patriotism, loyalty, affection and esteem. It is a rare combination and we should value it.'' Behind her move was the wish to avoid the annual budget-day ``pay rise'' announcement, which both politicians and the royal family found unseemly. Anti-monarchists used the budget announcement as a chance to attack the expense of maintaining the royals. Under the 1990 budget, the royal allowance totalled about $12.1 million. Queen Elizabeth II received the lion's share at $9.26 million. The Civil List officially repays the monarch and 10 other members of her family for official duties. About 70 percent of the money goes to salaries and employment costs for royal staff. The queen has 250 permanent full-time employees, including those in her private office, the Buckingham Palace press office staff and those responsible for ceremonial duties. Prince Charles, the heir to the throne, is not on the Civil List. He receives undisclosed income from royal estates. Opposition Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock applauded the new arrangement and said it would ``provide for greater continuity and more effective planning in the financing of the royal household.'' Meanwhile, the queen has recruited a leading London accountant to help run her households more efficiently. Michael Peat, 40, a partner in the accounting firm of Peat Marwick McLintock, was named the royal household's director of finance and property services. He will oversee the management of Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle, St. James Palace and Kensington Palace.

DOC.HEAD: `Brady' Handgun Bill Clears House Committee
DOC.TEXT: The House Judiciary Committee approved on Tuesday a seven-day waiting period for handgun purchases, brushing aside opposition from the National Rifle Association. Rep. Edward F. Feighan, D-Ohio, the bill's sponsor, hailed the committee approval on a 27-9 vote as ``a great victory in the war against crime.'' The measure's sponsors say it is designed to give police time to check the backgrounds of would-be purchasers. It is known as the Brady bill in honor of former White House press secretary Jim Brady, who was shot in the 1981 attack on then-President Reagan and has lobbied in favor of it. In the Senate, a similar bill has been introduced by Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio. The House Judiciary Committee on Monday approved an omnibus crime bill that would increase from five to 10 years in prison the maximum penalty for use of a sawed-off shotgun or rifle in a drug crime and establish a 30-year sentence for using a bomb or hand grenade. Earlier, the committee approved legislation to curb semiautomatic assault weapons. It would ban an estimated 12 guns made in the United States. The Senate-passed version of omnibus crime legislation would ban the import or domestic manufacture of nine semiautomatic assault weapons. It was unclear when the House would have a floor vote on the waiting-period bill, although supporters were hoping for one before lawmakers leave Washington on their August recess. Before approving its handgun bill, the House committee defeated on a 24-12 vote a substitute proposed by Rep. Bill McCollum, R-Fla. It would have required states to upgrade their law enforcement computer systems to allow for point-of-purchase telephone identification of felons attempting to buy guns. It also would have required states to put fingerprints on drivers licenses within five years or risk losing federal funds. McCollum argues that the measure would work too much of a hardship on honest gun purchasers and that his plan would strike more directly at criminals.

DOC.HEAD: Art Expert Gerald Hedley Dies in Avalanche
DOC.TEXT: Gerald Hedley, described by London's National Gallery as one of the world's top experts in art restoration, has been killed in a mountaineering accident in the French Alps. He was 41. The gallery said Tuesday that Hedley fell about 200 feet down a rockface to his death after being caught in an avalanche Saturday on Tour Ronde mountain. His guide, Dave Cuthbertson, survived with a broken leg, wrist and ribs when his rope snagged on an outcrop. David Bomford, senior restorer at the National Gallery, said Hedley lectured at the Courtauld Institute of London University and advised museums throughout the world on restoration. ``He was one of the most internationally celebrated people in the whole of the restoration scene,'' Bomford said. ``It is no exaggeration to say his research saved valuable works for future generations.'' Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Reserving Judgments On Bush Court Nominee
With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fax machines were whirring and researchers were combing legal opinions Tuesday as interest groups in the nation's capital began mobilizing to uncover information about David H. Souter, President Bush's choice for a Supreme Court seat. Conservative and liberal activists alike were taking a wait-and-see attitude. They acknowledged the president caught them a little off guard by moving so swiftly to choose a successor to William J. Brennan, who announced his surprise retirement from the court just three days before Souter was named Monday to succeed him. Activists on both sides agreed the Senate confirmation process for Souter would be searching but nothing like the battle royal that engulfed, and ultimately defeated, Robert Bork when former President Ronald Reagan picked him for a 1987 court vacancy. Souter is ``clearly not like Bork,'' said Elliot Mincberg of People for the American Way. ``He doesn't have much of a track record.'' Mincberg's liberal organization took a leading role three years ago in lobbying against Bork, who had written extensive attacks on liberal high court rulings and activist judges. But Mincberg said so far there are no similar plans this time. ``We just don't know enough about him (Souter) to make a judgment,'' he said. ``But we hope the senators will provide a searching inquiry.'' Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said his organization is withholding judgment. But he expressed concern that Brennan's departure comes at a time when the court ``is turning more and more to a narrow and restrictive view of the Constitution to the detriment of minorities, women, the poor and the powerless.'' Souter, a 50-year-old bachelor, served seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court before Bush appointed him to the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals this year. His record reveals little about his views on abortion and other divisive social issues he is sure to confront if confirmed by the Senate. Conservative activist Pat McGuigan said his fax machine was ``overheating'' as it spews out reams of material on Souter's opinions as a state judge. ``It looks on first impression like he's a good nominee,'' McGuigan said, adding, ``nobody knows anything about him.'' He said, ``In terms of Senate confirmation, this is very helpful.'' The United Conservatives of America gave the nomination ``a cautious thumbs-up'' with Richard A. Viguerie, chairman of the group saying, ``most conservatives today have nervous smiles.'' ``We think we can be happy, but we're a little apprehensive. We don't know a lot about Judge Souter,'' he said. But there was no approval, cautious or otherwise, from Peter Flaherty, chairman of the Conservative Campaign Fund and former chairman of Citizens for Reagan. ``There remain too many unanswered questions about who he is and how this nomination came about,'' Flaherty said. ``I do know one thing: President Bush needlessly passed over a number of highly qualified candidates for the court whose philosophy is well-known. In doing so, he has taken an unacceptable risk.'' Souter's nomination was compared by some to those of Sandra Day O'Connor and Anthony M. Kennedy, two of Reagan's appointees to the high court. Both underwent a fair amount of scrutiny in the Senate, and both were confirmed rather easily to become conservative justices. Brennan is the first liberal justice to leave the court since William O. Douglas retired in 1975. Kennedy replaced Justice Lewis F. Powell, a swing vote on the closely divided court. Bork was Reagan's first choice for the seat. Douglas Ginsburg, Reagan's second choice, withdrew after admitting he had smoked marijuana. Some activists said that by picking Souter, Bush achieved at least two short-term political gains. He short-circuited efforts by opposing sides lobbying for someone with a clear stand on abortion, they said, and he selected someone non-controversial with excellent prospects of winning Senate approval. Phil Gutis of the American Civil Liberties Union said his organization normally does not take a position on Supreme Court nominees, as it did in the case of Bork. ``We opposed Bork because it was such an extreme case,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts, Astronauts Promote Space Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: The Apollo astronauts and Soyuz cosmonauts who met in space 15 years ago this month said Tuesday greater space cooperation could save both of their countries time and money. ``We have now very good orbital complex,'' cosmonaut Alexei Leonov said, referring to the Soviet space station Mir. ``But we don't have good transport system. We use only Soyuz spacecraft. It is not enough.'' Leonov suggested that the Soviets use U.S. shuttles and Americans, in turn, have access to Mir, which was launched in 1986. ``I'm sure we could use Mir right now,'' said astronaut Vance Brand, commander of the shuttle Columbia's delayed astronomy mission. Both Columbia and Atlantis have been disabled by hydrogen leaks. Leonov, Brand and the other three men who made history on July 17, 1975, when Apollo and Soyuz docked 140 miles above Earth, said during a news conference at Johnson Space Center in Houston that their mission set the stage for U.S.-Soviet space relations. ``To us it was a symbol that here were countries with two absolutely different languages, two different units of measurement and two political philosophies, yet we set forth a common goal,'' said Thomas Stafford, who commanded the Apollo mission. Leonov and cosmonaut Valery Kubasov have been on an Apollo-Soyuz reunion tour of the United States the past two weeks with Stafford and former astronaut Donald ``Deke'' Slayton. The four plan to visit Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., on Wednesday and Florida's Kennedy Space Center on Thursday. Brand has been unable to take part in the reunion activities, except for Tuesday's program, because of his preparations for the Columbia mission. Stafford, a retired Air Force lieutenant general, said he would like to see a repeat of the Apollo-Soyuz mission, as well as a cosmonaut on a shuttle and an astronaut on Mir during the next decade. He stressed the importance of Soviet input in America's plans for missions to the moon and Mars. ``Sometimes it is very healthy to compete and some other times it is important and necessary to work together,'' said Kubasov. ``An important and complicated technological mission such as a flight to Mars is certainly one of those which would necessitate cooperation.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Senate Votes to Change National Day
DOC.TEXT: The Romanian Senate voted Tuesday to restore Dec. 1 as Romania's national day, as it was before Communist rule. The previous national day was Aug. 23, commemorating the date in 1944 when Romania broke its alliance with the Axis and sided with the Allies in World War II. The alliance with the Soviet Union paved the way for 45 years of communist domination of this country. Dec. 1 marks the 1918 union of Transylvania with the other provinces comprising present-day Romania _ Wallachia and Moldavia. The proposal must also pass a vote in the House of Deputies, which is scheduled to debate the issue Wednesday. The Senate vote was seen, however, as ensuring its final passage. The choice of a date not directly related to last December's revolution that toppled the communist dictatorship reflects popular disagreement over which date is most important _ Dec. 16-17, when riots in the western city of Timisoara began the uprising, or the overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22. ``Neither (possible date) can give people the right to cancel Dec. 1,'' said Sen. Dan Iosif of the ruling National Salvation Front. ``Communists alone dared to cancel it. Let's hope no one is ever so bold as to do it again.'' But Laura Anton, 23, reflected the opinion of some more concerned with recent events than the country's history: ``I do not think it is fair that the national day be Dec. 1, since it means nothing to us,'' she insisted. ``It should be either Dec. 22 or at least Dec. 17.''

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Activists Decry Annual Pony Swim
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights activists are gathering on Chincoteague Island this week to protest what they call the mistreatment of the island's famed wild ponies during the annual pony swim. Every year for 65 years, the volunteer firemen of Chincoteague have rounded up the wild ponies on the neighboring coastal barrier island of Assateague and auctioned off some of the foals to control the size of the herd. On Wednesday, the ponies will be driven across the narrow inlet that separates the islands and herded through the town's streets to a penning area. This year's auction will be Thursday, with the proceeds going to the volunteer fire department. Last year, the department sold 77 foals for $40,000. Some of the foals purchased are returned to the island at the request of the buyers. The weeklong celebration brings about 30,000 people to the tiny community. The animals are thought to be the descendants of ponies that washed ashore from shipwrecks during Colonial times. They gained fame from Marguerite Henry's children's classic ``Misty of Chincoteague,'' first published in 1947. Animal rights groups, such as the Charlottesville-based Voices for Animals and People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals in Washington, D.C., say the round up, penning and auction are cruel, especially to the young animals. The ponies ``must swim unfamiliar waters, after which they are stampeded through town, separated from their mothers and sold at auction,'' said Susan Weidman of Voices for Animals. ``It's obvious that the fire company does not have the best interest of the horses at heart,'' she said. PETA is upset that unweaned foals are auctioned off. Such animals need special care if they are to survive away from their mother, said PETA spokeswoman Siriol Evans. None of the groups said they planned to actively protest the pony swim or auction this year, but will observe the events and help the animals if necessary. The Humane Society of the United States has been monitoring the event for 20 years. Gail Eisnitz, a field investigator for the Humane Society in Washington, said conditions for the animals have improved, although six animals have died in the last two years. One year, horses ate toxic chokecherry leaves off bushes overhanging the pen, became sick and died. As a result of those deaths, the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge on Assateague threatened to revoke the fire department's permit to graze the animals on the refuge if the department did not provide a veterinarian for the swim, penning and auction. Last year, the department had veterinarians on call but two horses still died. This year, Terry said, the fire department has hired a veterinarian to stay on the site full time. Ms. Eisnitz said the national Fish and Wildlife Service has demanded other improvements in exchange for the grazing rights. ``The fire department has enlarged the corral, provided a shaded area and more water for the animals. They have also cut back the chokecherry bushes,'' she said. The fire department works year round to help the herd, which numbers around 200. The animals are regularly checked by a veterinarian.

DOC.HEAD: Victim's Family Seeks to Prevent Murderer From Profiting From Case
DOC.TEXT: The family of a young woman killed by her romantic rival has filed a lawsuit to keep the convicted murderer from profiting from the crime by selling her story to authors or movie producers. The parents of Lisa Cihaski filed a wrongful death lawsuit against Lori Esker, 21, seeking an undisclosed amount of money, including compensation for their daughter's funeral and burial. ``There is no way that she should be able to profit from this. She won't if we have anything to say about it,'' said Richard Weber, the lawyer for Vilas and Shirley Cihaski. Ms. Esker, a former county dairy princess, has had offers from movie producers to sell her story but won't pursue them, her lawyer said Monday. She was convicted June 14 of first-degree intentional homicide in the Sept. 20 strangulation of Ms. Cihaski, 21. She faces a mandatory life prison term when she is sentenced July 31. Testimony during the trial portrayed Ms. Esker as an obsessively jealous woman who believed Ms. Cihaski had stolen her boyfriend and intentionally killed her to eliminate the competition in a love triangle. Ms. Esker was the reigning Marathon County Dairy Princess _ an award based on talent and leadership in agriculture _ when she killed Ms. Cihaski. Weber likened the case to the highly publicized ``Son of Sam'' killings in New York in the late 1970s in which the killer, David Berkowitz, made money from his story. The state of New York subsequently passed a law banning such profiteering, Weber said. ``Maybe something like this will cause the Legislature to think about it and pass some sort of legislation to protect victims of crimes and their families,'' Weber said. One of Ms. Esker's lawyers, Dean Strang of Milwaukee, said producers for big-screen movies and made-for-television movies have sent ``feelers'' to her asking about buying the rights to her story. ``Both Lori and her family from the very start have made it crystal clear that they do not intend to profit from this tragedy in any way,'' Strang said. The civil suit against Ms. Esker was filed last week in Marathon County Circuit Court.

DOC.HEAD: He Modeled Himself on `the Great Dissenter,' Has a Piercing Humor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 22nd graf, A yearbook, with description of caveman sketch; grafs 24-25, Now he, with Souter help for crippled churchgoer, graf 27, When he, with mountain-climbing quote
DOC.TEXT: David Souter drives cars until they rust. He was an altar boy in his hometown clapboard Episcopal church. He has a sharp Yankee sense of humor, capable of piercing stuffed shirts. He climbs mountains. He lives alone on the family farm _ a ``monastic life,'' says Sen. Warren Rudman, a friend. He is sober, cautious, solidly conservative, erudite. When the White House telephoned Sunday night, Souter was home, researching the law books. Dissecting the life and thoughts of this 50-year-old New England bachelor became an overnight industry in Washington after President Bush picked him to take the Supreme Court seat of liberal justice William J. Brennan, a dominant figure even in dissent. At law firms, on Capitol Hill, at the pro- and anti-abortion lobbies, over a thousand lunch tables, on the long-distance phone to anyone in New Hampshire who might know him, Souter was Topic A on Tuesday. The nominee offered a thin paper trail: His resume lists only one article, a tribute to a new Hampshire judge. He has written no opinions in the scant time since Bush put him on the Boston-based 1st Circuit Court of Appeals. Still, a verdict was taking shape. ``Central to the right'' rather than ``central to the left,'' offered Stanley W. Brown, a prominent Manchester, N.H., lawyer. ``But you aren't going to pick it up in any of his writings,'' added Brown. ``You probably won't in the future. He will follow the case where the case takes him.'' Retired New Hampshire lawyer Gordon Tiffany said Souter is capable of shedding political biases when deciding a case. ``I believe whether it's liberal or conservative, it's not the issue in his mind,'' Tiffany said. ``The issue in his mind is what was intended in the Constitution that this democracy should live up to, and those are the ideas he believes in.'' Lawyers call that principle ``stare decisis'' _ respect for judicial precedent. One government official who is familiar with Souter's background _ but is unwilling to be quoted by name _ said Souter goes by the values and philosophy of ``the Great Dissenter,'' conservative court giant Oliver Wendell Holmes, another stickler for precedent. The official said he took that to mean that Souter would be reluctant to overturn a previous decision such as Roe vs. Wade, which legalized abortion in 1973. Souter (it rhymes with ``scooter'') steeped himself in classical law and literature; he continues a program of reading books that Holmes read. Acquaintances remark on Souter's humorous side. One calls him a raconteur. He has ``a wicked sense of humor that can skewer the most stuffed shirt,'' said close friend Tom Rath, who succeeded Souter as state attorney general. Another friend, lawyer John Barto, says he ``has a twinkle in his eye.'' His is the kind of humor that ``helps to make a person balanced,'' said Tiffany. Souter served as president of the board of Concord Hospital. At a retirement party, recalled hospital president Dr. Richard Warner, ``he displayed the most fantastic, dry sense of humor that you can imagine.'' For all that, Souter was a notorious hard worker, said Warner. ``I never worked so hard in my life than when he was here,'' the doctor said. ``His method of leadership is to kind of be behind the scenes and make things happen.'' Added another friend _ and sponsor _ Sen. Rudman, R-N.H.: ``If he has any faults, I believe it's that he's worked too hard all his life. But that's the way he is.'' Even in his 1957 yearbook at Concord High School, ``Soutie'' was described as studious and hard-working, but also witty and in constant demand. Classmates called him most literary, most sophisticated _ and most likely to succeed. A yearbook sketch shows the young Souter's face imposed on a drawing of a caveman, dragging a classmate, Marjorie Macleod, by the hair. His yearbook photograph shows a grinning young man with a crew cut and bushy eyebrows. He is wearing a conservative brown suit. He was an altar boy at the century-old Holy Cross Episcopal Church in Weare, N.H. Now he worships at the St. Andrews Episcopal Church in Hopkinton, N.H. A member of the congregation, Kathy Pepin, said he always helps a woman in a wheelchair. ``Every single Sunday he wheels her out of the church and brings her to her car, always joking and laughing with her at the same time,'' she said. Friends say Souter has a parsimonious nature. Despite a net worth of over $600,000, he drove cars until they were rusty with age. When he goes mountain climbing with his law clerks, said lawyer Jack Middleton, ``they come back dragging their tongues.'' He lives alone at the Souter family farmhouse in Weare, N.H. He shared the house with his widowed mother, Helen, until she moved into a retirement home. Mrs. Souter, 82, said she shed a tear when he called from Washington Monday with the news. She said she'll miss his weekly visits. ``Isn't that silly, but being a mother, I'd miss him if he went to Boston,'' said Mrs. Souter.

DOC.HEAD: AM-Citizens-Sovran Merger,000
DOC.TEXT: Creation of the 12th largest bank holding company in the nation, with offices from Delaware to Florida, was approved Tuesday by the Federal Reserve Board. Sovran Financial Corp. of Norfolk, Va., the largest bank in Virginia with $25.5 billion in assets, will merge with Citizens & Southern Corp., Atlanta, the largest bank in Georgia with $23.3 billion in assets. Combined under the name of Avantor Financial Corp., they bank will rank 12th in the nation. The consolidated company will have branches in Virginia, Delaware, Kentucky, Maryland, the District of Columbia, Tennessee, Georgia, Florida and South Carolina. Avantor will be headquartered in Norfolk. The merger, which had been previously announced, would be accomplished with an exchange of shares by Sovran and Citizens. It still must be approved by banking authorities in several of the states. dws

DOC.HEAD: Senate To Vote Wednesday On Denouncing Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: The Senate will vote Wednesday on a resolution denouncing Sen. Dave Durenberger for financial misconduct. Only Durenberger and, perhaps, fellow Minnesota Republican Rudy Boschwitz are expected not to vote for the resolution. Durenberger's press secretary, Lois West, said the senator would vote ``present.'' Boschwitz's press secretary, Tim Droogsma, said his boss may vote the same way. West said Durenberger had ruled out a challenge to the resolution, which she said the rest of Durenberger's colleagues are expected to approve. ``There have been senators who said they would support him in whatever he wanted them to do,'' West said. ``Durenberger, if asked, has been saying that he would just as soon they accept it _ as he has done.'' The Senate Ethics Committee recommended last week that the full chamber denounce Durenberger for ``unequivocally unethical'' conduct in connection with a book-promotion scheme and Senate payments on his Minneapolis condominium. Durenberger will be required to make up to $123,000 in restitution to the Senate. He had appealed to the committee for a lighter penalty, saying denouncement was ``much too onerous.'' ``Once the decision was made, he said he wasn't going to challenge it. It was appropriate to argue (the penalty) in advance,'' West said. Boschwitz was considering voting against the resolution until he talked to Durenberger and learned he would not challenge the sanction, Droogsma said. Boschwitz believes Durenberger has already been punished by the length of the 22-month-old ethics investigation and the $500,000 in legal fees he has incurred, Droogsma said.

DOC.HEAD: Viewers Try Hand at Interactive TV News
DOC.TEXT: About 1,400 viewers of Cable News Network's ``Newsnight'' dialed a 900 number to select two stories to be aired on the early-morning news show Tuesday. The winners of the viewer poll: stories on the controversial anti-depression drug Prozac and an Alabama marijuana eradication program. ``This was the shakedown cruise,'' executive producer Joshua Loory said after the show, which was the network's first attempt at interactive television. ``I think there were some minor production problems, but all in all, it went pretty well. I'm tickled right now.'' Near the beginning of the hour-long show, which starts at midnight, viewers were presented with a menu of six stories and the 900 number, which costs 75 cents to call. The calls were tabulated by computer and the two most popular stories were fit into the regular newscast, one in the top half-hour, the other in the second half-hour. Besides the two winners, viewers had a choice of stories on the latest testimony in Washington Mayor Marion Barry's drug trial, a sailing program designed to keep native American teens off drugs, summer jobs and efforts to save the spotted owl. The story on Prozac received 35 percent of the vote, while the drug eradication program received 26 percent. The stories on the sailing program, summer jobs and the spotted owl got few votes, he said. Loory said the show's producers are content to leave viewer selection at two stories. ``We're still very much in control of what's going into the show,'' he said. Although the network has no current plans to use the poll as a long-term guide, ``it'll probably be pretty interesting to look at the choices down the road and see what the viewers are selecting,'' Loory said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Souter-Record a0671
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from some of the New Hampshire Supreme Court opinions by David H. Souter, President Bush's choice for the Supreme Court.

_In a 1988 ruling, Souter said a state law was unconstitutional when applied to bar the New Hampshire Disabilities Rights Center, authorized by state law to provide legal services to the poor, from representing some disabled clients who were not poor. ``The DRC's request runs counter to the applicable state statutes,'' Souter said. ``Despite this conflict, we hold that enforcement of state law to prohibit the DRC, as a non-profit corporation, from representing non-indigent clients in its advocacy in behalf of disabled people would violate the First and 14th Amendments of the National Constitution. ``Organizations, their members and their staff lawyers may assert a protected First Amendment right of association for non-commercial purposes to advocate the enforcement of legal and constitutional rights of those members, or of others within a definite class whom the organization exists to serve. ``When such advocacy may reasonably include the provision of legal advice or take the form of litigation, the organization may itself provide legal representation to its members or beneficiaries despite state regulations restricting legal practice and the solicitation of clients.'' _In a 1988 decision, Souter ordered a new trial for a man who had been convicted of sexual assault. He said the man's lawyer wrongly was blocked from offering evidence of the alleged victim's public behavior with other men, a vital aspect of the defendant's claim that she had consented. ``During the noon hour of June 28, 1985, the defendant, Richard Colbath, went with some companions to the Smokey Lantern tavern in Farmington, where he became acquainted with the female complainant. There was evidence that she directed sexually provocative attention toward several men in the bar with whom she associated during the ensuing afternoon, the defendant among them. ``The two of them eventually left the tavern and went to the defenant's trailer. It is undisputed that sexual intercourse followed; forcibly according to the complainant, consensual according to the defendant. In any case, before they left the trailer the two of them were joined unexpectedly by a young woman who lived with the defendant, who came home at an unusual hour suspecting that the defendant was indulging in faithless behavior. ``With her suspicion confirmed, she became enraged, kicked the trailer door open and went for the complainant, whom she assaulted violently and dragged outside by the hair. It took the intervention of the defendant and a third woman to bring the melee to an end.'' _In another sexual assault case, Souter wrote for the court in 1987. ``During final argument in the defendant's trial on two counts of aggravated felonious assault and one of kidnapping, the prosecutor commented on defense counsel's failure to elicit any testimony indicating the victim was promiscuous. The defense objected on the ground that the (state) rape shield law would have precluded admission of any such evidence, and objected further to the (trial judge's) refusal to give any curative instruction. ``The comment can reasonably be interpreted as nothing more than a response to defense counsel's attempts, in cross-examination and closing arguments, to present the victim as a woman of small virtue seeking a stranger for sexual amusement. ``This intimation was the whole point of defense counsel's fishing for testimony that the victim and her friends went to the club to drink, mingle with the crowd and dance with men they did not know. Even though the fishing did not net much, defense counsel stuck to the point in a closing argument that held the victim up as someone who drank at the club, walked through the crowd, `maybe' danced, and invited male pursuit by her solitary departure. ``In a word, the defense tried to paint the victim as promiscuous, and there was nothing wrong with the prosecution's plain contention that the try had failed.'' _In a 1988 decision, Souter upheld a robbery conviction over arguments that the defendant had been arrested unlawfully. ``On otherwise deserted streets, and within minutes of a late evening robbery in a small town, the (police) officer saw an individual who matched the victim's description of the perpetrator as a male with bushy hair. While the rain might have induced his rapid gait, it did nothing to explain away his highly suspicious behavior in taking no ostensible notice of a bright spotlight suddenly shining upon him. ``Reasonable caution and prudence were satisfied in deciding that the man on the street had probably committed the robbery.'' _In 1989, Souter said a bank could not be held contractually liable for failing to discover poor workmanship on a construction project for which it had given loans to Ross and Virginia Seymour. ``The Seymours make a further try at salvaging the contract claim by asserting that bank officers orally agreed to shift the Seymours' responsibility to the bank, pointing to a loan officer's alleged remark that the bank's inspections would be a `safeguard and well worth it.' They conveniently forget, however, that they never asked the trial court for a specific finding that the remark was made.'' _A 1986 decision went against a child-abuse defendant who had sought to question the alleged victim at a pretrial proceeding. The defendant had wanted to secure a sworn statement, called a deposition. ``At the most basic level, these state and federal cases reflect the fact that court-ordered discovery does not exhaust the practical possibilities for investigating and preparing a criminal case. This defendant had access, for example, to a statement by the victim that not only anticipates the victim's (trial) testimony but provides a basis to attack the reliability of the testimony, if the victim offers it. ``Given such sources of information and evidence, we simply cannot say that discovery depositions are necessarily essential to adequate trial preparation.'' _The state court in 1986 ruled that doctors have a responsibility to test for birth defects and inform pregnant women of possible defects to given them the option of abortion. In a concurring opinion, Souter addressed an additional issue. ``The questions transferred to us ... fail to raise a significant issue in the area of malpractice litigation that we address today. The trial court did not ask whether, or how, a physician with conscientious scruples against abortion and the testing and counseling that may inform an abortion decision can discharge his professional obligation without engaging in procedures that his religious or moral principles condemn. ``I do not understand the court to hold that a physician can discharge the obligation of due care in such circumstances only by personally ordering such tests and rendering such advice. The court does not hold that some or all physicians must make a choice between rendering services that they morally condemn and leaving their profession in order to escape malpractice exposure.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Charge Rebels Blocking Food Shipments
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials charged Tuesday that rebels in Ethiopia have intentionally blocked shipments of desperately needed food from reaching thousands of hungry people in the country. ``They have basically betrayed their people ... they have lied ... they are using food as a weapon,'' Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, said of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, a rebel organization that controls portions of northern Ethiopia. Hall is chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger. The anger of Hall and Andrew Natsios of the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance was triggered by the rebel group's refusal to allow a Danish freighter flying the United Nations flag to enter the Red Sea port of Massawa. The rebels captured Massawa earlier this year. For 10 days the ship, the Nordland Saga, waited in vain for permission to enter Massawa, Natsios said. Finally, the ship left the region Tuesday because the rebels continued to stall. Natsios said excuses offered by the rebels for failure to admit the ship were ``ludicrous.'' Natsios and Hall spokes in interviews after meeting to discuss the food situation in northern Ethiopia. The ship contained a four-man technical team who intended to survey the channels and docks at Massawa to make sure they could accommodate vessels carrying 25,000 tons of food. Those ships have been diverted elsewhere. Hall said the rebels have reneged on an earlier promise to let the ship land. In an interview on ABC-TV's ``Nightline'' show on April 4, Tesfai Ghermazien, a spokesman for the liberation front, said the rebels would open up the port. If food cannot get into Ethiopia through Massawa, famine could worsen rapidly in the next few weeks, Natsios said. Until now, food has gone into the country by land from the south. But the rainy season, which began this week, will soon make roads impassable to trucks, he said. In April, the Ethiopian government estimated that 4.4 million people were threatened with starvation and said its total emergency food needs would total more than 900,000 tons this year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Also Interviewed Texan Edith Jones
With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush interviewed Edith H. Jones, a federal appellate judge from Houston, as well as appeals court judge David H. Souter before choosing Souter for the Supreme Court, administration sources said Tuesday. There were four finalists for the nomination, but only Jones, 41, and Souter, 50, were interviewed by Bush, said the sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Bush interviewed them separately at the White House on Monday, they said. Other finalists for the position were Laurence H. Silberman, 54, a member of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington, and Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr, 44, the sources said. Silberman voted in the 2-1 majority last Friday as the Washington appeals court set aside the Iran-Contra convictions of former White House aide Oliver L. North. Jones, a member of the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, had practiced in the same Houston law firm where Secretary of State James A. Baker III was once a partner. President Reagan appointed her to the appellate court in 1985. Bush was impressed by her during the interview and she will remain on the list of prospective Supreme Court nominees for possible future vacancies, said one administration official.

DOC.HEAD: Marla Fights Subpoena, Dreams of `Beautiful Ending'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, ``Didn't King ...,' with 2 grafs to ADD that Edward married a divorced woman; picks up 11th graf pvs, ```She had ...'
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples, still hoping for a fairy-tale ending with Donald Trump, is fighting a subpoena to testify about his prenuptial agreement with Ivana Trump, a publicist for the actress said Tuesday. Chuck Jones commented on a Daily News report that Mrs. Trump's lawyer, Michael Kennedy, had obtained testimony from bodyguards and other Trump organization employees for an Aug. 20 hearing on the prenuptial agreement. The testimony proves ``not only that Trump was having an affair with Marla, but that he funneled money through Chuck Jones to pay for her credit cards, and that he comped (didn't bill) her for anything and everything she wanted at his hotels,'' Kennedy was quoted as saying. ``In the hotel business, everybody comps,'' Trump told the News. ``So what? I took a gift tax on everything. And now that Marla's earning money, she's paying me back.'' Jones said he could not comment directly on Kennedy's assertions because he and Maples have been subpoenaed to give depositions for the prenuptial agreement hearing. But he said he would fight the subpoena because his opinion ``is irrelevant to the premarital agreement.'' He said Maples also is fighting the deposition subpoena. Kennedy said he was misquoted in the News, although he wouldn't specify how. He had no response to Jones's comments, said his assistant, Gregory Lenihan. The News, meanwhile, said Maples still dreams of a future with the mogul. ``Of course I would think about it, of course,'' she said when asked if she'd consider marrying The Donald. ``This could be a story with a very beautiful ending.'' ``Didn't King Edward once fall in love with a married woman and leave his throne?'' Jones said Tuesday. Edward abdicated to marry Wallis Simpson, a divorced American commoner. ``It's life,'' Jones said. ``She (Maples) can't be faulted for any of that.'' ``She had nothing to do with the marital problems of Donald and Ivana Trump and doesn't want the public to think that she did,'' said Jones. ``She just feels the timing is right to take a stand.'' Maples, who has been romantically linked to the New York developer for eight months, described Ivana Trump as a ``cold'' woman who is neglecting her children. She said Mrs. Trump is ``out every night in London and New York, going on dates to her society parties, while Donald is home raising the children.'' ``I see my children every single day,'' Mrs. Trump told the News through her spokeswoman, Lisa Calandra. ``Donald sees them once a week at most and has gone weeks on end without seeing them at all. ``Beyond that, I won't dignify anything Marla Maples has to say. She sounds just like Donald,'' Mrs. Trump was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Millionaire Battler Says Fast Food Fight Isn't Over
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS final graf to clarify legislation
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Fat-Glance
DOC.TEXT: The millionaire campaigning to lower Americans' cholesterol levels to reduce the risk of heart attacks said Tuesday his fight against fast-food fat isn't finished despite a victory on the french-fry front. Phil Sokolof, president and chief financial backer of the National Heart Savers Association, said he was pleased that McDonald's Corp. and Wendy's joined Burger King and several other fast-food chains in switching to all-vegetable oils for cooking french fries. McDonald's officials said the company's announcement Monday to switch to cottonseed and corn oil had nothing to do with Sokolof's anti-fat campaign against the fast-food restaurants. But Sokolof said his ads criticizing McDonald's and other restaurants for cooking foods in beef tallow or a vegetable-beef combination oil rather than using what he called heart-healthy oils speeded up the process. Sokolof, who claims to have spent more than $2.5 million in the ad campaigns, said the fat issue has been forced in front of food company executives by the public, not by him. ``The American public as consumers have the power to move mountains,'' he said. ``McDonald's is a mountain.'' Wendy's International spokesman Denny Lynch said from Columbus, Ohio, Tuesday that converting to corn oil will cost more, but he wouldn't say how much. ``It would be safe to say that each chain will spend millions more'' each year, he said. He said equipment will not need to be changed, but there will be changes in training employees, such as how often the oil should be changed and cooking time. McDonald's spokeswoman Terry Capatosto said the company will use the same supplier to buy the new french fry oil. ``Cost wasn't a factor at all,'' she said of the switch. The biggest consideration was making sure the company didn't change the taste, she said. Both companies said they worked for months to develop an oil that would fry potatoes with the same taste as before. Sokolof, 67, formed the private foundation National Heart Savers Association after he suffered a heart attack. The foundation's targets have been snacks made with tropical oils and fast-food restaurants, though he acknowledges Americans would have to lower the amount of meat and dairy products they consume to lower cholesterol levels. Americans will continue to eat meat and dairy products and continue to go to fast-food restaurants, he said. ``Fast-food restaurants are not diet emporiums. People are still going to eat there,'' he said. ``Now they can make healthier choices.'' The beef tallow industry will be hurt by the all-vegetable oil decision, said Rich Parker of the American Meat Institute. But he said he did not know how much of an effect there would be. U.S. Department of Commerce figures showed that 1.2 billion pounds of beef tallow was produced in the United States last year, but Parker said he did not know how much of that went into cooking oil or shortening. Beef tallow also is used in paint, as a lubricant, in some plastics and some cosmetics, said Roger Mandigo, an animal science professor at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. Sokolof said he would continue to run ads for as long as it takes to improve the public perception of cholesterol levels, though he said he is pleased with the ``tremendous'' results from the ads so far. He took out a full-page ad in Tuesday's Washington Post urging Congress to pass a food-labeling bill requiring nutritional information on food labels and establishing definitions for terms such as ``lite'' and ``high in fiber.''

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Top Mini-Series No. 1 in U.S., Too
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Broadcasting Company's ``Love & Hate: A Marriage Made in Hell,'' proved a happy union for America's NBC network. The second installment of Canada's top-rated mini-series was the No. 1 show on U.S. television in ratings released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. The four-hour docudrama about one of Canada's most sensational murder cases stars Kenneth Welsh and Kate Nelligan. It was pitched to NBC programming guru Brandon Tartikoff by producer Ivan Fecan, a former NBC employee who now is Tartikoff's counterpart at CBC. Part one of ``Love & Hate'' was shown on NBC a week ago and ranked sixth in the Nielsens for that period. The peacock network also scored with the debut of ``Real Life with Jane Pauley,'' on Tuesday at 10 p.m. The magazine-style show starring the former ``Today'' co-host tied for fifth place with a repeat of NBC's ``Empty Nest.'' The No. 2 show was a rerun of NBC's venerable ``Cheers,'' followed by a redux of ABC's ``Roseanne.'' ABC's prime-time news show ``20-20'' was fourth. In a three-way tie for seventh was NBC's ``The Golden Girls'' and Fox Broadcasting Co.'s runaway hits ``The Simpsons'' and ``Married...With Children.'' The ``Miss Teen USA'' pageant broadcast Monday at 9 p.m. was the No. 10 show and the eye network's only showing in the top 10. NBC won the overall ratings war with a 10.2 average, followed by CBS with 8.7 and ABC with 8.4. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Love & Hate: A Marriage Made in Hell,'' Part 2, NBC, 16.3; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 15.5; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 13.8; ``20-20,'' ABC, 13.4; ``Empty Nest'' and ``Real Life with Jane Pauley,'' (tie) NBC, 13.3; ``Golden Girls,'' NBC, 13.0; ``The Simpsons,'' Fox, 13.0; ``Married...With Children,'' Fox, (tie) 13.0; ``Miss Teen USA,'' CBS, 12.8. The network news battle was won again by ABC with an 8.9 average. CBS was second with an 8 and NBC finished last with 7.4.

DOC.HEAD: Union Leaders: Corporate America's Support Will Help Health Care Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Corporate America's interest in national health care reform improves the odds such legislation will ever go anywhere, according to union leaders who announced a new health care campaign on Tuesday. The business community's support for changing the nation's health care system should help persuade the Bush administration that federal legislation is needed, said four union presidents who announced a fall campaign to build public support for a health care law. ``If the administration view is going to be changed, it's going to be changed by corporate America and not the AFL-CIO,'' said Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America. The new ``Jobs for Justice'' health care campaign will attempt to rally the AFL-CIO's 14.2 million members into action on the issue, Bahr and other union leaders said. On Oct. 3, the unions hope to have millions of American workers sporting lapel pins calling for health care reform. Also that day, they will man information booths at work sites around the country and picket non-union businesses that don't provide their workers with health insurance benefits. ``Through our public demonstrations and displays of workplace solidarity, we'll be asking other workers and our communities to join the AFL-CIO's grassroots health care campaign,'' said John Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union and chairman of an AFL-CIO's panel studying health care issues. Union leaders said the health care problem is too large to be solved through labor-managment negotiations. There are 37 million Americans who have no insurance at all and another 50 million who have inadequate health care, they said. In addition, the problem has increasingly become the No. 1 dispute between workers and management as costs increase and employers try to make workers pick up a larger share of the expense. ``We can't accomplish this over the bargaining table ... it has to be through legislation,'' said William Bywater, president of the International Union of Electronic, Electrical, Salaried, Machine and Furniture Workers. Karen Brigham, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce's health care expert, said the business community ``no longer wants to maintain the status quo'' because health care costs have been speeding upward by 20 percent a year for employers. Neither the business community nor labor leaders have agreed on a specific proposal or how to pay for it. Workers have also been forced to take the matter more seriously, Bahr said. ``We've seen a rash of strikes at the collective bargaining table where workers have put their jobs on the line and said clearly this is an issue we will fight over,'' Bahr said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Wants Broader Investigation of Pierce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs `Pierce's lawyer ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with comment from attorney. Picks up 9th graf pvs `The letter ...'
DOC.TEXT: A House panel urged a special prosecutor Tuesday to widen the investigation of former HUD Secretary Samuel Pierce, saying it had evidence Pierce steered lucrative federal grants to his former law firm. In its most detailed finding, congressional investigators questioned whether Pierce's former law firm, a former top aide and Pierce himself may have violated federal bribery, conspiracy and conflict-of-interest laws during his tenure as secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The panel said evidence also suggested Pierce, who served throughout the eight-year Reagan administration, may have committed perjury at a panel hearing when he denied involvement in the awarding of key grants. ``It is obvious that Secretary Pierce did not give us the full story,'' the panel wrote. ``However, some of his statements stand out in that they are inconsistent and at odds with the sworn testimony of other witnesses.'' Pierce testified in the early stages of the probe, then invoked his 5th Amendment right against self-incrimination in refusing later questioning. Urging independent counsel Arlin Adams to substantially expand his investigation, the House Government Operations subcommittee said its 14-month investigation uncovered ``widespread abuses, influence peddling, blatant favoritism, monumental waste and gross mismanagement'' at HUD during Pierce's tenure. Its findings were offered in a letter signed by all eight subcommittee members _ three Republicans and five Democrats, including Chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif. Pierce's lawyer, Paul Perito, said there was ``nothing new, different or worthy of attention'' in the letter. He also said it was ``improper and inappropriate'' for the committee to direct a letter to the prosecutor rather than the Justice Department. ``It appears primarily to be a rehash of stale allegations or the stacking of faulty conclusions based upon surmise, innuendo or conjecture, and not on hard evidence or testimony,'' Perito said. ``Hopefully, this is the last spasm of life from this subcommittee, trying in vain to justify their continuing existence.'' The letter asked Adams to expand his probe to perjury, Pierce's dealings with the law firm and aide Lance Wilson, and his role in HUD's co-insurance program in which the federal government shared responsibility for backing large housing development projects. Congressional investigators said there was previously undisclosed evidence gathered by the panel's staff involving Pierce's dealings while secretary with the New York law firm Battle, Fowler, Jaffin and Kheel. Pierce was a partner before joining the Reagan administration and had intended to return to legal practice there, the letter said. Documents found in HUD files, the panel said, show that the firm frequently sought Pierce's assistance in HUD-related matters. It said they included having Pierce meet with their client to discuss a development grant application and helping secure lucrative housing subsidies. It cited a 1985 letter from partner Martin L. Edelman to Pierce assistant Deborah Gore Dean seeking her help in obtaining a subsidy for an Amherst, N.Y., project under the Section 8 Moderate Rehabilitation program. It also recounted er assistance in another project there, Allenhurst Apartments, the year before. ``It defies logic and reason that Ms. Dean would have assisted Battle, Fowler in obtaining these scarce and much-in-demand (subsidy) units for the Allenhurst project on her own without the direct and intimate involvement of Secretary Pierce,'' the letter said, adding that it appears Ms. Dean helped the firm at the behest of Pierce. The law firm denied any wrongdoing. ``We are confident that no member or employeeof the firm has engaged in any inappropriate conduct,'' said Thomas Glynn, a partner and spokesman for Battle, Fowler. The panel also said it had evidence that Wilson, who later became a housing specialist with the investment company Paine Webber, and Pierce engaged in activities aimed at benefiting each other. It cited 1988 telephone messages in which Wilson, while working for Paine Webber, called Pierce to tell him of the status of pending financial deals and of the role his former law firm had played in the deals. ``This suggests that ... Lance Wilson, with the secretary's knowledge and approval, acted to steer HUD-related legal work to the law firm in which Secretary Pierce had been a partner in the past, and was likely to become a partner again in the future,'' the letter said. In suggesting Pierce may have committed perjury, the panel cited Pierce's denial that he directed Ms. Dean or anyone else to approve particular grants. That was contrasted with public testimony by former HUD officials who said Pierce did direct funding on specific projects. Former assistant DuBois Gilliam testified that HUD ``dealt strictly in politics.'' Ms. Dean refused to testify, citing constitutional rights against self-incrimination.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Souter, Bjt
Souter Defended N.H. Rulings in Earlier Confirmation Hearing
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter, in a hearing on his nomination to a federal appellate judgeship earlier this year, defended overturning a sexual assault conviction on grounds that the defendant's right to interrogate his accuser overrode the woman's right of privacy. But Souter also assured Sen. Edward M. Kennedy that he respected the need for ``shield'' laws discouraging defense attorneys from prying into the sexual lives of sexual assault victims. ``Yes,'' Souter replied when asked if he would be sensitive to this problem. Nevertheless, he said, the New Hampshire case in question was one in which ``the rape shield law had to yield.'' He said the victim's right to privacy was effectively overridden by trial testimony that she had made sexually provocative statements to several men in a bar in the hours before the alleged assault. ``Sensitivity to that particular (privacy) dilemma is something which is enormously important in terms of the balance of interests,'' Kennedy told Souter during the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing April 5. The committee released a transcript of the hearing Tuesday. The 50-year-old Souter, selected by President Bush to succeed William J. Brennan on the Supreme Court, was explaining his thinking as a member of the New Hampshire Supreme Court. His opinion, on behalf of a unanimous court, was subsequently criticized by People for the American Way, a Washington-based liberal-oriented lobbying organization. The decision reversed the trial court conviction of a man accused of aggravated rape on the ground that the lower court had refused to admit evidence about the victim's public behavior with men in the hours before the alleged assault. The lower court had instructed the jury that the victim's conduct with other individuals was not relevant to the question of whether she consented to sex with the defendant. Souter told the hearing that the question before the court was whether the woman's privacy right under the state's rape shield law must give way to the defendant's constitutional right to cross-examine his accuser. ``The complaining witness' behavior immediately prior to their departure from the public bar in question had a very high degree of significance,'' Souter said. ``So that was an example of a case, which is not unfamiliar to us, in which the rape shield law had to yield.'' Kennedy also questioned Souter about a ruling in which he upheld the conviction of a man who, under questioning by police before his arrest, said, ``If you think I am going to confess to you, you are crazy.'' The Massachusetts Democrat noted that the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, on which Souter ultimately was seated, threw out the conviction in a ``rather critical'' ruling that reversed Souter's. The higher court said that Souter's ruling placed too much stock in the man's seemingly self-incriminating remark _ and gave short-shrift to the general theme of the remark in which the man was saying he wouldn't answer police questions at the time. Souter's ruling, the appellate court said, ``ignores the teaching that the protection of the Fifth Amendment (against self-incrimination) is not limited to those in custody or charged with a crime.'' The judge told the committee, ``The nub of the disagreement is that the language which you (Kennedy) quoted is language which we read to be essentially inculpatory and not a Fifth Amendment invocation.'' Kennedy asked, ``What assurance can you give us that you will not take a crabbed view of the scope of that fundamental constitutional protection?'' The judge replied: ``Well, I think the assurance that the principle that you have just enunciated goes without saying, or should go without saying, in the mind of any judge, including mine. ...'' He was approved by voice vote in the committee, and, subsequently, in the same fashion on the Senate floor, for the federal appellate judgeship.

DOC.HEAD: United States Against Forgiving Polish Debt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration opposes forgiving any of Poland's $41 billion debt but is reviewing the issue, Assistant Secretary of State Raymond G. H. Seitz told Congress Tuesday. Seitz, who is in charge of European affairs, appeared before the subcommittee on Europe of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The subcommittee chairman, Rep. Lee H. Hamilton, D-Ind, said in an interview afterwards that Poland's debt will have to be reduced sooner or later. Poland's government has been asking repeatedly for some reduction. Foreign business is wary of investing in Polish efforts to move away from a communist system because of the debt overhang. At the hearing, Hamilton pressed Seitz on the question. Rep. Jan Meyers, R-Kan, another member of the panel, also told him that Poland needs debt relief. Seitz said the administration is aware of Poland's problems and pointed out that debt repayments have been put off. According to the World Bank, Poland owed an additional $7.1 billion in back interest in 1988. ``You're opposed to forgiveness?'' Hamilton asked. ``Yes, at the moment,'' Seitz replied. Treasury Nicholas F. Brady devised a reduction plan last year for countries with big debts to banks. But Poland's debts are owed largely to other governments, and only about $9 billion is owed to banks. West Germany and France are major creditors. About $3 billion is owed to the United States. David E. Mulford, Brady's undersecretary for international affairs, had warned that forgiving Poland's debt would set a precedent for others with big debts to governments. President Bush set a precedent himself last month by offering to forgive some debt of Latin American countries, which owe to governments as well as to banks. Earlier he had followed some European creditor countries and Canada in offering to forgive a billion dollars worth of debts that the poorest countries in Africa owe to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Robertson Admits Only A Fraction of Oldest Trees Survive
DOC.TEXT: Forest Service Chief F. Dale Robertson acknowledged before Congress on Tuesday that only about 10 percent of the Northwest's ``old trees'' remain standing and half of those are scheduled to be cut over the next 50 years. However, Robertson disagreed with environmentalists who say the region's old-growth forests are being destroyed. New trees are being replanted in their place, he said. The House Interior national parks and public lands subcommittee is considering legislation to protect the region's forests without crippling its timber industry. Environmentalists have maintained for some time that only 10 percent of the Northwest's original forests, which they call ``ancient forests,'' have survived harvests and natural disasters over the past 150 years. However, the timber industry has disputed those figures and in the past the Forest Service has declined to offer an estimate. Under questioning from lawmakers, Robertson acknowledged that approximately 10 percent of what he called ``old trees'' remain in the region. ``I don't know if it is 10, or 9 or 12 (percent), but it is around that,'' Robertson said. Forest Service spokesman Jerry Mason said later Tuesday that ``old trees'' are those which are 200 years or older. In other testimony, assistant Fish and Wildlife Service Director Ralph Morgenweck said his agency opposes a proposal by Oregon Rep. Bob Smith that would for the next five years exempt Northwest timber sales from the protections granted the northern spotted owl under the Endangered Species Act. Smith, a Republican, attacked a recommendation by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas and other government scientists that would protect the owl by banning logging across 3 million acres of Northwest forests currently open to harvests. Meanwhile Tuesday, the House Appropriations interior subcommittee approved a 20 percent reduction in Pacific Northwest timber harvests. An area lawmaker said the deal, which would set harvests on Forest Service lands in the Northwest at 3 billion board feet, is the least economically disruptive his region can expect this year.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: Navy Should Move Slower On Submarine Program
DOC.TEXT: The Navy should slow down its $44 billion Seawolf attack submarine program because 15 of the costly vessels will be under contract before critical testing on the lead ship has been completed, congressional investigators said Tuesday. ``The SSN-21 program is using a concurrent scheduling approach which has construction ongoing while design is continuing,'' Martin Ferber of the General Accounting Office told a House Armed Services subcommittee. The subcommittee on seapower and strategic and critical materials heard testimony from the GAO and the Navy on the submarine program. The full committee begins crafting its version of the defense bill this week. To meet the House-approved military budget of $283 billion, the seapower subcommittee must cut $3 billion from President Bush's proposed request of $16.1 billion _ and the Seawolf program may be a victim of the budget ax. The Navy plans to buy 29 of the SSN-21 nuclear attack submarines by the year 2000 at a cost of $44 billion. The first submarine, designed by the Newport News Shipbuilding Co., of Virginia and Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics in Connecticut, is estimated at $1.9 billion. The Navy expects the cost of subsequent submarines to decline, averaging around $1 billion. The submarines will be equipped with a sophisticated computer system that will allow the vessels to locate targets faster than existing submarines and cut the time between detecting the enemy and launching weapons. The SSN-21 will be quieter, larger and deeper diving that the Los Angeles class of nuclear submarines, the SSN-688. But the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress, said the submarine program and the on-board computer system are being developed separately with varying target dates for delivery to the Navy. Under current plans, the Navy will have as many as 15 of the 29 ships under contract before the lead ship undergoes operational tests, the GAO said. In addition, the computer system is a ``developmental risk,'' Ferber told the subcommittee. ``The more mature you make the system, the better off you're going to be,'' Ferber said in recommending a delay in the program. But Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III argued that concurrency is something that can't be avoided. ``In this declining business environment, shipyards cannot build one ship, wait for the Navy to complete operational testing and still be in existence when we have proven the risk is behind us,'' Garrett said. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in approving a $289 billion defense bill earlier this month, deferred purchasing two Seawolf submarines at a cost of $2.3 billion because of excessive concurrency. The panel instead substituted two of the SSN-688 Los Angeles-class submarines at a cost of $1.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: No Increase in Disciplinary Action Against Physicians in 1988
DOC.TEXT: The number of serious disciplinary actions against physicians was the same in 1988 as during the previous year, breaking a pattern of increasing rates, a consumer group said Tuesday. The Public Citizen Health Research Group said state medical boards took serious actions against 1,489 physicians in 1988, the same number disciplined in 1987. The actions included license revocation or suspension and physician probation, the group said. The group analyzed the most recent data compiled by the Federation of State Medical Boards. In 1984, serious actions were taken against 745 physicians, Public Citizen said. That increased to 1,089 in 1985 and 1,277 in 1986. However, Public said the 1988 disciplinary rates weren't high enough. ``A physician could still operate drunk, commit a gross act of negligence, or sexually assault a patient and receive a mere slap on the wrist from his or her state's medical board in most states,'' the group said. The group, however, said it was encouraged that 44 state legislatures had passed legislation to strengthen state oversight of physicians. Public Citizen released a report last month listing the names of 6,892 physicians who have been disciplined by state medical boards and the federal government. The 1988 actions were not included in that report.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Lawmaker Wants Iran-Contra Office Closed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf pvs, Walsh's office, with comment; Updates 10th graf, Walsh's investigation, with additional law enforcement cost
DOC.TEXT: The independent counsel's office that prosecuted Oliver North and John Poindexter should be closed, a Republican member of the former House Iran-Contra investigating panel said Tuesday. ``I believe we are well past the point where further pursuit of this matter by an independent counsel serves any public good,'' Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan said in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. But Justice Department sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said such a move would be politically difficult for Thornburgh because it is believed Walsh is looking into the conduct of Donald Gregg, the U.S. ambassador to South Korea, in connection with the Iran-Contra affair. Gregg was George Bush's national security adviser when Bush was vice president and the sources said that closing down the office of Independent Counsel Lawrence Walsh would look like a coverup. Walsh has spent nearly four years and tens of millions of tax dollars investigating and prosecuting Iran-Contra cases, said Broomfield, who was a member of the House investigating panel. Broomfield's request comes just days after a divided federal appeals court panel set aside North's Iran-Contra convictions, reversing one of three guilty verdicts and ordering hearings to determine whether the other two were tainted by immunized testimony North gave Congress. Broomfield asked Thornburgh to exercise his authority under the 1987 independent counsel act to seek the termination of Walsh's office and turn over any loose ends in his Iran-Contra investigations to the Justice Department to be tied up. ``Nobody wants to complete this work more than we do,'' Walsh said through a spokeswoman. ``We simply don't feel that we can fail to develop the testimony of significant witnesses as they become available.'' North and Poindexter were the two highest-ranking Reagan administration officials prosecuted in the operation that sent arms to Iran and covert profits from their sale to Nicaragua's Contra rebels. Walsh's investigation, which had cost $21 million through May, has led to the conviction of seven people involved in the Iran-Contra affair. The Justice Department says the investigations have cost law enforcement agencies an additional $7.7 million, for a total of $28.7 million. Broomfield said the action on North's case focused new attention on what he termed Walsh's ``perpetual investigation.'' ``The Iran-Contra affair has been thoroughly investigated. We've paid for two congressional committees, a presidential commission and an independent counsel,'' Broomfield said. ``Still, Walsh seems intent on ensconcing himself as part of the permanent bureaucracy,'' he said. ``I believe the time has come to say enough is enough.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Thunderstorms Bring Flooding From Southwest to Northeast
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain fell across much of the nation Tuesday, and torrential storms sent floodwaters through Tucson, Ariz., and parts of Massachusetts. Several sections of Tucson were evacuated, Interstate 17 was closed and many intersections were under as much as a foot of water. Thunderstorms produced 7.02 inches of rain in less than 6 hours near Middleboro, Mass. Elsewhere in the state, more than 5 inches in less than 4 hours caused extensive flooding at Bridgewater, 4.33 inches at Taunton left 4 feet of water on roads, and 3.05 inches fell at Abington, stranding many vehicles. No strong thunderstorms or heavy rains were reported this morning in Texas, but earlier rains left Burnt Crossing, south of Juno, under 5 feet of water during the early morning. Crossings near the Val Verde and Crockett-Sutton county lines in Texas were under as much as 4 and 5 feet of water. Tuesday afternoon there were showers and thunderstorms over parts of Iowa and Nebraska, and showers stretched from west-central Texas into northwest Louisiana, and from northern New Jersey across eastern New England into central Maine and southeast New York state. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered through north central Ohio to the mountains of Wyoming, south to Colorado and into New Mexico. Showers also reached from Utah into Montana, Idaho, Washington state and northwest Oregon. Tropical storm Arthur has formed over the Atlantic Ocean. At 1:30 p.m. EDT the center of the storm was 160 miles east of Trinidad moving west about 20 mph. Highest sustained winds were about 40 mph, but there were stronger gusts. Low temperature records for the date were broken in Paducah, Ken., at 60, and tied in Pueblo, Colo., at 54. Low temperature for the Lower 48 states Tuesday morning was 43 at Butte, Mont., Truckee, Calif., and Yellowstone National Park, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 56 at Hayward, Calif., to 100 at both Needles and Imperial, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Tearful Mother Tells of Husband's Abuse in Potty-Training Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT to July 28 sted July 21. Note contents, especially of 6th graf, `Dressed in ...'
DOC.TEXT: A tearful mother used a lifelike rubber doll and a porcelain toilet to show jurors Tuesday how her husband fatally plunged her 2-year-old son headfirst into the commode as punishment for soiling his pants. ``He held him way up here,'' 21-year-old Sheryl Coe testified, grabbing the doll by the ankles and dunking its head into the toilet. ``He flushed the toilet water so the water would flush on his head.'' Thomas Coe, 23, stared straight down as Mrs. Coe testified that Bradley McGee's death came after weeks of her husband's torturing. Coe is charged with first-degree murder and aggravated child abuse. The state rested its case after Mrs. Coe's testimony. Bradley died of head injuries July 28, 1989, only two months after he was returned from state foster care to his mother and stepfather. Mrs. Coe agreed to testify against her husband after pleading no contest to second-degree murder and aggravated child abuse charges. She is serving 30 years in prison. Dressed in dark-blue prison garb, Mrs. Coe said her husband's disciplinary methods included forcing Bradley to stand in the corner with his hands on his head, making him eat feces off the ground and grinding his fist and cayenne pepper into the child's genitals. She testified that her husband had previously dunked Bradley in the toilet, but the last time came July 27, 1989, after Coe had returned from a job interview. Mrs. Coe said her husband became furious when she told him the child has ``made a mess'' in his pants. ``Tom took him back to the bathroom and dunked his head into the toilet several times,'' she said. She then described how Coe threw the boy under a cold shower ``with a clunk and a boom,'' and forced him to walk into the living room where they beat him with cushions ``until he collapsed and went into, like, an epileptic fit.'' Bradley was taken to Lakeland Regional Medical Center after a neighbor called for help. He was pronounced dead the next day. In a taped statement played for the jury Tuesday, Coe said he meant to scare the child. ``I turned him upside down and dunked him into the toilet. I don't know how many times I did it _ it happened so fast. I flushed it just to scare him,'' Coe said. ``I'm sorry I did it. I didn't mean to do it. I lost control. It was a bad day all the way around.'' Prosecutors are seeking the death penalty for Coe. Defense attorneys concede Coe dunked the child into the toilet, but say he should be convicted of a lesser crime because it was merely a one-time form of punishment and there was never any intent to harm the child. They have portrayed Mrs. Coe as an unstable, self-serving liar, arguing that she has changed her account of events at least four times. ``I was scared, I didn't know what to do,'' she said. Bradley's death came after a state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services caseworker recommended that a judge return the child to his mother, despite a psychological report that questioned the couple's abilities as parents and detailed their explosive personalities. Mrs. Coe had abandoned Bradley at a shopping mall when he was 3 months old. Public outrage over Bradley's death led legislators to change the law, placing child welfare above attempts to reunite families. Bradley's main caseworker, Margaret Barber, was convicted June 15 of felony child abuse, and sentenced to three months' probation. Three other caseworkers were cleared of criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Charles Lewis Recalled by Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thoroughout with defense recalling prosecution witness Charles Lewis. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry's lawyers recalled convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis to the stand Tuesday, suggesting he was at the center of a cocaine and prostitution ring whose members testified against the mayor. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy attacked Lewis' credibility and that of five of Lewis' friends who testified at Barry's cocaine and perjury trial. One of the government's chief witnesses, Lewis testified last month that Barry used cocaine and crack repeatedly on two trips to the Virgin Islands.
