The two smoked crack in a Washington, D.C., hotel room after the mayor dumped crack rocks out of a matchbox and pulled them out of one of his pants cuffs, Lewis testified earlier. In recalling Lewis, Mundy sought to undermine other witnesses, saying that City Attorney James McWilliams and two other men discussed ``a plan to distribute drugs.'' There was such a discussion, Lewis said. McWilliams has denied that he was involved in distributing drugs, but Lewis said he supplied McWilliams with drugs about a dozen times. McWilliams gave devastating testimony against Barry, testifying he found the mayor slumped on a bathroom toilet seat surrounded by narcotics paraphernalia. Mundy asked Lewis if four women who testified against Barry were working with or for him. ``No,'' said Lewis, who has acknowledged that he introduced all four to Barry when the mayor visited the Virgin Islands. Mundy asked if Lewis made the four women ``available ... to dignitaries visiting the Virgin Islands.'' Lewis said he did not. Did Lewis ``provide drugs to these ladies?'' Mundy asked. ``We shared,'' Lewis said. ``We would put money together.'' One of the four women testified that Barry forced her to have sex with him. Under questioning from Mundy, Lewis said the woman, Linda Crique Maynard, didn't appear to have been distraught after her time alone with Barry. Mundy also suggested that Maynard was related to one of the men who allegedly discussed drug distribution with McWilliams. Lewis said he didn't know if the two were related. Lewis said he had not heard from the four women since he began cooperating with the government last year. Mundy said Lewis gave different statements to the FBI a year ago than he did at Barry's trial. Lewis said law enforcement officers who interviewed him last year misunderstood what he said about who saw Barry allegedly smoke marijuana on a boat trip in the Virgin Islands. Earlier in the day, Barry's chauffeur testified that he never took the mayor to a municipal building the morning prosecutors say Barry picked up crack cocaine there. But on cross-examination by the prosecution, Walter W. Bracey said he had no memory of Barry's specific activities on any day other than Sept. 7, 1988. Bracey has been the mayor's driver for 12 years. Bracey said he drove to Barry's home Sept. 7, 1988, and took him directly to the grand opening of a supermarket. Bracey said he then drove Barry to fire department headquarters for a meeting with city officials. Barry stayed at the meeting until noon. ``Were there any stops made at any other location?'' Mundy asked. ``No,'' replied Bracey. Former crack dealer Lydia Reid Pearson has testified that she went to city offices the morning of Sept. 7, 1988, met with the mayor and ``handed him ... crack cocaine. ... He gave me the money for it'' and ``I gave him'' a job application seeking city employment. She eventually got a city job. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 cocaine possession counts, one count of conspiracy and three counts of lying to a grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Nun, Three Policemen Killed in Bomb Explosion Near Armagh
DOC.TEXT: A 1,000-pound bomb detonated by terrorists hiding near a rural road in this border city exploded Tuesday, killing a Roman Catholic nun and three policemen, authorities said. An anonymous caller claimed responsibility for the attack on behalf of the Irish Republican Army in North Armagh in a telephone call late Tuesday to a news organization in Belfast. The caller said the IRA had killed the four people in a ``military action,'' but expressed no regret over the nun's death. The slaying of a nun would be seen widely as a major embarrassment for the mainly Catholic IRA, which in recent months has escalated its terror campaign aimed at driving the British out of Northern Ireland. It was believed to be the first time a Catholic nun has been killed in 21 years of sectarian violence in British-run Northern Ireland, according to Jim Cantwell of the Catholic Press and Information Office. The terrorist attack _ one of the deadliest in Northern Ireland this year _aroused outrage among political and religious leaders on both sides of the Irish border. ``I know all the people of Ireland join me in my condemnation of this atrocity,'' Prime Minister Charles Haughey of the Irish Republic said in Dublin. The bomb set in a culvert under the road was detonated as an unmarked police car passed a hay field two miles outside Armagh, police said. The nun and a female social worker were approaching in a small car, police said. The blast hurled the police car into the air. It smashed into a hedge and landed on its roof, apparently killing the three policemen instantly. ``The ground shook beneath us and it was accompanied by a very large explosion,'' said Paul Corr, the owner of a nearby gas station. ``At first we did not see the police car,'' he said. ``The whole place was a terrible mess. Then we saw two young girls in the (mini Metro car). ... They were unconscious and looked in a pretty bad way.'' Corr helped emergency workers from a passing ambulance pull the injured women from their car. The nun, Sister Catherine Dunne, died later in a hospital. Her companion, whose name was not released, was listed in satisfactory condition, police said. No ages were available for the two women. ``There was nothing we could do for the policemen,'' added Corr. ``Nobody could have come out of that car alive. It was dreadful.'' The Royal Ulster Constabulary officers who died in the attack were identified by police as William Hanson, 37; David Sterritt, 34, and 35-year-old Joshua Willis. Two of the officers were married, one with four children and the other with two. The powerful explosion tore a crater 6-feet in diameter in the two-lane Killylea Road, near the border with the Republic of Ireland. The type of explosive used was not known, police said. Police and troops rushed reinforcements to the border area to search for the attackers. The area is considered prime territory for operations by the IRA. In Belfast, a police spokesman said an unknown number of gunmen took over a house about 400 yards from the road early Tuesday and held a married couple and their children at gunpoint until shortly before the 2 p.m. attack. Police said a detonating wire ran from the bomb through a freshly cut hayfield to near the house. The bombing was the deadliest terrorist attack in Northern Ireland since an IRA bomb killed four soldiers of the locally recruited Ulster Defense Regiment on April 9. It follows a spate of recent attacks by the IRA on British targets in England and continental Europe. On Friday, a bomb caused extensive damage to London's Stock Exchange, but no injuries were reported. A telephone caller had warned of an IRA bombing. In Armagh, the ancient religious capital of Ireland, church leaders condemned the latest attack. The town is the seat of both the Catholic and Anglican churches throughout Ireland, north and south. ``I am disgusted,'' declared the Most Rev. Robin Eames, the Anglican primate of Ireland. ``My reaction is one of absolute horror that somebody ... fulfilling their own calling as a nun has been murdered in what is one more indiscriminate attack on the Royal Ulster Constabulary.'' In Belfast, Britain's minister for security in Northern Ireland, John Cope, said, ``I have no doubt that we shall hear talk about mistakes and about legitimate targets and so on. ... Nobody deserves to be attacked in this way.'' Earlier this year, the IRA expressed regret after gunmen shot dead two Australian tourists who had been mistaken for British soldiers outside a restaurant in Holland on May 27. The slain nun was a member of the Sisters of St. Louis, an order of about 300 nuns throughout Ireland. Nearly 3,000 people have been killed since sectarian violence erupted in Northern Ireland in 1969 and the British government sent in troops. The IRA, outlawed on both sides of the border, is fighting to unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the overwhelmingly Catholic Republic of Ireland under a socialist government.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Complains That White House Not Equipped for Disabled
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, bgng, `The White House,' to UPDATE with White House comment; picks up 4th graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The White House lacks accessible restrooms and other facilities for disabled visitors and employees, a congressman said Tuesday. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., said in a letter to President Bush that a ``bewildering contradiction'' exists between the president's plans to sign major disabilities rights legislation and the existence of barriers to the disabled at the White House. A White House spokeswoman, Alixe Glen, said there would be no comment until the letter is received. According to Levine's office: _A former park ranger at the White House routinely crossed Pennsylvania Avenue and Lafayette Park to find a restroom she could enter with her wheelchair. When she complained, she was told to drink fewer liquids. _Some of the 30 children in wheelchairs who attended the Easter egg hunt on the White House lawn this year had to leave early because they couldn't use the portable toilets provided for visitors. _Unlike the Capitol, the White House provides no special tours for visitors with impaired hearing or vision. Bush plans to sign the Americans with Disabilities Act this week. The bill guarantees disabled employees and customers access to the workplace and to public accommodations. Federal buildings already are covered by a 1973 law, and Levine aide Jon Cowan said he could find nothing in that law to exempt the White House. President Franklin D. Roosevelt used a wheelchair as a result of polio, but Cowan said that none of the physical adjustments in the White House made for Roosevelt make life easier for visitors or employees.

DOC.HEAD: Gingrich Calls For Censure Of Frank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First 3 grafs new to show expulsion resolution could be introduced Wednesday; picks up 4th graf pvs, Republican floor; subs 9th graf to remove extraneous matter. ^By LARRY MARGASAK
DOC.TEXT: House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich, opening what could become a bitter partisan fight, said Tuesday he favors a censure, rather than a milder reprimand, of Rep. Barney Frank for using his office to help a male prostitute. Gingrich said he was not speaking for the House leadership, but his role as the chamber's second-ranking Republican could influence conservatives wavering between a censure and the lesser reprimand proposed by the ethics committee. The Georgia Republican's action leaves GOP members divided over how to punish Frank, a Massachusetts Democrat. While the committee resolution is scheduled for floor action Thursday, a move to expel Frank could be introduced and debated Wednesday by conservative GOP Rep. William E. Dannemeyer of California. The resolution, which would need a two-thirds vote, faces certain defeat. Republican floor leader Bob Michel of Illinois has not announced his position, but one influential member, Rep. John T. Myers of Indiana, said he will defend the reprimand in his role as ranking GOP member of the ethics committee. Gingrich also must contend with Democratic leaders, who are strongly backing the reprimand. Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington emphasized Monday and again Tuesday that he expected the unanimous ethics committee vote for a reprimand to be upheld. The panel has six Republicans and six Democrats. While Gingrich went public at a news conference, a group of Frank's liberal colleagues were quietly lobbying House members to uphold the committee. A reprimand is the lowest form of punishment voted on by the full House, and would involve approval of the ethics report. Frank's presence would not be required. A censure would require Frank to stand before his colleagues during the procedure. Also, Democratic caucus rules would require Frank, after a censure, to be stripped of his chairmanship of the House Judiciary subcommittee on administrative law and governmental relations. The most extreme punishment is expulsion, but even Gingrich said the action would be too extreme. But Gingrich's support of censure was enough to raise the political temperature, as Frank released an angry statement in response to the announcement. ``I am disappointed that there are efforts to politicize the ethics committee report, in sharp contrast to practice in the House in virtually every case,'' Frank wrote. ``As I said last week, I believe the ethics committee's 10-month long study has resulted in an accurate report and an appropriate recommendation.'' Gingrich said he based his conclusion on one of two official actions by Frank that, according to the committee, brought discredit upon the House. He referred to a 1986 Frank memo that contained misleading information favorable to the male prostitute, Stephen L. Gobie, who was convicted of sex and drug charges and was on probation at the time. The memo was written on Frank's official letterhead to an individual whose name was deleted by the ethics committee, but it wound up in the hands of a Virginia prosecutor. ``Should a United States congressman be allowed to misinform an officer of the court, which is the kinder way of saying to lie to an officer of the court, on behalf of a convicted felon who was a cocaine dealer and a child pornographer?'' Gingrich said at a news conference. ``Censure seems to me the minimum appropriate action,'' Gingrich said. The ethics committee also said Frank broke the rules when he used his office to have 33 parking tickets incurred by Gobie dismissed, and recommended that the House order him to make restitution to the District of Columbia. Gingrich insisted he was not engaging in gay-bashing, and commented Frank's ``private behavior is private. His sexual preferences are personal and I don't think they have any business in this dialogue.''

DOC.HEAD: Divided Bulgarian Parliament Fails to Elect President
DOC.TEXT: The deeply divided Parliament failed to elect a state president on Tuesday to replace Socialist Petar Mladenov, who resigned on July 6 in a row over asking for tanks to be used against demonstrators. Two rounds of voting failed to produce the two-thirds majority needed in the 400-seat Parliament to elect one of the three candidates. Contending were Chavdar Kyuranov of the governing Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party; Petar Dertliev, leader of the Social Democrats and the candidate of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces, or UDF; and Viktor Valkov of the mainstream Agrarian Party, which formerly was a Communist ally. In the first round, Kyuranov got 217 of the 383 valid ballots cast; Dertliev got 130, and Valkov, 36. A journalist for Bulgaria's official news agency BTA said that in the second round _ with fewer valid ballots cast _ Kyuranov got 211 votes; Dertliev, 131, and Valkov, 37. To win, 267 votes are needed. The Socialists hold 211 seats; the UDF, 144, and the Agrarians, 16. Also holding seats are six independents and 23 members of the Movement for Rights and Freedoms, which is mainly supported by members of Bulgaria's 1 million ethnic Turkish minority. The deep political rifts and the distribution of the seats made it unlikely any of the three candidates would secure the two-thirds majority. Political analysts and some deputies suggested that new candidates may be suggested following Tuesday's inconclusive votes. Balloting opened after four days of procedural wrangling between the Socialists and UDF. Opposition leader Zhelyu Zhelev threatened a walkout of his deputies Tuesday if there was no halt in what he called the obstructive tactics of the Socialists. Bulgaria has been without a president since Mladenov resigned 18 days ago after experts confirmed a recording on which he called for tanks to move against anti-government demonstrators last December. No tanks were used, but Mladenov previously had denied making the comment. At Tuesday's nationally televised Parliament session, each candidate outlined his program for dealing with spreading social and political unrest and Bulgaria's growing economic crisis. Kyuranov, a 69-year-old philosopher once expelled from the Communist Party for his dissident views, appealed for a coalition government but said the Socialists should face up to the responsibility of their Communist precursors for Bulgaria's woes. Dertliev, 73, recalled the repression of non-Communist forces after World War II, when he himself was imprisoned for his political views. He pleaded for tolerance now, and alone of the three candidates expressed support for peaceful political protests that have spread since last month's elections, won by the Socialists.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Silent on Abortion During Roles at Hospitals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, bgng `As with,' to CORRECT overseers to Medical School sted Medical Center
DOC.TEXT: Supreme court nominee David Souter was affiliated with two New Hampshire hospitals that perform abortions, but officials at both facilities said Tuesday that Souter never discussed the divisive issue. As with his judicial record, little about Souter's feelings about abortion can be gleaned from his performance as a board member of Concord Hospital or as an overseer to the Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical School, which has an affiliated hospital that performs abortions. Both hospitals have abortion guidelines; New Hampshire still has a law making some abortions tantamount to a felony. But those laws, which have not been enforced since the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion, never became an issue while Souter was serving either on the state Superior or Supreme courts. As a judge, Souter participated in just one known case dealing with abortion, siding with the majority in a 1986 ruling that said physicians have a responsibility to test unborn children for birth defects and in the event defects are detected to counsel the pregnant woman about options _ including abortion. Officials at the two hospitals said they had no recollection of Souter discussing abortion at meetings or in personal conversations. ``Over the course of time that I've been here that issue never came before the board,'' said Richard Warner, president of Concord Hospital. ``He and I never talked about it.'' Warner came to the hospital in May 1975, when Souter was a member of its board. Souter was president of the board from 1978-85. Warner and others couldn't provide a specific number, but said relatively few abortions are performed at the hospital. The procedure usually is done at area clinics or doctors' offices, the hospital officials said. At Concord Hospital and several area clinics, it's customary not to perform abortions after 17 weeks _ seven weeks short of the end of the second trimester, said hospital spokeswoman Beth Fensterwald. One exception is Dartmouth Hitchcock, where officials said there had been rare occasions when abortions have been performed up to the end of the second trimester. Those cases almost exclusively involve potential harm to the pregnant women, officials said. Written abortion guidelines at Dartmouth Hitchcock acknowledge a split among physicians and other staff over whether abortions should be performed. ``We feel very strongly that our patients have all alternatives discussed with them,'' the guidelines say. Dr. George A. Little, chairman of Dartmouth Hitchcock's child and maternal health department, said it was possible that the facility would refuse to perform an abortion for a woman past 17 weeks who didn't have a medical reason. Souter served on the overseers for the Dartmouth Medical School, which is affiliated with the hospital. Dr. Robert McCollum, who retired as dean of the medical school three weeks ago but remains on staff, said the overseers had no role in hospital affairs. He said that during the twice-a-year overseers' meetings Souter ``never mentioned the word abortion nor was the question raised during any meetings.''

DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Search for Cause of Mysterious Crop Circles
LaserPhoto LON5
DOC.TEXT: Engineers and photographers from the United States, Japan, West Germany and Britain have begun a high-technology investigation into what causes the mysterious circles that appear suddenly among crops in England and elsewhere in Europe. Equipped with $1.8 million worth of heat-seeking cameras and other sophisticated gear, they will be watching fields in the southwest county of Wiltshire for the next three weeks. They will try to capture on film whatever it is that flattens crops in decorative patters of perfectly formed circles, some with concentric rings, and other shapes. The circles have been variously attributed to whirlwinds, witches, magnetic forces, animals, hoaxers and spaceships. Team members are using light and sound equipment to try to locate the source in the Vale of Pewsey, a hilly district dividing Wiltshire between Salisbury Plain and the Marlborough Downs, 75 miles southwest of London. The circles were recorded in England as far back as 1678, but circles which appeared in a Vale of Pewsey wheat field last week were more elaborate than usual. The circles were linked and some had flattened straight areas like arms projecting from them. In other countries, circles have been reported in sand, snow and rice paddies. Colin Andrews, coordinator of the watch which began on Monday, said: ``This is a determined effort to secure on high-quality film the full event _ whatever that event will ultimately turn out to be.'' Amateur photographers who spent a night in the area last year saw nothing, but in the morning they found circles in a field behind them.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises to Tone Down Attacks in Budget Deficit War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with session for over for the day. ADDS quotes. Edits throughout to tighten. ^By TOM RAUM
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional Democrats agreed during a two-hour budget session Tuesday to tone down political attacks, but failed to narrow crucial differences on curing the federal deficit. At a later meeting, administration officials and congressional leaders of both parties failed again to agree to the overall size and components of the cuts they would make in next year's budget. But House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said the two sides could agree to the overall outline of a package by Wednesday. ``It's not as easy as it looks,'' Gephardt said. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., confirmed that the general consensus of the negotiators remained a package of about $50 billion in savings for next year, divided about evenly between tax increases and spending cuts. The bargainers have informally been using those numbers for several weeks. The sides agreed to a political cease-fire after Bush blistered Democrats last week at fund-raising events around the country, and Democrats responded in kind. ``He'll be very gentle'' from now on, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said of Bush. ``We need to concentrate on reducing partisan comments,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., adding that the peace pact applied to political campaign committees as well as individuals. At a midday speech to a GOP audience in Philadelphia, Bush said he saluted ``those Democrats in the leadership who are now working with me'' in reaching a budget agreement. However, he renewed his appeal for a constitutional amendment to balance the budget, saying it would end what he called an ``budget charade'' and ``fiscal follies'' in Congress. He also said that spending was ``out of control'' in ``Democrat-controlled House appropriations bills.'' Asked about Bush's remarks, Gephardt said: ``The president has to decide, all of us have to decide, if we want to bring this budget summit to a conclusion.'' A participant in Tuesday's budget bargaining, speaking on condition of anonymity, said no substantial progress was made. ``All the White House wants to talk about are entitlement cuts and domestic discretionary spending,'' the negotiator said. Entitlements are federal benefit programs such as Social Security and Medicare. The administration wants to cut those programs by about $14 billion, while Democrats would like to limit the reductions to $10 billion or less. Domestic discretionary programs cover general government initiatives such as environmental clean-ups and air traffic control. Republicans are more interested in cutting such programs than are Democrats. ``One of the things discussed today was to stop the political debate and start the substantive debate and to try to cut down on the political comment that's gone on on all sides,'' Gephardt said. ``I think you're going to see that that will happen,'' he added. ``I think a lot of that's out of everybody's system.'' In political speeches last week, Bush ridiculed the budget process and suggested that it was the Democrats' turn to make concessions on taxes and spending. Fitzwater told reporters on Air Force One en route to Philadelphia that Bush and the Democrats were ``working in a spirit of harmony and compromise.'' ``They agreed this morning at the meeting that they would try to keep the rhetoric under control and really try to make this a productive week of work,'' Fitzwater said. Another White House session with the five top congressional leaders _ Gephardt, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, Foley and House Minority Leader Bob Michel _ was scheduled for Wednesday morning. At the same time, a larger group of budget negotiators was meeting on Capitol Hill Tuesday in an effort to narrow differences. Despite the political truce, Bush and Congress seemed no closer to agreeing on a way to close the deficit gap than they were before the president revoked his 1988 ``no new taxes'' pledge in early July. The administration estimates that the deficit for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, will be nearly $169 billion _ more than $100 billion over the $64 billion target set by the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law. Foley, D-Wash., said decisions remain on the precise amount of deficit reduction that would be sought and how much of it would come from new taxes and spending cuts. ``I don't think there is at this point a clear definition of what each side wants,'' Foley told reporters. Noting Monday's 56-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average, Gephardt said: ``All through this I think people have been worried that the market is very touchy and the whole economy is very shaky.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Mercenary Readies Damage Suit Against Secord, Southern Air
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Hasenfus, a...,' to CORRECT model of plane to C-123 sted C-23; SUBS 5th graf, `The Sandinista...,' to restore dropped word ``about.''
DOC.TEXT: A CIA-linked airline would remain a target of a $135 million lawsuit filed by an American mercenary embroiled in the Iran-Contra scandal, a judge ruled Tuesday. Jury selection in the lawsuit filed by Eugene Hasenfus against retired Gen. Richard Secord and Miami-based Southern Air Transport was scheduled to begin Wednesday. Hasenfus, a cargo handler, or ``kicker,'' aboard a C-123 secretly supplying the Nicaraguan rebels, was captured after Nicaraguan troops shot down the plane in October 1986. He was the only survivor of the crash, which revealed details about U.S. government involvement in the flights. The Reagan administration later admitted that profits from arms sales to Iran were diverted to the Contras, despite a congressional ban on U.S. military aid to the rebels who sought to overthrow the leftist Nicaraguan government. The Sandinista government held Hasenfus, of Marinette, Wis., for about three months. In 1988, Hasenfus sued Secord and Southern Air, an airline once owned by the CIA and which continued to work under contract with the U.S. government. The family of a crewman who died aboard the plane, Wallace Sawyer Jr., has joined Hasenfus in a parallel suit that will be tried at the same time. Southern Air denies participating in the Contra supply operation. However, Senior U.S. District Judge C. Clyde Atkins ruled to keep the airline as a defendant. ``That was a good ruling for us, and it was a fair ruling,'' said Hasenfus' attorney Marc Sarnoff. Southern Air attorney David Kirstein said the ruling would limit the scope of the case to a contract dispute rather than a review of the Iran-Contra affair. ``Now it won't be a free-for-all,'' Kirstein said. Atkins also dropped a wrongful death claim from the Sawyer family suit, but allowed negligence claims to stand. Both Hasenfus and Wallace Sawyer Sr., father of the dead co-pilot, refused to comment Tuesday. The lawsuit claims Hasenfus was recruited in 1986 through the Pennsylvania airline Corporate Air Services and William Cooper, a Southern Air pilot. Cooper, who also died in the crash, led Hasenfus to believe ``the Contra resupply operation was being run `right out of the back door of the White House''' by former Reagan administration aide Oliver North, Secord and Southern Air, according to the lawsuit. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, pleaded guilty to lying to congressional investigators and was sentenced in January to two years' probation. The lawsuit claims Secord misrepresented the nature of the flights and failed to take routine safety precautions. Hasenfus said he was led to believe he was working for Southern Air through its subsidiary Corporate Air, on behalf of the U.S. government. In reality, the lawsuit claims, Secord was engaged in a profit-making scheme. The lawsuit also describes the plane as ``wholly inadequate and dilapidated,'' lacking such basic safety equipment as parachutes. Secord's attorneys describe Hasenfus as a mercenary _ earning about $3,000 a month _ who knew the risks associated with the flight. North and Elliot Abrams, former assistant secretary of state for Latin American Affairs, gave depositions for the trial. Expected to testify is Felix Rodriguez, the CIA official who ran the Contra supply operation out of El Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Souter a0734
DOC.TEXT: At 3:30 p.m. Monday President Bush summoned aides to the Oval Office and asked how quickly they could call a news conference. He wanted to announce his Supreme Court nominee that afternoon. Told they could be ready by 4:30 p.m., Bush said, ``I'd like another half-hour'' because he needed more time to make up his mind, a senior administration official said Tuesday. This official, who accompanied Bush on a campaign trip Tuesday, recalled events this way. He spoke with reporters on condition that his name not be used. Bush had spent much of Monday afternoon interviewing the two finalists for the high court vacancy, both federal appellate judges: Edith Jones, 41, of Houston, and David Souter, 50, of Concord, N.H. A third circuit court judge, Lawrence Silberman of Washington, had been ruled out of the running Sunday night, according to the source, who asked not to be identified. Souter had been summoned to Washington Sunday night, spending the night in the home of J. Michael Luttig, a Justice Department lawyer whom he had never met before. Luttig is an acting assistant attorney general in charge of the Office of Legal Counsel. Bush headed into his living quarters at the White House after saying goodbye to the president of Ecuador Monday afternoon. There Bush spent 45 minutes interviewing Souter, whom he placed on the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston just three months ago. White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray had already grilled Souter that morning about whether there was anything in his background that might prove embarrassing, such as the marijuana use that forced Douglas Ginsburg to withdraw as a Reagan administration nominee to the Supreme Court in 1987. Souter's answers ``were all satisfactory,'' the source said. Bush filled three yellow legal-sized pages with notes on Souter, under the heading ``plusses and minuses.'' He then returned to the West Wing, or business side of the White House, to interview Jones. Afterwards, both candidates cooled their heels elsewhere in the White House while Bush made up his mind. Souter was in the office of Andrew Card, the deputy White House chief of staff. At 4:15 p.m. Bush summoned his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, to the Oval Office. ``I have selected Judge Souter. Here's the bio. Where's the judge?'' the president asked. They agreed to proceed with a 5 p.m. announcement in the White House briefing room, and Fitzwater told reporters clustered outside his office that the president would be having a news conference with his nominee. Bush had filled out 2{ more pages of his thoughts about the selection, concluding that Souter was the right person for the job. ``The president was impressed by the fact that he's a humble man, quiet, studious,'' the official said. ``You get a sense of confidence that here's a serious person that's truly a student of the law.'' Bush called Souter into his private study next to the Oval Office to offer him the job. Souter said he would be honored. ``There's also a feeling this is a guy who wants to be a Supreme Court justice and is willing to devote his life to it,'' the official said. Souter, with an evident five o'clock shadow, was ``really kind of dazed'' when the walked into the briefing room with Bush. ``He doesn't know beans about a press conference,'' the official said. Souter had been told to expect to say a few words, but not to take questions. Bush didn't give the judge a chance until Fitzwater slipped the president a note several questions into the news conference. When Justice William J. Brennan Jr. announced his surprise resignation Friday, Bush was prepared. ``The president had been advised there would be an opportunity to name someone to the court in all likelihood in his first term,'' the official said. Also, ``it became clear that some of the special interests, particularly abortion and a few others, were going to try to build a public stew for this nominee to be dumped into'' if Bush failed to move quickly, the official said. After the announcement, the president, Souter, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Gray, and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu walked back to the Oval Office to watch television coverage. Souter called his mother at a nursing home in Concord and eventually spent the night at the home of John Schmidtz, a deputy White House counsel.

DOC.HEAD: Scouting Makes Strong Comeback in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Boy Scout and Girl Scout movements are making a strong comeback in Eastern Europe after decades of Communist repression, the World Organization of the Scout Movement said Tuesday after readmitting Hungary and Czechoslovakia. Scouting officials attending the 32nd World Conference of Scouting also received encouraging news about the prospects for the movement's revival in the Soviet Union, where Communist-controlled youth leagues replaced the pre-revolutionary scouting groups. In a letter read at the conference Tuesday, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev praised the ``noble objectives'' of the scouting movement. He also thanked the world organization for helping 1,235 youths from the region around the stricken Chernobyl nuclear power plant spend summer vacations in Western Europe. Gorbachev's letter was read by Albert Lichanov, president of the Soviet Children's Fund. He said the Soviet Union no longer sought to prevent the formation of independent youth organizations. ``More and more scouting movements exist,'' he said. Jacques Moreillon, secretary general of the world organization, said the Soviets had given ``a green light for the rebirth of scouting'' in the U.S.S.R. Scouting's status in Eastern Europe was a major topic during the first full day of the weeklong conference, which has brought together about 1,000 officials of national scouting organizations in more than 100 countries. ``In the past two years, there has been a spectacular renewal of scouting in Eastern Europe ... a spontaneous, intense movement,'' the world organization said in a memorandum distributed at the conference. The conference opened Monday night with a welcoming message from President Francois Mitterrand. Mitterrand saluted the scouting movement's ``universality'' and said its renaissance in Eastern Europe ``shows that scouting doesn't exist without democracy.'' Hungary and Czechoslovakia were among several countries accepted this week as members of the world organization. Others include Guinea, Comoros and newly independent Namibia. Hungary and Czechoslovakia had scouting programs until the 1950s, when they were suppressed by Communist authorities. The programs survived clandestinely, with occasional brief periods of legalization, until restrictions were lifted in 1988. Hungary now has about 10,000 Scouts, and Czechoslovakia more than 70,000, according to the World Scout Bureau. It also summarized the past and present status of scouting elsewhere in Eastern Europe: _The Soviet Union: There were nearly 100,000 scouts prior to 1917, but the movement was suppressed after the Bolshevik revolution. Now, scouting has revived in the Baltic republics, and the formation of scouting groups elsewhere is considered likely. _Poland: An active scouting program existed before World War II. In postwar years, the movement dropped out of the world organization, but an initiative began in March to qualify for readmission through policy reforms. _East Germany, Romania and Bulgaria: Scouting movements in these countries were persecuted systematically by the Nazis and their allies in the 1930s, and never were re-established fully. East Germany's program is expected to merge with West Germany's after unification. But in Bulgaria and Romania, the World Scout Bureau said, ``there are still great difficulties to overcome.'' The bureau is the central office for the World Organization of the Scout Movement, which represents about 16 million Scouts in 150 countries and territories. The largest scouting movements are in the United States with 3.9 million Scouts, the Philippines and Indonesia with about 2 million, India with 1.2 million and Britain with 681,000.

DOC.HEAD: Five Amateur Detectives Handle Mystery, Mayhem in CLUE Tournament
DOC.TEXT: Five super sleuths on a train bound for New York were expecting trouble even as they left the station. Before they reach their final destination, someone will die. It's up to them to find out whodunnit. A real-life murder mystery? Not quite. It's the first-ever U.S. CLUE championship, where amateur sleuths vie at the classic detective game created in 1947, which challenges players to figure out which of six characters commits the murder that starts the game. All the characters of the game turned out Tuesday afternoon for the one-day trip aboard the luxurious American-European Express. Miss Scarlet promenaded in a revealing black number; Professor Plum looked dapper in a brilliant purple dinner jacket and Col. Mustard strutted in his pith helmet. As the host welcomed his guests at the train station, a scream filled the air. ``Somebody's been shot!'' Miss Scarlet said. ``Danger! Danger on the train!'' cried Mrs. White, the maid, as she waved her purple dust whisk where Mr. Boddy lay sprawled on the carpet, blood pouring from his head. The ``Case of the Dead Boddy'' was under way. Which of the six characters was the killer? The sultry Miss Scarlet with a wrench? Rich Mr. Green with a gun? Dowdy Mrs. Peacock with a candlestick? The sleuths had 24 hours to find out _ and before they did, another murder was to take place. Unlike in the board game, where each player takes on the persona of one of the color-themed characters in the mystery, Tuesday's contestants watched actors portray Mr. Mustard, Miss Scarlet and the others. They also got to ask the characters questions. Busily taking notes, watching everything, the five contestants had little time to speak to reporters about the crime. ``How do I know you're who you say you are?'' photographer Sharon Dennison of Burbank, Calif., asked, watching in suspicion as a reporter reached into his jacket for identification. The contestants, who were chosen based on 250-word mysteries they wrote, were to complete three rounds of play, tallying points as they went along. The first round was a traditional board game of CLUE held at the train station. The trail for clues then took the detectives to Chicago's WaterTower Place shopping mall, where each jealously guarded his or her finds. ``This is great fun,'' said Katie Anders of New York City. ``When I was a kid, all my friends were watching cartoons. I was watching `I Led Three Lives,''' said Anders, a real-life mystery writer. The person who gathered the most clues at WaterTower would receive the second-round points. The contestants, who also included a retired judge, a playwright and the owner of an electronics company, were to compete for more points on the overnight train ride by questioning characters, observing clues in different cars, and then guessing the killer and his or her motive. Before the train pulled into Grand Central Station on Wednesday afternoon, the criminal would be revealed, and the contestant with the most points would be crowned winner, giving that person a chance to compete in an international CLUE tournament in Europe in September. Officials at Parker Brothers, which sponsored the interactive murder mystery, were hush-hush about who the murderer was, but Mrs. White was heard to remark, ``I can't imagine any of us hurting a fly.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Emerges from Hiding for Meeting with President
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer who had been threatened with arrest for his links to the campaign for multiparty democracy emerged from hiding Tuesday to hold what he termed a ``positive'' meeting with President Daniel arap Moi. The lawyer, Paul Muite, said Moi criticized some of his views during their wide-ranging 40-minute discussion at the president's official residence, but added that overall the meeting was cordial. Muite said Moi told him he was free to return to work. The talks come one day after Muite issued a statement calling for the release of political detainees. He also denied involvement in recent politically inspired riots in which at least 28 people died. Moi on Sunday accused Muite of fomenting the violence and urged him to come out of hiding and apologize in person. Muite went underground July 5, one day after two of his clients, former Cabinet ministers Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, were detained under security statutes that allow them to be held indefinitely without charge. The politicians had been at the forefront of the campaign to legalize opposition parties. Following the arrest of Rubia and Matiba, 15 other people linked to the democracy campaign were arrested. Muite said Moi's only mention of the political detainees was to say ``that he does not take any pleasure in detaining people.'' ``I thought that was very positive,'' Muite told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. Moi has come under criticism at home and abroad for the detentions of the pro-democracy activists and his government's handling of the recent riots in Nairobi and other cities. More than 1,400 people were charged in connection with the July 7-10 riots in which mobs of stone-throwing youths clashed with police, stores were looted and vehicles burned. The rioting broke out and spread after police used tear gas and gunfire to disperse a pro-democracy rally in Nairobi. The rally had been proposed by Matiba and Rubia, the leaders of a loose alliance of prominent Kenyans who accused the government of widespread corruption and election rigging and called for political change. Kenya banned its last opposition party in 1969. Kenya became a one-party state by law in 1982. Moi has rejected calls for political pluralism, claiming it could lead to tribal-based parties and possibly warfare.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Halts Multiple Prosecution Of Mail-Order Pornography
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge stopped the Justice Department's anti-pornography unit from prosecuting a mail-order distributor of sexually-oriented magazines and videos in more than one jurisdiction. U.S. District Judge Joyce Hens Green issued the preliminary injunction on Monday after finding evidence to suggest that federal prosecutors had investigated PHE, Inc. with the intention of forcing the North Carolina company, also known as ``Adam and Eve,'' out of business. The allegations by the company, and its owner, Philip D. Harvey, ``suggest a concerted effort ... through harassment and threats of multiple prosecution, to suppress plaintiffs' constitutionally protected activities,'' the judge said. She issued a preliminary injunction barring the Justice Department from bringing charges in more than one federal jurisdiction at one time. Bruce Ennis, who represented the company, said the Justice Department's National Obscenity Enforcement Unit has pursued a strategy of trying to wear down the financial resources of sexually oriented businesses by threatening to bring a series of indictments in numerous jurisdictions. He said Green's ruling ``casts a real cloud over the National Obscenity Enforcement Unit's new tactic of threatening multiple indictments as a way of coercing adult materials distributors to go out of business.'' Ennis presented evidence that the Justice Department used similar tactics to force Pak Ventures, another distributor of adult magazines and videos, to go out of business. In her ruling, Green noted that ``it is not without significance that defendants have not contested, disputed, or refuted any of the factual assertions contained in the declarations presented by plaintiffs.'' ``Taken as a whole, these allegations suggest a concerted effort by the defendants, through harassment and threats of multiple prosecutions, to suppress plaintiffs' constitutionally protected activities.'' ``Intrusive and intimidating'' searches of the company's Carrboro, N.C. offices, and ``the admitted desire to get Harvey `out of business' substantiate plaintiffs' allegations of bad faith,'' Green ruled. Federal prosecutors in Utah and the western district of Kentucky had threatened to bring charges against Adam and Eve. Earlier threats were made in the eastern district of North Carolina, even though the FBI had advised prosecutors that the materials distributed by PHE were not obscene by bureau standards, according to the ruling. In 1988, another federal judge issued a similar injunction to bar multiple prosecutions of Avram Freedberg and his Stamford, Conn., company. Freedberg ultimately entered a guilty plea, agreed to get out of the mail-order business and dropped his lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Chronology of Liberian Unrest Since December Uprising
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: December 24 _ Two groups of rebels led by Charles Taylor cross the border from the Ivory Coast. One group attacks a customs station in eastern Nimba County and the other heads toward the capital of Monrovia.

January 3 _President Samuel K. Doe fires his internal affairs minister, Col. Edward Sackor, and Stephen Daniels, superintendent of Nimba County, for mishandling reports of the rebel invasion. January 5 _ Fighting between Liberian forces and rebels opposed to Doe destroys two towns in northeastern Liberia and sends thousands fleeing across the border. March 31 _ The government orders journalists to submit for review all reports on fighting between its forces and rebels in Nimba County. May 7 _ Doe calls for negotiations with rebel forces on ending their four-month insurgency. May 29 _ Doe asks the legislature to call early elections after rebel forces move within 35 miles of the capital and take control of most of the country's major economic enterprises.
June 1 _ Doe announces he will not run for re-election, and he asks the United States and other nations to help end his nation's civil war. June 5 _ State Department officials say the American military has ``no role to play'' in Liberia's internal conflict even though more than 2,000 Marines are poised offshore to help evacuate U.S. citizens from the African nation. June 8 _ The government says it is willing to accept a cease-fire and begin negotiating with a rebel army. June 10 _ Rebels win control of Liberia's international airport. June 12 _ A delegation of Liberian rebels arrives for talks with government officials aimed at ending the fighting. June 16 _ The Liberian government proposes a 30-day cease-fire in its 5{-month civil war with rebel forces.
June 25 _ Liberian rebels break off peace talks with the government, announce plans to attack Monrovia. July 7 _ Liberia's shattered government announces cease-fire on a makeshift radio station and appeals to shops to open and government workers to return to their offices. July 12 _ Peace talks begin in Freetown, Sierra Leone, between delegations representing the Liberian rebels and the Doe government. July 19 _ Foreign Minister J. Rudolph Johnson and other prominent Liberians appeal to the United States for a temporary U.S. peacekeeping force to help prevent further bloodshed. July 21 _ Doe expels the U.S. military attache. A government communique accuses the head of the U.S. mission, Col. David Staley, of providing support to the rebels and urging government forces to defect. July 23 _ In a surprise attack, fighters from a splinter rebel group led by Prince Johnson wade across a swamp to shoot their way into the capital's center.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Relief Convoy Reaches Besieged Mohawks in Quebec
With AM-Mohawks-Dispute, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Red Cross relief team crossed police barricades and distributed relief supplies Tuesday to the Mohawks at Oka, the second such convoy since an armed standoff began July 11 between Indians and Quebec police. Efforts to end the confrontation have stalled. The dispute arose over attempts to expand a golf course onto what natives say is ancestral land. One policeman has been killed, but responsibility in the death has not been fixed. The Mohawks of Kanasetake refused conditions set Monday by the Quebec government for resuming negotiations. Red Cross official Linda Gauthier said the agency distributed milk, bread, bananas, oranges, laundry soap, sanitary napkins and toilet paper on Tuesday and hopes to be able to check on the situation every two or three days. She had made a spot check in Indian territory Monday night and other food or medical supplies did not appear to be needed. Ms. Gauthier said no one was starving but there are ``vulnerable'' people who need regular medical monitoring. She said the Red Cross now needs written agreement by all parties in the dispute before each visit, and is trying to negotiate a blanket agreement that will allow regular trips into Kanasetake every three or four days. The Kanasetake Mohawks have drawn support from other Indians across Canada, including roadblocks in British Columbia and a blockade by other Mohawks of the Mercier Bridge into Montreal, 18 miles from Oka. The federal government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney so far has left it up to Quebec provincial authorities to resolve the dispute. The Mohawks demanded that Mulroney's government become involved and also appealed to President Bush and the United Nations, among others. A representative of the Mohawks, Atsenhaienton, also known as Kenneth Deer, was in Europe to gain international attention for the confrontation. He planned to visit embassies in Geneva to ask for economic sanctions on Canada. He will argue that Canada's treatment of aboriginal people is on a par with South Africa's treatment of blacks, the Toronto Globe and Mail newspaper reported Tuesday. Among Mohawk demands are that the golf club development be abandoned at once; that police withdraw; that shipments of food, clothing, medical supplies and the like be freely allowed behind Indian lines, and that observers from either the United Nations or Amnesty International be brought in.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Calls Credit Union Sex Scandal A Hoax
DOC.TEXT: A story of sexual abuse, prostitution and judicial bribery told to a legislative committee investigating an Omaha credit union failure was ``a carefully crafted hoax,'' a grand jury said Tuesday. In a 42-page report, the Douglas County grand jury debunked many of the rumors that have surrounded the 1988 failure of the Franklin Community Federal Credit Union. Besides its report, the grand jury also issued three indictments, two of them charging perjury against witnesses who claimed to the Legislature that they were victims. A federal grand jury also is investigating Franklin-related matters. The county grand jury said it decided that financial matters, including a fund shortage of about $39 million, were best left to the federal grand jury. ``Perhaps never in the history of Douglas County has the discordant multitude played so feverishly upon the rumor pipe as in the allegations of sexual misconduct surrounding Franklin,'' the grand jury report said. In the wake of the Franklin collapse, allegations and rumors arose of sexual abuse of children, of an adult male homosexual prostitution ring, of drug use and cult activities, some involving prominent citizens. The grand jury cited many prominent residents by name and cleared them of wrongdoing. Its report indicated that the names may have been raised in rumors because of their prominence. The grand jury said it found ``no credible evidence of child sexual abuse, interstate transportation of minors, drug trafficking or participation in a pornography ring'' by former Franklin manager Lawrence E. King Jr., or other Franklin officials and employees. King, a prominent businessman who sang the national anthem at the 1984 Republican National Convention, still faces 40 counts in federal court of conspiracy, fraud and federal income tax evasion. He is accused of diverting money for personal use. He was ruled incompetent to stand trial and is receiving psychiatric treatment. Those indicted by the grand jury included Alisha J. Owen and Paul A. Bonacci, who had claimed they were victims and gave videotaped statements to the special legislative committee investigating Franklin-related matters. ``There is no doubt, after reviewing all relevant evidence, that the story of sexual abuse, drugs, prostitution, and judicial bribery presented in the legislative videotapes is a carefully crafted hoax, scripted by a person or persons with considerable knowledge of the people and institutions of Omaha,'' the grand jury report said. Ms. Owen, 21, of Omaha, was charged with eight counts of perjury and Bonacci, 22, also of Omaha, was indicted on three counts of perjury. The grand jury also handed up an indictment charging two counts of pandering against Alan A. Baer, 67, an Omaha businessman who once owned an Omaha-based department store chain. The indictment accused Baer of giving something of value to two males to become a prostitute or commit an act of prostitution. But the grand jury reported it didn't find any connection between Baer and the credit union. Its report said many of the allegations made against Baer were false and ``it appears Baer was written into the script because of his wealth ...'' Baer's office referred calls to his attorney, Steve Seline, who stressed that Baer was cleared of any sexual exploitation of minors. Seline said the pandering charges against Baer, which involved adults, were ``incorrect and inappropriate.'' Ms. Owen is serving time in the Nebraska Center for Women in York for writing bad checks. She was declining all interviews, said Lawrence Wayne, superintendent of the women's prison. Her attorney, Henry C. Rosenthal Jr., was out of town and unavailable for comment Tuesday, his Omaha office said. Bonacci is serving time in the Lincoln Correctional Center for sexually assaulting a boy and could not be reached for comment Tuesday. The grand jury reported it hadn't found any evidence to support allegations against former Omaha World-Herald publisher Harold Andersen. In March, Andersen acknowledged he had been named in the rumors, and said he had done nothing improper. ``The grand jury found no evidence to support allegations that Harold Andersen was involved in sexual misconduct of other illegal activity,'' said the grand jury report. Andersen's only connection with Franklin was as co-chair of the fund-raising committee for a new credit union building. The motive for naming him ``was probably politically generated due to his position as publisher of the Omaha World-Herald at that time,'' it said. The grand jury said Michael Casey, a former Omaha resident who has described himself as an investigative free-lance reporter, helped spread the rumors. Casey, 45, was arrested Monday on a South Dakota warrant for allegedly writing an insufficient-fund check 23 months ago. The arrest came less than an hour after he finished testifying before the federal grand jury in Omaha. The county grand jury report said Casey became fascinated with the Franklin case and ``endeavored to cover the `real' Franklin story, listening to street rumors, spending time with members of Omaha's gay community, and seeking out potential victim-witnesses.''

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Asks Museum to Describe Planned Season
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts has asked an outpost of avant-garde art to provide a detailed description of its upcoming season within 30 days or face a loss of funding, both parties said Tuesday. The endowment called it a routine request. But the Franklin Furnace Archives, a Manhattan museum that presents experimental performance and visual art, described it as ``harassment'' aimed at performances some consider obscene. ``The NEA is making this request because the Furnace's whole purpose on this earth is to show avant-garde art,'' said Barbara Pollack, the museum's spokeswoman. Such art ``doesn't fit in with (Sen. Jesse) Helms' definition of what should receive funding,'' she added. The four performance artists whom the NEA turned down for grants in June have performed at Franklin Furnace or received funding from it, Pollack said. And an installation by Karen Finley, one of the four, is currently on display at the organization's gallery. In one of her performance pieces, Finley dances nude and smears her body with chocolate to show the degradation of women. Martha Wilson, founder and director of Franklin Furnace, was traveling and unavailable for comment on the endowment's request. The request came after Franklin Furnace was notified in early June that the NEA had approved a $20,000 grant for its visual and performing arts programs and a $7,500 grant for audience development. The museum accepted the grant, signing the anti-obscenity pledge the NEA requires of grantees. Congress last year put strings on government aid to the arts by adding language to a 1990 spending bill that forbids the endowment from funding works that might be deemed obscene. In a letter dated July 13 but received Monday, the NEA asked Franklin Furnace for ``identification of the artists involved and the nature of the work to be performed or installed'' in order to make a ``final determination'' on its grant application. Failure to respond to the request within 30 days ``will result in the rejection of this application,'' Julianne R. Davis, the endowment's general counsel, wrote to Franklin Furnace. The NEA's request was first reported in The Philadelphia Inquirer on Tuesday. In a statement Tuesday, Davis said, ``A number of endowment programs have, for many years, routinely required the submission of additional information at appropriate times.'' Many arts organizations have not fully booked their upcoming season when they apply for grants, and it is not unusual for the NEA to later request a description of what is planned, said Kathy Christie, an endowment spokeswoman. Pollack is suspicious, however. She cited a June 21 call from the General Accounting Office asking for information on four performance artists, including Finley. She said the GAO had been asked by Helms, the Republican senator from North Carolina, in March to look into ``possible violations of law by the NEA.'' Now, she said, ``What they want to do is get a broader list of who to investigate. We do not want to assist them in developing a blacklist.''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Recovers 10 Red Eye Missiles from Former Contras
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista police recovered 10 surface-to-air Red Eye missiles from former rebels, Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado said Tuesday, a sign that the Contra guerrillas kept some weapons when they demobilized. Hurtado, in charge of police and security forces, also said two armed men captured Saturday admit being members of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the Salvadoran guerrilla alliance. He told a news conference at the foreign correspondents' club that the two would be turned over to a third country but did not elaborate. Police on Monday recovered three of the heat-seeking missiles in Ciudad Rama and the other seven in El Almendro. Both towns are in southeastern Nicaragua and El Almendro is the heart of one of the development centers the former rebels have been promised. Hurtado did not say whether arrests were made or give details on how the missiles were recovered except to say they had been held by former Contras. By the time the Contras disarmed in mid-June, they had turned in more than 100 Red Eyes, among thousands of other weapons. But it has been estimated that before the United States stopped military aid to the guerrillas in February 1989, it gave the Contras about 400 Red Eyes. Hurtado said the 10 missiles would be turned over to a United Nations mission supervising regional peace accords, including Contra demobilization, and would be destroyed. Despite Contra demobilization after President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro took office April 25, thousands of weapons remain in private hands. The outgoing Sandinistas turned over huge quantities to their supporters before leaving office. The new government asked that the weapons be turned in but made no move to force the issue. Sandinistas still dominate the army and police force. Hurtado said police have intercepted 1,100 pounds of cocaine since Mrs. Chamorro became president. He said drug traffickers seem to be taking advantage of peacetime conditions in Nicaragua to use the country as a transfer point.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Machine Ban Approved by Pittsburgh
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette vending machines would be banned from stores, fast-food outlets and most other public places under a measure approved Tuesday by the City Council. The ordinance, intended to make it harder for minors to get cigarettes, goes to Mayor Sophie Masloff, who has 10 days to sign or veto it. As a member of council in 1987, she cast the deciding vote for an ordinance banning smoking in most public places in the city. The measure, approved 7-1 by the council, bans cigarette vending machines except in bars and private clubs, factories, private businesses, offices or ``other private facilities not open to the general public.'' Places affected by the ban include grocery and retail stores, fast-food and family restaurants, service stations, bus stations, sports arenas and hotels. Institutions such as hospitals and universities can have cigarette machines in areas that are open only to to employees. Councilman Gene Ricciardi, who opposed the measure, said the bill would place ``an additional burden on the small business owner.''

DOC.HEAD: Bad Switch Replaced; Launch Attempt Set for Wednesday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with launch set for Wednesday. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Monday's launch ...'.
DOC.TEXT: NASA and rocket builder General Dynamics said they would try again Wednesday to launch an unmanned Atlas carrying a government scientific satellite. Liftoff was scheduled for 3:21 p.m. from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. Workers on Tuesday replaced a bad switch, which was designed to switch the rocket from external electrical power to its own batteries. Monday's launch attempt was called off after the Atlas failed to transfer to internal power just before liftoff. Bad weather forced postponement of Sunday's launch attempt, while a helium leak was responsible for Friday's unsuccessful try. The rocket's payload, the $189 million Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite, is a joint program of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Defense Department. The satellite is designed to illuminate Earth's normally invisible magnetic field lines.

DOC.HEAD: Baker to Pursue End to Afghan War
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Najibullah, one word, is CQ
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will take up with his Soviet counterpart hints from Moscow of a readiness to make a deal aimed at ending the 12-year-old civil war in Afghanistan, an administration official said Tuesday. But the official disputed a report from Moscow by ABC News that Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Baker already had cut a deal. Baker leaves Wednesday on a four-nation trip to Asia. He is scheduled to meet Shevardnadze in the Soviet Siberian city of Irkutsk on Aug. 1. The Soviets have not yet conveyed to the United States how Afghan President Najibullah might be removed from power in Kabul, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. For weeks the Bush administration has hoped for a breakthrough to end to war between Afghan government forces armed by the Soviet Union and a guerrilla coalition fighting with American-supplied weapons funnelled through Pakistan. But the Soviets failed this month to send a delegation to Washington for talks on the major obstacle to a settlement based on a cease-fire and elections _ that is, when Najibullah should yield power. Both sides already have reached a tacit agreement that Najibullah would play no role in the new government and would step down at some point before his successor take over. ``The Soviets hinted at a deal; they haven't fleshed it out,'' the official said. ``The thread of the deal is going to be pursued in Irkutsk by Baker.'' Administration officials did not find fault with Moscow for not sending the delegation to Washington. They said they thought the Kremlin was simply preoccupied with the 28th Communist Party Congress at the time. But when Baker saw Shevardnadze in Paris last Wednesday, again there was no major development on the Afghan front, the official said. The Soviet Union installed the Najibullah government in 1979, but the government in Kabul has been unable to impose its will on the countryside. The Soviets withdrew their troops last year but continued arms supply. Both superpowers have grown weary of the effort to defeat the other side's client in Afghanistan. The Senate Intelligence Committee, according to congressional sources, reflected this disenchantment Tuesday in voting for a cut about $100 million in the current $300 million annual aid for Afghan rebels. In a report attributed to unspecified western diplomatic sources, ABC said the Baker-Shevardnadze agreement called for an end to arms supplies for both sides. The United States had abandoned its position that Najibullah must go. The official who spoke with The Associated Press called the network report ``premature.'' The 2\-hour Paris meeting was dominated by Cambodia. Afterward, Baker, announced that the United States had withdrawn its diplomatic support from a rebel coalition that included the Khmer Rouge and would hold talks with Vietnam, supporter of the government in Phnom Penh and an ally of the Soviet Union. The State Department announced Tuesday that Kenneth Quinn, a deputy assistant secretary, will meet with Vietnam's ambassador to the United Nations in New York on Aug. 6. On his Asia trip Baker will also attend a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations in Indonesia; hold talks in Singapore and visit to outer Mongolia after seeing Shevardnadze.

DOC.BYLINE: Newspaper Executive Named CNN President ^By JAY SHARBUUTT
DOC.TEXT: Cable TV magnate Ted Turner on Tuesday named former Los Angeles Times publisher Tom Johnson as the new president of his Cable News Network, effective Aug. 1. Johnson called himself ``a strong champion of hard news'' who will try to expand CNN's overseas bureaus. He will succeed Burt Reinhardt, 70, CNN's president since 1982, who has been with the network since its start ten years ago. Johnson, who joined the Times in 1977 and now is its chairman and vice-chairman of the parent Times Mirror Co., said he'd first spoken with Turner about the new job less than a month ago. Johnson, whom Turner said was introduced to him by a mutual friend, said that during his first six weeks at work he'd just listen and learn. He plans no sweeping changes at CNN, he added: ``I am not a believer in Saturday night massacres. I believe in working with the people who are in place.'' He and Turner, chairman of Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System, spoke at a telephone news conference from Seattle, site of the Goodwill Games sports festival that TBS is sponsoring at a possible loss of $26 million. Turner said he made the change because Rheinhardt is 70 ``and everybody's got to retire some time.'' Turner emphasized that he has no plans to sell CNN, nor any plans ``to merge or jointly gather news with any other U.S. news organizations.'' NBC several years ago proposed buying part of CNN, but backed out when Turner refused to give up editorial control of the 24-hour news organization. Johnson, a former White House fellow, was President Johnson's special assistant in 1968. He was the Times' publisher for nine years until succeeded last August by David Laventhol, president of Times Mirror Co. Johnson said he's leaving the Times because ``quite frankly, it was time for a change...I'm looking forward to getting back to running a media organization. ``I feel much more comfortable in a quarterback role than I do a coaching role,'' he said, alluding to his current jobs in Los Angeles. Asked about his seeming lack of TV experience, Johnson noted that others have made the transition from print to broadcasting, including Walter Cronkite and Richard C. Wald, a senior ABC News execuutive and former NBC News president. He also said that he has some experience in broadcasting, having worked for two years as executive vice president of Texas Broadcasting Corp., whose holdings included station KBTC-TV in Austin. The company was owned by Lyndon Johnson's family until the former president's death in 1973. CNN says it has 1,700 full and part-time staffers, is seen in 55 million U.S. homes, and has viewers in 90 countries. Reinhardt, who CNN says plans to retire later, will become vice chairman of CNN and advise Johnson during a transition period. Johnson also will serve as Turner Broadcasting System's vice president for news and as a member of TBS' executive committee. He will report directly to Turner.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Seeks Compensation, Damages from U.S. in Airbus Downing
DOC.TEXT: Iran asked the World Court on Tuesday for punitive damages and compensation from the U.S. government for the July 3, 1988, downing of an Iranian commercial jetliner by a U.S. Navy missile. The 300-page brief, termed a memorial in World Court parlance, apparently set no monetary figures. All 290 people aboard the Airbus were killed. Iran also asked the court to order the United States to refrain from violating international law, and rebuked the U.S. government for its continued naval presence in the Persian Gulf. The Airbus was hit by a missile from the U.S.S. Vincennes, part of a task force in the gulf during the Iran-Iraq war. The jet, bound from Bandar Abbas to Dubai, was mistaken as an attacking warplane in the closing days of the war. Investigations showed the plane was in a normal climbing pattern when hit. Iran also submitted three volumes of exhibits. It sought compensation for families of the victims of the Airbus downing; for the Tehran government, and for the airline, Iran Air. It asked punitive damages for what it called ``the criminal nature of the act.'' Iran demanded a ``reparations declaration,'' but did not specify in the memorial's introduction what that declaration would involve. Elements of the introduction were obtained by The Associated Press. Iran filed the case in May 1989, and the Bush administration said it would take part in the proceedings. Washington has until March 4 to file its corresponding memorial. The court, the judicial arm of the U.N., has no enforcement powers and depends on the voluntary adherence of states coming before it. Iran's memorial was intended to prove that the court has jurisdiction over the case and to state the facts of its claim. The memorial said America refused to accept responsibility for the Airbus downing and continued to provoke Iran by its naval presence in the gulf. It also wants the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization to reverse a November 1988 refusal to condemn Washington for the incident. Iran said the United States violated Iranian sovereignty as well as U.N. Charter provisions barring the use of force and assuring freedom of navigation. Besides Iranians, the plane carried passengers from India, Italy, Kuwait, Pakistan, Yugoslavia and United Arab Emirates. Then-President Reagan announced an offer of compensation to victims' families eight days after the incident. The compensation process for non-Iranian victims began in 1989 _ $250,000 to the families of wage-earners, $100,000 to the families of other victims. Iran insisted on being compensated directly for the downing, and refused to provide a list of eligible next of kin. Iran's compensation demands include for life lost, mental suffering, the loss of the plane itself, and the cost of search and rescue operations. The World Court case is likely to be handled by the U.S. and Iranian officials representing their governments at the Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Gives Green Light to Build Voice of America Station
DOC.TEXT: The National Planning Board on Tuesday reversed its decision to delay construction of a Voice of America relay station after U.S. officials pleaded for an immediate go-ahead despite environmentalist protests. Israel's Nature Protection Society said it will appeal to the Supreme Court. The board initially voted in June to halt the project in Israel's Arava desert for a two-year ecological study of bird migrations, which environmentalists said could be disturbed by the transmitter. Environmentalists also spoke of possible radiation health hazards. The U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv said in a statement it was ``pleased by today's vote ... and looks forward to rapid approval by the government of Israel and early construction of the station.'' Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's aide, Avi Pazner, also expressed satisfaction. The U.S. government runs VOA. Tuesday's approval of the $300 million facility came a day after Washington repeated assurances the transmitter would cause no harm. U.S. Ambassador William Brown wrote to Communications Minister Rafael Pinhasi stressing the importance the United States attaches to the project. The National Planning Board includes representatives of 11 ministries. It must approve all major national construction projects. Final approval is up to the Cabinet. The station will transmit VOA broadcasts to Eastern Europe and Africa. It was conceived as a Cold War tool, but U.S. officials said it was also valuable in the era of detente.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Shiite Forces Battle for Control of Strategic Lebanon Town
DOC.TEXT: Militiamen loyal to Syria battled house-to-house Tuesday in an effort to dislodge Iranian-backed rival Shiite Moslems from a strategic hilltop town near Israel's enclave in southern Lebanon. Police said 13 combatants were killed and 59 wounded in the ninth day of fighting for control of the town of Jarjou and surrounding villages near Israel's self-proclaimed ``security zone.'' The fighting raged into the evening as militiamen battled with automatic weapons, shoulder-fired grenade launchers and hand grenades, but there was no clear victor, police said. A police spokesman said about 1,500 fighters of the Amal militia launched a pre-dawn attack on Jarjou behind a rain of mortar shells and rockets. They were backed by about 500 pro-Syrian Lebanese Baath Party militiamen. The attackers pushed through the defenses of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, said the police spokesman, who cannot be identified by name under briefing rules. In close-quarter combat, the attackers drove the Hezbollah forces back toward the town's northern sector, the spokesman said. Flames, smoke and dust obscured the embattled town as thunderous blasts of artillery shells reverberated across the rugged hills of Iqlim al-Tuffah. Baathist and Amal communiques claimed their fighters overran more than half of Jarjou. But Hezbollah contended the attack was repulsed in a ``new bloodbath.'' Both Amal and Hezbollah put out fresh claims that Israeli border gunners had pounded their positions in and around Jarjou. The claim could not be independently verified. Amal attempted to recapture Jarjou with the support of Palestinian guerrillas on Friday. But the attack failed after two days of close combat. The Palestinians apparently took no part in Amal's new attack. Tuesday's casualties raised the overall toll to 139 dead and 427 wounded since July 16, when Hezbollah wrested Jarjou from Amal in a surprise attack, touching off the latest round in a three-year, on-and-off confrontation. At stake is control of the 1.2. million Shiites who make up the largest single sect in Lebanon. The Baathist intervention on Amal's side suggests the Syrian government of President Hafez Assad wants to curb Iran's growing influence through Hezbollah. The Baath militiamen were sent to the south last week, but had kept a low profile until Tuesday's fighting. Syria, which was Persian Iran's main Arab ally in the eight-year Persian Gulf war against Arab Iraq, views Lebanon as its own backyard. The Syrians have 40,000 troops stationed in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab League mandate to quell Lebanon's Moslem-Christian civil war, now in its 16th year. But the Syrian army has refrained from entering southern Lebanon to avoid a collision with Israel. Israel has said it will not tolerate a Syrian military presence near its border with Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Networks Enlist Allies In Fight For Syndication Rights
DOC.TEXT: A major television network claimed new allies Tuesday in the networks' fight to change TV syndication rules while a motion picture industry leader accused NBC, CBS and NBC of trying to stifle competition. NBC told the Federal Communications Commission that the million-member National Education Association and the advocacy group, Action for Children's Television, no longer support the existing syndication rules and that several other groups support the network position. At issue is whether the three major networks should be given the right to invest in shows they air and then reap the benefits of both foreign and domestic syndication or redistribution as movies or videotapes. An FCC rule in effect since 1970 bars the networks from having a financial interest in shows they don't wholly own, and bars them from syndicating even their own shows in the United States. Opponents say the Financial Interest and Syndication Rule discourages the major networks from taking risks to develop innovative programs. Proponents of the rule say it prevents the networks from dominating prime-time television. The movie industry and the major networks failed to resolve the issue after several years of negotiations, and the FCC has said it will decide whether to rescind the rules after taking final comments Aug. 1.
