NBC, in a statement filed with the commission, said groups with a combined membership of about 20 million people support a repeal of the rule. They include hundreds of local television stations, labor unions, teachers' organizations, and senior citizen and other consumer groups, the network said. ``Most do not have any economic stake in the outcome of this rulemaking proceeding, but recognize the value of maintaining a free and diverse television program service,'' NBC said in its statement signed by general counsel Richard Cotton. In an interview, Cotton said the industry has changed considerably since the 1970s when the three major networks commanded 90 percent of the prime-time audience. A recent survey showed audiences for NBC, ABC and CBS totalling 52 percent, he said. He said 60 percent of U.S. homes now have cable television, with an average of 30 stations per household compared to seven in 1970s. He said networks purchase only 21 percent of programs compared with 75 percent in 1970. The network was responding to an assertion by Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, that only the networks support repeal of the rule. Valenti said in a speech Tuesday the public would be ill-served ``when a few people accumulate life-and-death authority over what Americans see on prime-time television.'' He said the rules serves as a check on network abuse of power. The rule, Valenti said, ``has restored competition to a program arena previously barren to competition, and it has allowed independent television stations to grow and prosper.''

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando's Son Ordered to Stand Trial in Slaying of Sister's Lover
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with bail set at $10 million, Christian Brando's statement to police; lawyer indicating bail will be posted. No pickup. ^LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's son was ordered Tuesday to stand trial for murder in the shooting of his sister's lover after a prosecutor quoted Christian Brando as saying of the victim: ``Death is too good for the guy.'' Municipal Judge Larry Fidler set bail at $10 million, saying that was the only way to ensure he wouldn't flee. A spokeswoman for the District Attorney said the amount may be the highest ever set by a Los Angeles County judge. Marlon Brando had offered to put up his house, worth more than $5 million, to guarantee his son's return. The prosecution had sought no bail. Defense attorney Robert Shapiro indicated the Brando family would post bail, but declined to say when or how it would be posted. ``I've talked to Christian's father, brother and family. They're anxiously awaiting his return home.'' Marlon Brando was hurriedly led out of a back door of the courtroom after making some notes on the judge's decision. The judge, who listened to two days of testimony about the killing of Dag Drollet, said he had to decide whether Christian Brando committed murder, rather than manslaughter, the charge the defense had sought. ``It would appear to me from the evidence presented that the district attorney has certainly met the burden of proof,'' Fidler said. ``There has been a killing and the defendant pulled the trigger.'' A Superior Court arraignment was set for Aug. 7. Deputy District Attorney Steven Barshop read the judge a statement the younger Brando made to the first police officer who arrived at his father's Mulholland Drive estate after the shooting May 16. ``I shot him, man, but not on purpose,'' he quoted Brando as saying. ``It was an accident. The gun was under the couch. I kept it there.'' Barshop quoted him as saying, ``I did it because he hurt my sister. My sister is pregnant....He was fighting with my sister.'' Later in the statement, Brando conceded that he disliked Drollet and declared, ``Man, death is too good for the guy.'' Christian Brando told police the gun went off during a fight, but prosecutors contend there wasn't any evidence of a struggle. They said paramedics found Drollet on a couch, with a cigarette lighter in one hand and a television remote control in the other. Moments before the hearing ended, Laurene Landon Coughlin, a former girlfriend of Christian Brando, testified that the 32-year-old defendant came to her apartment shortly before the shooting and appeared to be intoxicated. Defense attorney Shapiro told the court earlier that Marlon Brando planned to make a shrine to Drollet in the room where he was killed. That could explain why the elder Brando resisted police efforts to return to the scene weeks later to reconstruct the crime, Shapiro said. The white-haired, portly actor, who sat in a front row of the courtroom for a second day, closed his eyes and extended his hands at one point as if meditating. Across the courtroom, Drollet's mother wept as a firearms expert described the face wound that killed her son. The expert, David Butler of the Los Angeles Police Department, said that Drollet was shot under his left eye at such close range that minute particles of tissue were left on the muzzle of the .45-caliber semiautomatic pistol. Also at Tuesday's hearing, Fidler refused to admit into evidence a statement from Christian Brando's sister, Cheyenne Brando, that was taken before she left for Tahiti. She reportedly told police she considered the killing of her boyfriend murder, not an accident. Barshop said he hopes to coax Miss Brando into returning from Tahiti to testify at Christian's trial.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Threatens Kuwait with Tanks, Troops; U.S. on Alert in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 13 `Many observers' to make it `on' sted `of' and 23rd `The diplomats' to CORRECT to armed forces in Kuwait, sted residents. Minor editing thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Iraq accused neighboring Kuwait on Tuesday of conspiring to harm its economy and massed tens of thousands of troops and hundreds of tanks on the border. Informed sources in Kuwait said the Iraqi troop buildup had increased over the last 48 hours to at least 30,000, and that more than 200 Soviet-made tanks were posted along Iraq's 100-mile-long southern border with Kuwait. The area of the troop buildup is rich in oil reserves, and has been a source of contention since Kuwait gained its independence from Britain in 1961. The border demarcation has never been agreed on by Iraq, and a portion of it crosses the Rumaila oil field. The same sources said Kuwait on Tuesday reinstated its state of alert, declared July 16 and canceled after three days of tension between the two oil-producing countries. Iraq has 17 million residents, including 1 million troops. Kuwait was 1.8 million residents, and 20,300 members of the armed forces. The U.S. Defense Department, meanwhile, announced that U.S. Navy warships and aircraft were holding a ``short-notice exercise'' in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates, about 600 miles south of the Kuwait-Iraq dispute. The United States has at least seven warships in the Gulf at any given moment. The State Department announced at the beginning of the crisis that it backs Kuwait's territorial integrity. Iraq has accused Kuwait of being an American puppet and of conspiring with the United States to throttle the economy of Iraq, which has the world's second-largest oil reserves but endured a costly war from 1980-88 with Iran. In Washington, U.S. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said both Iraq and Kuwait had strengthened their armed forces. ``Iraq and others know there is no place for coercion in a civilized world,'' she said. ``All disputes should be handled through peaceful means.'' Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak flew to Baghdad and Kuwait on Tuesday to meet with mediate the crises with leaders of those countries. Mubarak said his mission was successful, but Iraq downplayed his efforts. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein claims his country lost $14 billion during the past year because of a world oil glut that has sent crude prices tumbling. He has accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of overproduction. In a long letter Tuesday to the Arab League, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tareq Aziz charged Kuwait with stealing Iraqi oil from the Rumaila field, which he said was entirely owned by Iraq. The field extends two miles into Kuwait. Many observers said they believe Saddam, who has spent an estimated $50 billion on sophisticated arms since coming to power in 1979, is engaging in saber-rattling to back his demands for lower oil production and higher prices. Iraq has said it will push for a $7 increase in oil prices at the Wednesday meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva. The 13-member group is to set production and prices for the rest of the year. Tuesday, Iraq's government newspaper Al-Joumhouriya accused Kuwait of coordinating its moves with the United States in order to ``clear the way for foreign powers to intervene in the area.'' It also accused Kuwait of ignoring Arab solidarity by demanding the repayment of loans made to support Iraq during the Iran-Iraq war. Kuwait loaned Iraq an estimated $15 billion during the war. Iraq owes foreign creditors about $70 billion. Reports of the troop buildup sent jitters through world financial markets. In Tokyo, the dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen over news of increasing unrest in the Gulf. Missiles, armored personel carriers and tanks were prominently displayed along the road from Iraq to Kuwait as travelers poured back to the Gulf state when the dispute erupted. Iraq was a popular vacation destination for Kuwaitis. Diplomats said the buildup has escalated since Monday, when the Washington Post quoted sources in Washington as saying two divisions of the elite Republican Guards Corps were moved to the border. The diplomats and informed sources in the Gulf on Tuesday put the number of Iraq troops at 30,000 on the southern border, nearly 50 percent more than the number of armed forces in Kuwait. In Washington, Pete Williams, a Defense Department spokesman, told reporters that the joint U.S.-Emirates exercise codenamed ``Ivory Justice'' began Monday and that two U.S. Navy vessels left from their port at Bahrain to participate. He declined to comment on the purpose of the maneuvers. The official Kuwait News Agency quoted Mubarak as describing his talks with Iraqi and Kuwaiti leaders as ``successful.'' But Aziz told the official Iraqi News Agency: ``With due respect to our Arab brothers, it has never happened in the past that such disputes were solved by Arab mediation committees.'' Shortly after Kuwait gained its independendence, Iraq claimed sovereignty and the Kuwaitis called on Britain for assistance. Britain sent in paratroopers and they were replaced by an Arab force led by Egypt, which acted as a buffer between the two countries until tensions eased in 1963. Kuwait suffered itself during the Gulf war when Iran attacked Kuwaiti shipping lanes, fired missiles on the coast, and was held responsible for acts of terrorism that included an attempt on the life of the Emir of Kuwait in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Impressed with Oil-Eating Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: Oil-eating bacteria are breaking down the mess left by the Exxon Valdez spill in Prince William Sound and should be used on other spills, the nation's top environmental official said. William K. Reilly, chief of the Environmental Protection Agency, said Monday that such ``bioremediation'' efforts should continue on shores fouled by the Exxon Valdez spill, even if that means a third summer of cleanup. State and Coast Guard officials disagree over how long manual and mechanical methods like flushing and tilling should accompany bioremediation. In the bioremediation method used here, chemical fertilizers that promote the growth of oil-eating bacteria were spread on sullied beaches. ``There's no question that we have made progress toward cleanup that is notable, significant and very encouraging,'' Reilly told reporters after his shoreline tour with Alaska environmental commissioner Dennis Kelso. It was Reilly's first visit to Prince William Sound since late last summer, and his third since the tanker Exxon Valdez ran aground in March 1989, spewing nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in the nation's biggest oil spill. The success of bioremediation here bodes well for other oil spills, and for sites nationwide that have been polluted by leaking underground storage tanks, Reilly said. ``I would very much hope that bioremediation comes on in a big way throughout the United States,'' Reilly said. ``We are developing an intimate familiarity with oil spills and we desperately need new technologies.'' Some environmentalists opposed spreading the phosphorous- and nitrogen-based fertilizers on the shoreline, fearing they might wreak havoc on an environment already battered by the massive spill. However, no major adverse effects have been reported since the fertilizers were spread earlier this summer, officials said. In June, natural oil-eating microbes were used to clean up a light crude oil spill off Galveston, Texas. The successful effort marked the first time bioremediation was used in open waters. Meanwhile, state and Coast Guard officials are arguing about how long the cleanup should continue in Alaska and who is authorized to end it. Kelso has said work should continue anywhere there are more than 5 grams of oil per kilogram of beach material. That's than one-tenth of an ounce of oil per pound of rocks or sand. The shores should be clean enough not only for wildlife habitation but also for recreational use, he said. But Coast Guard Rear Admiral David Ciancaglini, the federal on-scene coordinator, said the cleanup should stop before it intrudes on the natural, recovering habitat. Reilly said another summer cleanup would be warranted if a subsurface problem of any size remains next spring. Officials from Exxon Corp., which is funding the cleanup, have said they believe the effort can be completed this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Lost Supreme Court Case on License Motto
DOC.TEXT: When David Souter was attorney general, New Hampshire lost in the U.S. Supreme Court one of its most widely followed court cases, brought against a couple for covering the ``Live Free or Die'' motto on their license plates. George and Maxine Maynard taped over the motto in 1975, citing religious objections. They were Jehovah's Witnesses and said they didn't believe that freedom is more important than life. Their plates were taken away, and after refusing to pay a fine, George Maynard spent 15 days in jail. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., was attorney general at the time. A three-judge federal panel upheld the Maynards' right to obliterate the motto, but flamboyant Gov. Meldrim Thomson vowed to fight them all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court, and ordered Souter, who succeeded Rudman, to proceed with the appeal. Souter said he did not see the state's action as infringing on the Maynards' right to free speech. ``This was not an articulated statement of words _ it was an act,'' he said. The high court didn't see it that way, and ruled in 1977 that states may not force their residents to display mottoes or other ideological messages on license plates or other personal property. ``The First Amendment protects the right of individuals to hold points of view different from the majority and to refuse to foster, in the way New Hampshire commands, an idea they find morally objectionable,'' the court wrote. Souter said he was not surprised. ``We realized this was a difficult case since the law clearly didn't favor us,'' he said. Eight months after the high court ruled, the Maynards still were trying to collect $21,000 in legal fees from the state. So, a U.S. marshal, armed with a warrant, went to a busy state-owned liquor store and ordered the manager to hand over the money. The manager called the governor, who promised payment and the money came through two weeks later.

DOC.HEAD: Salvador Peace Talks Switch to Human Rights Issues
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran government and guerrilla negotiators skipped ahead to a discussion of human rights on Tuesday in an effort to salvage some accord from a crucial round of peace talks in San Jose. The talks had bogged down on the subject of overhaul of the armed forces. The Costa Rican session began last Friday. It is seen as vital to maintaining momentum toward a negotiated end to El Salvador's 10-year-old civil war, which has killed an estimated 72,000 people. The Salvadoran military meanwhile announced that a judiciary official was assassinated by rebels and five guerrillas were killed and four soldiers wounded in renewed fighting Tuesday in El Salvador. Senior guerrilla commander Schafik Handal told journalists in this Costa Rican capital that rebel delegates agreed to move on to discuss human rights, second item on the agenda, ``in an effort to save the negotiations.'' ``There is still time to reach accords,'' he said. The Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, has said lack of progress at this round would make a major insurgent offensive likely. High authorities of the government of President Alfredo Cristiani have said a big rebel push could scrap the talks. Justice Minister Oscar Santamaria, the chief government delegate, termed ``surrealist'' on Tuesday rebel demands for demilitarization of El Salvador. Handal characterized the government response to rebel proposals for military overhaul as ``irresponsible, not serious.'' He said the government position amounted to ``provocation.'' The session here, due to end Wednesday, follows negotiations in Venezuela in May and Mexico in June. The first round of U.N.-mediated talks produced an agenda, with the future role of the armed forces as lead item. Five days of talks in Mexico on the military and four days here produced no accord. The rebels said the government position presented since Friday in some aspects represented ``a step backward'' from Mexico. The FMLN demands: a purge of the officer corps to rid it of those it sees as flagrant abusers of human rights; an end to military impunity; creation of a civilian-controlled police force to replace the current militarized police; eradication of military-linked death squads; dissolution of paramilitary forces, and an end to forced conscription. The government proposed strengthening of existing mechanisms designed to permit the military to police itself and creation of new ones. It said it would dissolve paramilitary Civil Defense forces once the FMLN was demobilized. Handal said the armed forces issue ``is still the crucial subject, and remains to be resolved.'' Some type of accord on human rights appeared possible. International human rights groups have blamed the Salvadoran armed forces and military-linked death squads in the deaths of about 30,000 suspected leftists in the past decade. No officer has been convicted, or even tried in connection with a rights abuse crime. Guerrilla sources said the rebels will propose establishing a human rights office under a special prosecutor. The office would be subject to international supervision. Negotiators would work out the particulars. Santamaria told journalists Tuesday the government ``is willing to accept international vigilance over the human rights process.'' An armed forces news release in San Salvador said troops killed five guerrillas in a fire fight near Zafra, 112 miles east of the capital, and four soldiers were wounded in a clash near Cinquera, 42 miles east of San Salvador. Guerrillas on Monday night killed Jose Heriberto Rubio, a justice of the peace in Nueva Esparta, 124 miles east of San Salvador, the news release said. It identified Rubio only as the father of an army lieutenant. Guerrillas destroyed two city buses in San Salvador's working-class district of Soyapango, the release said.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans District Attorney's Trial Nearing End
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with case going to jury, deliberations to begin Wednesday; EDITS to conform. Pick up 10th graf, `Connick and ...'
DOC.TEXT: The federal racketeering and gambling trial of New Orleans' district attorney, a former federal attorney, a television actor and others went to a jury Tuesday. Jurors will begin deliberations Wednesday. At the heart of the six-week trial was the allegation that District Attorney Harry Connick illegally returned seized gambling records to known bookmaker Walton Aucoin so Aucoin could pay off and collect gambling debts. On trial with Connick are actor Paul Burke and former assistant U.S. Attorney Patrick Fanning. Aucoin also is a co-defendant, along with two of his alleged employees _ Steve Bertolino and William G. Condon of Metairie _ and New Orleans businessman Wilson Abraham. Connick, 63, is the father of Grammy-winning jazz musician Harry Connick Jr. He has been district attorney in New Orleans since 1973. Burke once starred in television's ``The Naked City'' and played a congressman on ``Dynasty,'' and had guest roles on numerous other series. Prosecutors, led by James Cole of the Justice Department in Washington, made much of the fact that Connick ordered the return of Aucoin's records just five days after Aucoin was arrested on Dec. 4, 1988. The records were returned before Connick's office accepted the case for prosecution, prosecutors said. Defense lawyers, who delivered their final arguments earlier Tuesday, have maintained Connick simply gave Aucoin something he was entitled to as a suspect in a crime and as a man who planned to pay federal taxes on his gambling income. ``The crime in this case exists solely in the minds of the prosecutors,'' defense attorney William Wessell said in his closing argument. The trial began June 11. The indictment was returned last December after a year-long investigation begun by U.S. Attorney John Volz. Connick and Volz had been at odds for years over various issues and Volz later turned the case over to the Justice Department saying he wanted to avoid any appearance of bias or conflict. Nevertheless, Connick blamed Volz when the indictment was handed down and accused him of carrying out a political vendetta. Aucoin, Bertolino and Condon were accused of running an illegal gambling operation. Fanning, Burke and Abraham were accused of helping cook up phony reasons for Connick to return records to the bookie, that is, that Aucoin had to have them to pay taxes on his bookmaking income. Fanning, once an assistant to Volz, was Aucoin's lawyer at the time. Burke was an acquaintance of Connick and Aucoin, as was Abraham, a contributor to Connick's political campaigns. The specific charges against the defendants were listed in the indictment as ``conducting the affairs of an enterprise through the collection of unlawful debt and conducting an illegal gambling business.'' Burke also was charged with lying to the grand jury. Connick faced a possible maximum sentence of 25 years in prison and a $500,000 fine. Burke, with the added perjury charge, faced up to 30 years and $750,000 in fines. The investigation also involved former Louisiana Gov. Edwin Edwards and a suburban sheriff, Harry Lee of Jefferson Parish, although neither man was indicted. Lee testified that he once returned gambling records to Aucoin after an arrest and Edwards was widely reported to have called Lee on Aucoin's behalf to urge return of those records.

DOC.HEAD: Study Questions Hospital Mortality Report
DOC.TEXT: A study casts new doubt on federal reports that list hospital death rates and fuels concern that the reports are a poor measure of hospital quality, a researcher said Tuesday. Researchers for the Rand Corp. found that varying death rates among two types of heart patients could be attributed to random statistical variations, rather than the treatment the patients received. Their report is published in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. It follows by six months a study published in the same journal that criticized the government for inadequately examining how the severity of illness may affect hospital death rates. The new study didn't test the most recent method used by the Health Care Financing Administration to compare mortality rates among Medicare patients at the nation's nearly 6,000 hospitals. But the Rand study still urges caution in analyzing the yearly reports by the health care administration, which adminsters the Medicare program, said Rolla Edward Park, principal author. ``I think what it points toward is the need to continue to try to improve the HCFA methods to figure out what kind of information can be put into consumers' hands that is the most useful,'' Park said. Officials at the HCFA, which funded part of the Rand study, said they would consider the study in a continuing effort to improve their reporting. But they said the Rand approach to death rates is not comparable to theirs. Reports titled ``Medicare Hospital Mortality Information'' have been issued publicly for the past three years by the HCFA, an arm of the Department of Health and Human Services. The reports use statistical techniques to compare predicted hospital mortality rates with the actual number of deaths. Federal officials each year have warned against using the reports as the sole measure of a hospital's quality. Rand's four-state study looked at a sample of 2,276 deaths among Medicare patients at 734 hospitals. Congestive heart failure, in which the heart's gradual loss of strength causes the lungs to fill with fluid, accounted for 1,126 deaths, and heart attacks accounted for 1,150. When analyzing the quality of care, researchers found some hospitals with higher-than-expected death rates _ called ``targeted'' hospitals _ actually provided better care than non-targeted hospitals. Researchers found that targeted hospitals treated more serious heart attack cases, and therefore could reasonably expect higher death rates. No statistical difference was found in the severity of illness among patients with congestive heart failure, the researchers said. The researchers used a computer model to measure how much of the difference in death rates could be attributed to random variations. The figures from the simulation roughly matched the actual difference in death rates between the targeted and nontargeted hospitals, the researchers said. The Rand Corp. is a private, non-profit organization researches and analyzes U.S. security and domestic policy.

DOC.HEAD: New York Governor Signs Dwarf Tossing Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 5th graf, `Dwarf tossing ...' to UPDATE with comment from promoter. Pick up 6th graf, `The games ...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo signed legislation Tuesday banning dwarf tossing and dwarf bowling in New York bars, calling the activities a ``strange diversion.'' ``Any activity which dehumanizes and humiliates these people is degrading to us all,'' Cuomo said. ``This bill recognizes that and, in effect, declares these bizarre games to be debased.'' The bill, similar to one that became law in Florida last year, amounts to a ban because the events have not been popular outside bars. It passed the legislature with only one dissenting vote. The law targets taverns, but has no penalties for participants. Bars could loose their liquor licenses. Dwarf tossing is a competition in which people pick up dwarfs, who are wearing harnesses, and heave them as far as possible at a padded target. It produced an offshoot, dwarf bowling, in which a helmeted dwarf is strapped to a skateboard and rolled into bowling pins. Both have been held as competitions for cash prizes, Cuomo said. A New York City area promoter said the law amounts to censorship. Baird Jones said his dwarf events are performance art designed to satirize the values of mainstream America. ``Because we're doing this where alcohol is being served, we're being lumped with bar sports,'' Jones said. ``This is not someone promoting wrestling in Jell-O between naked women.'' The games originated in Australia and made their way to the United States about five years ago. ``Dwarf tossing belongs in the Middle Ages, not the modern age,'' said state Sen. Nicholas Spano, who sponsored the bill. The legislation had been pushed by the Little People of America, an organization founded in 1957 by actor Billy Barty. In his approval message Tuesday, Cuomo said he was swayed by arguments from dwarf advocates that the games ``only perpetuate the outdated images of dwarfs as court jesters or circus freaks'' and posed medical dangers. Supporters of the bill had maintained that dwarfs have brittle bones. Cuomo said he was also sensitive to arguments, voiced recently by syndicated columnist Mike Royko, that ``government has no business meddling in the rights of a consenting adult dwarf to be tossed or bowled.'' ``This state does not lightly impose limits on the activities of consenting participants,'' Cuomo said. ``But balancing all the interests affected, I am persuaded that approval of this bill respects human dignity and protects the safety and self respect of the special people who are the subject of this strange diversion.'' The legislation may be largely symbolic. Officials at Little People of America say dwarf tossing has virtually stopped, killed at least in part by negative publicity. Heidi Heinrich, of Tallahassee, Fla., who has been a national leader in the fight against dwarf tossing, has said she was aware of only one exhibition of the game in recent months. That was in South Carolina and took place while that state's Legislature was considering a bill to outlaw the practice. The bill was defeated.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes 5 Percent Budget Increase for Arts Endowment
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf: ``A major,'' with postponement of floor debate from Friday to September
DOC.TEXT: A proposed $180 million budget for the embattled National Endowment for the Arts, including a $900,000 increase in federal funds for state arts agencies, was approved Tuesday by a House Appropriations subcommittee. The bill was sent to the full House Appropriations Committee by voice vote without action on any anti-obscenity amendments that would restrict the kinds of art eligible for tax-paid endowment grants. A major House floor fight had been expected to begin Friday on separate legislation that would extend the NEA's life for another five years, but late in the day Tuesday Jeff Biggs, press aide to Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said that debate had been postponed until after the August recess because more than 20 amendments needed to be considered. Republicans are drafting proposals for a drastic overhaul of the endowment as a result of past financial support for art that conservatives have denounced as obscene or sacrilegious. The appropriations bill approved by the subcommittee Tuesday would provide a 5 percent increase in the NEA budget, from $171.3 million to $180 million in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. At the urging of Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., the subcommittee chairman and a staunch arts advocate, the panel approved boosting endowment funds for states arts councils from $26.1 million to $27 million. Increases for dance, music, opera and musical theater, the media arts and design arts also were approved. A major proposal of the House Republican plan to restructure the arts endowment would funnel 60 percent of NEA grant money to the states, compared with the current level of 20 percent. The GOP measure, drafted chiefly by Reps. Tom Coleman of Missouri and Steve Gunderson of Wisconsin, also would require the NEA chairman to assure Congress that federally supported art is ``sensitive to the nature of public sponsorship and to the cultural heritage of the United States, its religious traditions or racial or ethnic groups, and does not violate prevailing standards of obscenity.'' The obscenity provision is the most controversial feature of the Coleman-Gunderson plan, which will be submitted when the House begins debate on the NEA's re-authorization bill later this week. The endowment is an independent federal agency that underwrites a wide variety of artists and arts institutions with tax-paid grants requiring matching funds from private sources. For more than a year, the NEA has been the focus of a growing political controversy over its previous support for exhibitions of sexually explicit works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. Under pressure from Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other conservative legislators and from religious fundamentalists, Congress voted last fall to prohibit the NEA from supporting artwork that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of sex acts, sadomasochism, homoeroticism or sexual exploitation of children.'' The Coleman-Gunderson anti-obscenity provision is based on the Supreme Court's 1973 definition of obscenity, which covers works that appeal to prurient interest, portray patently offensive sexual conduct and lack serious artistic, scientific, political or literary value based on community standards. The Republican bill would allow the endowment to recover grant funds if the NEA chairman concluded that a recipient's work violated the Supreme Court standards on obscenity. The recipient could appeal in federal court.

DOC.HEAD: Sensational Anti-Semitism Trial Begins in Raucous Soviet Courtroom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to CORRECT to courtroom dock, sted docket, RAISES arrest date, details. Picks up graf 15 pvs, `The case...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB2
DOC.TEXT: A man went on trial Tuesday for allegedly inciting anti-Semitism in a violent protest that galvanized fears of pogroms among Soviet Jews and prompted some to flee. Konstantin Smirnov-Ostashvili denied being anti-Semitic, but in a conversation with reporters from the dock charged that Jews wielded a disproportionate share of power. ``A Russian person is brought to trial in the center of Russia ... for insulting, injuring the dignity, and for instigating intolerance against those who enjoy massive privileges, and who hold the leading posts in our society,'' he said. He said he faced charges that could bring him up to five years in prison because of a campaign by the Soviet press ``that belongs ... to the left, the democrats, the Zionists. I think it's all the same.'' Smirnov-Ostashvili was apparently the first person charged under a strengthened law prohibiting ethnic insults, or appeals for ethnic intolerance. He was arrested for allegedly being one of the organizers of a Jan. 18 protest. The protesters broke up a meeting of writers at Moscow's Central House of Literature and roughed up some of the participants. Judge A.I. Muratov postponed the trial in the Moscow City Court for a day before Smirnov-Ostashvili could enter a plea because of a crush of reporters surrounding the dock and a raucous crowd of several hundred people. Some of those present applauded the defendant's statements and shouted ``Shame!'' when Muratov denied his motion to dismiss his attorney. More than 71,000 Jews emigrated from the Soviet Union as travel laws were eased last year, and thousands more have left this year. Jewish leaders have cited ``an unprecedented panic among the Jewish population'' in the face of threats from extreme Russian nationalist groups such as the Pamyat society. Such groups accuse the country's 1.4 million Jews of dragging Russia down into a morass of Soviet socialism. One Jew who attended the trial said it would test the Soviet court system, which historically has been viewed as little more than an arm of the Communist authorities. ``I am going to find out how just Soviet justice is, how much we are going to be protected,'' said the 36-year-old psychiatrist who identified himself only as Eduard. He said he also would learn how strong Smirnov-Ostashvili's supporters are. The case has received wide publicity in the Soviet press, and served to highten Jews' fears of anti-Semitic attacks. The popular weekly Ogonyok quoted demonstrators as saying through a megaphone at the Jan. 18 meeting: ``Your time is over. Neither the police, nor the KGB, nor the party will help you. Now we will be the masters of the country, and you, newcomers, clear out and go to Israel. How long can we tolerate your Russophobia?'' In a rare preview, the government newspaper Izvestia published a short report announcing the trial last week. On Sunday, the Communist Party daily Pravda printed an editorial urging the country to come to grips with its history of anti-Semitism. S. Rogov, a historian, wrote in Pravda that it would be ``at minimum stupid'' to pretend there is no problem. Many Jews do not want to emigrate, he said, but ``their fear of the specter of pogroms is beginning to grow into a panic.'' In another development, a Jewish parliamentarian demanded Monday that Russian writer Valentin Rasputin resign from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Presidential Council for alleged anti-Semitic statements. Smirnov-Ostashvili, 64, was brought to trial after a five-month investigation in which more than 400 people were questioned. He said that if Muratov and two civilian assistants tried him on a strictly legal basis, he likely would be given a heavy sentence. But if they consider the polarization in the country, they should not punish him severely because that would worsen the political tension, he said. Smirnov-Ostashvili said he could not be considered anti-Semitic. ``Nowhere in any of my declarations was there an insult to Jews as a nation,'' he said. ``I have spoken all the time about Zionists.'' He also showed reporters an award from the Soviet government for giving blood, and said that also proved he was not a racist. ``How can you be an honored donor of the Soviet Union, having given 30 liters of blood to our medicine, not knowing where it is going _ to Georgian children, to Jewish children, to Russian children _ how can an honored donor be an anti-Semite?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: Jewelry Store Owners Charged In Fencing Scheme
DOC.TEXT: Sixteen people were charged Tuesday with participating in a scheme to rob homes and businesses of jewelry, rare coins and precious gems and then resell the merchandise in Manhattan's Diamond District. Two men who owned several businesses in the district were identified as the leaders of the fencing ring, which authorities said was in operation since 1982. James M. Fox, assistant director of the FBI's New York office, said the participants would use every opportunity to commit a robbery. ``Some were blatant armed robberies in broad daylight on the streets of Manhattan. Other times, they cased out residences or businesses ... and would go in covertly,'' Fox said at a news conference with U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier. Fox said it was not uncommon for jewelry to be reset and displayed in one of the ringleaders' stores as quickly as two hours after it was stolen. Although court papers said the defendants netted $1.2 million, Fox said the amount could be much higher because the scheme had been going on for so long. Court papers listed a series of robberies of homes and businesses in New Jersey from 1983 to 1985; the theft of $221,000 worth of jewelry from a Greek exporting company in 1987 and 10 Rolex watches from a foreign shipment in 1986; and the armed robbery of a North Palm Beach, Fla., home in 1983 that netted $60,000 worth of jewelry and merchandise. Fox and Obermaier released three separate indictments arising from the fencing scheme. One charged the two store owners, Felix Friedman and Lawrence Tinnirello, and seven others with racketeering and various fraud counts. Friedman and Tinnirello operated as many as 13 stores, some of which are still in business, in the Diamond District, located on 47th Street between Fifth and Sixth avenues, authorities said. The racketeering indictment also outlined a scheme in which the defendants allegedly obtained jewelry from other merchants on consignment and then kept the items without paying the owner. Friedman, who was described by a prosecutor as ``the business brains behind the fence people,'' was ordered held without bail by U.S. Magistrate Naomi Buchwald. She found he was likely to threaten witnesses if released. Tinnirello was held overnight pending a further bail hearing Wednesday. Assistant U.S. Attorney James Comey said both had been involved in acts of violence. Four other men were charged with robbery conspiracy in connection with the robbery of a Brooklyn jewelry store last year, and a fifth was accused of fraud in the consignment scheme. A third indictment charged the wives of the store owners, Irina Zaritskaya and Mindy Tinnirello, with making false statements to banks in order to hide the profits of the fencing scheme. They each face up to five years in prison on one count of making false statements to banks. They were released on their own recognizance.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Panel Won't Grant Protection to NJ Camera Maker
DOC.TEXT: Keystone Camera Products Corp., claiming to be the last American maker of conventional fixed-focus cameras, lost its bid Tuesday for trade relief from imports. The four U.S. International Trade Commission members voted unanimously against granting the import quotas and higher tariffs the Clifton, N.J. firm sought. ``Imports of cameras were not a substantial cause of injury to the domestic camera industry,'' the commission members found. Keystone, which made 2.5 million cameras last year, claims it is the sole remaining American manufacturer of conventional 35mm fixed focus and point-and-shoot cameras and pocket cameras in the popular 110 film size. Its petition excluded imported disc, single-lens reflex, instant print and 110 cameras with variable focus. Keystone contended that imports from Japan, China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Mexico, South Korea, Thailand and Brazil have hurt the domestic camera industry and could jeopardize the future of 500 manufacturing and distribution jobs. The company said that imports of the types of cameras it produces increased from 11 million in 1985 to 27.5 million in 1987. Earlier, Chairman Myron J. Berman had said that without import restrictions, Keystone would be forced to move production overseas, as other camera makers have done. He said Keystone already had cut costs to the bone. Keystone could pursue alternate appeals for help, such as charging that foreign cameras have been dumped in the American marketplace at less than fair-market value, said Betsy Godley, a spokesman for the trade panel. Photography giant Eastman Kodak Co. of Rochester, N.Y., which said it was not being hurt by imports, had asked the trade commission to deny relief to Keystone. Kodak, which operates around the world, argued that Keystone was responsible for its own market troubles because of poor management decisions. Kodak also had disputed Keystone's claim to be the last bona fide American camera maker.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Motion to Dismiss Indictments Against Northwest Pilots
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge refused to dismiss charges Tuesday against three former Northwest Airlines pilots accused of flying drunk. Judge James Rosenbaum, following recommendations made by U.S. Magistrate J. Earl Cudd on July 6, also denied defense motions to suppress physical evidence and statements, and to grant the defendants separate trials. Jury selection was to begin Wednesday morning in the U.S. District Court trial of the former pilots, accused of being drunk while flying a commercial airliner from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis March 8. The Boeing 727, with 91 passengers aboard, landed safely at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport. Cudd had ruled that blood-alcohol tests could be used as evidence against Capt. Norman Prouse, of Conyers, Ga.; 1st Officer Robert Kirchner, of Highland Ranch, Colo.; and flight engineer Joseph Balzer, of Antioch, Tenn. Prosecutors claim Prouse drank 19 rum and Diet Cokes the night before the flight and that Kirchner and Balzer shared seven pitchers of beer. A bar patron tipped the Federal Aviation Administration and Northwest, prompting an FAA inspector to visit the cockpit before the plane left Fargo, officials have said. FAA officials have said the pilots were warned not to fly. Defense attorneys have said the inspector could have stopped the flight, but did not intervene. The three pilots were arrested by an FAA official when the plane landed. Northwest fired the trio for violating a company prohibition against drinking alcohol within 12 hours of a scheduled flight. The FAA revoked their licenses after its own investigation showed the three had boarded the flight within eight hours of drinking. Separate tests by the FAA and Northwest showed each of the pilots had a blood-alcohol level exceeding 0.04 percent, a violation of federal regulations for flying. Conviction on the federal charge carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. In North Dakota, each faces a state misdemeanor charge that carries a maximum sentence of a year in prison and a $1,000 fine. That trial is to begin Aug. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Valdez Skipper Faces New Fight to Keep License
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood, who was acquitted four months ago of most criminal charges in the nation's worst oil spill, faces a Coast Guard hearing that could strip him of his license as a ship's master. In a hearing scheduled to start Wednesday, an administrative law judge will decide whether the former Exxon Valdez skipper was guilty of negligence and should forfeit his license. The judge, Harry J. Gardner, has a number of options in deciding the case, according to the Coast Guard and Hazelwood's lawyers. He could choose to dismiss all charges, revoke Hazelwood's license or place him on probation. He cannot impose a fine or prison term. Hazelwood is accused of breaking a Coast Guard rule by drinking within four hours of assuming command of his ship and leaving the ship's bridge while the tanker was traveling through icy waters. He also is accused of leaving a crewman who lacked a required license in control of the bridge. Hazelwood's attorney, Michael Chalos, said the defense would argue that Hazelwood wasn't responsible for the ship's running into a reef. The Exxon Valdez was en route from the Alaskan port of Valdez to Long Beach on March 24, 1989, when it struck a charted reef. Gashed by jagged rocks, the 987-foot tanker spilled 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil into Prince William Sound. ``Capt. Hazelwood looks forward to putting on his case and being vindicated much as he has been in Alaska,'' Chalos said. ``He's been spending most of his time helping us prepare for this hearing.'' The defense will argue that any drinking within four hours of sailing was unintentional because the ship left port an hour earlier than it was supposed to. The defense also plans to argue that the Coast Guard itself had waived its requirement that the person in control of the bridge have a pilot's license for Prince William Sound and that the Coast Guard failed to adequately monitor the Exxon Valdez via radar. Hazelwood was acquitted at his two-month trial of being drunk and reckless, but was convicted of one misdemeanor charge of negligent discharge of oil. He was ordered to pay $50,000 restitution and spend 1,000 hours cleaning beaches at Prince William Sound. He is appealing the verdict. An administrative hearing resembles a trial but is held without a jury before an administrative law judge. The hearing could last anywhere from a day to weeks. The hearing is being held in Long Beach because it is the headquarters for the 11th Coast Guard District, which includes Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: Wife of Cult Leader Stands Trial in Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to restore dropped first reference to defendant.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the conspiracy and kidnapping trial of a cult leader's wife will visit the farm where a family of five was killed and buried, the judge said Tuesday. The announcement followed completion of jury selection in the trial of Alice Lundgren, 39. She is charged with five counts each of conspiracy and complicity to commit aggravated murder and five counts of kidnapping. She is the first of 13 defendants to be tried in Lake County Common Pleas Court. She faces a possible life prison term if convicted in the April 17, 1989, shooting deaths of religious cult members Dennis Avery, 49; his wife, Cheryl, 42; and their daughters, Trina, 15; Rebecca, 13; and Karen, 7. Their bodies were found in January buried under a barn in Kirtland, where members the cult lived. Kirtland is about 30 miles east of Cleveland. Mrs. Lundgren's husband, Jeffrey, a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, is charged with five counts each of kidnapping and aggravated murder in the case. Authorities have said the Averys may have been killed to cleanse the spirits of other cult members or because Lundgren questioned their devotion to the cult. Judge Paul H. Mitrovich told the jurors they would travel by bus Wednesday morning to the farm, then return to the courthouse for opening statements. Prosecutor Sandra A. Dray told prospective jurors she would call as witnesses four cult members who have pleaded guilty in the case. Richard Brand pleaded guilty to five counts of murder. Gregory Winship pleaded guilty to five counts of complicity to commit murder. Deborah Olivarez and Sharon Bluntschly pleaded guilty to five counts of conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. All lived at the Kirtland farm. Brand, Olivarez and Bluntschly were originally from Independence, Mo.; Winship was from Euclid. Jeffrey Lundgren could get the death penalty if convicted. His trial is to begin Aug. 13. Mitrovich said Mrs. Lundgren's trial would last at least a week.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Bus Crash Kills 19, Injures 15
DOC.TEXT: A passenger bus rolled down a mountainside after being hit by a truck Tuesday in eastern Mexico, killing 19 people and injuring 15, a Red Cross official said. Red Cross spokeswoman Isabel Cervantes said in a telephone interview that the crash occurred about 7:20 a.m. on a curve on a mountain road near Ciudad Mendoza, a town in Veracruz state. ``The truck was going up the mountain road and sideswiped the bus which was going down, then crashed into it again. The bus kept going at great speed toward the next curve, then rolled off the road and down the mountain,'' she said. Ms. Cervantes said the bus fell 33-48 feet down the mountain before coming to a stop. She said the bus was on its way from Puebla to the port of Veracruz on the Gulf of Mexico. The truck was carrying a load of empty bottles. A police report said there was no immediate indication what caused the accident, but investigators at the scene suspect the drivers of both vehicles were traveling much faster than road conditions allowed.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: Didn't Use Litmus Test on Souter and Senate Shouldn't Either
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 15-16: ``Some members,'' on demonstrations and ADDS 2 grafs
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Souter, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush launched the public campaign for his Supreme Court nomination of Judge David H. Souter Tuesday as he urged the Senate to avoid any ideological litmus test in the confirmation process. In speeches to Republican fund-raising events in Philadelphia and New York, Bush lavished praise on the man he picked Monday to serve on the Supreme Court. ``I look forward to the Senate hearings of David Souter; I am sure they will find him to be tough but fair,'' the president said in a speech on behalf of New York GOP candidates at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. ``He's a first-rate appellate judge, an outstanding jurist and a great legal mind.'' Before his speech in New York, Bush met for 25 minutes with former President Ford, Deputy White House Press Secretary Stephen Hart said. Hart said the president invited Ford to his room after learning that the former president was at the hotel. He did not say what they talked about. ``The Supreme Court must be guided by independent minds and its members are appointed for life largely to keep them above the flames of political passion,'' Bush said in Philadelphia. ``So in my nomination of Judge David Souter for Senate confirmation ... there was no single issue, no litmus test or standard dominating my decision.'' ``And I will add there should be no litmus test in the process of confirmation,'' Bush said. His statements drew applause from a crowd of about 500 at a fund-raising luncheon for Pennsylvania Republicans. Later, Bush visited a neighborhood drug prevention center, and declared, ``No crack in Philadelphia except for the one in the Liberty Bell.'' He pushed for swift action on an administration-backed crime bill that he said would provide ``strong new tools to fight this war on drugs.'' Bush said on Monday he would nominate Souter, a former New Hampshire Supreme Court justice recently named to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, to succeed retiring Justice William J. Brennan. Souter is widely expected to be questioned, in confirmation hearings before the Democratic-dominated Senate Judiciary Committee, about his views on the issue of abortion. Both abortion rights supporters and opponents were among a variety of demonstrators carrying placards and chanting outside the hotel where Bush spoke. Some members of the radical ACT UP _ AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power _ hurled fake dollar bills from a window, and nine others managed to evade security and stage a sit-down in the hall outside the ballroom where the dinner was held. Still others staged ``die ins'' in the lobby, dousing themselves with fake blood. Police said they arrested 37 people. ``My sole priority was to appoint a justice true to the life and spirit of the Constitution,'' the president said, ``a priority that I am confident will also guide the Congress in the confirmation process.'' ``I believe I am recommending an individual with a strong, incisive independent devotion to interpreting the Constitution, a quiet man of enormous intellectual strength, a tough trial court judge with a great legal mind and an impartial quality that will serve the court well,'' said Bush. ``I firmly believe that he will be a great justice,'' he said. In Washington, Souter met at the White House with Frederick D. McClure, the president's chief of congressional liaison, for a briefing on the confirmation process. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the nomination would be officially sent to the Senate on Wednesday and Souter would then begin visiting with Senate leaders and members of the Judiciary Committee. In Philadelphia, while Bush was making his introductory remarks, a protester arose and accused him of being a liar. The crowd booed and Bush quipped, ``I haven't even said anything yet, and I'm lying.'' ``These people feel strongly,'' he said. ``Let them have their say, and then a little politeness should prevail and the guy that's up here speaking ought to be given his day in court.'' The protester apparently was upset about U.S. policy in El Salvador. Bush also discussed deficit-reduction talks, saying, ``The Congress and I are working hard to put America's fiscal house in order, to put the spending policies that brought us to this point behind us.'' In Washington, Democrats involved in the negotiations appealed to the president to tone down criticism of Democratic policies in the interest of seeking an agreement. Fitzwater said Bush would be ``very gentle.'' Still, in New York Bush complained of ``Democratic dominance'' which he said has caused ``government by gridlock, with spending skyrocketing out of control, good legislation thrown aside for pork and a budget deficit looming over our children's children.'' He ended on a slightly kinder note, taking note of his daily meetings with the leaders of Congress, saying ``I think they are trying'' to reach an agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Communists in Mongolia Rout Opposition Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The government said Tuesday that Communist Party candidates routed most of the opposition in the primary round of Mongolia's first multiparty election ever. Mongolia has been ruled by the Communists since 1921, when it gained independence from China with Soviet help. It has remained in the Soviet bloc since. Near-final results from Sunday's primary showed only 101 of the five opposition parties' 338 candidates survived the first round, said the vice president of the National Election Commission, Khurmitbek. ``For the first attempt, it's good,'' said Zorig, leader of the opposition Mongolian Democratic Association. He said the opposition hoped to win 40 to 50 seats in the national legislature in next Sunday's runoff. The Communist Party's chairman, Gombojavyn Ochirbat, said a Communist victory would not end Mongolia's dramatic transformation since December from an authoritarian, one-party state obedient to Moscow, to a multiparty nation eager for Western contact and investment. ``We are confident to say that Mongolian society is standing firmly on the path of restructuring,'' he told a news conference. He, President Punsalmagiin Ochirbat and other top Communist officials survived the primary, government officials said. The two Ochirbats are not related. Most leaders of the opposition groups also won, Zorig said. About 2,400 candidates from all parties ran in the primary for 430 seats in the national legislature, the Great People's Hural. Primaries were held in districts with more than two candidates. A total of 799 survive for the second round. The new legislature will elect a president. Prime Minister Sharavyn Gunjaadorg told a news conference the elections so far had been ``comparatively free and fair.'' ``Of course since we are exercising this kind of election for the first time there are some shortcomings and some bumps,'' he said. Party chairman Ochirbat said he was willing for some non-Communists to sit on the new Cabinet. Zorig said he had seen isolated cases of irregularities in Sunday's primary, partly because of confusion over how to fill out the ballots. ``I know a few cases where people at polling centers were trying to suggest what person (voters) should vote for,'' he said. One of 19 foreign observers, Maciej Jankowski of Poland's Solidarity, reported similar incidents but called these mistakes rather than deliberate attempts to cheat. The U.S. observer team said it would make its comments to election officials. Mongolia is especially eager that the election be perceived as fair because Secretary of State James A. Baker III is to visit next week and discuss extending most-favored nation trade status to Mongolia. Formed only over the past few months, the five non-Communist parties claim a combined membership of about 12,000, to the ruling party's 98,000. Although the opposition appears to have substantial support in cities, where half of Mongolia's 2 million people live, it has had to scramble to reach the rural people. Many herders are only dimly aware of the mass demonstrations in Ulan Bator beginning in December that forced the Communists to agree to elections. They know even less of the anti-communist revolutions in Eastern Europe that inspired Mongolia's opposition. The opposition hopes, however, to win a significant presence in the 53-seat Small Hural, which will govern between the Great Hural's annual sessions. In the Great Hural, one seat is allocated for every 2,000 rural residents but only every 10,000 urban residents, hurting the city-based opposition. The Communists recently have embraced many of the goals of the opposition, including its demand for market-style economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Ariane Rocket in Successful Launch from French Guiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with director-general quotes, time it took for orbit, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An Ariane rocket successfully lifted a double payload of French and German TV satellites into orbit Tuesday night, five months after a similar rocket exploded minutes after takeoff. The rocket blasted off at 7:25 p.m. (6:25 p.m. EDT) from the Ariane space center in French Guiana, on the northeast coast of South America, and deployed the two satellites into orbit in less than 25 minutes, officials reported. Ariane Flight 37 was the first launch of a European rocket since an Ariane carrying two Japanese communications satellites blew up less than two minutes after takeoff Feb. 22. Launches were suspended after the accident. Tuesday's flight put the five-channel French television satellite TDF 2 and the 11-channel DFS Kopernikus 2, for West Germany's Deutsche Bundespost Telekom, into geostationary orbit _ always staying above the same spot on the Earth's surface. All preparations proceeded smoothly, mission chief Yvan Cherica reported. He said the weather was good, despite worries of a storm before the launch. The Ariane project has been dogged by embarrassing and costly setbacks, including rockets that have exploded or crashed, and expensive delays. But Ariane rockets dominate the private aerospace industry, carrying about half the world's commercial payloads into space. Arianespace, the commercial branch of the European Space Agency, has contracts worth $2.8 billion to launch 37 more satellites. The French satellite launched Tuesday weighs 4,621 pounds and will join a twin already in orbit to form a powerful relay system that can serve 400 million television viewers, Arianespace said. Kopernikus weighs 3,126 pounds. Tuesday's flight ``is important in two ways,'' said Arianespace Director-General Charles Bigot. ``It is putting into orbit two satellites of the countries who have given the most support to Ariane politically, technologically and industrially. It is also the flight in which we pick up after the failure of Flight 36.'' Ariane officials say that failure was caused by a small piece of cloth that clogged a line carrying water coolant to one engine. The French weekly L'Express said sabotage may have caused that explosion, and at least two previous Ariane failures. Arianespace officials have said no evidence of sabotage emerged, but technical and security checks would be intensified. February's failure was the fifth in the Ariane series and was particularly costly because Arianespace had lobbied hard for the Japanese contracts. Tuesday's satellites were lifted into space by an Ariane 4 rocket, the latest version introduced in 1988. It features four strap-on boosters powered by liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen, and stands 190 feet high on the launch pad. A newer version, the heavy-lift launcher Ariane 5, is being developed for planned introduction in 1995. Arianespace is a consortium made up of aerospace, electronics and banking companies from 11 western European countries _ Belgium, Britain, Denmark, France, Ireland, Italy, Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland, Sweden and West Germany. Its rockets have sent into space 45 commercial satellites from Canada, France, West Germany, Britain, India, Italy, Spain and the United States, as well as international organizations such as Intelsat and Eutelsat. Ariane is facing increased competition, however, from American private-sector rockets including the Titan-4 made by Martin Marietta Corp., General Dynamics' Atlas-Centaur and the Delta built by McDonnell Douglas. Other rivals include China's Long March rocket; the Soviet Union's Proton, and Japan's H-2 rocket, now under development. Until now U.S. rockets have mainly launched military and scientific satellites under the supervision of the U.S. Air Force and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

DOC.HEAD: NAACP Chapter Firebombed for Second Time in Two Weeks
LaserPhoto AX6
DOC.TEXT: The office of an NAACP chapter was heavily damaged Tuesday by gasoline bombs, the second firebombing eight days, authorities said. The office was vacant and no injuries were reported. Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called on the public to denounce those responsible for the fires. ``We ask, in the wake of this latest vicious attack against the NAACP, when will this madness cease?'' he said. Hooks accused law enforcement agencies of inadequately guarding the office in this Atlanta suburb after the first attack July 16, when a gasoline bomb was thrown through a window. The office of the NAACP's Clayton County chapter was vacant then and damage was described as minor. Police Lt. Douglas Jewett said two Molotov cocktails were found inside the building and two outside early Tuesday. The firebombing was under investigation by the FBI, the Georgia Bureau of Investigation and local police and fire departments. The FBI took the case because the incidents ``could be racially motivated and the violation of civil rights statutes could be involved,'' said Joseph L. Coleman, a special agent in Atlanta. Jewett said police have not established a motive for the attacks. The fire burned holes in walls and destroyed furniture and documents. James Jackson, president of the NAACP chapter, said he has no plans to relocate the office. ``This is really ridiculous ... but we're going to stay here in the county,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Signs Health Proxy Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo signed legislation Tuesday to give New Yorkers the power to designate someone to make life-and-death medical decisions for them when they are no longer able to. Cuomo's action makes New York the first state to change its laws regarding ``living wills'' since the U.S. Supreme Court last month ruled that the Constitution guarantees a person the right to refuse medical treatment. New York was one of just nine states that lacked such a law. ``The choices posed by medical advances will still be difficult ... But the added anguish of legal uncertainty and confusion will be removed for patients who have created a health care proxy,'' Cuomo said. The bill, effective in six months, allows New Yorkers to designate a friend or relative to make health care decisions for them, such as when life-support systems should be unplugged. The proxy must be signed in front of two witnesses and two doctors must certify a patient is no longer able to make such decisions before the proxy can be used. Proxy forms will be distributed in such places as hospitals, nursing homes and doctor's offices, said Tracy Miller, executive director of the state Task Force on Life and the Law. The Health Department is also printing a brochure that will explain the new rights to people, she said. The legislation was passed a week after the Supreme Court, in a decision involving a Missouri woman named Nancy Cruzan, gave a boost to ``living will'' legislation. New York state's highest court has said a competent adult has the right to refuse medical treatment, even if it is life-sustaining.

DOC.HEAD: Tribe Leader's Election Fraud Trial Delayed
DOC.TEXT: A tribal court on Tuesday delayed the election-fraud trial of suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald until later this year. Navajo Judge Robert Yazzi said the election-fraud trial would be held after two other trials scheduled for MacDonald. The first is set for Aug. 28 on charges he accepted kickbacks and bribes from businesses operating on the reservation. The second is scheduled for Sept. 25 on conspiracy charges stemming from the tribe's July 1988 purchase of the Big Boquillas Ranch in northern Arizona for $33.4 million. The election-fraud trial was to have started Tuesday. Yazzie also postponed the trial of suspended Vice Chairman Johnny R. Thompson, who was to have gone on trial with MacDonald on Tuesday. MacDonald, who was placed on paid leave by the Tribal Council, is charged with 93 counts and Thompson with 47 counts of filing fraudulent campaign reports by failing to report contributions from non-Indians and Indians in the tribe's 1986 election. The charges also allege the funds received exceeded the maximum of $84,192 allowed. The proceedings were delayed after the Navajo Supreme Court ordered Yazzie to reconsider MacDonald's indigency petition and to appoint legal counsel to represent him. Yazzie ruled after reviewing the petition that MacDonald wasn't indigent, then appointed Navajo Legal Aid attorney Peter Breen and Farmington, N.M., attorney Doug Moeller to represent MacDonald. Had Yazzie declared MacDonald indigent, he could have appointed a member of the Navajo Nation Bar to represent him without pay. Under the Supreme Court ruling, Breen and Moeller will be paid by the tribe, but the tribe could seek to be reimbursed by MacDonald later.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Wound Leader of Peru's Jewish Community
DOC.TEXT: Assailants shot and wounded a leader of Peru's Jewish community Tuesday, and a police officials said three suspected Arab terrorists recently released from jail may have been responsible. Jacob Hasson, director of the Israeli Union in Peru, suffered four gunshot wounds to his left hand and arm after the gunmen opened fire on his car, Lima Prefect Jacobo Mishkin said. Hasson, 60, was treated at a nearby hospital, and his wounds were not considered serious, Mishkin said. Hasson's attackers were believed to include three suspected Arab terrorists who were released from a Peruvian jail two months ago, Mishkin said in an interview for the radio station Radioprogramas. An automobile carrying three men and a woman cut off Hasson's car at 4:15 p.m. as he was driving down a major avenue in the Peruvian capital, police said. The assailants opened fire on Hasson's car with revolvers and sub-machine guns, police said. Hasson's car spun out of control and smashed into a sidewalk fruit stand, slightly injuring the vendor and her 14-month-old daughter, according to police. The gunmen escaped. Hasson has lived in Peru for 30 years and manages the Israeli Union, a Jewish community organization. His office is in a Lima synagogue. Mishkin, whose duties include Lima police chief, told Radioprogramas that the three Arabs were arrested in Peru in July 1988 and ordered released two months ago by a judge for lack of evidence. The three were arrested on suspicion of belonging to the Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal. They were identified as Hocine Bouzidi, 36, of Algeria; Mohamed Abdelrahman Abed, 19, of Egypt, and Ahmad Assaad Mohamed, 19, of Lebanon. Peruvian officials said at the time that the three men would probably be deported. Instead they were held for two years awaiting trial and then released. Police said in 1988 that the men may have been planning attacks against Jewish, U.S. and Israeli targets in Peru. They said documents were found showing the men had kept the U.S. Consulate, the Israeli Embassy and the Synagogue of Israel in Lima under surveillance. Police also suspected the three men may have tried to form ties with leftist guerrillas in Peru. Peruvian officials said Interpol, the international police organization, has accused Bouzidi of being a member of Abu Nidal's central committee and of being linked to the planning of more than 30 terrorist attacks in Europe and the Mideast since 1976. Among the attacks were the November 1985 hijacking of an Air Egypt jetliner in which 59 people were killed when Egyptian troops stormed the aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: 9-Year-Old Girl Dies After Accidental Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A nine-year-old girl died in a hospital early Tuesday, two days after a stray bullet hit her in the head as she slept in the family car following a weekend outing. A spokesman for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office indicated that authorities would seek a grand jury indictment of second-degree murder against Dorian G. Daughtry, 22. He is accused of firing the fatal shot during a shootout in the drug-ridden East New York neighborhood. The girl, Veronica Corales, was the eighth person known to have been killed in New York City this year by a stray bullet, said Detective Joseph Gallagher, a police spokesman. Veronica had been kept alive on a respirator at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center and ``died naturally, of the trauma,'' said Mimi Grinker, a hospital spokeswoman. The spokeswoman said members of Veronica's family were ``beside themselves with grief.'' Veronica's mother, Deborah Corales, 28, and stepfather, Daniel Cosme, 24, had kept a vigil with other relatives and friends at the hospital since the shooting on Sunday. Police said Veronica was hit as she lay sleeping next to her mother in the family car, parked on the street shortly after returning from an outing to Great Adventure amusement park in New Jersey. They said a bullet pierced the car door and hit her in the back of the head. Daughtry, a one-time minor league baseball prospect for the Seattle Mariners, was arraigned in Brooklyn criminal court on one count of attempted murder and two each of assault and criminal possession of a deadly weapon, three hours before the girl's death at 2:30 a.m. He pleaded innocent. The Brooklyn district attorney planned to urge that he be held pending a presentation to the grand jury, said spokesman, Pat Clark. A requested indictment for second-degree murder, intentional or through depraved indifference, was possible, Clark said. Norris Gordon, a longtime friend of Daughtry, said the arrested man studied criminology in community college for a year, then played outfield in 1987 for the Mariners' Class A farm team at Bellingham, Wash. There, Gordon said, he roomed with Ken Griffey Jr., who is now the parent club's regular center fielder. Daughtry was working double shifts at a state facility for the mentally retarded in Brooklyn to support a 3-year-old son, Dorian Jr., and debating whether to take the police tests or try out with the Cincinnati Reds, the team that employs Ken Griffey Sr., Gordon said.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Says S&L Fraud Penalties Becoming Tougher
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs two grafs; Metzenbuam claims Fail-Thompson agreement
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh complained Tuesday of the ``unwillingness'' of federal courts to punish savings and loan fraud with long jail terms, but said punishment was becoming tougher. ``We have been troubled throughout the course of this effort by the seeming unwillingness of judges to impose stiff sentences,'' Thornburgh told the Senate Judiciary Committee. He was responding to criticism from the panel's chairman, Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., who cited FBI statistics showing the average S&L offender in 1989 received a sentence of 1.9 years while the average bank robber was sentenced to 9.4 years. ``Whether bank robbers steal their loot with a pistol or with a pencil _ either way they should serve hard time,'' Biden said. Thornburgh, making his first congressional appearance devoted to S&Ls since financial institution fraud has become a hot political topic, said the sentences have been more to his liking since the Supreme Court upheld federal sentencing guidelines in January 1989. ``Of late we have had considerable improvement in particular cases where major executives of failed savings and loans have been convicted of fraud,'' he said, citing several cases. On Friday, a federal judge in California sentenced Janet Faye McKinzie to 20 years in prison and restitution of $13.4 million. She had been found guilty of stealing millions of dollars from North America Savings and Loan Association, Santa Ana, Calif. Last month, Woody Lemons, former chairman of Vernon Savings and Loan Association, Vernon, Texas, was sentenced to 30 years. In Written testimony, the nation's top S&L regulator, Timothy Ryan, said that stiff sentences ``unfortunately ... are the exception.'' Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, cited a number of examples. For instance, an Alabama S&L vice president found responsible for $2 million in losses was given one year of unsupervised probation, he said. Thornburgh endorsed get-tough legislation passed 99-1 by the Senate two weeks ago. It increases the maximum jail sentence for a single count of S&L fraud from 20 years to 30 years and establishes a life sentence for so-called S&L kingpins. They are defined as people who acted in concert with others to steal $5 million or more. However, the attorney general said similar legislation moving through the House has provisions that would interfere with the administration's pursuit of thrift fraud. In a separate development, the Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights authorized four subpoenas in the panel's investigation of Bluebonnet Savings Bank, Dallas, an institution created in a December 1988 federal bailout. The panel, chaired by Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, is looking into whether the now-defunct Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp. should have awarded Bluebonnet to James Fail, a Phoenix, Ariz., insurance company owner. Fail put up only $1,000 of his own money to acquire the S&L and was selected even though a company he controlled in Alabama had pleaded guilty to fraud in 1976. The subcommittee authorized subpoenas for Thomas Lykos, former assistant director of the FSLIC, and Robert Pennington, former president of an insurance company controlled by Fail. It also authorized subpoenas for Fail and Robert Thompson, a GOP lobbyist who represented Fail in the deal, but said the two should first be given a chance to cooperate voluntarily. The two have been challenging whether Metzenbaum's subcommittee has jurisdiction over S&Ls. Metzenbaum told the subcommittee that documents in his possession show that Thompson, a former aide to then vice president George Bush, claimed a 2 percent interest in Bluebonnet worth millions of dollars. Nancy Coffey, the senator's spokeswoman, said she could not release the documents or describe them. Lance Morgan, a spokesman for Thompson, declined to comment.

President Bush's choice of David H. Souter for the Supreme Court now heads for Senate confirmation hearings, where the little-known New Hampshire judge is sure to be quizzed about his views on abortion and other divisive social issues. Calling Souter ``a remarkable judge of keen intellect and the highest ability,'' Bush said Monday that he and his advisers had deemed it ``inappropriate'' to ask Souter his views on specific issues. That will be the task of the Senate Judiciary Committee, expected to hold hearings in September. Souter, 50, spent a dozen years as a state judge before joining the Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on April 30.

Just as the Bush administration and Congress are gearing up to fight savings and loan crooks, a new study indicates that fraud caused only a small percentage of thrift losses. Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va., maintains that fraud cost $5 billion, or only 3 percent of what he figures is the bailout's $147 billion total cost. Most of the losses come from falling real estate values and from excessive interest rates paid by ailing institutions to attract depositors, he figures. Bad bailout deals made in 1988 and losses on junk bonds also contributed. Fraud, nevertheless, has become the focus of political debate on S&Ls. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, making his first congressional appearance on the subject, and top-banking regulators were scheduled to testify on the subject today before the Senate Judiciary Committee.

The flawed mirrors that have crippled the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope were a worry for NASA officials even as the agency was selecting a contractor for the telescope optics, according to a 1977 report. The report, released by NASA on Monday after a request by The Associated Press, said officials selected Perkin-Elmer Corp. of Danbury, Conn., to make the Hubble optical assembly, even though the company planned to use an unproven computer-driven system in the critical mirror polishing. Engineers for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration now believe that a flaw manufactured into one of the mirrors by Perkin-Elmer blurred the vision of the Hubble telescope, reducing its effectiveness by at least 50 percent.
