The error is now under investigation. The report, signed on Aug. 26, 1977 by then-NASA Administrator Robert A. Frosch, said the bid by Perkin-Elmer, now Hughes Danbury Optical Systems Inc., was preferred over a bid by Eastman Kodak Co. for several reasons, including cost.

After a little prodding from a well-heeled health crusader, the nation's top four hamburger chains agree: french fry lovers need an oil change. McDonald's Corp. and Wendy's International announced Monday they are switching to cholesterol-free, all-vegetable oil to cook their fries. Hardee's made the change two years ago and Burger King said last week it will no longer use beef tallow, the industry's previous standard oil for french fry vats. ``Everything that's deep fried is now done in 100 percent cholesterol-free oil,'' said McDonald's spokesman Chuck Rubner. The company started cooking its chicken items, pies and fish in vegetable oil four years ago, he said.

House Republicans are divided over what punishment Rep. Barney Frank should be given for actions on behalf of a male prostitute, but the Democratic leadership predicts the ethics committee's recommendation for a reprimand will be upheld. One conservative Republican is committed to a seemingly futile attempt to expel Frank, D-Mass., while others are considering a motion to upgrade the reprimand to a censure. On the other hand, Rep. John T. Myers of Indiana, ranking Republican on the ethics panel, said he will urge House members to uphold the committee position for reprimanding Frank, an acknowledged homosexual. The Republican leadership planned to discuss the party's strategy at its regular meeting this afternoon. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said the Frank case would be considered on the floor Thursday.

A political party quit East Germany's coalition government Tuesday and another group threatened to follow suit in a political crisis over how united German elections should be held. The Liberal Party, which controls 21 seats in the 400-member Parliament, said it was leaving the seven-party governing coalition of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. Rainer Ortleb, charman of the Liberal faction in Parliament, said his party's decision was based partly on de Maiziere's ``scandalous'' alliance with the deposed former Communists on the election question. The dispute is over whether December elections for a single German Parliament should be held separately in each nation, or whether the two countries should be treated as a single electorate.

A House panel urged a special prosecutor Tuesday to widen the investigation of former HU Secretary Samuel Pierce, saying it had evidence Pierce steered lucrative federal grants to his former law firm. In its most detailed finding, congressional investigators questioned whether Pierce's former law firm, a former top aide and Pierce himself may have violated federal bribery, conspiracy and conflict-of-interest laws during his tenure as secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The panel said evidence also suggested Pierce, who served throughout the eight-year Reagan administration, may have committed perjury at a panel hearing when he denied involvement in the awarding of key grants. ``It is obvious that Secretary Pierce did not give us the full story,'' the panel wrote. ``However, some of his statements stand out in that they are inconsistent and at odds with the sworn testimony of other witnesses.''

Congressional Democrats extracted from President Bush a pledge to tone down political attacks during a two-hour budget session Tuesday that failed to narrow crucial differences on curing the federal deficit. Bush agreed to a temporary political cease-fire after blistering Democrats in recent Republican fund-raising speeches around the country. ``He'll be very gentle'' from now on, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush made no mention of contentious budget issues during a midday speech to a GOP audience in Philadelphia, focusing instead on praise for his day-old selection of David Souter for the Supreme Court.

The government, concerned that the one skill the industrious Japanese have yet to master is how to relax, is offering advice on how hard workers can become happy campers. The Health and Welfare Ministry this week released a 38-page report titled: ``A Study on How to Take Proper Rest and Recuperation.'' It suggests Japanese forget about their jobs when they leave the office and take leisurely and lengthy vacations, concepts well-rooted in the West but yet to take hold here. To help the nation relax, the government report offers a wide range of general guidelines. For example, it argues that constant overtime work cuts down on sleep, adversely affects the quality of work and results in ``chronic fatigue physically and mentally, eventually leading to bad health and illness.''

DOC.HEAD: Reparations Paperwork Costs Aleuts Government Aid
DOC.TEXT: For 80-year-old Hilda Berikoff, the reparations she received this year for her World War II evacuation and internment meant the end of one bureaucratic battle _ and the beginning of another. Legally, reparations should have no effect on public assistance. But bureaucratic and communication snags are costing Berikoff and some other elderly Aleuts their Medicaid coupons and old-age benefits. Berikoff said she hasn't gotten that aid for a couple of months. ``I was getting it all the time before,'' she said, ``but then when they found out I had money in the bank, I think, I stopped getting it.'' At least three people in this Aleutian Island village have had their assistance suspended or canceled by the state Division of Public Assistance, said Marti Norton, a fee agent who helps people correspond with the agency. ``A lot of these elderly people aren't familiar with paperwork and they're being required to provide more and more information,'' said Norton. ``One person even had his case closed.'' The number of Aleuts denied aid in smaller villages, without fee agents, may be much higher. Aleuts on the Aleutian and Pribilof islands were evacuated on 24 hours' notice after the Japanese bombed Unalaska in 1942. Berikoff said she still can close her eyes and hear bombs dropping and feel the fear and panic. The Aleuts were taken to camps in Southeast Alaska. For 2{ years, the Berikoffs lived in a defunct cannery and bunkhouse on Burnett Island. Four families shared a room with one large table; many slept on the table, others on the floor. Berikoff stuffed blankets under the doors to keep out the cold. ``They said they'd have everything for us ready in Southeast and when we got there there was nothing,'' she said. ``I had two little kids so it was pretty hard on me.'' Many Aleuts returned after the war to find their homes and belongings missing or destroyed, and the Russian Orthodox Church vandalized. For years, they sought reparations; Berikoff was among those who lobbied Congress. In 1988, Congress approved reparations of $12,000 per person, to be distributed by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. Berikoff has arthritis. Doing without Medicaid coupons and $136 in old-age benefits each month means she has little money left after paying bills, she said. She has spent most of her reparations money to fix her house. ``I wouldn't be able to go to the clinic unless they pay,'' she said. In Berikoff's case, the division sent a letter saying it would close her file unless she provided a copy of her bank statement, proof she received reparations and an account of what she did with the money, Norton said. ``I'm really offended that they would burden an 80-year-old lady with all of this,'' said Norton. ``This payment was supposed to make up for wrongs. It was supposed to make their lives a little easier.'' Of some 550 Aleuts eligible for reparations, all but about 130 received checks by May, said Dimitri Philemonof, executive director of the non-profit Native corporation Aleutian-Pribilof Islands Association. The rest, he said, will be paid by next year. The money should not affect individuals' government aid. Reparations are not considered income and are not taxable. State welfare workers were told this, but some were confused and in at least one case benefits to an Aleut were cut off without proper notice, said Curtis Lomas, a program officer in Juneau. Workers will receive new materials to reiterate the rules, he said. The state must make sure that the $12,000 its public-aid clients received were reparations, Lomas said. If the division doesn't get the right documents, it sends letters giving clients 10 to 15 days to respond. ``If it's not provided after a reasonable period of time, we have no choice but to close the case,'' he said. ``There are people who just don't respond.'' Norton said some older Aleuts who receive packets in the mail don't open them immediately. ``Many of them are intimidated when you get a big, fat envelope in the mail,'' she said. ``A lot of them would put it on a dresser for awhile and look at it because they were sure it was bad news. Then they'd bring it to me, and a lot of times it was too late.'' State aid forms are dense and hard to read even for people whose first language is English, Norton said. Many elderly Aleuts speak little or no English. Lomas says welfare officials ``do the best we can. We don't have the capability of issuing notices in Aleut.'' Reparations have created other problems. ``I think there are some carpetbaggers out there,'' ready to pounce on people with new wealth, Philemonof said. ``All of a sudden you've got friends.'' Norton tells of one man who bought a gold-nugget watch and ring, and drank away the rest of his settlement in a month. Then he had to sell the jewelry. One of the biggest problems people have run into, Philemonof said, is cashing checks in smaller villages. ``There's not enough revenue there and they were more or less forced to come into Anchorage,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Part III: The Catastrophe
A Great Sea Is Dying; `Hundreds Will Die With It'
LaserPhoto NY307 of July 24; Graphics SOVNEWSO3, SOVNEWSOL
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: A tragedy vast in scope is unfolding on the arid plains of Central Asia, a region already unsettled by stirrings of dissent and nationalism. This is the third article in a four-part series based on an AP special correspondent's journey through the Soviet south.

Beyond Bukhara's irrigated deserts, the noble Amu Darya river dwindles down to a pathetic, poisonous trickle, a victim in one of the world's worst ecological disasters. Deprived of the Amu Darya and its sister stream, the Syr Darya, the Aral Sea is dying. Within 30 years, what was the world's fourth largest inland sea is expected to be only a dry bed of deadly salt. Scientists say the sea's condition reflects a far greater crisis across much of Central Asia, caused by years of Soviet insistence on defying nature to plant cotton in the desert. Near the Aral, the effects are devastating. Authorities refused entry to a Western reporter seeking to verify reports of the highest infant mortality rates in the world. But videotape made in June by a Soviet filmmaker showed ecological refugees in squalid camps, a hospital full of children poisoned by their mothers' milk and whole communities disappearing. In some places, doctors said on film, 63 percent of the children are sick with lung or kidney disorders, damaged livers, rickets, pneumonia, anemia or other diseases. Sickness comes from pesticides and defoliants, inhaled with blowing salt or swallowed with tainted water. Mothers pass on chemicals to nursing infants. The physical setting has suffered as dramatically. Rusting hulks sit stranded on a vast desert, once a seabed, the remains of one of the Soviet Union's richest inland fishing fleets. No fish has been caught in the Aral since 1977. The filmmaker, Andrei Yatsenia, was among specialists who met in Tashkent, late in May, to focus attention on what they agreed was the ecological plunder of Central Asia. ``This is catastrophic,'' said Permat Shermuhamedov, a regional legislator who heads the Committee to Save the Aral Sea. ``At this rate, the sea is finished.'' The experts blamed two problems: widespread irrigation by raw gashes in the porous earth, which wastes as much water as it carries, and the excessive use of pesticides, defoliants and corrosive chemicals that pollute the remaining seawater. Since 1960, the Aral Sea has lost half its surface area, the equivalent of almost two Lake Eries. Each year, winds carry millions of tons of salt from dried lakebeds, tainting fields up to a thousand miles away. Close to its former shores, the lake is already regarded as a mass murderer. In parts of Karakalpakia, an autonomous region of Uzbekistan, the official infant mortality rate is 112 per 1,000, four times the Soviet average and higher than in most poor African nations. But doctors say even that figure is understated. ``Pediatricians in some pockets say the rate is 500. Every second child dies in his first year,'' said Gulchehra Nurullaeva, a poet and official of Birlik, an Uzbek grass-roots opposition party. Doctors link the high rate directly to health problems from the dying Aral Sea. Karakalpak authorities invited a correspondent to investigate conditions, but the Uzbekistan Foreign Ministry would not grant a visa. ``What can we do with the land salted and no water?'' asked one desperate father on Yatsenia's tape, in a squatter camp of 650 mud hovels. ``If the Aral dies, hundreds and thousands will die with it.'' In the moribund town of Muynak, water once lapped at the back door of a large cannery. Now the sea is at least 14 miles away. The plant still operates. Frozen fish are brought thousands of miles from the ocean. Even here in Bukhara, 400 miles to the south, the crisis is evident. Every fall, at the edge of this ancient caravan hub, the Madaniyat Collective Farm picks its cotton crop and bundles it off toward Moscow. And every year, the cost is higher. Long ago, Bukhara's Zeravshan River exhausted itself before reaching the Amu Darya, bled by too many irrigation canals. To replace it, a new canal was cut to drain yet more of the Amu Darya. Before fields can be planted, they must be washed clean of salt and excess chemicals, which are carried down toward the Aral. A decade ago, a grand dream envisioned a 1,400-mile, multibillion-dollar canal from Siberia to the Amu Darya. But that would devastate Siberian marshes, environmentalists showed. With no alternate sources, Central Asia water users merely fought harder for their allotments. ``The tragedy is that most of this water is just wasted, into the desert and into the air,'' said Vladimir Kovaleyev, a geologist who has studied the problem for decades. ``I shouted in Literaturnaya Gazeta in 1975, but people were deaf,'' he said, brandishing clippings from other papers, as well. ``Today, they still are not listening.''

DOC.HEAD: Hit-and-Run Docs Make Millions Off Golden Arches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jeffry in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: The first time special prosecutor Edward J. Kuriansky uncovered a major case of foot fraud _ an $800,000 scam in 1985 _ he was convinced it was an aberration. He was wrong. Dr. Jeffry Simon proved him wrong to the tune of $1.8 million. The Seigal brothers did the same with $1.2 million. And Dr. Michael S. Greenburgh made Kuriansky $965,000 wrong. These four, along with dozens of other podiatric specialists, made fortunes hand-over-feet through Medicaid rip-offs uncovered in a state crackdown on crooked podiatrists. ``I heard someone refer to it as white-collar wilding, and that's not too far off the mark,'' said Kuriansky, who was dubbed ``Medicaid Fraud's Top Gun'' in a Podiatric Staff magazine article focusing on his efforts against corrupt foot doctors. But those efforts, particularly in the past year, have drawn an angry outcry from podiatrists who contend Kuriansky has overstepped his role of prosecutor and ``assumed the role of zealot.'' The New York State Podiatric Medicine Association has promised to fight a recent round of indictments brought by Kuriansky's office. Kuriansky and the podiatrists agree that rip-offs are not confined to any branch of medicine. But podiatry _ due to since-closed loopholes in state Medicaid policies _ became the most fertile fast-buck field, Kuriansky said. Podiatrists looked at feet and saw golden arches during the mid-1980s, he said. Doctors, who were not required to get prior Medicaid approval, would order expensive orthopedic devices and deliver inferior products. The most popular scam had the doctors funneling patients to shoe stores in return for kickbacks, with everybody making a quick illegal buck. ``They knew the system, they knew they weren't being watched, and they exploited it mercilessly,'' said Kuriansky. ``There was a feeding frenzy by podiatrists and orthopedic shoe vendors from 1983 through 1986.'' Statistics bear him out. In 1982, Medicaid billings in New York state for orthopedic footwear totaled $2 million; by 1985, they skyrocketed to $30 million. That same year, podiatrists' billings for office visits and services hit an all-time high of $35 million. Since the state crackdown, the figures are down to $2 million for footwear and $17.5 million for office billings. But the cheating goes on, as the steady flow of Kuriansky press releases announcing new indictments attests. Medicaid policy changes deserve some credit for the drop, but aggressive prosecution didn't hurt. Since 1985, Kuriansky's office has indicted and prosecuted 137 cases involving podiatrists, orthotic labs and orthopedic shoe vendors. The results are astounding: 135 convictions and more than $23 million in fines and restitution. Medical fraud is not a solely a New York problem; Dick Ekfelt, spokesman for the National Health Care Anti-Fraud Association in Washington, estimates it costs more than $10 billion a year nationally. Insurance industry estimates run as high as $80 billion, or 25 percent of the country's annual health-care bill. New York state, which has the nation's largest Medicaid system, also has the highest number of Medicaid frauds, said Kevin Ryan, a Kuriansky spokesman. But Steve Adler, bureau chief for medical fraud in the California attorney general's office, said foot fraud ``might be kind of a New York thing.'' Such cases are rare in California. ``There's not enough so you would notice,'' said Adler, who cited major rip-offs in the adult diaper industry as California's biggest scam. Kuriansky estimated 5 percent of New York's 2,555 licensed podiatrists are involved in fraud. Between 5 percent and 10 percent of all Medicaid claims in the state are bogus, he speculated. In New York City, evidence of the problem's deep roots came when five doctors on the faculty at the New York College of Podiatric Medicine were indicted in a $56,000 fraud case. ``When you see professors engaging in the very schemes their students are convicted of, you see a very depressing pattern,'' Kuriansky said. But it was that indictment that convinced the New York State Podiatric Medicine Association that Kuriansky had gone too far, said the group's executive director, Stanley Matek. ``Until this year, the cases he brought were legitimate. But he's become the Inspector Javert of New York Medicaid, chasing after Jean Valjean,'' said Matek, a reference to the obsessive manhunt that is the plot of Victor Hugo's ``Les Miserables.'' Matek concedes there was a problem when Kuriansky first started his crusade. Foot fraud was spreading faster than fungus five years ago, with doctors being recruited right out of medical school, Kuriansky said. ``It was an interesting phenomenon. Most of them were sort of yuppies _ young, fresh out of podiatry schools. ... They bankrolled their early careers at the expense of Medicaid,'' he said. Among them was Dr. Michael S. Greenburgh, indicted in October 1988 for stealing $965,000 in Medicaid funds beginning in 1984. Greenburgh, in an oft-repeated scenario, worked in a poverty-stricken city neighborhood where Medicaid recipients were plentiful. He pleaded guilty and was sentenced to one year in prison while agreeing to make full restitution. One scam, run by another podiatrist, was advertised on fliers at a city high school. Students were offered free sneakers at certain shoe stores; the doctor would instead file for orthopedic shoes and split the profit with the store. The Seigal brothers, Sheldon and Otto, were accused of making $1.2 million in seven months through a sneaker scam. They pleaded guilty, and were sentenced to one to three years in prison. They also were ordered to repay some of the money they stole. But Kuriansky described Dr. Jeffry Simon as ``the archetypal profiteer.'' Simon was charged with ripping off Medicaid for $1.8 million, and went to great lengths to cover up his efforts. When investigators closed in on Simon, the podiatrist created an entirely bogus lab to cover up his phony Medicaid claims, filling the room with molds made from the feet of any employee he could get his hands on. It didn't work; he was sentenced to one to three years. His indictment came two years after his first bust, the $800,000 scam that broke in 1985 and was then the largest Medicaid fraud in history. At the time, Kuriansky felt sure it ``couldn't be replicated.'' He knows better now, and that knowledge is not limited to podiatry: ``I have not found greed limited to any part of the medical field. It's big business. That's really what's going on.''

DOC.HEAD: Veep's Traveling Road Show Helps Fill GOP Coffers
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The local McDonald's was under siege, beset by a convergence of squad cars, police motorcycles and plainclothesmen. Customer Lynn King, who ``just came in to get a shake,'' thought there must have been a shootout. Instead, she found Dan Quayle and his traveling road show. The vice president was buying iced tea, shaking hands and introducing youths in tank tops to the Republican who wants to be Texas attorney general. ``Do you know Buster Brown?'' Quayle asked, pulling the candidate along as he distributed vice presidential pens and signed autographs for excited onlookers. Soon Quayle whisked his entourage on to more lucrative pastures at a nearby hotel. He sat for press interviews and then helped Brown, a state senator, collect more than $100,000 for his campaign from well-heeled GOP faithful. About 250 people paid $100 each to eat hors d'oeuvres and hear Quayle speak at a stand-up reception. Sixty others forked over $1,000 each for a more exclusive reception where they were photographed with Quayle. An elite 20, $2,500 contributors, got to sit on stage while he spoke. It was a typical morning on the campaign trail with Quayle. The vice president, who has battled for credibility ever since George Bush selected him, is on the road with increasing frequency as he devotes himself to electing other Republicans. Since early this year, Quayle has averaged a couple of days a week stumping for gubernatorial, state and congressional candidates across the country. He is credited with raising some $12 million for party groups and candidates over the past 1{ years. He has been in 42 states and made return trips to places with high priority races. He has bolstered his savvy staff by hiring an operative with respected political credentials, Michigan state party chairman Spencer Abraham, to coordinate his travels. While Quayle conducts some official business on most trips, ``The political trips drive the whole schedule,'' said his press secretary, David Beckwith. By combining vice presidential events with politicking, the vice president can charge part of his travel to the taxpayers. The political part is charged to the Republican Party organizations. Quayle's principle mission is raising money. He also generates considerable local media coverage, like the page-one Austin American-Statesman photo of him holding a child in McDonald's. The Republican National Committee touts him as immensely successful on the money front. ``He really is extremely popular among the party types, the state chairmen,'' said B.J. Cooper, a spokesman for the committee. ``He's very effective wherever he goes.'' ``He has been a very, very effective fund-raising tool,'' said Ed Rogers, who oversees political operations at the White House. Quayle's assignment is not to swing votes or lead rallies. Rather, he focuses on filling GOP coffers in a year when both parties are jockeying for the upper hand in preparation for the redrawing of legislative district lines. Even Democrats, who insist Quayle is a policy lightweight, give him backhanded credit for political skill. ``Our sense is they are using him almost solely to stoke the fires in their own political base camp,'' said Mike McCurry, spokesman for the Democratic National Committee. ``He's very successful.'' While Quayle says that to a large extent ``the novelty factor has worn off'' following relentless negative press early in his tenure, it seems the curiosity factor still draws people to see him. ``Many people don't know whether what they've read about him is true,'' said Lee Yaekel, GOP chairman in Travis County, Texas. ``A lot of people want to meet him ... know a little bit about him.'' As for raising money, Yaekel said, ``The vice president of the United States is the vice president of the United States'' and wealthy Republicans are going to shell out top dollars to see him. In Raleigh, N.C., Republicans had only two weeks notice that Quayle was coming to town, just a few weeks after President Bush had campaigned there for Sen. Jesse Helms. Despite the close timing of the two visits, the party managed to get 18 people to put up $2,000 each for a private reception and photo with Quayle, and 270 people to pay $125 each for a luncheon, said Andy Wright, state GOP political director. Although he carefully avoids discussing the topic, Quayle also reaps personal benefits through his nationwide travel. Aides privately acknowledge that the politicking gives Quayle a chance to establish a network of supporters for his own future, as Bush did in making himself the heir apparent to Ronald Reagan. Beckwith refused to comment on whether Quayle is laying that kind of base. But he allowed, ``Loyal party-building work served George Bush well.'' Quayle, too, sidesteps questions about his aspirations. ``I would acknowledge that it's building up friendships. It's building up contacts. I know people all over the country now that are quite supportive of me _ and supportive of George Bush, and it doesn't hurt the president to have the vice president out there making friends all the time,'' he said. In the meantime, a more polished, practiced Quayle is emerging. His stump speech, a call to arms for the Bush agenda and for making GOP headway in the Democratic-controlled Congress, is paced for applause lines. He delivers it in a more natural style than the stiff Quayle of months past. At every stop, he meets with local reporters and sits for TV interviews, smoothly giving the administration line on the issues of the day. He appeared momentarily stumped when a TV reporter asked how, if he did not know Buster Brown very well, he could give him such a laudatory recommendation. Quayle recovered quickly, saying that Bush knows Brown, and ``the president's word to me is golden.'' Local reporters, while sometimes complaining that he glosses over issues, often express surprise at his smoothness and unflappability. ``He was a little bit sharper than I thought he would be,'' said John Gonzales, a reporter based in Austin for the Fort Worth Star-Telegram.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 29

DOC.HEAD: Showdown Over Water Pits Las Vegas Against Rural Counties
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It is high noon and 108 degrees in the shade at the ritzy residential compound called Spanish Trail, a vista green and wet almost as far as the eye can see: past the golf course, the artificial pond, the bubbling fountains and the pristine pools _ right up to the edge of the desert. There is water, water everywhere in Las Vegas. It runs off neat lawns from sprinklers going full-blast at the hottest time of a scorching day. It rolls down sidewalks and gutters and streets and evaporates like a gambler's stake, never to be seen again. While the West Coast suffers through the fourth year of a drought that has people feeling guilty for taking showers and flushing toilets from San Diego to San Francisco, Las Vegas _ a city dry and dusty as a neon bone, save for its share of Colorado River water _ has been busy doubling the number of golf courses and building 4,000-room hotels. But now its unstoppable growth and unquenchable thirst have thrust America's desert playground into a bitter power struggle with the rest of Nevada, a showdown being played out in states all over the West. Urban takes on rural in a water war some say threatens to tear Nevada apart. ``If you work on the premise, `Let's not do anything about future water supply and let's just let it run its course, and when we run out, then we'll have to stop' _ that's economic homicide,'' said Pat Mulroy, general manager of the Las Vegas Valley Water District, which regulates water in much of Clark County. The region's explosive growth caught the water district with its hydrological pants down. Its allocation from the Colorado River, the seemingly endless bounty that has kept the area afloat and awash for years, suddenly appears to be insufficient in the wake of a two-year growth spurt that has brought 6,000 new residents each month. ``Why didn't we see this sooner? It just fell on us, absolutely fell on us,'' Mulroy said. ``The first year we thought, that's got to be construction water because of all the massive construction going on. So in the second year, 1989, we finally said, `Wait a minute! Something's got to be done.''' What the district did was ask the state water engineer to grant it the rights to an ocean of unappropriated groundwater in 20,000 square miles, most of it in Nye, Lincoln and White Pine counties, three huge rural areas to the north. The plan involves constructing 1,200 miles of pipeline over the next 30 years to transport that water out of the desert and to the people. The multibillion-dollar project _ its cost is placed at between $1.5 billion and $7 billion, depending on who's estimating _ is described as three times the size of the huge Central Arizona Project, which carries Colorado River water over the mountains to Phoenix and Tucson. And it is at least five times the size of the disastrous Owens County water grab by Los Angeles 77 years ago, the legendary scandal that inspired Roman Polanski's movie ``Chinatown.'' ``You can put taxes on us. You can do anything to us,'' said Nye County Commissioner Dick Carver, a life-long rancher. ``But you take my water, I'm done. I can't exist.'' In Nevada, where water is lifeblood and ultimate power, water law is a century old. Applications for water rights must be approved by the state water engineer, who decides whether the applications meet three criteria: Is the water unappropriated? Would rights affect any existing rights? And are the appropriations in the public interest? So far, his meetings with the counties have ended in shouting matches. ``They're more than upset; they're outraged,'' said State Water Engineer Mike Turnipseed, who could start making decisions on the applications as early as this fall. ``They fear more than just the basic idea of `You're stealing my water.' They feel it's a threat to their economic existence.'' The counties believe their future already is in Clark County's hands. Any business that wants to move in needs water. If the water rights are approved, the rural counties will have to ask Clark County for it. If the dispute ends up in court, as both sides believe, the water might be tied up for years. ``Basically, you end up with somewhat of an annexation of the counties,'' said George Benesch, an attorney for the rural areas. ``It scares the counties to death.'' Scares them so much, in fact, that they have turned to their sworn enemies for help. Ranchers and miners, whose battles over water date back 100 years, have joined forces. And they've enlisted the aid of others who they have often considered adversaries: environmentalists and the federal government. ``We've had the Sierra Club come in with the wilderness issue, and we fought wilderness,'' Carver said. ``But now we're saying, `Won't you please come and help us? Because without water, what good's a wilderness area?''' Their greatest allies, in fact, may turn out to be the inch-long pupfish _ the last 400 or so of which live in Devil's Hole National Monument near Death Valley _ and other endangered species on federal land. Clark County has said it plans to temporarily remove more groundwater than is replenished over time, a process park officials say can upset delicate ecological balances. ``The water source at Devil's Hole is so sensitive, the drop of the water table there a matter of inches could expose the rock shelf on which the algae grows that is the pupfishes' only source of survival,'' said Ed Rothfuss, superintendent of Death Valley. The federal Bureau of Land Management, which controls most of the land in Nevada, plans to protest most if not all the applications, as do the National Park Service and the Fish and Wildlife Service. When Clark County asks to use federal land, the Bureau of Land Management has the power to order an environmental impact statement, which the counties hope could stop the project for good. ``Where the battle is going to be fought, probably in court, is the decision of what is in the public interest,'' said Steve Bradhurst, a planning consultant hired by the rural counties to coordinate their attack. More than anything else, perhaps, it is the spectre of the Owens Valley that most frightens the rural counties. Agents for Los Angeles secretly bought up water rights in 1913; now Los Angeles ships almost all the valley's water 250 miles south via two giant aqueducts. The valley's thriving agricultural landscape was reduced to a noxious dustbowl by the depletion of its water. Decimated and nearly dead, it remains one of the oldest surviving symbols of urban greed and contempt for the rural areas in the West. Despite the water district's assurances that it would never happen, Nevada's counties fear they might become the newest one. ``Las Vegas has to be crazy if they think we're going to lay down and watch them do this to us,'' said Carver, who raises alfalfa and cattle on his 860 acres in Nye County.

DOC.HEAD: No Contest: Las Vegas has Clout in Nevada
With BC-Nevada Water War, b0537-b0538
DOC.TEXT: In a state with few people, the city with the most wins the power game. In Nevada, that makes Las Vegas the undisputed champ. Las Vegas, which welcomes as many as 6,000 new residents a month, is the reason Nevada is the nation's fastest-growing state. The city's population is expected to reach 1 million by 1995, four times what it was in 1980. An estimated 800,000 people live there now, out of 1.3 million in the state as a whole. The three rural counties fighting Clark County's water plan have a combined population of less than 35,000. That means Clark County controls the Nevada Legislature: 36 of 63 state lawmakers are from the Las Vegas area, and the contingent is sure to grow with next year's reapportionment. So what Clark County wants, Clark County has the numbers to get. ``If there's something in state water law we can hang our hat on to deter this plan, the power is in Las Vegas and Clark County and they'll just go ahead and change the law,'' said Steve Bradhurst, a consultant to the rural counties. Las Vegas also is the state's financial anchor. Last year, Clark County casinos accounted for 70 percent of the state's $4.6 billion in gaming revenues. Clark County needs to keep growing for the state's economic health, officials say. ``There is one large metropolitan area from which the bulk of all revenues in this state come, and that's Clark County,'' said Pat Mulroy, manager of the Las Vegas Valley Water District. ``If . .. it goes downhill, the whole state goes downhill.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 29

DOC.TEXT: It's a high-stakes game they're playing in Nevada, far removed from the blackjack, roulette and slot machines of the nation's gambling capital. This one involves water _ fast-growing Las Vegas wants it, but three rural counties say they'll fight for every drop. When it comes to water, all bets are off.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Some quotes from BC-Nevada Water War, offered for your use in laying out the story.
DOC.TEXT: ``If you work on the premise, `Let's not do anything about future water supply and let's just let it run its course, and when we run out, then we'll have to stop' _ that's economic homicide'' _ Pat Mulroy, general manager of the Las Vegas Valley Water District.
``You can put taxes on us. You can do anything to us. But you take my water, I'm done. I can't exist'' _ Dick Carver, rancher and Nye County commissioner.
``Nevada's water contracts ... are structured around a race to use and develop that water, to stake your claim to it'' _ Mulroy.
