DOC.HEAD: LAS VEGAS: Nye County.
DOC.TEXT: Nye is the third largest county in the nation, with a population that averages one person for each of its 18,000 square miles. Las Vegas' population of 800,000 is expected to reach 1 million by 1995, supplemented by some 18 million tourists a year. At that rate, Clark County's Colorado allocation of about 300,000 acre feet _ an acre foot is about 326,000 gallons, the amount of water it takes to cover an acre to the depth of one foot, enough to supply a family of four for a year _ will last just into the 21st century, with some conservation, the water district estimated. Changing the Colorado River Compact would take an agreement by other states that share the water, an unlikely scenario. California drains the basins south of Las Vegas, leaving ``barely enough water for two hotels,'' Mulroy said. The only option, she said, was unappropriated groundwater in Nevada. ``If you say the valley needs an additional supply, where does it go? It has nowhere else to go,'' Mulroy said. ``This really is the extremes, where you've got one community that has no alternative, and where the entire state is dependent on the economic livelihood of that community. Clark County's economic base is the state's economic base.'' Opponents of the plan believe that Clark County's Colorado water, plus properly conserved water from basins within its own borders, would last well into the next century. They scoff at the district's first-ever conservation plan, which introduces tiered water rates that hit big users, landscaping and building requirements and public education campaigns. Artificial lakes have been banned, and officials are allowed to turn off sprinklers if water is running into the streets. ``A conservative first time out,'' Mulroy calls the plan. The constant flow of tourists helps make the city's water consumption among the nation's highest: 380 gallons per person each day, more than twice as high as Tucson and 50 percent higher than Phoenix. But tourists aren't the only reason for that figure. Las Vegans have always had more water than they needed, and they have used it with gusto. Ponds, fountains and pools abound. There are at least 21 golf courses in and around Las Vegas, twice as many as six years ago. Hotels and housing are popping up as fast as the desert can be graded. ``All the contracts on the Colorado River are built around developing your water resource _ the use-it-or-lose-it theory,'' Mulroy said, adding that 80 percent of the area's water comes from the Colorado. ``So Nevada's water contracts ... are structured around a race to use and develop that water, to stake your claim to it.'' Rural Nevadans care little about why Clark County wastes water, or about efforts to scale back. They are just galled by the injustice of it. ``It makes us sick,'' Carver said. ``You go to Las Vegas, they water 24 hours a day, seven days a week. And it runs down the streets.'' The bottom line, however, is that Clark County has the people and the power. Even State Engineer Turnipseed acknowledges that any decision he makes could be overturned by the county's powerful legislative contingent. The rural counties know that, but they have no intention of giving in. ``There have been lives lost in the West over water. And we can see that kind of feeling here,'' Carver said. ``What it's going to be now is a civil war.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 29

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Asks Probe of Metzenbaum Involvement in Times Story
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 3rd graf to UPDATE with Times report of deal between Thompson and federal bank regulator. Also moving on general news wires. ^By DAVE SKIDMORE
DOC.TEXT: An attorney representing a GOP lobbyist involved in a controversial savings and loan bailout asked the Senate Ethics Committee on Monday to investigate whether Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, or his aides struck a ``sordid deal'' to share investigative material with The New York Times. Attorney Stanley M. Brand, representing lobbyist Robert J. Thompson, a former aide to then-vice president George Bush, asked the panel to ``initiate an ethics inquiry into improper conduct which reflects upon the Senate, and which may include violations of federal and state law by ... Metzenbaum or ... Senate staff members.'' Metzenbaum chairs the Judiciary subcommittee on antitrust, monopolies and business rights, which is looking into Thompson's involvement in negotiating the bailout of 15 thrift institutions now combined under the name of Bluebonnet Savings Bank, Dallas. Meanwhile, the Times reported in Tuesday editions that Thompson invested $100,000 with a federal regulator, Paul G. Heafy, who also was involved in Thompson's negotiations to buy an insolvent bank in Oklahoma. The newspaper reported that the investment, which was to buy distressed loans from federal regulators, did not violate conflict of interest laws, but Senate investigators wanted to look into the financing of the deal. Heafy is chief liquidator for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in Oklahoma City. He and Thompson refused the Times' requests for interviews. Brand said there is ``substantial probability'' that New York Times reporter Jeff Gerth obtained access to confidential investigative information from Brian McTigue, an aide to Metzenbaum. The information, including private financial records, was obtained ``under the cloak of Senate authority'' and was ``released ... inappropriately'' to the Times, Brand said. In December 1988, Thompson represented James M. Fail, a Phoenix, Ariz., insurance executive, who acquired the thrifts. Fail paid the government $1,000 of his own money and $70 million in borrowed funds to obtain Bluebonnet, which was bailed out with a government subsidy estimated at $1.8 billion. The now-defunct Federal Home Loan Bank Board selected Fail as the acquirer over a competing group even though an insurance company he controlled had pleaded guilty to fraud in 1976 in Alabama. The New York Times ran a front-page story on questions surrounding the Bluebonnet deal July 8, the day before Metzenbaum's subcommittee held its hearing. ``It now appears indisputable that sensitive investigative information ... gathered in the name of the U.S. Senate, was deliberately, intentionally and inappropriately given to a major national newspaper,'' Brand wrote. ``If this type of investigative information ... (is) released maliciously to reporters it can cause incalculable harm to private persons. This is exactly what appears to have happened in this case ... (in) what can only be described as a sordid deal to provide the Senate's investigative information to a single newspaper in return for favorable coverage on the eve of the Senate's hearing,'' he wrote. Brand based his complaint, in part, on a statement from Cable News Network reporter Brooks Jackson, who said he was told by Metzenbaum's staff that they had made an exclusive arrangement to share information with Gerth in exchange for an agreement that the Times would hold the story until the day before the hearing. Jackson, who was quoted in Saturday editions of The Washington Post, said he was quoted accurately but declined to reveal which Metzenbaum aide had told him about the arrangement with the Times. McTigue declined to comment, referring questions to Metzenbaum's press spokeswoman, Nancy Coffey. Gerth also declined to comment and referred inquires to Howell Raines, the newspaper's Washington bureau chief. Raines said, ``As a matter of policy, we don't discuss sources or the editorial process.'' He said the story was ``meticulously researched from a number of sources'' and ``was industriously and honorably reported.'' Coffey said Metzenbaum considered Brand's complaint too ridiculous to comment on. ``Since when is it against the law for a senator to talk to one reporter?'' she asked, adding that ``no prearrangements'' were attached to Metzenbaum's comments. ``Nobody's rights were harmed here,'' she said. ``Mr. Thompson is complaining because he is in trouble right now. There are a lot of people with a lot of questions about how Mr. Fail was able to get such favorable deals with his background. Those are legitimate questions.'' Wilson Abney, staff director of the ethics committee, said he could not reveal what action the panel was taking on the complaint or even if it had been received. He said typically complaints are referred to staff attorneys, who can then recommend whether or not the complaint should be investigated. Meanwhile, Metzenbaum's panel is continuing its investigation and has scheduled a second hearing for Tuesday afternoon. So far, Thompson and Fail have declined to appear before the subcommittee and are disputing its jurisdiction over the matter.

A sharp turnaround on stock market psychology is seen as a key reason for the latest jolt by the Dow Jones industrial average. The nation's best-known stock barometer had toyed with breaking a record high just a week ago. The average plunged more than 100 points within the first 90 minutes of trading on Monday, recouped part of the loss and yo-yoed through much of the day in heavy trading. It finished down 56.54 points to 2,904.70. Strategists called the volatile selloff a scary reminder of weaknesses in the market that surfaced late Friday, when the Dow average fell abruptly after a long runup that did not seem based on any strong economic reason.

Kansas City Power and Light Co. has made an $857 million tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric Co., a move KCPL officials said would cut costs for both utilities and delay their need to add generating capacity. The $27 a share offer begun Monday would be financed by a $1 billion credit agreement that KCPL has signed with two banks, Westpac Banking Corp. and the First National Bank of Chicago, company officials said.

Ford Motor Co. says it has chosen to negotiate with Loral Corp. for the sale of the automaker's Ford Aerospace Corp. subsidiary. New York-based Loral was one of three finalists in the bidding for the nation's No. 2 automaker's primary defense contractor. Ford put its aerospace subsidiary up for sale on Jan. 12. ``Now that we've narrowed it down to the single bidder, we begin a negotiations process with them,'' Ford spokesman Tom Rhoades said Monday.

WASHINGTON _ Ford Motor Co. has agreed to pay a $1.2 million fine for repeatedly failing to keep track of on-the-job injuries at a Ford Electronics and Refrigeration facility in Lansdale, Pa. In a separate settlement announced Monday with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, Ford agreed to launch a program to reduce ergonomic hazards _ or workplace injuries caused by repetitive-motion tasks _ at 96 percent of its plants.

Education Department officials are searching for a solution to financial problems that threaten the viability of one of the nation's largest student loan guarantors. The Higher Education Assistance Foundation, a non-profit corporation based in Overland Park, Kan., guarantees $9.6 billion in student loans. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said late last week HEAF had notified him it was facing serious financial problems. Education Department spokeswoman Etta Fielek said Monday the agency was conducting meetings on a daily basis to find a way to ease the situation.

The House has voted to limit the amount of advertising on children's television shows, which one lawmaker complained have become ``the equivalent of a Toys R Us catalog.'' By a voice vote, the House approved legislation Monday that also would require regulators to weigh, in renewing the licenses of television stations, how well broadcasters are serving the educational needs of children. The bill and a similar measure approved by the Senate last week effectively would reverse the Reagan administration's deregulation of the commercial content of children's TV programming in 1984.

Resorts International Inc. says its bondholders have approved a reorganization plan designed to take entertainer Merv Griffin's casino company out of bankruptcy. Resorts' plan filed in December under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code would give bondholders 78 percent of the company, dropping Griffin's ownership to 22 percent. Resorts, in turn, will exchange the $911 million in debt held by those bondholders for a reduced debt service.

The French government says it will provide state-owned Thomson SA with the equivalent of $540 million over the next five years to finance research and development of high-definition television. The Industry Ministry said Monday that the electronics company has agreed to a program that sets specific targets in terms of research, product development and the launch of a product. Thomson has linked up with NV Philips of the Netherlands in a $3.6 billion, high-definition TV joint research and development program over five years. It already has devoted $1.08 billion, to its research.

Nine Swiss bank employees bought Contel Corp. securities in the days before GTE Corp. announced a deal to acquire the company, a Securities and Exchange Commission lawyer said Monday. The employees of Union Bank of Switzerland were the latest to be mentioned in the SEC's investigation of alleged insider trading that preceded disclosure of a $6 billion merger of Contel and GTE. The disclosure was made during a hearing at which a U.S. District Court judge issued a preliminary injunction extending a freeze on accounts the SEC has identified as holding the illegally obtained profits.

Stock prices plunged Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial aveage taking its worst jolt in six months. The average dropped more than 100 points in the first 90 minutes but recovered to finish down 56.44 points at 2,904.70. The dollar fell sharply against foreign currencies due to Wall Street's selloff. Bond prices declined Monday on worries about inflation and heavy government borrowing needs. Gold futures prices surged to their highest levels in two months. On other commodity markets, stock-index futures tumbled; energy futures climbed; livestock and meat futures retreated; and grains and soybeans were mostly higher.

DOC.HEAD: Eccentric Computer Programmer Wins MacArthur Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: ``Genius grant'' recipient Richard Stallman is noted as much for his eccentricities as he is for his prodigious talent as a computer programmer. He can be found in his cluttered office, his hair long and matted, his bare feet cradling an open box of crackers on the cot where he sleeps. Stallman, 37, last week was among 36 recipients of MacArthur Foundation grants. Stallman, who will receive $240,000 during the next five years, is more than a gifted nerd. In an era when his genius could earn him millions, Stallman eschews material possessions and leads a crusade for ``free'' computer software. ``Clearly, I could have gone to some company and made a lot of money,'' said Stallman, sitting cross-legged on a couch outside his office. ``But I'm more interested in a certain quality of life. When a program is free, a community of enthusiasts develops,'' he said. The term ``free software'' does not refer to cost, but to the idea of being able to openly share information about computer techniques and applications, in contrast to commercial software applications, which are restricted and sometimes patented. With free software, people can trade programs and information freely, not unlike the idea of one person buying a cassette tape or a CD and allowing others to copy them. Without free software, Stallman argues, computer enthusiasts are unable to improve existing programs because their knowledge is restricted. The brave new world pioneered by freewheeling computer ``hackers'' in the 1970s led to a static commercial ethic that threatens future progress, he said. ``It's not in the public interest, everything has turned into a commercial trade secret,'' he said. Stallman is one of the founders of the League for Programming Freedom, which has 135 members. The group is planning a protest march Aug. 2 at the Cambridge headquarters of Lotus Development Corp. A federal judge recently sided with the company, ruling it illegal to develop a program that uses the same commands and menus as an existing program. Stallman sees himself as a true hacker. A Harvard graduate, he began working on the computer system at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1971. In the highly charged atmosphere of MIT's artificial intelligence community, he was a legendary hacker, usually at his keyboard 10 hours a day, seven days a week for years. Eighteen months ago, he developed tendinitis in his hands and now must employ a typist to carry out his commands. ``I'm determined not to let it stop me,'' he said in an interview. He earns what can be considered little more than stipend money by working occasionally as a consultant, but only on what he considers free software. He has no grand plans for the no-strings-attached grant, apart from a trip to the Soviet Union, where he was invited to meet with programmers. He recalls the early days in the mid-1970s as near-Utopia in the hacker community. But around 1980, when many hackers cashed in on their talents and went corporate, Stallman found himself a maverick. ``All software was originally free,'' said Stallman. ``There was a real communal feeling. Then, in the '80s, it all changed.'' But Stallman stuck to his ideals. He left MIT in 1983 to begin working on the development of his own system of free software. His products are priced far less than comparable systems, he said. He has a staff of 15 people. ``What I set out to do was to make a complete free system,'' Stallman said. ``I want to use nothing but free software.'' In the rare hours when he leaves the computer pulsing in his tiny cubicle, Stallman socializes with other hackers. He has had a girlfriend for the past year, unusual for him, he said. His farewell is always the same: ``Happy hacking!''

DOC.HEAD: Aspin's Attack on B-2 Further Clouds Prospects for Aerospace Industry
DOC.TEXT: The call by the head of the House Armed Services Committee to build only the 15 B-2 bombers now in the production pipeline is the latest cloud to darken the skies over California's aerospace industry. Northrop officials said Monday's speech by Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., is just the latest word in a long debate over the bomber's importance as the Cold War ends. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has proposed building 75 B-2s, down from the 132 originally envisioned. So far only one B-2 has been completed, and it would take several years for the program to be phased out even if Aspin and other opponents cap production at 15 operational planes. Northrop already had announced plans to decrease the 12,700 people working on the B-2 program as it moves from its development phase to production. By year-end, Northrop plans to lay off 1,400 of the 10,500 workers at the Los Angeles suburb of Pico Rivera, where the plane was developed. But it will add 800 employees to the 2,200 now at Palmdale in the immense desert factory where final assembly takes place on the manta ray-like, radar-evading bombers. Those layoffs, announced this month, are part of a long-established decline in aerospace employment here. McDonnell Douglas Corp. is slicing about 10,000 jobs in the area and Lockheed Corp. as many as 7,000 over the coming years. Hughes Aircraft, TRW and Rockwell International had made big job cuts in Southern California before this year. At Northrop itself, peak employment of 48,200 came at the end of 1987. After cutting 2,500 employees during the past year, Northrop announced in May it would eliminate another 3,000 jobs, many of them related to the B-2. Chamber of Commerce economist Jack Kyser said Los Angeles and Orange counties have 10,000 fewer aerospace jobs now than at this time in 1989. By the end of the year the loss is expected to be 17,000 jobs, he said. ``I am surprised that the cuts are coming so fast,'' said Kyser, whose forecasts generally are at the positive end of the spectrum of economists' predictions. ``It's almost like the aerospace firms see the storm warnings coming and they're cutting back and getting into shape.'' Kyser said that it's generally believed that each job lost at prime contractors leads to another two or three layoffs at smaller aerospace companies. ``We're seeing a real scramble in the subcontracting area,'' he said. Northrop spokesman Tony Cantafio said Northrop subcontracts about 70 percent of the work on the B-2. Nationwide, between 30,000 and 40,000 people are employed in connection with the plane, most in California, but others at Boeing in Washington, LTV in Texas, General Electric in Ohio, and elsewhere. Cantafio repeated arguments by B-2 proponents that the $830 million-plus cost figures routinely given for each plane are misleading. Much of that money was absorbed by the costs of devising new technology to make the plane nearly invisible to Soviet radar _ costs that are the same whether 132 planes or none are built, he said. The 15 B-2s now in the pipeline would cost $35.8 billion total, ``but for $27.1 billion more you get 60 more airplanes,'' Cantafio said. Northrop gets about half of its more than $5 billion in yearly revenue from the B-2. That heavy reliance on one program is cited as one of the company's biggest weaknesses, along with its $800 million debt load. Lawrence Harris, an aerospace analyst at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles, said capping the B-2 program would generate enough cash to erase that debt as Northrop reduced inventories, collected receivable accounts and sold equipment back to the government. Cantafio agreed. Without the B-2 program, Northrop ``would be a much smaller company, with a much stronger balance sheet,'' he said. But if that were to happen and Northrop also lost the competition against a team led by Lockheed Corp. to build the next-generation advanced tactical fighter, the company would plummet from the ranks of major aerospace contractors. ``Then Northrop returns to where they were in the late 1970s _ major subcontractor,'' Harris said.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Faults Two Regulators on 1989 Stock Slide Studies
DOC.TEXT: A Senate leader called on the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to work out their differences after a report faulted both agencies for their conflicting analyses of last October's stock market slide. A General Accounting Office report found that differences in the SEC and CFTC studies stemmed from ``subjective interpretation and judgment.'' The two rival agencies, which have been embroiled in a jurisdictional dispute, each issued reports last month analyzing the Oct. 13 190-point drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Both studies differed in their conclusions and both agencies later lambasted the other's methodology, prompting a Senate panel to request a study of the issue by the GAO, the investigative arm of Congress. ``SEC and CFTC emphasize different factors and take different points of view to reach their conclusions. This sometimes results in different conclusions, each of which is supported by basically the same trading data,'' said the GAO report, which was released by the securities subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee. The SEC reported that index arbitrage and other program selling strategies significantly worsened the market decline while the CFTC reported that neither program trading nor futures sales explained the sharp price movements on the day of and first trading day after the drop. Index arbitrage is a computerized program trading strategy that seeks to take advantage of small differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in the other. Stock index futures, often used in program trading strategies, allow investors to trade on the movement of a basket of stocks without having to buy the underlying stocks. ``The GAO report finds the SEC-CFTC jurisdictional dispute continues to detract from their working relationship,'' said Sen. Christopher J. Dodd, D-Conn., chairman of the subcommittee. ``The agencies' major differences threatens their ability to work together to minimize risks to the capital markets. This untenable situation must be resolved,'' he added. Spokesmen for the SEC and CFTC denied that their feud was hurting their ability to work together on other issues. ``We don't feel that the ongoing debate has compromised the commission's ability to work with its sister agency, the SEC,'' said CFTC spokesman David Gary. ``That fact has most recently been shown by today's market activity,'' he said referring to a more than 100-point drop in the Dow during the early hours of trading Monday. ``Our staff people have talked to the exchanges. (CFTC Chairman) Wendy (Gramm) has spoken with (SEC Chairman Richard) Breeden, and when appropriate we have passed along information that was necessary for the SEC to do its job,'' said Gary. SEC officials declined to comment because they had not seen the final report but they noted that except for the dispute over stock index futures the agencies ``get along wonderfully.'' The Bush administration wants to strip the CFTC of its authority over stock index futures and give it to the SEC. The SEC said it stood by written comments on an earlier draft of the GAO report. In a letter to the GAO, Richard Ketchum, the director of the SEC's Market Regulation Division, maintained that the SEC's findings ``are amply supported both by detailed analyses of specific trade data and extensive interviews with relevant market participants.'' Ketchum's letter then went on to criticize a letter by CFTC Chairman Gramm last month that faulted the SEC study as ``misleading'' and ``contradictory.'' In its study, the SEC concluded that index arbitrage and other program trading strategies accelerated the 6.9 percent market drop and accounted for an unusually high percentage of share volume during the 90-minute slide.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Market Drop, Bjt ^Market Plunge Triggers Circuit Breakers in Futures Markets
DOC.TEXT: Tumbling prices tripped ``circuit breakers'' on the Chicago Board of Trade and Chicago Mercantile Exchange, prompting brief trading halts that are designed as safeguards against a market crash. Like the stock market, which sometimes leads and sometimes follows the futures markets, stock-index futures closed Monday well above their lows of the day. The index futures mimicked the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell more than 100 points in early trading and finished with a loss of about 56 points. At 10:34 a.m. EDT, about one hour after trading opened in the Merc's Standard & Poor's 500 index futures pit, the contract for September delivery dropped to 12 points below Friday's settlement price. Under the Merc's rules, if the price of an S&P 500 futures contract falls 12 points, trading is allowed only at or above that level for a period of 30 minutes. A similar episode occurred on the Chicago Board of Trade, which trades the Major Market Index futures contract. The August MMI contract hit its downside limit of 20 points at 10:40 a.m. and fell no further all day, settling at 58.869, off 11.21 points. The contract is valued at $250 per point. Stock-index futures are contracts for future deliveries of baskets of stocks. They allow investors to speculate on stock-market movements without actually owning stocks. The Merc's S&P 500 futures are the nation's most widely traded index futures.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Expands Investigation to Include Kay Jewelers
DOC.TEXT: A Securities and Exchange Commission probe into alleged insider trading preceding GTE Corp.'s announcement of a deal to buy Contel Corp. has prompted an investigation into another major takeover bid. SEC attorney James A. Kidney said Monday that the commission is looking into trading activity surrounding the July 2 offer by Ratners Group PLC, Britain's largest jewelry chain, to buy Kay Jewelers Inc., a retailer based in Alexandria, Va., for $328 million. Some of the foreign accounts that are the subject of the Contel-GTE probe also ``seem to have been doing a lot of trading in Kay Jewelers,'' Kidney said. The lawyer made his comments while seeking a preliminary injunction to continue freezing accounts the SEC has identified as holding the illegally obtained profits in the Contel-GTE case. U.S. District Judge Charles Haight Jr. granted the injunction. Kidney said nine Swiss bank employees bought Contel securities in the days that preceded disclosure of a $6 billion merger of the company and GTE. They were the latest to be mentioned in the probe. The SEC alleged in court papers filed July 13, the day after the Contel-GTE merger was announced, that ``individuals or entities whose identities are yet unknown'' used inside information about the deal to make profits of at least $1 million. On Friday, the SEC named four West Germans and three European entities that allegedly traded Contel securities based on inside information about the then-undisclosed buyout. One of the Germans has told investigators he overheard a conversation about the pending merger at a restaurant, Kidney said. Kidney said other individuals or companies that ordered the purchase of large blocks of Contel securities through European bank accounts have not yet come forward. He said it could take months before they were identified because the U.S. government would have to use international treaties to force the banks in Switzerland, West Germany and Luxembourg to identify their customers. He said Union Bank of Switzerland was cooperating in the investigation and had interviewed six of its nine employees who bought Contel call options on July 10 and 11 for their own accounts. A call option is the right to buy 100 shares of a stock or stock index at a set price before a certain date. Because Contel stock jumped in price after the buyout proposal was revealed, a buyer of its call options at the pre-announcement price could reap big profits after disclosure of the deal. The six Union Bank employees were identified as Frederic Galliard, Alfred Keller, Rolf Koechli, Phillip Colliard, Thierry Racine and Oliver Roth. Bank attorney John Dickey said the employees, most of whom worked in the bank's trading department in Geneva, bought the securities because they noticed an increase in Contel call option trading and because a ``substantial customer'' had placed a large order for Contel securities. The customer was not identified. The three other Union Bank employees had not been interviewed because two were on vacation and one was recovering from injuries from an automobile accident, Dickey said. The West Germans named Friday by the SEC are: Ortwin Heider of Hofheim; Hans-Jurgen Klisch and Hannelore Mirbach-Krahn, both of Meerbusch and Bodo Pawlik, of Ratingen. The SEC complaint also identified three entities accused of violating insider trading laws: Union Investment, a Dusseldorf mutual fund; and two companies with offices in Switzerland, Nalasag Corp. in Geneva, and Sigesse SA in Lausanne.

DOC.HEAD: Pa. Companies Saying No To Key Sections of Takeover Law
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 50 Pennsylvania corporations have decided to exempt themselves in whole or part from the state's tough anti-takeover law and the list is growing as Thursday's deadline for acting approaches. By Monday, 47 companies had said no to embracing the full law, and more companies were expected to join the ranks, according to William A. K. Titelman, an attorney who lobbied against the law and is now tabulating the companies who are opting out. Among those taking the action are roughly half of the Pennsylvania companies on the Fortune 500 and Standard and Poor's 500 lists. ``The more the Pennsylvania business community has gotten to know the bill, the more they dislike it at least for themselves,'' Titelman said in a telephone interview. But Bill Baer, vice president for government affairs for the Pennsylvania Chamber of Business and Industry, which championed the law, said ``it was agreed that this was not going to be one size fits all'' and companies were going to decide what was in their best interest. Enacted in April, the law gave publicly traded companies until July 26 to decide. Privately held companies have a year to make up their minds. The law, regarded as the nation's toughest against hostile takeovers, for the first time requires unsuccessful raiders to surrender their profits if they sell the stock within 18 months of the attempted takeover. The clause is aimed at so-called greenmailers who target a company they hope will buy back its shares at a premium to make the raiders go away. Raiders who gain 20 percent or more of a company will not get voting rights until other stockholders approve. And company directors can balance the interests of stockholders, employees and others in weighing a takeover bid. Investor groups bitterly fought the bill, arguing it would depress stock values. But proponents said it was vital to stopping profit-hungry financiers from gobbling up Pennsylvania companies, breaking them up and destroying jobs and communities. Impetus for the law came from lawmakers intent on saving Armstrong World Industries of Lancaster from a takeover bid by the Belzberg family of Canada. The Belzbergs have since abandoned their plans. Titelman, a partner in the Klett Lieber Rooney & Schorling law firm of Pittsburgh, represented the Belzbergs. State Sen. Noah Wenger, R-Lancaster, who sponsored the law, said he hoped companies weren't being lulled by the slowdown in hostile takeovers and would remember that takeovers could start anew if financing again became available. ``Some may feel the protections are not as needed as they were a few years ago,'' Wenger said. ``That may be deceptive.'' William George, president of the AFL-CIO, which succeeded in adding job protection sections to the law, said investors have pressured some companies into exempting themselves. He also noted that some companies that were presented as needing protection have since exempted themselves. When lawmakers were considering the bill, proponents said Conrail was an example of a Pennsylvania company that needed protection, and the argument swayed votes to the bill. But July 18, Conrail's board announced it was exempting itself from the sections stripping raiders' profits, also known as disgorgement, and blocking immediate voting rights for a raider, known as control shares. Company spokesman David Neurohr said Conrail felt initially that the bill moving through the Legislature was ``a mixed bag,'' although the company supported it. But once optional features were added and remained in the law, the Conrail board felt compelled to choose those that are in the best interest of the company, employees and community, Neurohr said. Among the top companies opting out of all sections of the new law are H.J. Heinz Co., PNC Financial Corp., Westinghouse Electric Corp., and the Reading Co. Companies opting out of disgorgement and control shares include Allegheny Ludlum Corp., Dravo Corp., Duquesne Light Co., Kennametal Inc., and Mellon Bank. The Sun Co. has opted out of disgorgement. Despite the decision of its board to push for the law, the Chamber of Business and Industry was by no means unanimous on accepting all its provisions. Richard Ross. Jr., the chamber's chairman, announced Monday that his company, First Eastern Corp., had opted out of the disgorgement and control shares sections of the laws.

DOC.HEAD: House Combines, Passes Securities Reform Legislation
DOC.TEXT: The House has passed legislation giving the Securities and Exchange Commission new powers to impose fines for illegal activities beyond insider trading. Less than a week earlier a similar bill cleared the Senate. The House also passed legislation that would crack down on penny stock fraud. The penny stock bill, which combined two earlier bills cleared through committee last month, was passed on a voice vote by the House Monday. The Securities Enforcement and Penny Stock Reform Act of 1990 also would give the SEC authority to order alleged wrongdoers to ``cease and desist'' illegal activities without first having to go to court and obtain a restraining order. The legislation would widen SEC authority to seek court orders barring convicted securities law violators from serving as officers or directors of companies with publicly traded stock. The Senate passed a bill last week giving the SEC similar authority to fine, issue cease and desist orders and ask courts to bar crooks from serving as corporate officers. A separate penny stock bill also is pending in the Senate. The penny stock provisions of the House bill would give the SEC the power to bar crooked promoters and consultants from selling the highly speculative stocks which usually sell for $1 or less. Penny stocks are not traded on most stock exchanges. The bulk of the information obtainable about them comes from the brokers sho sell them. While not illegal, penny stocks _ which typically are used to finance new or small companies _ are considered to be very risky at best. The House bill would allow the SEC: _ To close a loophole that now allows unscrupulous penny stock brokers to evade SEC removal from the securities business by calling themselves promoters or consultants, which the SEC has no power to regulate. _ To tighten disclosure requirements for highly speculative investments known as ``blind pools'' and ``blank checks.'' ``In their combined form, these two bills represent a powerful expansion of the enforcement weapons available to combat the problems of securities fraud in general and the penny stock market in particular,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., who sponsored the initial penny stock legislation along with Reps. Matthew Rinaldo, R-N.J. and Ron Wyden, D-Ore. The other half of the bill originally was introduced by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee which oversees the SEC.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Company Announces Bondholder Approval of Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc.'s bondholders have approved a reorganization plan that will give them 78 percent of hotel and casino company, leaving entertainer Merv Griffin with the rest. The reorganization is part of the casino company's plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The plan, approved by bondholders Monday, must still be confirmed at a hearing scheduled today at U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Camden, and approved by the New Jersey Casino Control Commission as well as the government of the Bahamas. The plan would give bondholders 78 percent of the company, dropping Griffin to 22 percent ownership. Resorts, in turn, will exchange the $911 million in debt held by those bondholders for a reduced debt service of $430.3 million. The plan, filed in December and amended in April to include the proposed sale of Resorts' Paradise Island operations in the Bahamas. Resorts officials estimated Paridise Island could fetch between $250 million and $300 million for the struggling company. ``Now that our bondholders have approved our plan, we are looking forward to obtaining the court's approval,'' Resorts President David Hanlon said in a news release. ``Our reorganization should be complete by the end of the summer, and we will focus all of our energy on making Resorts the finest resort, and the best investment, it can be.'' Bondholders have said the plan is the best way to get some return on their investments. The plan gives senior secured bondholders $292.8 million in new notes and 2.5 percent of Griffin's shares. Those bondholders approved the plan with 98.4 percent of the vote, representing 99.9 percent of the principal they owned, Resorts said. Holders of Resorts' highest paying bonds, 16| percent, would receive 32.4 percent of the shares and $58.9 million in new bonds. Those bondholders approved the plan with 90 percent of the vote representing 98.5 percent of their principal amount. The remaining bondholders would get 43.1 percent of the company stock and $78.6 million in new notes. They approved the plan with 89.8 percent of the vote representing 93.6 percent of the principal amount. The plan also sets aside a legal kitty of $5 million to pursue a possible fraudulent conveyance action against Donald Trump, who swapped Resorts to Griffin for the newly opened Taj Mahal Casino Resort next door on the Boardwalk. Resorts had expected that the April 2 opening of the Taj Mahal would bring more customers to that end of the Boardwalk but that has failed to occur. The casino continues its slide of declining gross gaming revenue, or ``win'' when compared to the same time period the year before. The casino has posted lower win figures each month for more than a year, with the latest month down 12.7 percent from June 1989, according to the state Casino Control Commission. For the year through June 30, Resorts has pulled in $97.7 million in gross gaming revenues, an 11.9 percent drop from the first six months of 1989. The company recorded a $3.1 million loss for the first quarter of 1990 on overall operating revenues of $107.6 million. Resorts had a loss of $18.7 million in the first quarter of 1989 on overall operating revenues of $113.5 million.

DOC.HEAD: Decision Expected Soon in Aerospace Bid
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. expects to finish negotiations with a New York company in the next three months to sell its Ford Aerospace Corp. subsidiary. If negotiations with Loral Corp. are successful, Ford will join Chrylser Corp. in getting rid of its non-automotive, defense-oriented subsidiaries. Loral and Ford announced Monday that the New York City-based defense electronics company was chosen for intensive negotiations from three finalists, one of which included a subsidiary of General Motors Corp. ``Now that we've narrowed it down to the single bidder, we begin a negotiations process with them,'' Ford spokesman Tom Rhoades said. ``We hope we'd be able to wrap it up in the next three months.'' Loral issued a statement from New York saying it will form a new corporation with the merchant banking operations of Shearson Lehman Hutton of New York to acquire Ford Aerospace. Each will contribute about $150 million of equity. The balance, which was not disclosed, will be financed. Loral would have the option of increasing its stake later, the company said. The Los Angeles Times said in Monday editions that Loral's proposal involves $800 million in cash and an assumption of Ford Aerospace liabilities that would add another $500 million to the offer. The newspaper said Ford was seeking $1.2 billion in cash. Chrysler sold its main defense contractor, Gulfstream Aerospace Corp., in February for $825 million. Ford and Chrysler said in putting the subsidiaries up for sale that they wanted to concentrate on designing, building and selling cars and trucks. The subsidiaries were put on the block as Defense Department orders began shrinking. GM, the nation's largest automaker, said it has no intention of selling its primary defense contractor, GM-Hughes Electronics Corp. In fact, GM-Hughes was part of a joint effort with Alcatel Co. of France as one of the three final bidders for Ford Aerospace. The third was a consortium of Westinghouse Electric Corp., the investment firm Carlyle Group and Aerospatiale of France, which is connected to the Airbus aircraft. ``Loral's offer was the best financially and meets all of our requirement,'' Ford Chairman Harold Poling said in a statement Monday. ``The sale is for the whole of Ford Aerospace Corporation _ a fundamental objective for us throughout the sale process.'' Poling said Loral had agreed to keep pay and benefits for Ford Aerospace's 17,000 employees in force for at least two years. Ford declines to supply earnings figures for Ford Aerospace, but said the Newport Beach, Calif.-based company received about $1.8 billion in contract awards. At year's end, it had a backlog of about $2 billion in contracts.
Ford Aerospace's operations include the Sidewinder air-to-air missile, space vehicles including the INTELSAT communications satellite and computer programs.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Cuts Fares Up to 57 Percent For Three Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines announced it is cutting its nationwide fares up to 57 percent during the next three weekends. The Houston-based carrier's sale fares range from $39 to $129 one way. They are first available for travel beginning Thursday, Friday or Saturday and ending Saturday, Sunday or Monday. Continental said the fares also apply to travel beginning Aug. 2-4 and returning Aug. 4-6; and beginning Aug. 9-11 and returning Aug. 11-13. The sale fares are available on virtually all mainland U.S. flights and some international flights. For example, the fare from Boston to Austin, Texas, will be $99 each way, compared with a regular low fare of $182 each way. That's a savings of 46 percent. Continental also is offering some international weekend sale fares. The sale fare from Houston to Acapulco is $69 each way, while travel from Newark, N.J., to Bermuda is $99 each way. ``The enormous popularity of our most recent weekend sale fares for travel between hub cities have encouraged us to offer a weekend sale for travel nationwide,'' a Continental spokesman said. Continental said seats are limited. Tickets must be purchased on Tuesday or Wednesday and within 24 hours of making a reservation. A round-trip purchase is required, and tickets are nonrefundable. Travel must occur on the same weekend.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Repels Changes to Farm Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Senate resumes debate at 9 a.m. EDT, House at 11 a.m. EDT. Tops prospects uncertain. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 farm bill sent to the Senate by its agriculture committee is surviving major changes. The Senate was debating an amendment today that would reduce guarantees to sugar producers from 18 cents a pound to 16 cents. The House, meanwhile, faced more than 100 amendments in taking up its version of the bill today. On Monday, the Senate defeated an amendment that would have made significant changes in the section on ``sustainable'' agriculture, that system of farming the seeks reduction in chemical use. The proposal offered by Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, would have weakened a provision was meant to enhance government activities to encourage sustainable agriculture. It was defeated, 60-32. The Senate defeated, 62-29, an amendment by Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., to discontinue use of animals for acute toxicity testing in product safety experiments. Opponents said the measure said it was a Commerce Committee problem that should make its way to the floor through that panel, not as an addition to the farm bill. The Senate approved amendments that would: _Authorize $250,000 to study the effects of timber harvesting and deforestation in the New York and New Jersey highlands. _Make wood products eligible for agricultural export programs. _Require that the Agriculture Department phase in changes in research programs so that by 1993, the Agricultural Research Service is spending 20 percent of its budget on alternative crops and products. The bill authorizes $730 million annually for the service during the five-year life of the bill. Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., criticized the Agriculture Department as oriented too much toward increasing crop yields. ``We produce so much we don't know what to do with it,'' Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said in support of the amendment. ``This says we want to channel some of this research into non-food uses.'' Products that are under development now include using corn as a substitute for road salt, soybean oil as a pesticide carrier and corn and wheat starches to make products biodegradable.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Boosting Prices for '91s by Average of 3.2 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The average price for a 1991 model Ford Motor Co. car will be 3.2 percent, or $528, higher than a comparably equipped 1990 model, a company spokesman says. Ford spokesman David Krupp also said Monday the average light truck price would increase 3.6 percent, but did not say how much money that would involve. The increases were outlined to dealers who are placing orders for 1991 vehicles now. In addition to the vehicle price increases, Ford said delivery charges would increase by $10 per car and prices for some options will rise. Neither General Motors Corp. nor Chrysler Corp. have announced prices for their full 1991 car and truck lineups.

DOC.HEAD: Says Earnings Gain 27 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Reuters Holdings PLC, the British news agency and financial information services group, said Tuesday that earnings jumped 27 percent in the first half of the year, helped by strong sales in all major markets, particularly Europe. Reuters said earnings for the six months ended June 30 totaled 108 million pounds or $188 million, compared with 85.3 million pounds or $148 million in the same period a year ago. Sales gained 26 percent to 688.3 million pounds or $1.2 billion from 548.3 million pounds $954 million. The company said sales strength was partly due to the relative weakness of the pound during the period. That makes British companies more competitive in selling products and services in other countries. The pound has since moved up to 18-month highs against the dollar and nine-month highs against the German mark. On Tuesday, the pound was quoted at $1.82. Reuters noted in its statement that ``conditions in financial markets remain difficult and cancellations of Reuter services, which were already high, have recently risen further.'' The company didn't break out quarterly results. It isn't required to under British law. The figures were converted at the company-provided exchange rate of $1.74 to the pound.

The stock market opened tentatively today as investors sifted for bargains through the wreckage of Monday's selloff. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 5.70 at 2,910.40 at 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Declining issues narrowly outnumbered advances on the New York Stock Exchange, with 464 up, 511 down and 522 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 23.65 million shares after the first 30 minutes of trading. The NYSE's index of all its listed issues was almost unchanged at 194.21, off 0.01. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.26 to 355.18. Market watchers expect continued volatility today because traders lack a compelling reason to buy or sell heavily. Some stocks battered Monday could benefit from selective buying, analysts say. In the early going, McDonald's was unchanged at 33, stabilizing after Monday's steep slide. The hamburger chain reported unexpectedly poor quarterly results late Friday, prompting investors to dump the stock Monday in heavy trading. Elsewhere among the heavily trading blue chips, General Electric fell { to 72, Philip Morris dropped \ to 48}, International Business Machines shed | to 115\ and Exxon was up ~ to 48}. Dow Chemical tumbled 4| to 53{ after reporting a 50 percent plunge this morning in its second-quarter earnings. Disappointing corporate earnings reports released recently set a negative tone in the market Monday and acted as one of the catalysts causing the setback that had the Dow industrial average off more than 100 points in morning trading. The average managed to regain about half of its early loss. By the close Monday, the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices, stood at 2,904.70, down 56.44 points from last week's close. Concerns that inflationary pressures may be building at a time of economic weakness contributed to the bearish outlook on Wall Street. Computer-aided program trading also played a part in the selloff and added to the volatility. On Monday, declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 6 to 1 in nationwide trading of NYSE-listed stocks Monday, with 227 up, 1,430 down and 365 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 209.03 million shares, up from 177.81 million Friday. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 3.43 to 194.22. The American Stock Exchange's market value index closed at 354.92, down 5.53.

DOC.HEAD: Many Strategists Don't Foresee Another Stock Market Rout
DOC.NOTE: EDS: graf 6 NEW to UPDATE with early Wall Street activity; uppicks 6th graf pvs: Equities markets ...
DOC.TEXT: A scary drop in stock prices has resurrected memories of market instability and suddenly cast doubt on the ability of the Dow Jones average to decisively crack the 3,000 barrier. But investment strategists say elements that caused the price tumble Monday had been building for awhile. Many said they didn't presage any significant bailout from the stock market unless there's some unforeseen economic calamity. ``We're at or slightly below the levels where we closed at the end of June,'' said David Edington, a portfolio manager at Pacific Investment Management Co. in Newport Beach, Calif. The Dow average, the most widely watched barometer of the market's direction, dropped more than 100 points early Monday and sent shock waves throughout the financial markets. But the index regained half the loss by the end of the day and closed down 56.44 points at 2,904.70. Still, it was the biggest one-day point loss for the average in six months and a sharp turnaround in psychology from last week, when the Dow average neared closing above the 3,000 mark for the first time. Trading was tentative when the market opened today amid expectations of continued volatility. The Dow was up 5.70 at 2,910.40 in the first half hour of dealing as investors searched for bargains in the wake of Monday's selloff. Equities markets overseas appeared to have a mixed response to Wall Street's Monday decline. Japan's 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 192.33 points today, losing 0.60 percent to close at 31,702.46 following a 526.72-point loss on Monday. But in London, stocks were higher around midday as cash-rich institutions took advantage of cheaper prices created by Monday's drop in New York. At about noon local time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 11.6 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,371.3. Lawrence Helfand, a senior strategist with the Rodman & Renshaw investment firm in Chicago, said he had been expecting a correction. ``I anticipate (Monday's drop) is part of that correction. There's lots of negative news around, with no real reason to anticipate any positive news.'' Broader measurements of the stock market also dropped Monday for reasons ranging from from a rash of disappointing corporate earnings, to revived fears of higher interest rates, to continued anxiety over the federal deficit. Many strategists also called the drop a classic Wall Street symptom known as ``Blue Monday,'' the tendency for prices to fall right after weekends. In this case, the excuse to sell was aggravated by the market's sudden weakness late Friday. ``It's the kind of shakeout we've had before,'' said Robert Farrell, chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch & Co. in New York. ``I don't think it's the start of a really big decline.'' Many attributed the volatility in stocks to the use of high-volume computerized strategies known as program trading, which critics say can severely exaggerate price movements. The Dow drop helped cause a similar decline in the stock-index futures market, where traders bet on the direction of stock prices by buying and selling contracts based on market indexes. The futures drop activated a ``circuit breaker'' that briefly halted trading in the Standard & Poor's stock-index contract. The New York Stock Exchange also requested voluntary compliance with its proposed ban on computerized selling tactics in a falling market. The circuit breakers were put in place to forestall a collapse like that of Black Monday, Oct. 19, 1987. The NYSE proposal for voluntary program trading halts has been awaiting federal regulatory approval for several months. It was unclear what effect the NYSE's request had Monday, but Sharon Gamsin, spokeswoman for the nation's largest stock market, said ``by and large, it appears there was compliance.'' Although the Dow average is the most widely recognized yardstick of the stock market, it had recently surged ahead of broader, more important measurements of the stock market's health. Therefore, many strategists weren't surprised by the size of the average's drop. ``The market is sick and it's been camouflaged by the phobia for 3,000,'' said Stan Weinstein, a widely followed strategist who publishes the investor newsletter Professional Tape Reader. He accurately forecasted the 1987 plunge. ``I'm not telling you you have to have a crash,'' Weinstein said. ```I'm just saying, when you have this kind of stuff, the caution flags are flying.''

DOC.HEAD: Employment Costs Jumped 5.2 Percent Over Past 12 Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 5-7, In another sign, with collective settlements report, comment.
DOC.TEXT: Wages, salaries and other benefits paid to American workers shot up 5.2 percent in the 12 months ending in June, the government reported today. The Labor Department said its Employment Cost Index, considered one of the best gauges of inflationary wage pressures, was pushed ahead both by rising wage costs and higher benefit costs. The 5.2 percent jump was well above the 4.5 percent increase of a year ago for the 12-month period ending June 1989, the department said. Today's report was sure to add to analysts' worries that the nation is suffering from entrenched inflation. Last week, the government reported that consumer inflation has risen 5.9 percent so far this year, well above the 4.6 percent inflation rate for all of last year. In another sign of higher wage pressures, the Labor Department said today that major collective settlements reached so far this year provided average wage increases of 3.8 percent over the life of the pacts, up from a 2.5 percent average increase the last time those contracts were negotiated. Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co., called the government's data on rising labor costs ``more of the same story on inflation.'' ``The message is that there is no relief in sight ... it is stable, but stable at a high and entrenched rate,'' Sinai said. Following the bad news on inflation last week, analysts said it was unlikely the Federal Reserve would be able to stray any time soon from its inflation-fighting campaign and lower interest rates. The 5.2 percent rise in the cost index for private industry workers covered total compensation, which includes wages, salaries and the employer costs of providing such benefits as health insurance. The wage and salary component of the index climbed by 4.5 percent in the 12 months ending in June while benefit costs rose a sharper 6.9 percent. Part of the jump in wages and salaries reflected the rise in the minimum wage that took effect April 1, when the minimum wage went from $3.35 an hour to $3.80 an hour, the Labor Department said. However, the impact of that increase _ the first rise in the minimum wage in 10 years _ was probably minimal, the agency said. Workers in the service sector of the economy fared better than the manufacturing sector in pay gains, the government said. Service industries saw wages and salaries go up by 4.6 percent in the past 12 months compared to a 4.2 percent rise for the manufacturing sector. In part, that gain reflects the fact that service industries have been more affected by shortages of workers in the past year. However, there was a wide fluctuation in both the services and manufacturing categories. Wage increases ranged from 2.3 percent in transportation to 6.3 percent in health services in the service industry, while pay gains ranged from 2.9 percent in construction to 4.8 percent in non-durables manufacturing. Non-union workers received better wage gains than their union counterparts, continuing a trend that's been ongoing since 1983-84, the government said. Non-union workers' pay rose 4.8 percent while union workers saw gains of 3.3 percent. The 5.2 percent increase in total compensation for private industry over the 12 months ending in June matched the 5.2 percent rise in the 12 months ending in March. The 4.5 percent rise in wages and salaries was faster than the 4.1 percent increase from a year ago and the 4.2 percent increase for the year ending in March. The 6.9 percent jump in benefit costs was down slightly from the 7.2 percent increase for the 12-month period ending in March, but well above the 5.6 percent increase of a year ago. Pressures of wage inflation have intensified every quarter since June of 1988, when the Employment Cost Index rose above the 4 percent level for the first time. In part, analysts blame rising wage and benefit costs on a tight labor market that is forcing employers to spend more to recruit and keep workers.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 10 Percent Profit Rise in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: PepsiCo Inc. said Tuesday its earnings for the second quarter rose 10 percent from a year ago on a 17 percent sales gain, led by double-digit advances in the snack food and restaurant divisions. The company, whose largest business is soft drinks, said it earned $292.5 million, or $1.10 a share, in the three months ended June 16 compared with $264.9 million, or $1 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose to $4.20 billion from $3.59 billion a year earlier. The latest results were reduced by a $5.5 million after-tax charge resulting from a customer bankruptcy, while the 1989 results were boosted by $22.2 million mainly resulting from the company's decision to keep rather than sell a bottling operation in Japan. Soft-drink sales rose 8 percent to $1.6 billion but operating profit fell 3 percent to $233.2 million. If one-time items are excluded from both years, operating profit from soft drinks would have been up 15 percent. Domestic soft drink sales rose 5 percent, including a 4 percent gain in bottler case sales that were driven by double-digit growth in the Diet Pepesi products, strong gains in Mountain Dew and a solid Pepsi brand performance. International soft drink sales rose 23 percent. Snack foods sales climbed 24 percent to $1.2 billion, including sales from Smiths and Walkers acquired last year, while operating profit rose 18 percent to $226.2 million. Excluding Smiths and Walkers and onetime items in both years, sales and operating profit would have each risen 12 percent. Domestic sales rose 6 percent, while international sales more than doubled, helped by a strong volume increases and lower commodity costs. Its brands include Chee-tos, Santitas and Crunch Tators. Restaurant sales rose 22 percent to $1.4 billion while operating profit rose 36 percent to $228.6 million. Excluding the impact od onetime items, operating profit would risen 25 percent. Sales rose 25 percent to $676 million at the Pizza Hut chain, 21 percent to $399 million at Taco Bell and 18 percent to $358 million at Kentucky Fried Chicken. For the first half, PepsiCo said it earned $474.4 million, or $1.78 a share, up 10.2 percent from $430.0 million, or $1.62 a share, a year ago. Revenue for the first half rose 20 percent to $7.88 billion from $6.55 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Seeks Class-Action in Asbestos Cases
DOC.TEXT: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. is seeking class-action status for 65,000 asbestos-related claims to avoid arguing the same issues repeatedly in individual cases. The company said Monday it has filed a request for class-action status with U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein in New York, who last week was given authority to reorganize the Manville trust. The $3 billion trust, which was formed as part of the 1988 bankruptcy reorganization of Manville Corp., has run out of money to pay about 130,000 new claims. Manville was driven into bankruptcy court by thousands of lawsuits by victims of asbestos-related diseases. Eagle-Picher, which reported settling 7,800 asbestos claims in the first six months of the year, said it believes the Manville trust will have to participate in the settlements. A federal judge in Cleveland recently authorized creating a national class-action to settle more than 100,000 asbestos lawsuits crowding U.S. court dockets. Negotitations have begun on structuring the settlement mechanism. Eagle-Picher has been inundated with lawsuits by people who say their health suffered from exposure to an asbestos-based pipe sealer Eagle-Picher made for ships during World War II. Eagle-Picher said its own settlements for the first half of the year averaged $5,900. About 11,300 new plaint too ridiculous to comment on. ``Since when is it against the law for a senator to talk to one reporter?'' she asked, adding that ``no prearrangements'' were attached to Metzenbaum's comments. Meanwhile, the Times reported in today's editions that Thompson invested $100,000 with a federal regulator, Paul G. Heafy, who also was involved in Thompson's negotiations to buy an insolvent bank in Oklahoma. The newspaper reported that the investment, which was to buy distressed loans from federal regulators, did not violate conflict of interest laws, but Senate investigators wanted to look into the financing of the deal. Heafy is chief liquidator for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. in Oklahoma City. The Times said he and Thompson refused the Times' requests for interviews.

Stocks traded tentatively today as investors sifted for bargains through the wreckage of Monday's selloff. DOC.HEAD: Earnings Plunge 39 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. today reported a 39 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, blaming the weakness on high insurance payouts and a decline in retailing income. The retailing and financial services conglomerate reported earnings of $237.9 million, or 69 cents per share, for the three months ending June 30 vs. $391.2 million, or $1.11 per share, for the same period a year ago. Revenues rose 4.3 percent to $13.9 billion from $13.3 billion, Chicago-based Sears said in a statement. The year-ago results included a gain of $56.3 million, or 16 cents per share, from discontinued operations. Ten days ago, Sears announced it expected second-quarter earnings to be about 65 cents per share. Sears said earnings were depressed by unexpected catastrophe-related losses in its Allstate Insurance Group. The company also cited a weaker performance by its Sears Merchandise Group, the nations' largest retailer. The retailing operation reported a 32 percent drop in operating income, to $110 million from $162 million. Retailing revenues rose about 2 percent to $7.9 billion from $7.7 billion, Sears said. For the first six months of 1990, Sears earned $344.2 million, or $1 per share, on sales of $26.5 billion, vs. $648.9 million, or $1.81 per share, on sales of $25.4 billion in the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Little Progress Reported At White House Budget Talks
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; INSERTS new grafs 7-8, bgng, Flying to... to UPDATE with White House comment; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders met for two hours today in hopes of spurring a deficit-reduction compromise, but a top House negotiator later said ``fundamental disagreements'' remain. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., also said that President Bush's recent attacks on congressional Democrats at Republican fund-raising events aren't helping the process of finding a compromise. ``One of the things discussed today was to stop the political debate and start the substantive debate and to try to cut down on the political comment that's gone on on all sides,'' Gephardt told reporters outside the White House. Bush himself seemed downbeat, refusing to answer questions at a picture-taking session at the start of today's meeting. ``Don't even try, I'm in a bad mood today,'' Bush told reporters. He did not elaborate. Bush has been lashing out at Democrats and the congressional budget process in a series of GOP fund-raising speeches. In fact, he was attending similar events today in Philadelphia and New York. Gephardt said that Bush had agreed to cool down his attacks and ``I think you're going to see that happen.'' Flying to Philadelphia aboard Air Force One, White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush would be ``very gentle'' toward the Democrats in his campaign speeches. ``They're working in a spirit of harmony and compromise. In fact, they agreed this morning at the meeting that they would try to keep the rhetoric under control and really try to make this a productive week of work,'' Fitzwater said. Gephardt, who is the leader of the ``budget summit'' negotiations when Bush is not present, said he still thought it possible that accord could be reached by early August, when Congress begins its summer recess. ``But I don't know for absolute sure that we can do that,'' he added. ``It may be that we can't get all of it done. But we're going to give it the good old college try.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said decisions remain to be made on the precise amount of deficit reduction that would be sought, and how much of the savings would come from new taxes and spending cuts. Bargainers have said they expect any compromise to contain about $50 billion in savings, divided in half between revenues and spending reductions. ``I don't think there is at this point a clear definition of what each side wants,'' Foley told reporters. Gephardt said budget negotiators would meet again on Capitol Hill later today. He said a smaller group including top House and Senate leaders and the president would meet again at the White House on Wednesday morning. ``We'll try to work both groups together as we try to work toward a solution of the problem,'' he said. ``There are still some very difficult areas of discussion that will be hard to close on. This is not easy to do.'' ``There are fundamental disagreements'' on taxes, spending cuts in entitlement programs and on defense spending levels, the Democratic leader added. Gephardt said the president did not offer any specific proposals on new taxes at today's session. The Oval Office session also included Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine; Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan.; and House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill. After 11 weeks of bargaining, there is still very little agreement on specifics, Gephardt conceded. The two sides have made no decisions about where they will find $50 billion in new taxes and spending cuts for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Bush met with congressional leaders last Wednesday in hopes of advancing the negotiations. But since then, the two sides have done little but argue. The House's 176 minority Republicans voted informally that same day to oppose any tax increases as part of a budget-cutting package. Democrats said that vote hurt the talks by casting doubt on whether GOP lawmakers would eventually support a compromise. Negotiators met last Thursday but spent the closed-door meeting yelling at each other, participants said. And Friday, on a Western campaign trip, Bush accused congressional Democrats of causing the recent run of $150 billion a year-plus budget shortfalls, prompting Democrats to fire back. The budget negotiators hope to produce a package within the next two or three weeks, when Congress' August recess begins. But bargainers concede it will be hard to accomplish that goal.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Executive to be Named Cable News Network Head
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with appointment official, CORRECT from 18 to 17 years at Times Mirror. A version is moving on the business wire.
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Co. Vice Chairman Tom Johnson, who has spent most of his career in print journalism, was named today as as president and chief executive of Ted Turner's Cable News Network. Johnson, 48, who began at the Macon Telegraph and News in his native Georgia, will succeed Burt Reinhardt, 70, on Aug. 1. Reinhardt has been with the all-news cable network since Turner began it 10 years ago and became its president in 1982. Turner, chairman of Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System, announced Johnson's hiring in Seattle, where he is attending the Goodwill Games sports competition his company is sponsoring. Reinhardt will become vice chairman of CNN and advise Johnson during the latter's transition into his new job. Reinhardt plans to retire later, a CNN spokeswoman in New York said. The Atlanta-based CNN, the 24-hour all-news network, reached 53.8 million U.S. households last year. It says it reaches 90 other nations. Johnson would leave his job as chairman of Times Mirror's newspaper management committee. Last year, he stepped down as publisher of the Los Angeles Times after nine years in that post. Turner, who conducted a yearlong search for Reinhardt's replacement, spoke with Johnson about three weeks ago and the job was offered to him Thursday, the Los Angeles Times said. Johnson leaves Times Mirror after 17 years, 13 of them at the Los Angeles Times. During his tenure as publisher, the newspaper's revenue tripled from $333 million to more than $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Just Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing stock prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday after an anticipated early advance on Wall Street failed to materialize. Shares shot higher from the outset, rebounding from Monday's deep losses. But the gains were undermined by the uninspired Wall Street start, dealers said. The Dow Jones industrial average struggled for most of the morning session in New York, vacillating between small gains and losses. By the close of the London session, the Dow Jones average was up 3.47 points at 2,908.17. On Monday, the Dow average lost 56.44 points to close at 2,904.70, after falling as much as 107 points during the session. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 1.2 points, or 0.05 percent, to close at 2,360.9. The index's session peak was 2,378.1 and its low was 2,351.8. The Financial Times 30-share index was off 0.4 point at 1,866.7 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 0.64 point to close at 1,273.22. Volume came to 385.7 million shares compared with 369.8 million shares Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Lloyd's Sues McDonnell Over Satellite Damage
DOC.TEXT: Aerospace manufacturer McDonnell Douglas Corp. is defending itself against a $6 million lawsuit filed by Lloyd's of London, alleging negligence for damage to a satellite. The case stems from a June 20, 1989, accident at a Cape Canaveral launch pad in which a 65-pound crane hook crashed into an $80 million communications satellite on a Delta rocket. The satellite was insured by Lloyd's, and the manufacturer repaired it at an estimated cost of $10 million. The insurance group wants to recover part og the costs. The suit alleges that McDonnell and employees of its space operations unit ``negligently and carelessly planned, simulated, trained for and conducted the handling and removal procedure'' in a way that caused the crane cable to snap while loading the satellite. It accuses McDonnell employees of ``reckless, wanton and gross negligence'' in violating statutes and industry standards for operation of an overhead crane. The suit was filed last month in Brevard County Circuit Court, and McDonnell has petitioned for its transfer to federal court because the accident occurred on U.S. government property. The case is the second in the commercial space launch industry in a month. Martin Marietta Corp. and the International Telecommunications Satellite Oraganization went to court earlier this month to decide who should pay for a satellite launch failure in March. A Martin Marietta-built Titan 4 rocket failed to boost the $157 million Intelsat satellite into the proper orbit.

DOC.HEAD: Martin Marietta Reports Increased Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Earnings for Martin Marietta Corp., a leading aerospace and defense contractor, increased in the second quarter due to the success of several space programs, the company said Tuesday. Second-quarter net income was $94.5 million, or $1.85 per share, compared to $86.9 million, or $1.64 per share during the same quarter last year. Sales for the second quarter increased from $1.4 billion to $1.7 billion, the Bethesda-based company said. Norman R. Augustine, chairman and chief executive officer, said several major programs, including the Titan IV space launch system and LANTIRN night vision and targeting system, led the way with sales increases. ``The advance in second-quarter net income moves us a step closer to achieving our 1990 objective _ maintaining our upward trend of earnings per share,'' Augustine said. Net earnings for the first half of 1990 were $161.6 million or $3.17 per share, compared to $146.1 million or $2.76 for the first half of last year. Net sales were $3.1 billion, up from $2.7 billion in the 1989 period.
