DOC.HEAD: Major Oil Companies Report Mixed Earnings
By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: A drop in crude oil prices worked to depress earnings at Texaco Inc. and Phillips Petroleum Co. during the second quarter, but Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. managed to improve results during the period, the companies reported Tuesday. Though relatively strong during the year's first quarter, crude oil prices fell an average of $4 a barrel in the subsequent quarter because of worldwide oversupply. As a result, Texaco's profits during the period slipped 4 percent, while Phillips reported a 47 percent tumble in net income. Several other major oil companies have reported lower earnings due to lower crude prices, including Atlantic Richfield Co., Amoco, and Amerada Hess Corp. But Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil concern, reported a 24 percent jump in net income, largely due to special factors, and profits at Chevron were up a sharp 60 percent.

Mobil estimated net income for the second quarter at $498 million, or $1.19 a share, up from $401 million, or 98 cents a share a year earlier. The 1990 quarter got a $182 million boost from the sale of a 5 percent stake in a North Sea oil field and the sale of Mobil's refining and fuels marketing business in Italy. Revenue for the period was $13.8 billion, off 1 percent from $14 billion in the year-ago period. Mobil Chairman Allen E. Murray said excluding special items, petroleum operations were slightly lower than a year earlier, and stronger refining margins did not offset sharply lower crude oil prices. The company's chemical operations also reported lower results. For the first half, Mobil estimated net earnings at $898 million, or $2.13 a share, up 8 percent from $830 million, or $2.02 a share in the first half of 1989. Excluding special items, first-half earnings of $856 million were down $114 million from the year-ago level. Revenue for the period increased 3 percent to $28.9 billion, from $28.1 billion in the first half of 1989.

Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, said net income during the quarter totaled $353 million, or $1.26 a share, down from $366 million, or $1.39 a share a year ago. Revenue rose 3 percent to $8.72 billion, from $8.45 billion a year ago largely because of higher crude and oil product sales volumes. In addition to lower crude prices during the second quarter, natural gas prices also fell and petrochemical results were ``significantly lower ... because of oversupply and reduced demand,'' Texaco Chief Executive and President James W. Kinnear said in a statement from the company's White Plains, N.Y., headquarters. For the year's first half, Texaco reported net income of $681 million, or $2.41 a share, down 63 percent from $1.82 billion, or $7.19 a share in the year-ago period, which included a $1.19 billion gain from the sale of Texaco Canada Inc. Without the gain, net income was up 8 percent, the company said. First-half revenue was off 1 percent at $17.88 billion from $18.06 billion.

San Francisco-based Chevron said $58 million in special items boosted second-quarter earnings to $648 million, or $1.83 a share, from $404 million, or $1.18 a share a year ago. Revenue totaled $8.9 billion, up 9 percent from $8.2 billion a year ago. For the year's first half, the nation's fourth-largest oil company said net income totaled $1.12 billion, or $3.16 a share, up 56 percent from $717 million, or $2.09 a share in the 1989 first half. Revenue rose 15 percent to $18.3 billion, from $15.9 billion on higher sales volumes for crude oil, natural gas and petroleum products, particularly in the first quarter.

Phillips, of Bartlesville, Okla., reported second-quarter net income of $105 million, or 43 cents a share, down from $197 million, or 81 cents a share a year ago. The recent quarter included $58 million in insurance reimbursement that compensated for lost earnings at Phillips' Houston chemical complex, which was shut down after an accident in October 1989 and remains closed. Revenue declined 9 percent to $2.98 billion, from $3.3 billion a year ago. For the year's first half, Phillips' profits slipped 6 percent to $364 million, or $1.49 a share, from $387 million, or $1.59 a share. Revenue declined by 5 percent to $6.11 billion, from $6.40 billion in the second half of 1989.

Sun Co., of Radnor, Pa., said second-quarter profits rose 10 percent to $115 million, or $1.07 a share from $105 million, or 98 cents a share a year ago. Revenue totaled $2.89 billion, down 1 percent from $2.92 billion a year ago. For the first six months, net income was unchanged at $186 million, or $1.73 a share, compared with a per-share profit of $1.74, on revenue of $6 billion, up 8 percent from $5.56 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Declines at Times Mirror, Tribune, Knight-Ridder, Washington Post
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Co. said Tuesday its earnings dropped 44.7 percent from results a year ago that included a gain on a timberlands sale, while Tribune Co. said its profit tumbled 25 percent in the second quarter. Another major media company, Knight-Ridder Inc., said its net income skidded 64.8 percent for the second quarter from results last year that were inflated by gains on the sale of a newspaper and television stations. Washington Post Co. said its earnings for the quarter fell 7.5 percent, reflecting a weak advertising environment for newspapers and TV stations.

The publisher of the Los Angeles Times and six other newspapers said it earned $47.0 million, or 36 cents a share, in the second quarter compared with $85.0 million, or 66 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 5.3 percent to $906.6 million from $861.3 million. The 1989 results included a gain of 11 cents a share on the sale of timberlands. Robert F. Erburu, chairman and chief executive, said weak economic conditions continued adversely affecting the company's newspaper and other advertising-driven businesses. Times Mirror also owns four TV stations, a professional book company, cable TV systems and consumer magazines. For the first half, the company earned $93.0 million, or 72 cents a share, compared with $153.8 million, or $1.19 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose to $1.78 billion from $1.71 billion.

Chicago-based Tribune said its profit decline was due mainly to operating losses at the New York Daily News and a decline in newsprint operating profit. The company said it earned $58.1 million, or 78 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $75.3 million, or 98 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 2 percent to $656.2 million from $643.1 million a year earlier. The company said its operating profit from newspaper publishing fell 33 percent, mainly due to losses at the Daily News that reflected economic weakness in the New York area and costs of contract negotiations with the paper's labor unions. Results from the Chicago Tribune improved, but results from its other papers were flat or lower because of softness in retail and classified advertising, the company said. Operating profit from the newsprint group fell 83 percent to $3.1 million because of lower newsprint selling prices and the adverse impact of a stronger Canadian dollar. For the first half, Tribune earned $89.6 million, or $1.21 a share, down 20 percent from $112.1 million, or $1.47 a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose 3.6 percent to $1.239 billion from $1.196 billion.

The Miami-based newspaper and business information services company said it earned $44.6 million, or 88 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $126.8 million, or $2.44 a share, a year earlier. But the 1989 results were inflated by $1.67 a share due to gains on the sale of the Pasadena Star-News and television operations. Otherwise, Knight-Ridder said its net income rose 14.3 percent when compared with last year's earnings from ongoing operations. Second-quarter revenue rose 2.2 percent to $591.7 million from $578.7 million a year earlier. Advertising at its 31 newspapers was under pressure in the quarter, with retail and general advertising revenue marginally higher while classified ad revenue fell slightly, the company said. For the first half, Knight-Ridder said, it earned $70.5 million, or $1.37 a share, down 52 percent from $147.3 million, or $2.82 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose to $1.15 billion from $1.12 billion.

The owner of the Washington Post newspaper and Newsweek magazine said it earned $55.9 million, or $4.60 a share, for the second quarter compared with $60.5 million, or $4.72 a share, a year earlier. Second-quarter revenue edged up 1 percent to $379.6 million from $374.5 million a year earlier. Newspaper division revenue was off 2 percent as ad volume fell 9 percent at the Washington Post. Newsweek revenue rose 6 percent with one additional issue published in the second quarter this year. Revenue was down 4 percent for the broadcast division, which has four TV stations. But revenue rose 11 percent in the cable division. For the first half, the company earned $95.0 million, or $7.76 a share, down from $102 million, or $7.94 a share, a year ago. First half-revenue rose to $720.5 million from $716.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Weyerhaeuser Earnings Drop 26 percent in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Second-quarter declines of 26 percent in profits and 10 percent in sales were reported Tuesday by the Weyerhaeuser Co., with the pulp and paper markets blamed for most of the slump. A statement issued by the forest products corporation said net earnings for the 13 weeks ending July 1 amounted to $114.3 million or 54 cents a share on $2.4 billion in net sales, down from $154.9 million or 73 cents a share on $2.6 billion in sales for the year-earlier period. Sales for the first six months of fiscal 1990 were $4.7 billion, down 6 percent from 1989's first-half sales of $5 billion, while net earnings fell from $302.9 million or $1.43 a share to $244.3 million or $1.15 a share, a 19 percent decline. Company chairman George H. Weyerhaeuser said the biggest factor in the second-quarter drop was a 40 percent decline in earnings on pulp and paper products over the past year. The pulp division was hit by maintenance work that cut production at a time of soft markets, and prices were weak in the paper division until a recent upward turn, Weuerhaeuser said. Forest products results were flat as a decline in export volumes and lower prices for Western products were offset by stronger sales of southern lumber and plywood and better results for engineered fiber panels. Real estate earnings slumped, largely because of weak markets in Baltimore, Southern California and Florida, while a reorganization of financial services brought gains in mortgage and insurance subsidiaries, the statement said. A corporate structural review will be completed in the third quarter, with reorganization and improvement plans for lumber and plywood to begin taking effect in September, Weyerhaeuser said.

DOC.HEAD: Page Will Acquire Competitor in Airport Services
DOC.TEXT: Orlando-based Page Avjet Corp. will expand its service operations to 19 airports with the acquisition of competitor Van Dusen Airport Services Co. of Minneapolis, company officials said. Page, known primarily for converting huge commercial jets for private use, would become one of the nation's largest ``fixed-base operators,'' which provide fuel, storage and maintenance to private and corporate pilots. Page and Van Dusen would not disclose terms of the transaction, expected to take place within 90 days, but industry experts estimate the sale price at $65 million. In addition to its modification work, Page also provides fuel, storage and maintance to small aircraft at eight airports. Locations include international airports in Orlando, Miami and St. Petersburg. Van Dusen is even larger in the fixed-base industry. The company serves private and corporate pilots at 11 airports and serves commercial airlines at two other airports. Its Southeastern locations include Atlanta; Columbus, Ga.; Corpus Christi, Texas; Lexington, Ky.; and Nashville, Tenn. Page's revenue totaled about $200 million last year. It employs 2,500 people. Van Dusen, which employs about 800 people, had revenue of about $72 million last year, according to company figures.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Prices Continue Rising
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices continued their rally, finishing modestly higher Tuesday after profit-taking brought contracts down from their highest levels. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 6 cents to settle at $20.56 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Other contract months also gained ground. The near-month contract rose 44 cents on Monday to its highest level since April. Crude prices opened on a firm note following reports that Iraq was amassing troups on the Kuwait border and threatening military action. But prices held to a ``fairly narrow range'' before losing some ground on the day on profit taking, said Andrew Lebow, an analyst at E.D.&F. Man International Inc. Also supporting prices was a report that Iraqi Oil Minister Issam al-Chalabi will insist on a $25-a-barrel price for crude at the OPEC meeting Thursday. Ministers from the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are scheduled to gather in Geneva, Switzerland. Iran, Iraq's foe in the eight-year Gulf war, has said it supports a $20-a-barrel price, up from the current benchmark of $18 a barrel. Traders are anticipating OPEC will approve a production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day. The current ceiling is 22.09 million barrels, but members consistenly have been pumping more than 23 million barrels daily. Prices for refined products traded on the Merc were mixed. Unleaded regular gasoline for August delivery, which rose 0.39 cent on Monday, settled off 0.07 cent at 63.28 cents a gallon, but later contract months gained ground. The August contract for home heating oil, which rose 0.71 cent on Monday, was up 0.82 cent to close at 57.32 cents a gallon, with subsequent months also settling higher. In natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.450 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.460 Monday.

The stock market steadied today after Monday's rout and blue chips got a lift from a rally in oil issues. Speculation that a meeting this week of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could pave the way for higher oil prices encouraged investors to favor oil and oilfield service stocks. Other stocks benefitted from selective bargain hunting as investors sifted through the wreckage of the selloff on Monday. Market watchers attributed part of today's volatility to traders reacting to fresh news from the corporate front. Disappointing corporate earnings reports released in recent days had set a negative tone in the market Monday and acted as one of the catalysts causing the selling that temporarily drove the Dow industrial average down more than 100 points. The average managed to regain about half of its early loss. By the close Monday, the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices, stood at 2,904.70, down 56.44 points from last week's close. Concerns that inflationary pressures may be building at a time of economic weakness contributed to the bearish outlook on Wall Street. Computer-aided program trading also played a part in the selloff and added to the volatility.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: the volatility.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 17.82 to 2,922.52. Advancing and declining issues ended in almost a dead heat on the New York Stock Exchange, with 749 up, 745 down and 513 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 181.92 million shares, against 209.03 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index advanced 0.23 to 194.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.59 to 355.51.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold End Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar weakened Tuesday against key foreign currencies in worldwide trading. Gold prices ended lower after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $367.90 a troy ounce, off $1.20 from late Monday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $367.25 an ounce, down 90 cents. Currency dealers said continued concerns about interest rates helped push the dollar lower. However, technical factors, along with news of an Iraqi troop buildup along the Kuwaiti border, helped temper its fall, they said. The dollar is often seen as a safe haven in times of political turmoil, such as the Iraqi military action. The markets were paying particular attention Tuesday to Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before the House Banking subcommittee. Greenspan said a ``credible and enforceable'' budget deficit agreement could bring about lower interest rates in the financial markets. But he warned the Fed wouldn't move to accelerate a drop in rates unless it was assured inflation was under control. Lower interest rates tend to bring down the value of a currency. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar rose to a closing 148.70 Japanese yen from 148.50 yen Monday. It traded at 148.35 yen in London, and at 148.40 yen in New York, up from 148.19 yen. The dollar was mixed against the British pound compared to Monday. Sterling rose to $1.8250 from $1.8215 in London, and fell to $1.8140 from $1.8255 in New York. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's levels, included: 1.62075 German marks, down from 1.62225; 1.3785 Swiss francs, down from 1.3815; 5.4365 French francs, down from 5.4410; 1.15655 Canadian dollars, down from 1.15545; and 1,186.00 Italian lire, down from 1,187.50. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6185 German marks, down from 1.6278; 1.3750 Swiss francs, down from 1.3880; 5.4275 French francs, down from 5.4598; 1.8230 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8430; 1,184.75 Italian lire, down from 1,192.00; and 1.1557 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1568. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $368.25 an ounce from $368.15 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to $368.35 an ounce from $367.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $6.97 to close at $369.25 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $$4.811 a troy ounce, down 7.1 cents from late Monday. Silver rose in London to $4.85 an ounce from $4.90.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Governor Seger Reportedly Mulling Resignation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush may get a third chance to appoint a member of the Federal Reserve Board if Martha Seger resigns. Seger, 58, a governor on the seven-member board since 1984, said in an interview published in Tuesday's editions of The Wall Street Journal that she may resign to care for her elderly mother, who lives in Arizona and recently underwent hip surgery and suffered a stroke. Seger, who has eight years remaining in her 14-year term, is the board's most outspoken advocate of an easy money policy to keep economic growth vigorous. She frequently is at odds with other board members who favor higher interest rates to slow the economy and reduce inflation. ``I'll probably make a decision by the end of this year on whether or not I have to leave,'' she told the newspaper. ``I'm going to play it by ear.'' Seger did not return several telephone messages seeking comment. Bush already has appointed David Mullins, a former assistant secretary of the Treasury, to fill one vacancy on the board. He is due to select a successor to Fed Vice Chairman Manuel Johnson, who has announced he plans to resign next month. In recent months, Bush and his cabinet members have clashed with the Fed over the central bank's monetary policy. The administration wants lower rates to keep growth strong through the fall congressional elections and offset any negative economic effects from a budget deal calling for higher taxes and spending cuts. On Tuesday, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told a House subcommittee that the central bank has not abandoned its battle against inflation as part of any deficit-cutting deal. Greenspan said the Fed remained intent on achieving ``within a few years'' its goal of pushing inflationary pressures close to zero.

DOC.HEAD: Conglomerate Reports Big Gain, Largely on Sale of Alcatel Stake
DOC.TEXT: ITT Corp., one of the world's largest conglomerates, reported a 63 percent jump in second-quarter earnings Tuesday, largely due to a one-time gain from selling a stake in a leading telecommunications company. The New York-based company, with global operations ranging from insurance to defense gear to Sheraton hotels, said it earned $397 million or $3 a share in the three months that ended June 30, vs. $244 million or $1.70 a share in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue totaled $5.2 billion, unchanged from a year earlier. The company attributed the lack of growth to divestures in 1989 as well as flat revenues by its insurance and automotive-components businesses. ITT said the second-quarter earnings were enlarged from the sale of a 7 percent stake of Alcatel NV of France to Compagnie Generale d'Electricite in June, which resulted in an after-tax gain of $139 million. ITT retains a 30 percent interest in Alcatel, one of the biggest telecommunications equipment concerns. The 1989 second-quarter earnings figures included a $18 million gain on the sale of ITT's European headquarters, as well as a $28 million decline to reflect the cost of ITT's investment in Thompson McKinnon Inc., a failed Wall Street investment firm. Excluding these extraordinary items and the Alcatel gain, second-quarter earnings were only marginally higher. Still, the results were better than expected, considering the weakness in some of ITT's most important businesses: insurance, defense and hotels. The company's stock price rose 62.5 cents a share to $57.37{ Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. ITT said earnings fell at its defense, electronic components, financial and hotel units but remained sound or strengthened in the automotive, fluid technology and pulp-timber businesses. ITT's insurance business also improved from higher investment income and life insurance operations, which offset weakness in casualty underwriting, the company said. For the first half of the year, earnings totaled $650 million or $4.88 a share, a 46 percent increase over the $444 million or $3.10 a share earned in the first half of 1989. Revenues totaled $10.2 billion vs. $10 billion, a 2 percent gain.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Strength in Oil Stocks Lifts Dow Industrials
DOC.TEXT: The stock market steadied Tuesday with the help of a rally in oil issues ignited by speculation about higher petroleum prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials ended with a gain of 17.82 points at 2,922.52. Most of the increase reflected movements in the blue chip oil stocks Chevron, Exxon and Texaco. The blue chip average had see-sawed between minor gains and losses all morning until futures-related sell programs pushed it to a double-digit decline in early afternoon. Renewed buying _ particularly in the oil patch _ sparked a recovery. Advancing and declining issues ended almost even in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 753 up, 755 down and 509 unchanged. Trading activity slowed slightly from Monday's brisk pace. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 181.92 million shares, down from 209.03 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 216.73 million shares. Oil stocks were the star performers. Analysts said a meeting this week of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could pave the way for higher oil prices. OPEC ministers began gathering in Geneva, Switzerland, Tuesday to plot strategy to cope with a world oil glut. Exxon soared 2[ to 50 in heavy trading of more than 2.4 million shares. Chevron climbed 1~ to a 52-week high of 78} and Texaco jumped 2} to a 52-week high of 62{. Elsewhere in the oil patch, Amoco advanced 1{ to 54~, Atlantic Richfield added 1[ to 125{, Mobil moved 2 higher to a 52-week high of 67 and Kerr McGee gained 1] to 49. Stocks of companies serving the oil industry also benefitted from the buying spree. Baker Hughes rose | to 29|, Haliburton surged 2] to 53| and Schlumberger rose 1] to 64~. All three set new 52-week highs. Market watchers attributed Tuesday's generally erratic trading pattern to nervousness after Monday's steep slide. The volatility also reflected traders reacting to fresh news from the corporate front. Disappointing corporate earnings reports released in recent days had depressed market sentiment Monday, which touched off a setback that temporarily drove the Dow industrial average down more than 100 points. The average managed to regain about half of its early loss. By the close Monday, the oldest and best known measure of trends in stock prices, stood at 2,904.70, down 56.44 points from last week's close. Concerns that inflationary pressures may be building at a time of economic weakness contributed to the bearish outlook on Wall Street. The parade of poor earnings reports continued Tuesday as Dow Chemical posted a 50 percent plunge in its second-quarter profit. The stock tumbled 5} to 52] and led the Big Board's list of active issues on turnover of more than 3.44 million shares. The Student Loan Marketing Association, or Sallie Mae, ended down 1} at 48[. The stock has suffered in the wake of news that the Higher Education Assistance Foundation, a major student loan guarantor, is in financial trouble. Sallie Mae is among the foundation's largest creditors. One of the day's biggest losers was Reuters Holdings, which is traded in the over-the-counter market. Reuters' American Depository Shares tumbled 10 to 56\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market edged up $805 million, or 0.02 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.23 to 194.45. Standard & Poor's industrial index increased 0.91 to 421.70, and S&P's 500-stock composite index finished at 355.79, up 0.48. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 2.08 to 442.56. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 355.51, 0.59 higher.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Tumble On Weather Outlook
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices resumed their slide Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as many traders who had cashed out of the market in the previous session became sellers again amid forecasts for good growing weather. Most corn futures also retreated while wheat futures advanced on expectations for new export sales of the grain. On other commodity markets, crude oil futures rose; livestock and meat futures were mostly higher; and precious metals fell. Soybean futures settled 8{ cents lower to 2 cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in August at $5.84\ a bushel. Wheat finished 1 cent to 1} cents higher with September at $3.03{ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents lower to 3{ cents higher with September at $2.61{ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with September at $1.28\ a bushel. Bullish chart signals in the soybean market were eclipsed by a National Weather Service forecast that predicted normal temperatures and above-normal rainfall in the Midwest during the first half of next week. The outlook for a continuation of near-perfect growing conditions brought back into the market traders who had evened up their books Monday, said Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``The weather remains the main bearish influence,'' he said. ``The bias was generally toward the downside and that's the way we ended.'' Selling interest was tempered, though, by concerns about the slow pace at which the soybean and corn crops are developing, a function of heavy spring rains that delayed planting. A weekly Agriculture Department report released late Monday showed only 28 percent of the corn crop at the silking stage as of Sunday compared with the average of 62 percent for that date. The USDA said 36 percent of the soybean crop was blooming compared with a 57 percent norm, and 6 percent of soybeans were setting pods compared with the average of 20 percent. Lespinasse said fears are filtering into the market that an early frost could damage late-maturing crops, reducing the overall yields. Crude oil futures extended their gains on the New York Mercantile Exchange following reports that Iraq was amassing troups on the Kuwait border and threatening military action. Further support stemmed from a report that Iraqi Oil Minister Issam al-Chalabi will insist on a $25-a-barrel price for crude at the OPEC meeting Thursday in Geneva. After the close the American Petroleum Institute released its weekly stocks report, which showed U.S. supply levels of crude and refined products to be in line with expectations. Crude oil stocks declined 1.6 million barrels, gasoline stocks rose 672,000 barrels and supplies of petroleum distillates rose 2.4 million barrels, the API reported. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 2 cents lower to 14 cents higher with September at $20.56 a barrel; heating oil was .39 cent to .82 cent higher with August at 57.32 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .14 cent lower to .60 cent higher with August at 63.28 cents a gallon. Pork belly futures staged a dramatic turnaround on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, rising the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound after posting limit losses in three of the four previous sessions. Analysts attributed much of the buying to strength in the cash belly market, which boosted prices of fresh pork bellies over frozen bellies for the first time in several days. Live cattle settled .23 cent to .73 cent higher with August at 76.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to 1.07 cents higher with August at 88.37 cents a pound; live hogs were .33 cent lower to .42 cent higher with August at 59.37 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with August at 45.12 cents a pound. Precious metals retreated on New York's Commodity Exchange with silver down substantially on indications of abundant supplies and slack demand. Gold futures settled $1.10 to $1.30 lower with August $368.40 a troy ounce; silver was 7.1 cents to 7.5 cents lower with July at $4.811 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Political Tension High As OPEC Ministers Gather for Critical Oil Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf, The September... to UPDATE with closing crude price.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers Tuesday began gathering for a critical strategy session that has been overshadowed by Iraqi threats to punish cartel members that exceed their oil production limits. The meeting is taking place as oil prices continue a rebound from lows of earlier this year that served to aggravate the political tensions raised by Iraq, especially against neighboring cartel member Kuwait. A number of ministers expressed support for increasing the cartel's benchmark price for its crude from the current $18 a barrel, which would require agreement on new production limits. But ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries sidestepped the confrontation between Iraq and Kuwait. ``We are here to solve oil problems,'' said Saudi Arabia's influential oil minister, Hisham Nazer, as he arrived for the mid-year meeting scheduled for Thursday. Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, was surrounded by dozens of reporters as he entered the lobby of a luxury hotel where the talks are held. He only discussed his plans to press for an increase in the current $18 a barrel benchmark price for the cartel's crude oil. The cartel's discussions have taken on added significance since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week threatened to use force against countries that exceed their OPEC-set production quotas. His remarks were aimed at Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, two Gulf producers that have violated their output ceilings. Saddam claimed his debt-ridden country has lost $14 billion during the past year because of a world oil glut that sent crude prices tumbling. Iraq also has charged that Kuwait stole $2.4 billion worth of Iraqi oil since 1980 from wells it dug on Iraqi territory across their common border. Iraq reportedly has moved 30,000 troops to its border with Kuwait, and battlefield missiles, armored personnel carriers and tanks were displayed prominently along the road from Iraq to Kuwait. The United States on Tuesday expressed concern with the buildup and confirmed its naval forces were holding a joint exercise in the Persian Gulf with the United Arab Emirates. The Iraqi threats were made a week after Saudi Arabia and four other Gulf producers proposed an accord designed to halt the runaway production of Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Nazer told reporters he was confident OPEC would reach an agreement along the lines of the Gulf proposal. That plan would limit the cartel's production to about 22.5 million barrels a day in the next few months. The cartel's cap for the first half of the year was 22.1 million barrels. However, a confidential report prepared by OPEC's secretariat in Vienna put actual production at 23.5 million barrels a day in the April-June quarter, according to sources familiar with the document. Demand for the cartel's oil was estimated at 21.8 million barrels a day in the third quarter of this year, rising to 24.4 million barrels in the last three months of the year, said the sources, who demanded anonymity. The OPEC market report said an overall production ceiling of 22 million barrels a day in the second half of the year would improve prices considerably. OPEC's excess production sent prices tumbling in the spring. The average price of a basket of seven crudes monitored by the cartel plummeted to $13.64 a barrel in June before climbing to $16.25 a barrel last week. The September contract for the benchmark U.S. crude finished at $20.56 a barrel late Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up 6 cents from Monday and up about $5 from its lows in June. Iran has proposed a reference price of $20 a barrel while Iraq wants a $25 level. Nazer said Saudi Arabia supported a price hike, but he did not mention a figure. Iraq's Chalabi said his country was aiming for $25 and Gabon's Jean Ping said he would like to see the target raised above $18. Under the Gulf proposal, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates each would limit output to 1.5 million barrels a day. The two separately have been pumping as much as 2 million barrels a day. Kuwait's current production cap is 1.5 million barrels a day, and the U.A.E. quota is 1.1 million barrels. While the cartel's official summer meeting opens Thursday, its eight-member monitoring panel will hold talks Wednesday. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Rental Company Initiates Business with Retailer
DOC.TEXT: Thrifty Car Rental will open offices in Montgomery Ward department stores in 15 cities and will accept the retailer's credit card in all 24 of its Washington offices, Thrifty announced Tuesday. Thrifty, the fifth-largest car rental company in North America and a subsidiary of Chrysler Corp., will begin accepting Montgomery Ward credit cards on Aug. 1 in its Washington offices. The agreement calls for as many as 20 rental offices in Montgomery Ward stores by the end of the year. Montgomery Ward has 336 stores in 39 states. Bernard F. Brennan, chairman and chief executive officer of Montgomery Ward, said stores to house Thrifty offices this year include Baltimore, Washington, Denver, Sacramento, Calif., and Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla. ``The arrangement will enable us to offer our customer base one of the nation's best car rental values and should bring new customers into our stores at the same time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Fast Food
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. and Wendy's International announced Monday they are switching to cholesterol-free, all-vegetable oil to cook their french fries. In April, anti-cholesterol crusader Phil Sokolof placed ads in newspapers criticizing McDonald's and other restaurants for cooking fries in beef tallow rather than using ``heart-healthy oils.'' Here is a brief explanation of fats:

All dietary fats are mixtures of three kinds of fatty acids: saturated, mono-saturated, and polyunsaturated. According to some studies, the relative health merits of different oils and fats are determined by the proportions of each of the three different kinds of fatty acids in the individual oil or fat.

Fats with a higher proportion of saturated fatty acids are generally solid at room temperature. Research indicates they increase blood cholesterol. ANIMAL FATS have a higher proportion of saturated fatty acids than most fats from plants. Animal fats also contain cholesterol. TROPICAL OILS are derived from plants, and therefore contain no cholesterol. However, they are high in saturated fatty acids. Some tropical oils such as palm oil, coconut oil and palm kernel oil actually have more saturated fatty acids than the animal fats. HYDROGENATED FATS are other fats of plant origin that have been processed, or hydrogenated, and have become saturated fats. The degree of saturation is dependent on the processing, but generally the harder the product is at room temperature, the more saturated it is. Examples of hydrogenated products are hard shortenings, hard or stick margarines, and some kinds of peanut butter.

Fats with a high proportion of monosaturated fatty acids do not increase blood cholesterol. Studies suggest the monosaturates, particularly olive oil, actually reduce blood cholesterol levels. Monosaturated fats include olive oil, peanut oil and avocado oil.

Fats with a high proportion of polyunsaturated fatty acids are found primarily in plants and in some kinds of fish. Polyunsaturates reduce the risk of heart disease by lowering cholesterol levels in the blood. Polyunsaturates include sunflower oil, corn oil, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, safflower oil and some fish oils.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Trying To Solve Problems With Student Loan Guarantor
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS two grafs for 7th graf pvs, There was, to include HEAF comment; Picks up 8th graf pvs, The OMB. A version also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Administration officials said Tuesday they had scrapped the idea of turning over the troubled portfolio of the nation's largest guarantor of college student loans to a much smaller Nebraska program. The officials said the Department of Education is exploring other options, including the possibility of finding another agency to take over the strained Higher Education Assistance Foundation. The foundation informed the government it is having serious problems meeting its obligations to insure nearly $300 million in defaulted student loans for fiscal year 1990. The foundation's troubles have raised doubts that it can ensure the availability of new loans, service its outstanding debt and pay on default claims. ``We're looking at a range of alternatives whereby another entity or entities insure all of those functions either on a short-or long-term basis,'' said Education Undersecretary Ted Stevens. ``Under the scenario that I'm talking about here, HEAF would not exist,'' he added during a press briefing. ``We're trying to get to a point of a friendly takeover by a stronger guarantor,'' said an official from the Office of Management and Budget who requested anonymity. In a written statement, HEAF said it was ``pursuing on its own additional options that would enable us to restore confidence'' to its loan guarantees as the peak activity season begins. However, the foundation said, ``It is best that we not speculate on how these problems might be resolved or who might be involved.'' The OMB official identified the United Students Aids Funds in Indianapolis, Ind., as one possible candidate to take over HEAF. But a proposed merger agreement that would have transferred many of HEAF's loan default obligations to the Nebraska Student Loan Program Inc. apparently has been abandoned. The department determined that the Nebraska program would have been unable to manage a portfolio the size of HEAF's. It also said such a merger would offer only a short-term remedy and might have circumvented the law. HEAF was the nation's largest guarantor of student loans last year with $9.6 billion in loans outstanding. The outstanding loan program of the Nebraska program is just under $500 million. Under the merger agreement, the federal government would have footed the bill for HEAF's fiscal year 1990 default obligations and the foundation would have been allowed to start anew on Oct. 1, the beginning of the 1991 fiscal year. Through the government's Guaranteed Student Loan program, 55 guarantors, including HEAF, insure 100 percent of student loans to banks or secondary lenders. The education department reinsures the loans and reimburses the guarantor agency for payments to lenders. The reimbursement rates begin at 100 percent but drop to 90 percent when re-insurance payments exceed five percent. When the payments reach 9 percent the rate falls to 80 percent. HEAF is the only guarantor to reach the 9 percent level, dropping the government's repayment rate to 80 percent in April. HEAF has guaranteed billions in trade school loans with high default rates. Such loans accounted for 59 percent of HEAF's 1988 portfolio but only 35 percent in 1989. Officials also sought to assure students, lenders and other agencies that HEAF's problems do not signal system-wide problems for the student loan program. ``This situation will not affect the ability of students to obtain loans, of lenders to make those loans or of guarantors to insure those loans,'' Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos said. Officials said HEAF's problems are serious but are isolated to that organization. However, education officials said the government is not obligated to pay lenders in event of insurance defaults by HEAF or other guarantors in the event of student loan defaults. The OMB official dismissed temptations to compare problems in the student loan program with the multi-billion dollar savings and loan crisis. ``This is not a big federal bailout. ... This is not a federal bailout, period,'' he said. ``The numbers are big but it is not an S&L-type situation.'' A nine-member education department review team and two high-ranking OMB officials were sent Monday to HEAF offices in St. Paul, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell Announces Spinoff of Defense and Marines Systems
DOC.TEXT: Honeywell Inc. announced details Tuesday of plans to spin off its defense and marine systems business into a new company to be called Alliant Techsystems Inc. After the spinoff is completed, Alliant Techsystems would be the 17th-largest direct supplier to the Defense Department, and would rank about 300th on the Fortune 500 list, Honeywell said. The company said Alliant Techsystems would be the eighth-largest publicly held industrial corporation in Minnesota. Honeywell said it expects to obtain final board approval of the spinoff in the fall. According to preliminary plans, people who own Honeywell stock on the record date for the distribution would receive one share of Alliant Techsystems' common stock for every four shares of Honeywell. Based on 38.2 million shares of Honeywell stock currently outstanding, about 9.5 million shares of Alliant Techsystems' stock would be distributed to Honeywell shareholders. Application will be made to list Alliant Techsystems' common stock on the New York Stock Exchange. It would trade separately from Honeywell Inc. common stock. Alliant Techsystems' management team will be led by Toby G. Warson, president and chief executive officer, who was formerly chief executive officer of Honeywell's United Kingdom subsidiary. Alliant Techsystems' defense and marine systems and test instruments businesses provide products and services to the U.S. government, allied governments and other customers. Products include tactical munitions, torpedos, electronics systems, sonar and signal processing subsystems, undersea vehicles, information storage and testing and certification services and products for the information security and intelligence market. James J. Renier, Honeywell chairman and chief executive officer, said the spinoff will give shareholders an opportunity to hold ownership in a new defense company, while Honeywell focuses exclusively on its core controls businesses. Honeywell is a global controls company that provides products, systems and services for homes and buildings, industry, and aviation and space. The company had 1989 sales of $6.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Confirmation Hearing Begins on Resorts Restructuring Plan
DOC.TEXT: Resorts International Inc. took its plan for reorganization to bankruptcy court Tuesday where an official of the casino company said the restructuring will secure recovery. ``From my point of view, the company has bottomed out and is on the way back,'' Christopher Whitney, a resorts vice president testified. ``The company is ahead of its plan.'' The hearing is expected to continue for several days. The reorganization plan was overwhelmingly approved by bondholders Monday, but is being opposed by several dissident investors and Donald Trump, who swapped Resorts to Merv Griffin for the newly opened Taj Mahal Casino Resort next door. Trump's attorneys are in the courtroom because of a provision in the restucturing plan to set aside $5 million to pursue a possible suit against him. A suit would force Trump to answer claims he left Resorts financially insolvent. Under the restructuring, bondholders would get 78 percent of the company, leaving Griffin with 22 percent. The plan needs the approval of U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Rosemary Gambardella, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission, as well as the government of the Bahamas. The plan calls for the sale of Resort's Paradise Island operations there. Resorts has been dissappointed by the lack of spillover since the April 2 opening of the Taj Mahal. The casino continues its slide of declining gross gaming revenue, or ``win'' when compared to the same time period the year before.

DOC.HEAD: Johnson & Johnson Reports Second Quarter Earnings Up 19 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Johnson & Johnson said Tuesday its second-quarter earnings increased almost 19 percent on strong showings in its pharmaceutical and professional health care lines. Pharmaceutical sales for the quarter were up 26 percent worldwide, and professional sales, which include surgical instruments and diagnostic products, rose 20.8 percent from last year's second quarter. For the second three months of the year, profits totaled $353 million, or $1.06 per share, on revenue of $2.82 billion. That compared with earnings of $297 million, or 89 cents a share, on revenue of $2.39 billion in the same period last year. Profits for the first six months of 1990 fell 2.8 percent to $597 million, or $1.79 per share, from $614 million, or $1.84 a share for the first half of 1989. Sales rose to $5.66 billion from $4.8 billion. Earnings dropped in that period primarily because of one-time first-quarter losses sustained in shutting down Johnson & Johnson of Argentina, said company spokesman F. Robert Kniffen. The Argentina division produced consumer and professional products, Kniffen said. Ralph S. Larsen, chairman and chief executive officer, said Ortho Diagnostics, which introduced a test for hepatitis C in the United States in the quarter, more than doubled its sales worldwide during the second quarter, compared to the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith Reports Second-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. Tuesday reported a loss of $11.2 million for the second quarter of the year as sales fell and expenditures to develop high-definition television increased. The loss, which came on sales of $334.1 million, translates to 42 cents per share. For the same period last year, the loss from continuing operations was $5.2 million, or 20 cents a share, on sales of $385 million. The company said the $3 million spent toward HDTV development was a substantial increase over the expenditure in the same period last year. Jerry K. Pearlman, Zenith president and chairman, said in March the $24 million research and development project on HDTV would affect earnings for the next few years. The project is a partnership with American Telephone & Telegraph Co. For the first six months of 1990, Zenith reported a net loss from continuing operations of $15.2 million, or 57 cents a share. During the first half of 1989, losses from continuing operations were $11.9 million, or 45 cents a share. Conintuing operations do not include the company's computer business, which was sold Dec. 28. Zenith computer operations lost $11 million in the first half of 1990.
